abstract: Coroner COLLIN yesterday afternoon commenced an inquest at the Twenty-seventh Precent Station house, in Cedar-street, upon the body of THOMAD BYRNES, who died on Saturday evening from a pistol shot wound in the abdomen, at the hands of DENNIS P. SULLIVAN. The excitement in the First Ward, ran very high yesterday, among the social and political friends of the respective parties. The inquisitiou will be resumed this morning at ten o'clock at the same place.

abstract: TWELFTH WARD, SEVENTEENTH ALDERMANIC DISTRICT -- FOR ALDERMAN, WILLIAM DUNNING. -- This gentleman should receive the earnest support of the voters of the Twelfth Ward. He is an old resident identified with the varied interests of his Ward, combined with superior intelligence and activity. Such a one is wanted in the Aldermanic Board, and the Twelfth Ward would earn a still higher position by electing WILLIAM DUNNING; and our readers will excuse us in our earnestness, when we remind them that the two opposing candidates are each led on by bitter factions of the Democratic Party, and the golden opportunity now presents itself to elect WILLIAM DUNNING as the people's candidate, indorsed as he is by Democrats, Republicans, taxpayers and working men, and pledges himself if elected he will owe his election to the people, and not to party. Then, fellow-citizens of the Twelfth Ward, vote -- and, reader your one vote may elect WILLIAM DUNNING Alderman Seventeenth Aldermanic District, Twelfth Ward.

abstract: We don't see why the Washington authorities should have furnished to the rebels the bit of information they had telegraphed to the New-York Press last night, to the effect that five of our gunboats had entered the Rappahannock, and gone as far up as to a point opposite King George Court House, or,...
lead_paragraph: We don't see why the Washington authorities should have furnished to the rebels the bit of information they had telegraphed to the New-York Press last night, to the effect that five of our gunboats had entered the Rappahannock, and gone as far up as to a point opposite King George Court House, or, on the south side of the river, as high up as the point to which the rebel right wing extends. We hope the dispatch is not untrue because it had the approval of the censor. And, if true, we trust the rebels will not know the fact any the sooner because it is printed an all the newspapers this morning.

abstract: VETERINARY SURGEON-GENERAL--Dr. SIEGFRIED NEUMANN, well knomn in Newark as a veterinary surgeon, has received the appiontment of Veterinary Surgeon-General, with the rank of LieutenantColonel in the United States Army. Dr. NEUMANN is said to have passed a most searching examination, in competition with over one hundred applicants. The office is a new one, and the appointment for life.
lead_paragraph: VETERINARY SURGEON-GENERAL--Dr. SIEGFRIED NEUMANN, well knomn in Newark as a veterinary surgeon, has received the appiontment of Veterinary Surgeon-General, with the rank of LieutenantColonel in the United States Army. Dr. NEUMANN is said to have passed a most searching examination, in competition with over one hundred applicants. The office is a new one, and the appointment for life. Dr. NEUMANN has been ordered to report to Gen. BURNSIDE.

abstract: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes
snippet: Editorials on work to be done by Congress when it reconvenes
lead_paragraph: Congress meets to-day, after four months' vacation, under circumstances very favorable to calm and wise action. It has no organization to effect, no new Administration to greet, no perplexing questions as to its proper subdivision into Committees to settle. It meets... We ask the special attention of voters in the Fifteenth Ward, in which the management of the Common Schools has been especially suc ccesful and creditable, to the fact that on the regularly organized and in working order, with a full understanding of its duties and in thorough sympathy with the coordinate Executive Department of the Government. More: nearly every question relating to the great rebellion and the employment of means for its suppression, was at the late session fully discussed and settled, and the Army and Navy, under the President, are engaged in executing the will of the nation in a manner that, it is believed, will meet the general public approval.

abstract: ALLEGED GROSS NEGLECT OF THE OFFICIALS AT BELLEVUE HOSPITAL. -- Upon the Police returns of the Eighteenth Precinct, made to the Police Inspectors yesterday, we find the following statement: At about 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, a man named CHARLES BOOKHAM, residing at No. 68 East Twenty-sixth-street, but doing business at No. 307 Fourth-avenue, while in an intoxicated condition, fell on the sidewalk, in Seventeenth-street, betweenIrving-place and Fourth-avenue, thereby injuring his head so severely as to render him insensible. He was soon afterward discovered by Officers RHOADES and MCCORT, bleeding profusely and unable to speak. In this condition he was immediately conveyed to Bellevue Hospital by these officers, who, upon their arrival there, at once inquired of the officials in charge of the institution what they should do with the injured man, at the same time saying that he was fast bleeding to death. The Policemen in their return then go on to say that in reply to the latter question, "we were met with the sarcastic rebuff of 'who are you? we want none of your dictation,' we replied that we were the officers who had brought a dying man to the Hospital, and that if he was not attended to soon he would die. The Hospital officials then told us that Policemen were not much and that we would have to wait our turn. At this time there was no other patient in waiting, and in fifty-five minutes after entering the Hospital, the man was allowed to bleed to death through the gross negligence of the officials of that Institution. Cannot there be something done in future to prevent such inhuman proceedings?"
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED GROSS NEGLECT OF THE OFFICIALS AT BELLEVUE HOSPITAL. -- Upon the Police returns of the Eighteenth Precinct, made to the Police Inspectors yesterday, we find the following statement: At about 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, a man named CHARLES BOOKHAM, residing at No. 68 East Twenty-sixth-street, but doing business at No. 307 Fourth-avenue, while in an intoxicated condition, fell on the sidewalk, in Seventeenth-street, betweenIrving-place and Fourth-avenue, thereby injuring his head so severely as to render him insensible. He was soon afterward discovered by Officers RHOADES and MCCORT, bleeding profusely and unable to speak. In this condition he was immediately conveyed to Bellevue Hospital by these officers, who, upon their arrival there, at once inquired of the officials in charge of the institution what they should do with the injured man, at the same time saying that he was fast bleeding to death. The Policemen in their return then go on to say that in reply to the latter question, "we were met with the sarcastic rebuff of 'who are you? we want none of your dictation,' we replied that we were the officers who had brought a dying man to the Hospital, and that if he was not attended to soon he would die. The Hospital officials then told us that Policemen were not much and that we would have to wait our turn. At this time there was no other patient in waiting, and in fifty-five minutes after entering the Hospital, the man was allowed to bleed to death through the gross negligence of the officials of that Institution. Cannot there be something done in future to prevent such inhuman proceedings?"

abstract: Congress meets to-day, and the Message of the President will be delivered to that body in time for publication in the afternoon papers. It is understood to be longer than the last, as the questions of Emancipation and Confiscation are very fully discussed. The reports of the Secretaries of War and the Navy are also ready, and will accompany the Message.

lead_paragraph: In the very able communication to the London Times, which we published on Saturday, attributed to the British Secretary of War, it was said that "in 1849 the American Government chose to recognize the independence of the Hungarian insurgents." This is an error which does us great injustice. In fact, our Government can ask nothing better from the European Powers than that they shall conform precisely to its action in that case. Let us see.

abstract: The success of Mr. GRAU's reason at the Academy or Music has been so marked that he announces it will be extended for a few nights beyond the original limits of ten. From the affiche of the establishment we learn also that "Dinorah" will be given for the last time to-night -- not because it has been unsuccessful, but because it excludes several popular artists from the bills. Those who have not yet seen this fine romantic work would do well to avail themselves of the present opportunity. "Lucrezia Borgia" will be given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to-morrow evening.

abstract: editorial urges all-out effort to secure Republican victory
snippet: editorial urges all-out effort to secure Republican victory
lead_paragraph: We trust that no Republican will refrain from doing every thing in his power to secure the election of Republican candidates to-morrow, by the apparently slight prospect of success which the November result would warrant. A Democratic majority of 30,000, in the ordinary course of things, is not easily overcome, and every one must concede, that under ordinary circumstances, the chances are against it.

lead_paragraph: We are not surprised to find our foreign exchanges unanimous in their execrations of the act of Gen. McNEIL, of Missouri, in shooting ten rebel prisoners, in alleged retaliation for the disappearance of one Union man when the rebels took possession of the town of Palmyra. The Times, the Herald, the Post and other open and avowed advocates of the rebel cause, denounce the act with all the venom which their hatred of the Union cause naturally engenders. But the censures of the Star and other friendly journals are all the more weighty, because less unmeasured in their language and prompted by a real zeal for the honor of the American name. The Star, while it "will not admit even a momentary supposition that the Federal Government can lose an instant in washing its hands of the stain of this bloody business," -- declares that "if sanctioned or even tolerated, it will justly call down upon its abettors the reprobation of the civilized world."
headline: {'main': 'The Missouri Execution.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Missouri Execution.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Fifteenth Aldermanic District, (Twenty-first Ward,) ANDRE FROMENT is the regular Democratic candidate for Alderman. He is a member of the present Board, and we only express the opinion of all who know anything of his official action and of his personal character, when we say that no man has more fairly earned the confidence and respect of the public than he. He is a practical business man, perfectly upright and trustworthy, and experienced in City affairs. He ought to be reelected.

abstract: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the 20th ult., and Londonderry on the 21st, passed Cape Race on Saturday evening, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. It was reported at Liverpool that another craft, similar to the Alabama, had sailed from that port, to capture and destroy vessels sailing under the American flag, ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernian, from Liverpool on the 20th ult., and Londonderry on the 21st, passed Cape Race on Saturday evening, and a summary of her news is telegraphed. It was reported at Liverpool that another craft, similar to the Alabama, had sailed from that port, to capture and destroy vessels sailing under the American flag, and that still another would soon follow. The London Times mentions a rumor that Mr. SEWARD has addressed the British Government in a tone of displeasure relative to the aid given to the Alabama in British ports. This rumor, the Times says, created for a time some little uneasiness on the Stock Exchange. A dispatch from Hamburg states that the steamer Bavaria, from New-York, was ashore off Altona Beach. The mails and passengers were safely landed. The sales of Cotton in Liverpool for three days were 4,500 bales, the market closing steady on Wednesday evening. The Manchester market was dull. The Liverpool Breadstuffs market was steady, but quiet. Corn upward. Provisions dull. Console closed on Thursday at 93 1/2 for money.

abstract: Aliah beebe vs. Roswell D. Halch, Executer, &c. -- The complaint in this [???] set out two causes of action. The refers to whom it was [???] reported in favor of the [???] on the [???] action, and for the defendant on the first. The defendant therefore claimed his right to tax costs in the suit, which the clerk declined to fellow. The matter was then taken before the Court, the defendant relying on 2 R.S., (see 26 p. 617) which provides that where there are two or more separate and distinct causes of action set up in the complaint, the plaintiff shall recover on those in his favor, and the defendant on those found for him, and that such provision of the statute is in full force, and has not been abrogated by the Codes of 1848.

abstract: We have noticed,  with surprise and regret, that no further steps have been taken in the United States Circuit Court in relation to the missing cargo of the prize Hiawatha.
lead_paragraph: We have noticed, with surprise and regret, that no further steps have been taken in the United States Circuit Court in relation to the missing cargo of the prize Hiawatha. There has been neglect somewhere. Here has been $20,000 worth of property spirited out of the custody of the United States Marshal, and which will not be forthcoming when the final decree shall be made in the cause, and if that final decree shall forfeit the goods there will be $10,000 less for the Government, and $10,000 less for the naval captors, unless some steps are taken in the matter.

lead_paragraph: Samuel Engle and another vs. John Yates.-- This case was stated in the TIMES of the 23d and 30th November, at which times certain orders of arrest obtained against the defendant were vacated--the former on the ground that the arrest had been made by fraudulently inducing the defendant within the County for the purpose of arresting him; and the latter on the ground that in consequence of the former action -- for the same cause -- being in another Court, and the order having been vacated, the matter was res adjudicata. The former arrest was in the Supreme Court, and the latter in the Common Pleas.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. STAHL has just returned. He attacked the enemy at Snicker's Ferry, and followed them with 300 cavalry into the camps on the other side of the river, and near Perryville. Our men charged splendidly whenever they met the enemy. WHITE's Cavalry was driven in all directions, nearly all their officers captured, and their colors taken. WHITE himself fled, and hid himself at a house in Perryville.
lead_paragraph: CHANTILLY, Va., Sunday, Nov. 30 -- 7 P.M.

abstract: Both Houses of Congress assembled yesterday at noon, and immediately proceeded to business. In the Senate, after the opening prayer by Rev. Dr. SUNDERLAND, the customary message was sent to the House notifying that body that a quorum was ready. A similar message was received from the House, when a Joint Committee was appointed to notify the President. The President's Message was shortly afterward received, and after its reading the Senate adjourned.

abstract: editorial reminds public to vote
snippet: editorial reminds public to vote
lead_paragraph: We desire merely to remind our readers that our municipal election takes place today, and that it behooves them not to neglect the duty of voting for the candidates who seem to them best fitted for responsible public trusts. The most important of the offices to be filled is that of Comptroller, and the choice lies between ROBERT T. HAWS, whose discharge of the duties of that most responsible position for the last two years have commended him to the universal confidence and esteem of all our intelligent citizens, without distinction of party, -- and Judge BRENNAN, whose only claims to the place grow out of the fact that he is the regular nominee of the Democratic Party. For Corporation Counsel, the candidates are A.W. BRADFORD, formerly Surrogate of the City, and JOHN E. DEVELIN -- both men of character and professional ability. For Aldermen, Councilmen and School officers, both parties have their candidates in the field, and it is for every citizen to exercise his best judgment and discretion in making a selection.
headline: {'main': 'The Election To-Day.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Election To-Day.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news telegraphed from the Headquarters of the Army of the Potomac is not important. The cannonading mentioned in yesterday's dispatch, it now appears, was from one of the enemy's right wing batteries.
lead_paragraph: The news telegraphed from the Headquarters of the Army of the Potomac is not important. The cannonading mentioned in yesterday's dispatch, it now appears, was from one of the enemy's right wing batteries. The explanation of it is not known. We have some additional news of much importance from the rebel side of the Rappahannock, brought over by two gentlemen recently from Richmond, and holding positions under the rebel Government -- one as a Captain in a Texas regiment, and the other as a clerk in the Quartermaster's Department -- and who have concluded to seek protection under the old flag. These gentlemen agree that the rebel force at Fredericksburgh numbers from 75,000 to 100,000 men -- certainly not exceeding the latter figure. LEE and his associates are for once, however, puzzled by the movements of our army, and are in doubt as to its future movements. They think the attack on Richmond is to be made from some other quarter, and acting upon this idea, they have commenced the erection of earthworks for the protection of a garrison force, while the main body of their army has again commenced moving toward Richmond. The Quartermaster's clerk further says that the entire rebel army has never exceeded 475,000 men.

abstract: The funeral of BYRNES took place from his residence, No. 3 Morris-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Long before the hour appointed for the ceremony to take place the house was crowded with the relatives and friends of the deceased, among ...
lead_paragraph: The funeral of BYRNES took place from his residence, No. 3 Morris-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Long before the hour appointed for the ceremony to take place the house was crowded with the relatives and friends of the deceased, among whom were a large number of distinguished Democratic politicians. Soon after 10 o'clock the coffin was closed and placed in the hearse. About half an hour later the funeral cortege, which was very extensive, proceeded to St. Peter's Catholic Church, in Barclay-street, where a solemn Requiem Mass was offered for the repose of the soul of the deceased. The remains were laid on tressels in the centre aisle, near the high altar, and Rev. Father QUINN, assisted by Rev. Father MADDEN, officiated in the solemn and impressive ceremonies. At the conclusion of the services, the body was removed to the hearse, and the long procession proceeded to Cavalry Cemetery, where the remains were interred.
headline: {'main': 'The Funeral of Byrnes.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Funeral of Byrnes.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, published THIS MORNING, and to be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, will be found the President's Message in full.
lead_paragraph: In THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, published THIS MORNING, and to be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing, will be found the President's Message in full. In addition to containing the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details, of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, will be found in the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. European news with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and marketreports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: editorial on proposal
snippet: editorial on proposal
lead_paragraph: The Message of President LINCOLN, which we publish in another part of this morning's TIMES, is a concise, clear and perspicuous document. It will of course be read by every one able to read in this country, and by every person in Europe and over the world, who takes an interest in the military and civil affaire of this Government and people. The view which it presents of the progress of the war for quelling the rebellion, if not as brilliant as could be wished, is still sufficiently encouraging to stimulate hopes of speedy and decisive results.

abstract: The French pro  posal for mediation will give to many among us a different idea from what they have had of the purposes and wishes of France. There have been two parties among us on this question,--the one insisting that ...
lead_paragraph: The French pro posal for mediation will give to many among us a different idea from what they have had of the purposes and wishes of France. There have been two parties among us on this question,--the one insisting that France had been from the first impatient to interfere in behalf of the South, and the other representing her as continually repressing the impatience of England to interfere. Vanity Fair some two or three weeks ago had an expression of this latter view representing John Bull urging on Monsieur Crapaud to attack the American Eagle in its wounded condition, while the latter responded, "Not yet." Vanity Fair will have to reconsider that picture. The diplomatic notes show plainly that this time, at least, it was France who was impatient to go forward, and England who was inclined to look before she leaped.

abstract: Editorial on US Government relations with Indians based on report by US Interior Dept
snippet: Editorial on US Government relations with Indians based on report by US Interior Dept
lead_paragraph: -- IMPORTANT SUGGESTION REGARDING OUR GOLD AND SILVER LANDS. -- The report from the Department of the Interior (Secretary SMITH) and the accompanying reports from subordinate bureaus, such as the Land Office, the Indian Bureau, and the Pension Bureau, will be perused with interest. They contain, all of them, highly valuable information. The Pension Bureau has now become a far more extensive and important organization than ever before; the Indian Bureau, too, has had heavy duty and grievous labor during the year; but the business of the Land Office has steadily continued to decline, owing to the decrease of immigration and the passage of the Homestead law. The most interesting portion of Commissioner EDMUNDS' report is that which is devoted to a discussion of the relations between the financial condition of the country and the gold fields of the public domain. The facts and speculations he furnishes in regard to the present and prospective yield of gold from the far West will astonish those who have not paid special attention to the subject. For the present year the yield of precious metals will undoubtedly be $100,000,000 at least; and within ten years the annual product must reach two thousand million dollars in the precious metals alone. The Government should, of course, secure a handsome revenue from these mineral lands, and Commissioner EDMUNDS discusses this point with force. He does not recommend any measure for the sale of the mineral lands, but advises the retention of the fee in the United States, and that they be held open to the free occupation of all our people, subject only to a nominal annual license, and such monthly, quarterly or annual moderate percentage upon the product as shall be prescribed by law. A limitation as to the quantity which may he held by any person is also advised, with the guarantee that such quantity may be retained so long as the location shall be occupied, worked and payments duly made to the Government. This will furnish a permanent basis of revenue to the Government. We hope this important subject will at once be taken up and legislated upon by Congress.
headline: {'main': 'DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Commissioner DOLE'S report on Indian Affairs is very long, and presents the subject in all its aspects. He opens the document by recommending the plan of placing all the Indians upon reservations, teaching them civilization, and when developed sufficiently, dividing up the lands among them. Then they will some time be so far advanced as to have interests identical with those of the citizens of the various States.
lead_paragraph: Commissioner DOLE'S report on Indian Affairs is very long, and presents the subject in all its aspects. He opens the document by recommending the plan of placing all the Indians upon reservations, teaching them civilization, and when developed sufficiently, dividing up the lands among them. Then they will some time be so far advanced as to have interests identical with those of the citizens of the various States. Hostilities the States, may be apprehended in the Spring with the Sioux of Dakotah, the most powerful tribe on the continent. He sketches at length the intrigues of the rebels with the various tribes, and the measures adopted by Gen. HUNTER for the relief of the refugees, the state of affairs in New-Mexico and California, and then turns to the consideration of the recent troubles in Minnesota. He states that the origin of the difficulties, as well as it can be understood from the imperfect facts yet reported, seems to have been a dissatisfaction with the payments. These had been reduced by the necessary subtractions from their annuities of the sums needed to pay for the depredations lawless Sioux had committed. This reduction had caused much complaint, and the Indians could not be made to understand its cause. Finally it was decided, so threatening had become their demonstrations, to make the last annual payment in full. In order to do this, it was necessary to defer the payment beyond the usual time, till certain needed appropriations should become available. About the usual time of making the payment, bands of the Sioux, without previous notice of the Agent's readiness to pay, (which they always received heretofore before assembling,) assembled at the Agent's residence, and in the most threatening and insolent manner demanded their annuities. Troops had to be ordered out to protect the Agency, and it was only after the most positive assurances of speedy payment that they were induced to disperse.

abstract: The old Wigwam was ablaze last night, in honor of the great Democratic victory -- the election of a Comptroller from the Sixth Ward. The council fires were lighted, the pipe of peace was smoked. The fire-water poured plentifully forth from the great spring, and jubilation predominated. THOS. WHEELAN, Esq., presided, and addresses were made by Capt. RYNDERS, Crazy Count STUART, Capt. CALLAHAN, Mr. DAVIS, and others of less note, who fairly talked the room empty quite early in the evening. The harmonious Democracy, however, enjoyed itself out of doors, as well as in, and tasked to the utmost the capacities and hospitalities of the adjacent Pewter Mug. Some of the more boisterous even overflowed in the publication office of our peaceful neighbor of the Tribune, giving numerous cheers for candidates not supposed to be in much favor in that locality.
lead_paragraph: The old Wigwam was ablaze last night, in honor of the great Democratic victory -- the election of a Comptroller from the Sixth Ward. The council fires were lighted, the pipe of peace was smoked. The fire-water poured plentifully forth from the great spring, and jubilation predominated. THOS. WHEELAN, Esq., presided, and addresses were made by Capt. RYNDERS, Crazy Count STUART, Capt. CALLAHAN, Mr. DAVIS, and others of less note, who fairly talked the room empty quite early in the evening. The harmonious Democracy, however, enjoyed itself out of doors, as well as in, and tasked to the utmost the capacities and hospitalities of the adjacent Pewter Mug. Some of the more boisterous even overflowed in the publication office of our peaceful neighbor of the Tribune, giving numerous cheers for candidates not supposed to be in much favor in that locality.

abstract: Whether the recommendations of the President touching "compensated emancipation," ought to be adopted or not, is a question open to doubt. They are so wide in their range, and so complex in their consequences, that nobody but a sciolist or a dogmatist will decide upon them off-hand. But this one thing we say unhesitatingly: the President is to be commended for his largeness of view. He rises entirely above the little makeshifts of the day, which so easily satisfy the mousing politician; and, like the true statesman, seeks a broad policy, which shall embrace and protect the future as well as the present. His specific plan may be wise, or it may be unwise; but no thoughtful man will deny that it originated in a just appreciation of the mighty bearings of the subject upon the future peace and welfare of the country.

abstract: - The Indian has made himself more conspicuous during the last year than he had been for a long time previous. The rebel Indians in the territory west of Arkansas, the wild Indians who again rule in Arizona and who have figured extensively in New-Mexico, and the murderous Indians who have carried desolation and slaughter over a large section of Minnesota, have successively attracted attention. There has been an idea widely prevailing among those best informed on the subject, that attempts have been made by white and red rebels to form a general league of all the tribes this side of the Rocky Mountains against the settlers; and of this there is a great deal of confirmatory proof. That has failed, but the horrid deeds of the red men have induced a stronger feeling of animosity than ever against them in the West. The people of Minnesota threaten to exterminate all those in that State, and along the whole line, from Minnesota to Texas, there is a strong desire to have the Indian question quickly brought to a definite solution. Most of the settlers are in favor of at least "driving them out" -- no matter where they may be driven to. This, however, like "putting down the rebellion," is a thing easier spoken of than accomplished.

abstract: The steamer Union, which arrived at this port yesterday, brought advices from Vera Cruz to the 12th of November. There is no news of military movements in the interior, except the confirmation of the report of the peaceful occupation of Jalapa by the French troops. Troops were continually landing at Vera Cruz, the number exceeding 36,000 outside the walls of the city. The sickness among them, however, is frightful. According to the Diario de la Marina, of Havana, operations will not commence before the beginning of January, when they are to be undertaken on a grand scale against Mexico and Puebla, the French troops advancing in two columns and by different roads.

abstract: Editorial lauds establishment of ambulance corps
snippet: Editorial lauds establishment of ambulance corps
lead_paragraph: -AN AMBULANCE CORPS. -- We are glad to learn that it has not only been determined to raise an ambulance corps for our army, but that the thing is now well under way, and will be available, to a large extent, in the first engagement that may take place in Virginia. Heretofore the care of the wounded who fell in the field has devolved upon their comrades by their side. When a man has fallen, the two others nearest to him have been accustomed to bear him to the rear, where he was put in charge of the surgeons. In such sanguinary battles as we have often had, where regiments have been doubly decimated, this system has almost entirely broken up the lines; for many of those who go to the rear with a wounded man never return; and if they do return, it is only to confuse still more the ranks which their absence has already confused. A regiment of four hundred men, with fifty wounded, can thus retain in steady action little more than half its strength. An army surgeon informs us that at the battle of Cedar Mountain, as doubtless at many other battles, this mode of operating produced the greatest disturbance in regiments, and almost entirely broke up one brigade.

abstract: A German Festival, to raise funds for a German Hospital, was held on Monday night, in the hall on the corner of Broadway and Fourth-street. A want has long been felt for a hospital for German immigrants who reach this country sick, friendless, ignorant of the English language, and otherwise wrong side up. The efforts to build this hospital have thus far been made, almost wholly, by the German mechanics and ladies. They expect to receive from the City a building lot on Fifty-ninth-street, between Second-avenue and Fourth-avenue. The hospital will probably cost $100,000. The building will not be put up till $50,000 have been raised; $6,000 have already been secured through the exertions of German ladies.

abstract: The necessary preparations having been completed, all the cases not yet disposed of will be taken up in turn, and acted on with the least possible delay. It should be remembered that a considerable per centage of application will not be found allowable on examination. It is also to be borne in mind that the total number of applications, on account of the present war, (10,804,) includes a large proportion of all the supposed cases for pension that have arisen during a period of hostilities extending over a period of eighteen months. The number of soldiers discharged on a certificate of disability is by no means a measure of the number that are entitled to receive invalid pensions. The latter class, in fact, includes buf a small proportion of the former. Of the thousands who die on the battle-field, or in the hospital, it will probably be found that the larger number have neither widow nor dependent relatives entitled to receive a pension under the late act.

abstract: The Report of Postmaster-General BLAIR is one of the few papers from the Departments that will give universal satisfaction. It tells of increased mail accommodations, of rigid economy in administration, and a reduction of over two millions of dollars in the expense of the Department to the National Treasury. Not for twenty years has the Post-office Department promised so fairly to become self-supporting. A continuance of the policy of the present chief may yet give us that very desirable result.

abstract: The month of November, 1862, has been remarkable for extremes, but the average temperature has not been very far from a true mean, notwithstanding. On the 1st and 2d, the mercury rose to 69° and 70° at 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 P.M., the highest maxima in November that I have ever recorded, except in 1845, 1854, 1857 and 1860 -- in 1845 to 71° on the 1st, in 1854 to 71° on 1st and 15th, in 1857 to 72° on 9th, and in 1860 to 72° and 71° on 1st and 2d. On the morning of the 7th the mercury was down to 27°, a fall of 43° from 2 1/2 P.M. of the 2d, and 3° lower than any previous morning of the season. At noon a drifting snowstorm commenced, and continued until 7 P.M. The amount of snow was not more than 2 1/2 inches, yet it formed drifts in some places 30 inches in depth. The thermometer was not above 27° all day -- the lowest maximum that I have ever observed so early in November, and one of the lowest at any period of November, the lowest being 19° on Nov. 30, 1847.
lead_paragraph: The month of November, 1862, has been remarkable for extremes, but the average temperature has not been very far from a true mean, notwithstanding. On the 1st and 2d, the mercury rose to 69° and 70° at 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 P.M., the highest maxima in November that I have ever recorded, except in 1845, 1854, 1857 and 1860 -- in 1845 to 71° on the 1st, in 1854 to 71° on 1st and 15th, in 1857 to 72° on 9th, and in 1860 to 72° and 71° on 1st and 2d. On the morning of the 7th the mercury was down to 27°, a fall of 43° from 2 1/2 P.M. of the 2d, and 3° lower than any previous morning of the season. At noon a drifting snowstorm commenced, and continued until 7 P.M. The amount of snow was not more than 2 1/2 inches, yet it formed drifts in some places 30 inches in depth. The thermometer was not above 27° all day -- the lowest maximum that I have ever observed so early in November, and one of the lowest at any period of November, the lowest being 19° on Nov. 30, 1847.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--One of the most successful pieces of Mr. WALLACK'S old repertoire--or rather the repertoire that he made delightful at his old house--was PALGRAVE SIMPSON'S "Bachelor of Arts." Slight in itself, and so short that it hardly sufficed for an evening's entertainment, it had to depend, as it still does, on the true ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--One of the most successful pieces of Mr. WALLACK'S old repertoire--or rather the repertoire that he made delightful at his old house--was PALGRAVE SIMPSON'S "Bachelor of Arts." It was produced under the most favorable circumstances, and with a company which we can hardly expect to see surpassed. Slight in itself, and so short that it hardly sufficed for an evening's entertainment, it had to depend, as it still does, on the true rtistic expansion of their various rules. Mr. LESTER WALLACK, Mr. LYSANDER THOMPSON and Mr. SETCHELL, distinguished themselves in the parts which were last right intrusted to the first-named gentleman, (who reappeared in his original part,) Mr. GILBERT and Mr. FLOYD. It is always unpleasant to draw comparisons, as it is difficult to avoid doing so. We may say briefly that Mr. JOHN GILBERT was excellent as Andrew Wpie, and made his exit in the last act with much of the force of his predecessor. Mr. FLOYD as Adolphus, was all that could be desired, and in the introductory scene with his tutor, displayed the nicest perception of youthful gaucherie. Mr. LESTER WALLACK was, of course, admirable. It is unnecessary to speak of the other characters except in terms of general praise. Mr. CHARLES FISHER, Mr. GEORGE HOLLAND, Mr. TURNER, Miss MARY GANNON and Miss FANNY MORANT, were alike excellent. The piece is light, pleasant and delightful, and was completely successful.

abstract: Editorial on success of German opera in NYC; compares Italian opera
snippet: Editorial on success of German opera in NYC; compares Italian opera
lead_paragraph: The elasticity of the American temperament, its easy transition from gloom to gaiety, its happy faculty of forgetting the evil of the day in the event of the evening, are just now singularly illustrated in the uniform and remarkable prosperity of all the places of Metropolitan amusement. In the olden times the Muses hung their heads when strife was in the land; now they are friskier than ever. The success of the theatres alone would not be remarkable. They can adapt themselves to the exigencies of the moment; if it is war, they can reflect the valor of the combatants, the heroic deeds of the brave; if it be commercial ruin, they can preach on the evil effects of stock-gambling, and so on through the catalogue of national disasters. But with the higher class of entertainments it is widely different. Music, in particular, appeals to that nice balance of the intellectual powers which in its ultimate condition is called taste. It is surprising, at least, to hear of the flourishing condition of music in such times. Yet we have two operas in full operation, and there is hardly a night that Irving Hall is not the scene of a Philharmonic or other concert. It seems, indeed, as if people, without regard to actual merit, were content to rush to any and every place.

abstract: MR. TASISTRO At IRVING HALL. -- An audience of especial respectability and intelligence comfortably filled the auditorium of Irving Hall on Monday evening, to hear Mr. FITZGERALD TASISTRO deliver a lecture on "The Giants and Pigmies of America." The subject is suggestive, and of interest to all classes of the community. It deals with personalities of the great and little public men of the country, in that gossiping, piquant way which is so irresistibly attractive to the curious and inquiring mind of the great mass of the people. It gives us the inner social and political life of many of our public men for several years past, pleasantly analyzing the characters of Presidents and place-hunters. Senators and snobs, lobbyites and loafers, and enabling as to form a juster opinion than we may, perhaps, have hitherto done, of the real value to their native land which we should put on some tritons, who were very insignificant, and other minnows, who might, had circumstances admitted, have developed into size and usefulness. Mr. TASISTRO has been behind the scenes. He speaks of that whereof he has had observation and experience; and his manner of telling what he knows is clear, colloquial and entertaining. His lecture should be repeated at not very distant intervals. It will always be listened to with pleasure; and cannot fail to become -- if varied in detail from time to time -- a standard source of amusement during the coming Winter.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was offered by Mr. Grimes, of Iowa, and adopted, calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for information regarding the acceptance of the title to League Island. Mr. Powell, of Kentucky, offered a resolution, which was laid over, asking for information relative to the arrest and confinement of citizens of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was offered by Mr. Grimes, of Iowa, and adopted, calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for information regarding the acceptance of the title to League Island. Mr. Powell, of Kentucky, offered a resolution, which was laid over, asking for information relative to the arrest and confinement of citizens of Kentucky. A resolution was offered by Mr. MCDOUGAL, of California, and laid over, asking for information relative to money paid for prosecuting land titles in California and for searches in Mexico. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, offered a joint resolution, denouncing arbitrary arrests, and declaring that they shall not be made henceforth. It was laid over. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, offered a joint resolution, recommending the choice of delegates to meet in convention at Louisville on the first Monday in April next, to take into consideration the present condition of the country, and the proper means to be pursued for restoring the Union, and that the Legislatures of the different States take such action as they may deem fit for the purpose, at the earliest possible date. This was also laid over, and the Senate then adjourned.

abstract: -GEN. MCCULLAM's REPORTS. -- An abstract of the report of Secretary of War STANTON was permitted to be telegraphed to the New-York Press at a very late hour last night, and in a Philadelphia paper of yesterday we find the introductory paragraphs in full, which we copy. The first half-dozen sentences are very concise and business-like, but of the merits of the document, as a whole, we can express no opinion until we see it in its complete form. The Secretary states that the scene of warlike operations comprises ten military departments, and that "the armies operating in those departments, according to recent official returns, constitute a force of 775,336 officers and privates, fully armed and equipped. Since the date of the returns this number has been increased to over 800,000. When the quotas are filled up it will number a million of men, and the estimates for next year are based upon that number." He then proceeds to give a review of the campaigns of the armies in the different departments, and states that "if these campaigns have not equaled in their results the expectations of the Government and the public hope, still they have not been unproductive of good results." We suppose we shall receive the whole of the document to-day, and learn officially what we already know unofficially -the progress and fruit of all the campaigns against rebels in the East and West.

abstract: THE REBELLION.  We have intelligence from Falmouth that the rebels have been attempting to post pickets near our lines on the right, but that they were driven back by a judicious display of force, of cavalry and infantry. The rebel force was not large, and did not offer to dispute the ground.

abstract: Commander WORDEN, whose services on the Monitor have been so highly appreciated by his country, will sail from this City next week, in command of a better ship than even the Merrimac's antagonist. His eyes are well enough for duty, and his spirits excellent. By the laws of rank alone he is a commander, no special promotion having been conferred on him. His new craft, the Ericsson Battery Montauk, now ...
lead_paragraph: Commander WORDEN, whose services on the Monitor have been so highly appreciated by his country, will sail from this City next week, in command of a better ship than even the Merrimac's antagonist. His eyes are well enough for duty, and his spirits excellent. By the laws of rank alone he is a commander, no special promotion having been conferred on him. His new craft, the Ericsson Battery Montauk, now [???] Delamater Iron Works, is nearly finished, and will be ready to fight in a few days. Her new gun and [???] apparatus is receiving the final touches, the officers appointed by the Navy Department have newly all reported to Admiral PAULDING, and the guns are already on board. She is even more carefully completed than the [???]. The Weehawkeu, too, is hurrying up at Jersey City, and will be finished soon after the departure of the Masters.

abstract: THE MONITOR WEEHAWKEN. -- The iron-clad monitor Weehawken, which was launched from Mr. COLWELL's yard in Jersey City a short time since, is fast approaching completion, and it is expected will be in readiness for service in about two weeks. The turret has been placed in position, and the port-holes for the two monster guns are nearly finished. The pilot-house, which is made of plates of iron, eleven inches thick, will be placed on the top of the turret, and is pierced with small holes for lookouts near the top. A couple of days since, while some workmen were moving a small engine on rollers on he deck of the monitor, it suddenly lurched overboard, carrying with it sixteen men, who fortunately escaped with only a ducking.

abstract: There is no denying the fact that the esprit du corps of certain regiments is worth more to the man who wishes to enlist than all the bounties that can be showered upon him; and yet the soldier is not entirely willing to forego whatever benefits may be deduced from the bounty system. The old Twelfth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, has opened a station at No. 546 Pearl-street, under the charge of Capt. WM. FOWLER, a gallant officer, who was wounded at Manassas, who is anxious to take men with him to join this regiment. In addition to the chance of joining such a regiment, the Twelfth offers a bounty of $79. Those who are soldierly inclined will join this regiment it they know their own welfare. The record of the regiment will show that the promotions in this regiment have been from the ranks.

abstract: We have advices from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to last evening. No important movement has yet taken place. Another body of our cavalry, numbering about sixty, were surprised on Tuesday morning by a superior number of rebels, and some of them were taken prisoners. About forty of them were known to have escaped, and it was thought that more of them would come in. Gen. BURNSIDE has issued an order ...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac to last evening. No important movement has yet taken place. Another body of our cavalry, numbering about sixty, were surprised on Tuesday morning by a superior number of rebels, and some of them were taken prisoners. About forty of them were known to have escaped, and it was thought that more of them would come in. Gen. BURNSIDE has issued an order dismissing from the service in disgrace Capt. GEORGE JOHNSTON, who had command of the picket of Pennsylvania cavalry surprised by the rebels on the 28th ult. Deserters from the rebel army continue to come over the river, and represent their army as being very destitute, particularly in clothing. LEE, it is said, has issued an order that such of his soldiers as are without shoes must make moccasins from raw hides, or do duty barefooted. The conclusion of the correspondence with the authorities of Fredericksburgh, showing why that city was not shelled, is given in the TIMES this morning, as found in the Richmond papers.

abstract: Gen. BANKS was, yesterday morning, served with a writ of habeas corpus, issued by Judge MCCUNN, directing him to produce the body of one of the soldiers of his Expedition, belonging to a New-York regiment, before the Judge, at his office in Wall-street, at 2 P.M. At the hour appointed, ETHAN ALLEN, Assistant United States District-Attorney, appeared before the Judge and made return to the writ on behalf of Gen. BANKS, to the following effect: First, that the body of the aforesaid soldier was then on board the Northern Light, and on its way to the Narrows -- the transport having sailed from her dock before the General was served with the writ. Second, that the General himself had set sail on the same errand with his soldiers at 1 P.M. Notwithstanding these obstacles to a literal compliance with the writ. Gen. BANKS desired the Judge to understand that he entertained the greatest respect for the mandates of the Civil Courts, and would do all that lay in his power to obey the processes emanating therefrom; he would therefore direct that the soldier alluded to be put on shore from the Northern Light, before she left the Bay, and leave it to him to present himself in obedience to the writ. Judge MCCUNN expressed himself entirely satisfied with the above return to the writ, and gave utterance, in the most exalted terms, to his high esteem and admiration of Gen. BANKS as a lawyer, statesman, soldier, civilian and gentleman.

Judge MCCUNN expressed himself entirely satisfied with the above return to the writ, and gave utterance, in the most exalted terms, to his high esteem and admiration of Gen. abstract: The report from the Ordnance Department, by Capt. J.A. DAHLGREN, abounds in interesting and important matter. He first urges that suitable provision of ordinance material be made for the probable future necessities of the navy, and after suggesting various other steps which should at once be taken to increase the efficiency of his department, turns to the discussion ...
lead_paragraph: The report from the Ordnance Department, by Capt. J.A. DAHLGREN, abounds in interesting and important matter. He first urges that suitable provision of ordinance material be made for the probable future necessities of the navy, and after suggesting various other steps which should at once be taken to increase the efficiency of his department, turns to the discussion of "Iron-clads and Ordnance." He sketches the progress made by our own, as well as by the French and English Governments in the construction and the improvement of ordnance, discusses the difficulties in constructing a ship impregnable to the heaviest shot, and in working a gun of the largest calibre. In the experiments which have been made in England, he acknowledges that the advantages remain with the guns, and there, he thinks, they will continue for the present. He adds:

abstract: We do not need to direct public attention to the report of Secretary Stanton, nor to that of the subordinate Bureau of Ordnance. The opinions of Capt. DAHLGREN, however, as given in the latter, have a positive and scientific value, possessed by the matter of no other official report with which the public has been favored. He discusses ably, and in such a way as to command the attention of the world, the important question of iron plates and ordnance, and gives some new and very interesting facts bearing upon the ever-memorable contest of the Merrimac and Monitor. He discourses upon the respective merits of rifled and smooth-bore ordnance, and the proper mode of arming iron-clads. Concerning harbor defences, and particularly those of this port, he gives some valuable suggestions. He thinks "that a trustworthy and thorough defence can only be made by a harmonious and just combination of forts, iron-clads and rams, with such other minor auxiliaries as may be contributed to the general purpose; singly, neither would be effectual." And he indicates the defences that are necessary for the protection of the main passage to the City of New-York. Coming from the source they do, these suggestions certainly merit an equal attention from the Government to what they will receive from the citizens of the commercial metropolis of the country.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  While perusing the financial article of one of your Anti-Administration cotemporaries of this day, I felt very much befogged, until I arrived at the dire announcement that the Bank of England had entered into a conspiracy with the Foreign Exchange Bankers ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: While perusing the financial article of one of your Anti-Administration cotemporaries of this day, I felt very much befogged, until I arrived at the dire announcement that the Bank of England had entered into a conspiracy with the Foreign Exchange Bankers of New-York, (chiefly British,) to financially garrote Uncle Sam, whose money, it would appear, they have already had the audacity to make use of to the extent of $30,000,000!

abstract: The steamship China passed Cape Race on Monday afternoon, with two days later news from Europe, which was not telegraphed through until last evening. She left Liverpool on the 22d ult., and Queenstown on the 23d. The news of Gen. McCLELLAN's removal has reached England, and had caused depression in American Securities. The London Times regards the removal as the ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship China passed Cape Race on Monday afternoon, with two days later news from Europe, which was not telegraphed through until last evening. She left Liverpool on the 22d ult., and Queenstown on the 23d. The news of Gen. McCLELLAN's removal has reached England, and had caused depression in American Securities. The London Times regards the removal as the first effect of the elections on Mr. LINCOLN, and thinks it makes MCCLELLAN a conservative martyr. The Army and Navy Gazette regards the removal as a defiance of the Government to the Democrats, and thinks the moment favorable for bold Confederate movements. The London Star appears to be the only English paper which justifies the President in his action. The text of the Russian note declining the proposal of mediation had been received, and fully bears out the telegraphic summary. The Saturday Review thinks NAPOLEON has movements on foot which do not appear on the surface of the mediation scheme, and hints at a probable alliance between France and the Southern States in connection with the designs on Mexico. The sale of a number of fast coasting steamers in England, for the purpose of running the blockade, is noted, and a steamer recently left the Mersey with arms, etc., for the rebels. GARIBALDI had written a letter pledging himself strongly in favor of the North. The probability of the elevation of Prince ALFRED, of England, to the Greek, throne, caused some excitement among the diplomats. Cotton was firmer and a trifle higher. Breadstuffs were unchanged and Provisions flat. Consols closed on the 22d at 93 5/8@93 3/4 for Money.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock P.M., yesterday, and had a very important session. Alderman DAYTON sent in his resignation, but the Board declined to receive it, and ordered it to be sent back to him. The Mayor sent in the name of Senator CHAS. G. CORNELL, Democrat, for Street Commissioner. A secret session of half an hour, and a brief conference with the Mayor on the subject, by Committee, in she meantime ensued; afterward, this nomination and that of ROBERT L. DARRAGH, Republican, for Croton Commissioner, were confirmed in one and a unanimous vote. The resolution to have a portrait of Gen. MCCLELLAN, at a cost of $1,000, was taken up and passed, and the Board adjourned till 1 o'clock P.M. to-day. They meet by law one hour earlier as City Canvassers.

abstract: The friends of Gen. SICKLES sometime since had prepared for him by TIFFANY & Co., a full set of Brigadier-General's equipments, intending to have the presentation take place at a dinner expressly for the occasion, which the General, with his exceedingly good taste and judgment, declined as unsuitable to the distracted state of the country, preferring the plain simplicity of a letter, with the indorsement of his friends and fellow-citizens. This was done sometime since, but the arduous duties to which he has been subjected, from his new position as commander of a division, prevented him from answering as promptly as he otherwise would have done. The articles are of the most recherche description, consisting of presentation sword, belt, sash, epaulettes, pistols, gauntlets, spurs, saddle, saddle-cloth, (a most superb article,) &c., &c., &c. The presentation letter has been gotten up in a unique and tasty style, the letters splendidly engrossed, and, with the signatures of our most distinguished citizens, is encased in a very rich velvet binding of oriental style.

abstract: "THE CASE OF GEN. McNEIL.--We perceive that some of our metropolitan cotemporaries are squeamish about Gen. McNEIL'S action in shooting ten men in Missouri, in retailation for the supposed murder of a Union guide. They seem to regard it as of a piece with that sort of retaliation which JEFF. DAVIS proposes. This would, perhaps, be a fair criticism if the ...
lead_paragraph: "THE CASE OF GEN. McNEIL.--We perceive that some of our metropolitan cotemporaries are squeamish about Gen. McNEIL'S action in shooting ten men in Missouri, in retailation for the supposed murder of a Union guide. They seem to regard it as of a piece with that sort of retaliation which JEFF. DAVIS proposes. This would, perhaps, be a fair criticism if the persons executed were regular soldiers of the Confederacy. Such was not the case. They were guerrillas -- land pirates and outlaws of the basest sort. They were not fighting in regular modes of warfare, but in entire opposition to them -- murdering helpless, unarmed men, ravishing women, burning houses, and plundering everything upon which they could lay their hands. By common usage among nations, their lives were forfeited; Gen. MCNEIL would have been justified in having them shot, even had the outrage for which they suffered never been perpetrated. Our cause is not likely to suffer from too much severity toward the enemy, but from the contrary weakness."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted making inquiries of the Secretary of War relative to the purchase of land in Portsmouth harbor. The Standing Committee of last session were continued, with a few changes. Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution, which was laid over, calling upon the Secretary of War for information relative to the arrest of several ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted making inquiries of the Secretary of War relative to the purchase of land in Portsmouth harbor. The Standing Committee of last session were continued, with a few changes. Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution, which was laid over, calling upon the Secretary of War for information relative to the arrest of several citizens of Delaware. The Committee on Patents was instructed to inquire into the expediency of abolishing the Department of Agriculture. A resolution was adopted directing the Committee on Public Affairs to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill indemnifying the people of Minnesota for the outrages of the Indians. The Secretary of War was requested to furnish information regarding the sale of freemen into Slavery by the rebels. The Committee on Military Affairs was directed to consider the expediency of organizing an ambulance corps in the army. Mr. HALE gave notice of a bill to repeal the act establishing and equalizing the grades of officers in the navy. The Senate then went into Executive session, and subsequently adjourned.

lead_paragraph: We are very much pleased that the Chamber of Commerce has taken in hand the duty which we have repeatedly urged upon it, of practical action in the matter of sending relief to the starving operatives of the cotton manufacturing districts of England. A special meeting to consider the subject was held on Monday last, and on that occasion a Committee of seventeen of our most eminent citizens were appointed to bring the thing into shape; and they have now called a meeting of "gentlemen interested in the subject," at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce, this afternoon at 2 o'clock, "to take action in the matter." We trust the meeting will be a full one, and that all those who have expressed themselves anxious to contribute to this peculiar and international charity will be present to offer practical and feasible suggestions and donations.

abstract: To-day the Honton, a naval transport, heavily laden with stores and provisions at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, will go to sea. The Massachusetts, transport, will be taken in hands for immediate repairs. The Circassian is to be finished as soon as possible as a supply ship. The Vanderbilt lies off te Battery. The Connecticut is now a full-rigged man-of-war, heavily armed, and will be reported ready for sea this week. The steam-gunboat Wamsutta is to be overhauled at once, and put in sea trim. A large fleet of vessels has been chartered for the Banks Expedition, but their movements are secret. The yacht America is about to be armed.

abstract: A very elegant sword, belt and other appropriate appendages, are soon to be presented by the patriotic citizens of the Fifth Ward, to Maj. MICHAEL W. BURNS, Second Regiment Fire Zouaves, Excelsior Brigade, as an appropriate testimonial for gallantry in the field. Maj. BURNS was promoted from a Captaincy in the above-mentioned regiment, after the seven days' fight before Richmond, where he was taken prisoner by the rebels and subsequently exchanged. He was a member of Hose Carriage No. 21 at the time of joining the army, and his associates and friends of the Fifth Ward, of which he was a resident, have watched his military career thus far with pride and gratification.

abstract: editorial holds report of great historical value because it covers most critical period of war
snippet: editorial holds report of great historical value because it covers most critical period of war
lead_paragraph: We copy from the Tribune Gen. HALLECK'S report of the operations of the Union army since he became its Commanding General,--a period of but little over four months. It is a clear, unimpassioned statement of facts, with few comments, and these merely such as any intelligent reader would have made for himself. It has very great historical value, for it covers the most critical period of the war, -- that which followed Gen. MCCLELLAN's retreat from his position on the Chickahominy in front of Richmond, extending to the date of his removal from command. Every reader of this document will see at once that it involves and very seriously impugns the military reputation of Gen. MCCLELLAN.

abstract: If it Here not that perhaps one man in a hundred of the people of England may doubt the correctness of the London Herald's statement that a "recent steamer from Liverpool took out twenty-four French guillotines, consigned
lead_paragraph: If it Here not that perhaps one man in a hundred of the people of England may doubt the correctness of the London Herald's statement that a "recent steamer from Liverpool took out twenty-four French guillotines, consigned to a confidential agent of President LINCOLN, in New-York," we should not think it necessary to confirm its accuracy. But we have been assured by Mr. ARROWSMITH that it is literally true. He further states that the twenty guillotines mentioned are only the first installment of twenty thousand which Mr. LINCOLN has ordered; and moreover that all of these guillotines are of the kind which Mr. GEORGE SANDERS once desired to see in operation -- "guillotines worked by steam!" Mr. ARROWSMITH further confidentially states that it is Mr. LINCOLN's purpose to have all these instruments erected and in full blast by the first of next year; and that then he will spare neither man, woman nor child, white, black or speckled, until like the Hibernian Napoleon, "grand, gloomy and peculiar, he sits alone, a sceptered hermit, wrapt in the solitude of his own individuality."

abstract: Editorial speculates on Confederate strategy
snippet: Editorial speculates on Confederate strategy
lead_paragraph: The remarkable outburst of passion manifested in the rebel Congress when news was received of President LINCOLN's Emancipation Proclamation, will not easily be forgotten. Resolution after resolution was introduced for the consideration of the body, each more violent than the one preceding it, but all breathing a desperate and volcanic excitement that threatened to alter the whole aspect of the war by making it one of indiscriminate unsparing and implacable slaughter. The black flag was to be raised. No quarter was to be given. It was to be "war to the knife and the knife to the hilt," till the South was exterminated or the North driven back in defeat.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains the Reports of the Secretary of the Navy and the Secretary of War, with ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains the Reports of the Secretary of the Navy and the Secretary of War, with Gen. HALLECK's Important Report touching the action of our Armies since he was placed at their head. In addition to the latent intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and marketreports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Editorial questions mode of raising future armies
snippet: Editorial questions mode of raising future armies
lead_paragraph: There is one subject of very great importance to the future military efficiency of the Government that we do not find alluded to, either in the report of the Secretary of War or of the General-in-Chief. That is, the modes by which future armies are to be raised for the public defence. Hitherto there has been little difficulty about the matter. The Regular Army was always kept easily up to the limit of law by recruits. And when this small body of soldiers proved inadequate to any work in hand, it was found easy enough to get any number of Volunteers to vindicate the Government. A law of draft existed, but it was never thought of as a means of raising armies.

abstract: --Five years ...
lead_paragraph: --Five years ago a sailing sloop-of-war would have been considered well armed with sixteen or twenty 32-pounders. About 100 men were needed to fire such a battery, both broadsides of which discharged between 550 and 650 pounds of iron, in sixteen or twenty separate quantities. "A broadside," from such a vessel, would consist of some 290 pounds of iron. One single shot from the Passaic's 15-inch gun weighs 450 pounds, or nearly twice as much as the twenty guns of an old John Adams or Marion. And four men fire the 450 pounds while 100 were required to discharge 200 pounds. Could any fact better illustrate the nature of the revolution going on in naval affairs than this? abstract: Gen. GRANT is marching on with steady step toward the heart of Mississippi. He has got some twenty miles below Holly Springs, over forty miles from the northern line of the State, and has crossed the Tallahatchie, where the ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT is marching on with steady step toward the heart of Mississippi. He has got some twenty miles below Holly Springs, over forty miles from the northern line of the State, and has crossed the Tallahatchie, where the enemy was said to be preparing to resist him; but the rebels thought better of their resolve and fled "further south." This flight is rather surprising to us, and we believe it is equally so to the Mississippians. "We discover signs of haste on the part of the rebel army. They "destroyed supplies," of which we may be sure they had not too great abundance. And the people, the planters, who supposed themselves protected by the rebel army, when they saw it retiring put their own houses in order as rapidly as circumstances would permit, and rushed on ahead of the retreating troops, seeking some hiding-place that they might not be found by the terrible "Yankees." The Grenada Appeal, the valiant organ of treason that withdrew from Memphis in time to save its editor's neck, has executed another successful manoeuvre and removed from Grenada to Jackson. This change of base is timely, for Grenada is undoubtedly the first town of especial note to be visited by Gen. GRANT. The Appeal, in its new home, cries out against the apathy of the people, in the centre of Mississippi, and tells them that unless they arise in mass to resist the invaders they will be irretrievably ruined.

abstract: A fair for the benefit of the Institution for Children of Deceased and Disabled Soldiers, began at Cooper Institute on Monday. The Institution was started last May, and is in charge of the President, Rev. S.R. DAVIS, the lady President, Mrs. J.R. DAVIS, and a Board of more than thirty ladies, who give personal attention to the welfare of the children.
lead_paragraph: A fair for the benefit of the Institution for Children of Deceased and Disabled Soldiers, began at Cooper Institute on Monday. The Institution was started last May, and is in charge of the President, Rev. S.R. DAVIS, the lady President, Mrs. J.R. DAVIS, and a Board of more than thirty ladies, who give personal attention to the welfare of the children. It now supports thirty children, about half of whom find a home in the four-story building, No. 334 Sixth-avenue. This building is hired by the Society having charge of the Institution. The Society intends to try to erect a building in which, for a long time after the war is over, the children of soldiers shall be supported and educated. The Society's Board of Counsellors, including Rev. Drs. TYNG. D. DUNBAR, S.I. PRIME, and W.C. NOYES, Esq., recommend the Institution as worthy of cordial support. The Fair, in behalf of the Institution, is held every day this week, from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. Single tickets, 10 cents; season tickets, $1. The rooms are at the east of the large hall in Cooper Institute. They are decorated with American flags, and contain refreshment tables, furnished forth with turkey, oysters and ice cream; tables spread with toys and other valuables, and a posse of little girls, who wheedle irresolute visitors into a reckless and indiscrimate purchasing of shares. At one booth Mme. DEMOREST's $5 sewing machines, about as large as your hand, and going on the principle of the grindstone, are sold. The young lady presiding over them, shows that they are attached, like a sewing-bird, to the table, and take sixteen stitches at each revolution of the crank. At the Fair, this evening, there will be music by the Seventh Regiment Band.

abstract: SERIOUS STABBING AFFRAY.--About 1 o'clock yesterday morning an altercation occurred on Thirdavenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first-streets, between JAMES BRADY and PATRICK CAULEY, during which the latter was seriously stabbed in the abdomen, with a dirk-knife in the hands of BRADY.
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS STABBING AFFRAY.--About 1 o'clock yesterday morning an altercation occurred on Thirdavenue, between Fortieth and Forty-first-streets, between JAMES BRADY and PATRICK CAULEY, during which the latter was seriously stabbed in the abdomen, with a dirk-knife in the hands of BRADY. The wounded man was taken to his residence in East Forty-second-street, where he was attended by Dr. DERBY. The Police state that Drs. HODGMAN and SMITH were called upon by them to attend the injured man, and although they were informed that it was a case requiring immediate attention, they both refused to have anything to do with it. The offender managed to escape, but as he is well known to the Police, he will doubtless be speedily taken into custody.

abstract: THE MOUNT PROSPECT INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.-- A Fair and Festival in aid of the Mount Prospect Industrial School was commenced at the Academy of Music Wednesday evening, and was continued yesterday.
lead_paragraph: THE MOUNT PROSPECT INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.-- A Fair and Festival in aid of the Mount Prospect Industrial School was commenced at the Academy of Music Wednesday evening, and was continued yesterday. Some five years since, the benevolent ladies of the neighborhood of Grand and Atlantic avenues, where the institution is located, conceived a plan to improve the condition of the poor children of that vicinity by establishing a school, and as an inducement to attend, they provided them with one meal a day, and furnished each with decent clothing. The school was first opened in a stable, but it is now held in a fine building, erected at a cost of $5,800, and all paid for. The school has thus far been supported by the residents of the neighborhood, and this is the first time that an appeal is made in a public way. There is also connected with the institution a Bible-class for the parents of the children attending school, to which some 30 or 40 adults belong. The males have formed themselves into a band, now numbering 8 or 10 members, who have, during the past year, made commendable progress in the musical art. The band was present last evening, and played a number of fine airs. The number of children in the school is about 100, all well cared for, and with a good prospect that, under the influence of the ladies having them in charge, will become good members of society. A large number of useful and fancy articles were on exhibition at the Fair, and from appearances last evening, a considerable sum will be realized before the close this evening. The officers are: Mrs. S.B. Jenkins, First Directress; Mrs. H.P. Messenger, Second Directress; Mrs. J.W. Camp, Secretary; Mrs. A. Smithers, Corresponding Secretary; Mrs. M.A. Welch, Treasurer, and 30 managers.

abstract: A new Supreme Court Circuit Calendar will be made up for January Term, 1863. Causes on the present Circuit Calendar will not be transferred to the new Calendar unless notice that the same are not disposed of is filed with the Clerk with the Court on or before Saturday, the 20th inst. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted making inquiry as to the expediency of submitting appointments in the volunteer naval service to the Senate for confirmation. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted making inquiry as to the expediency of submitting appointments in the volunteer naval service to the Senate for confirmation. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill providing that soldiers shall be discharged within the limits of their own States. A joint resolution, referring so much of the President's Message as relates to emancipation, compensation and deportation to a Select Committee of three members of the Senate and five of the House, was laid over. A joint resolution, approving the President's policy in setting the slaves free in insurrectionary districts, was ordered to be printed. Mr. HALE introduced his bill relative to line officers of the navy, and it was referred. A resolution was offered by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and laid over, calling for all the information attainable relative to the movements of the Army of the Potomac and the surrender of Harper's Ferry. The death of Mr. THOMPSON, of New-Jersey, was then announced, and, after the customary proceedings in such cases, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The Heads of Departments whose appointment was made on Wednesday by the Mayor and Aldermen, took their respective official places at noon yesterday, and each was welcomed by the former incumbent, who, it appears, have in each case given up the idea of contesting their removal. Mr. CORNELL, the new Street Commissioner, filed bonds for $20,000. No bonds are required from Mr. DARRAGH, who was very handsomely received at the Croton Department by Mr. TAPPEN, who goes forth from it highly esteemed by the host of friends he made while in it. A man of more gentlemanly demeanor in office than Mr. TAPPEN has been to all persons, and under all circumstances, there could not be.
