abstract: On Tuesday evening last Mr. BROWN, a resident and doing business in this City, and whose Unionism, respectability and inoffensiveness are established, was arrested in Chatham-street by Officer MOORE, of JEFFERD'S case notoriety, under the following circumstances, as the story goes: Mr. BROWN, who is a ...
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening last Mr. BROWN, a resident and doing business in this City, and whose Unionism, respectability and inoffensiveness are established, was arrested in Chatham-street by Officer MOORE, of JEFFERD'S case notoriety, under the following circumstances, as the story goes: Mr. BROWN, who is a Massachusetts man, after having inspected the several election bulletins at the newspaper-offices, called into a saloon for the purpose of partaking of a glass of lager-bier. On entering the saloon he found there a number of soldiers from Massachusetts, and, feeling friendly toward them, said: "How are you, Massachusetts boys; I am glad to see you." As soon as he had spoken, MOORE stepped up and said to BROWN: "Stop your noise." BROWN, thinking he had not been making what could, as the term is generally used, be considered a noise, asked MOORE who he was. MOORE replied: "I am a Marshal." Mr. BROWN said to one of the soldiers, upon receiving the reply, "I don't believe he is any more a Marshal than I am." Upon this Mr. BROWN was arrested and lodged in the Park barracks, and in a very short time afterward, was conveyed to the Second Ward Station-house. Appearing there, accompanied by Mr. MOORE, the Captain of the Police asked Mr. MOORE by what authority he had arrested Mr. BROWN. Mr. MOORE stated his authority was verbal -- not written; and that he had received it informally from Mr DRAPER. In short, that his own word was all he had to present in support of his proceeding. The Captain discharged Mr. BROWN immediately, and Mr. MOORE departed.

abstract: --A friend in Tennessee has ...
lead_paragraph: --A friend in Tennessee has sent us a specimen of "cow-cotton" -- a novelty among manufactures, uniting in its fabric both the animal and the vegetable kingdoms, being a mixture, half and half, of cotton and cows hair. It makes a cheaper and stronger fabric than all cotton for common clothing. Its gray color, its coarse grain, its tough fibre, give it a little of the old-time homespun look, when men wore linsey-woolsey. The mode of manufacture is by hand-carding, as practiced by our mothers and grandmothers. If the pure Southern stuff that is fed to the Manchester mills should utterly fail, the English aristocracy may be glad to hear that their backs need not go bare, but can be clothed with cow-cotton. -- Independent.

abstract: An influential meeting of the merchants of New-York was held at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, for the purpose of securing material aid for the starving operatives of England. Mr. A.A. LOW presided, and addresses were made by Messrs. W.E. DODGE, ...
lead_paragraph: An influential meeting of the merchants of New-York was held at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, for the purpose of securing material aid for the starving operatives of England. Mr. A.A. LOW presided, and addresses were made by Messrs. W.E. DODGE, S.B. RUGGLES, S.B. CHITTENDEN, the Chair, JONATHAN STURGIS, EZRA NYE, and others. The most praiseworthy spirit of Christian charity was evinced toward the suffering masses of England, and a determination evinced to raise a subscription which shall do honor to the City, State and county. Over twenty-six thousand dollars was raised on the spot, and a ship offered by Messrs. N.L. and GEO. GRISWOLD to carry the needed supplies to Liverpool.

abstract: The infantry and cavalry which went on a  reconnoissance toward Grove Church yesterday morning, returned to camp this afternoon. The force consisted of two regiments of cavalry from AVERILL'S Brigade, and Col. BARNES' Brigade of ...
lead_paragraph: The infantry and cavalry which went on a reconnoissance toward Grove Church yesterday morning, returned to camp this afternoon. The force consisted of two regiments of cavalry from AVERILL'S Brigade, and Col. BARNES' Brigade of infantry, from GRIFFIN's Division. The entire force was under the command of Gen. AVERILL. It left camp at 8 A.M., the cavalry taking a direct road to be Church, and the infantry a road winding round to be right and approaching the Church from a different direction. The plan of procedure was well arranged, and had there been anything like the force of rebels which was represented to be hovering in that vicinity by semi-responsible parties, the efforts of our men would have resulted in the capture of two or three hundred prisoners instead of a single one. The expedition was projected under the conviction that a large body of rebel cavalry was attempting to make a raid upon our right wing. It appears, however, that only a few of STUART's scouts were discovered, one of whom was captured.

abstract: INTERNAL REVENUE.--The books of Mr. GEO. A. HALSEY, Assessor for the Fifth District of NewJersey, show the total number of licenses for the City of Newark to be 2,360, total amount of assessments for licenses, carriages and plate, $38,535 45.
lead_paragraph: INTERNAL REVENUE.--The books of Mr. GEO. A. HALSEY, Assessor for the Fifth District of NewJersey, show the total number of licenses for the City of Newark to be 2,360, total amount of assessments for licenses, carriages and plate, $38,535 45. Of the whole number of licenses, 631 are for retail liquor dealers. This, taking the population in 1861 (74,000) as a basis, would be one drinking-place for every 117.27 inhabitants. Of these drinking saloons, the greatest number (107) are in the Fourth Ward, and the smallest (31) in the Third Ward. Several manufacturers in Newark pay very large sums, monthly, to the Government, by way of tax on their products, in some cases the amount reaching $3,000, or $36,000 yearly. The Assessor has given public notice that manufacturers' returns for the month of November must be made on or before Dec. 10. The assessment books will be open for inspection from the 3d to the 19th of December. From the 20th to the 27th, the Assessor will hear appeals relative to erroneous or excessive valuation by the assistant assessors.

lead_paragraph: Court met again this morning at 11 o'clock. Col. R.D. GOODWIN was called to the stand. This witness is the author of a letter published in the NewYork Sunday Mercury, Sept. 28, 1862, in which he reflects upon the character of Gen. McDOWELL, accusing him of liberating traitors arrested by officers of his command, of giving protection to the cornfields of traitors when at Camp Ellsworth, July, 1861, while his men were sick from eating tainted meat, and unally, of having repeatedly seen him under the influence of liquor at Fairfax Court-House and at Col. GOODWIN's, in this city.

abstract: The military expedition which has been fitting out at this port for several weeks past, under the command of Maj.-Gen. N.P. BANKS, set sail yesterday, and is now fairly under way for its final destination. What that destination is has been a subject of much speculation on the part of the loyal public, and of anxiety on the part of the rebels, but thus far it has ...
lead_paragraph: The military expedition which has been fitting out at this port for several weeks past, under the command of Maj.-Gen. N.P. BANKS, set sail yesterday, and is now fairly under way for its final destination. What that destination is has been a subject of much speculation on the part of the loyal public, and of anxiety on the part of the rebels, but thus far it has been a well-kept secret. Time will soon disclose the mystery, however, and loyal men, we are sure, can afford to wait; and, as for the rebels, they will have to wait, whether they can afford it or not. The probabilities are that the first announcement of its destination was correct, and that in due time the expedition will find its way to the shores of Texas. For the present, therefore, and, until further advised, it will be safe to label it with the old initials, "G.T.T." The magnitude of the expedition is also a subject about which it is not proper to go into details, for, though not so much a secret as its destination, it is a species of contraband news of which the rebels already get more than their share, and deserve no addition from loyal sources. Suffice it to say that it is the largest, best-equipped and most formidable expedition that has yet been sent out by the Government, and on whatever part of the Southern coast it may land, it is safe to predict that results will follow corresponding with its magnitude, and justifying the most sanguine expectations of the Government and people of the North.

abstract: The merchants of this City, at the meeting held at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, gave a munificent response to the mute appeals of the starving operatives of the cotton manufacturing districts of England, as well ...
lead_paragraph: The merchants of this City, at the meeting held at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, gave a munificent response to the mute appeals of the starving operatives of the cotton manufacturing districts of England, as well as to the appeals of a portion of the New-York Press in their behalf. The proceedings of the meeting, and particularly toward its close, were grand and thrilling. We cannot, perhaps, describe the thing better than by saying that it was characteristically American; or, closer still, that it was peculiarly New-York-like; and especially, after the style that characterizes all the action of the enterprising and wealthy mercantile classes of the commercial Metropolis of the country. After the speeches and resolutions, which were all both humane and businesslike, a brief letter was read from the eminent shipping house of Messrs. N.L. & GEO. GRISWOLD, which contained the following sublime sentence: "As an earnest of our desire to further this cause, in behalf of ourselves and others, owners of a new ship now in Boston, we tender her entire capacity, 1,800 tons, for the conveyance of the supplies, and our services, if needed, to forward them free of charge for freight." The meeting at once tendered thanks for the generous offer, and Mr. DODGE stated it was virtually a contribution of $20,000 to the fund. Another letter was read from a gentleman who did not wish his name mentioned, which closed no less eloquently than the first one: "Thank God!" said the writer, "we have bread and to spare, and they will not say, 'I was an hungered, and ye gave me no meat.' Will you add to your list one thousand barrels of flour, from one whose loaf will taste the sweeter for sharing it with a famished brother, and brand it -- UNION." After the reading of this letter, the same munificent anonymous donor who had sent it, handed in, as an additional contribution, seven one-thousand dollar United States Treasury Notes, but he still desired his name should not be mentioned. Mr. DODGE desired that the firm of which he is a member might be put down for five thousand dollars; Mr. JOHNSTON, the Secretary of the meeting, offered twenty-five hundred; Capt. MARSHALL, two thousand; BABCOCK BROTHERS, two thousand; six other individuals or firms gave a thousand dollars each; and several sums nearly as large were offered from other donors -the names of all of whom will be found in our report of the meeting. The amount collected in a few minutes -- independent of the offer of the ship and the thousand barrels of flour -- reached $26,200. After which good beginning, the meeting adjourned to assemble again at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: We scarcely  need direct attention to the letters of onr intelligent and well-informed Paris correspondent. He gives what we have good reason for regarding as a just and accurate ex
lead_paragraph: We scarcely need direct attention to the letters of onr intelligent and well-informed Paris correspondent. He gives what we have good reason for regarding as a just and accurate explanation of the motives of the French Emperor in offering to join England and Russia in soliciting an armistice between the Government of the United States and the rebels who are seeking its overthrow. That explanation confirms the opinion we have already expressed, that this offer ought not to be considered hostile to the North.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted calling upon the President for information regarding the late Indian massacres in Minnesota. The bill concerning judgments in certain suits brought by the United States, having been passed
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was adopted calling upon the President for information regarding the late Indian massacres in Minnesota. The bill concerning judgments in certain suits brought by the United States, having been passed by the House, was referred to the Finance Committee. The report of the Secretary of the Treasury was handed in. The resolution offered by Mr. SHERMAN, on Thursday, calling for the correspondence, &c., relating to the Army of the Potomac, was passed. A bill repealing the law limiting the number of Major-Generals was referred. A resolution was adopted making inquiries as to the expediency of providing for a railroad from Washington to New-York, to carry the mails with certainty and dispatch. A resolution was adopted making inquiries as to the expediency of repealing that part of the Revenue law which imposes a tax upon powers of attorney for the collection of pensions, back pay and bounty for soldiers. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, called up his resolution relating to arbitrary arrests in Kentucky, and it was adopted, after the insertion of the words, "if not incompatible with the public interests." A resolution was adopted directing inquiry into the expediency of negotiating a treaty with the Indians of Southern Oregon and Northern California. The Senate then went into Executive Session, and subsequently adjourned until Monday.

abstract: It would, perhaps, be unwise for us to speculate on the details of the plan by which the General-in-Chief expects to capture Richmond. But we see nothing to forbid our noticing the speculations of the rebel press on the same subject. We copied yesterday
lead_paragraph: It would, perhaps, be unwise for us to speculate on the details of the plan by which the General-in-Chief expects to capture Richmond. But we see nothing to forbid our noticing the speculations of the rebel press on the same subject. We copied yesterday morning a letter from Richmond to the Grenada (Miss.) Appeal, dated November 13th, in which the writer gave it as his opinion that the new attack upon Richmond was to be made from the south side, -- up the James River and from Weldon; and that the mission of the Army of the Potomac whether under MCCLELLAN or BURNSIDE, was to amuse and detain the main body of the Rebel Army on the Rappahannock or Rapidan. He mentioned several incidents which led him to the opinion, that the Federal movements in the neighborhood of Culpepper were merely a feint -- intended to direct attention from the serious attempt upon the rebel Capital from another quarter.

abstract: Confederate Vice Pres. Stephens speaks, Georgia, giving his views on war
snippet: Confederate Vice Pres. Stephens speaks, Georgia, giving his views on war
lead_paragraph: Vice-President STEPHENS made a speech at Craswfordvilie, Ga., some weeks since, which we and reported in the Augusta Chronicle. The present war, he said, is emphatically "the people's war." It is the effort of one people to blot another from existence, and it becomes every man in the South to exercise every capacity in aiding the army which is preventing his becoming worse than a serf. He said, frankly, that the Government, while doing all it can, cannot compass as thorough relief for the army as the efforts of communities and individuals.

abstract: The Report of Mr. Secretary CHASE is able in argument and comprehensive in its review of the great resources of the country for the support of the Public Debt, if not in all its recommendations suffciently clear and prac
lead_paragraph: The Report of Mr. Secretary CHASE is able in argument and comprehensive in its review of the great resources of the country for the support of the Public Debt, if not in all its recommendations suffciently clear and practical. Some of these, in respect to the best means of raising Money for the prosecution of the War, and looking to the establishment of a system of voluntary banking under Federal authority, are mere repetitions of his previous Annual Report. He adds, to be sure, to his banking scheme the suggestion of making all local or State Banks which consent to a registered circulation on the pledge of United States stocks at the Department in Washington, Banks of deposit for the Treasury. In doing this he would not repeal the Sub-Treasury system, but simply hold out an inducement for banking under National authority, by the employment of the National stocks as the basis of security. A privilege to this tenor was voted by the present Congress as early as the 5th of August. 1861, before the suspension of specie payments; but, after due consideration. Mr. CHASE declined to avail himself of this clause in the supplemental Loan act of that date, beyond leaving with the Banks the avails of his loans made, in gross, for a short time, and then transferring them in specie to the Sub-Treasury. He never checked to the public creditors or the disbursing officers of the Government directly upon the Banks, and as the provision on the subject was left to his choice or discretion, it was never made part of the machinery of the Treasury. The provision now stands virtually repealed by the suspension of payments in specie.

abstract: editorials speculate on destination
snippet: editorials speculate on destination
lead_paragraph: It has already been announced in all the newspapers, that Gen. BANKS set sail on Thursday, on his long talked of Southern expedition. He takes with him, so it is said, some 20,000 soldiers, more or less, with subsistence stores and war munitions of the lighter kind; but no horses or heavy artillery. Gen. BANKS was about five weeks in New-York, fitting out his expedition. He met with innumerable and unexpected delays; and the interest in his movement, which was very lively when he reached here, almost died out before he got away. The General worked with patient and indefatigable zeal in his enterprise, carefully avoiding all public displays, and keeping the secret of his destination with modest and masterly silence. He has been rewarded with final success in his tedious preparations, and is now, with his prow turned Southward, buffeting the waves of an inhospitable coast, to meet at length, perhaps, when his haven is reached, a more inhospitable reception.
headline: {'main': 'The Expedition of Gen. Banks.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Expedition of Gen. Banks.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: COMMISSIONER IN NEW-ORLEANS.--We copy in  another column from the National Intelligencer a card from Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, in reply to statements made by our New-Orleans correspondent concerning his action as Uni-- ted States Commissioner in New-Orleans. It
lead_paragraph: COMMISSIONER IN NEW-ORLEANS.--We copy in another column from the National Intelligencer a card from Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, in reply to statements made by our New-Orleans correspondent concerning his action as Uni-- ted States Commissioner in New-Orleans. It was stated in our correspondent's letter that a sum of $405,000, which had been seized by Gen. BUTLER while in the hands of the French, Consul, and which, on Mr. JOHNSON's recommendation, was repaid to the Bank of New-Orleans for the French citizens by whom it was claimed, had actually been handed over to agents of the Confederate Government, and disbursed in its service. The implication of the letter was that Mr. JOHNSON had been completely deceived in the matter, and had been made the instrument of replacing this amount of money in the service of the rebellion, from which Gen. BUTLER had rescued it.

abstract: Several of the leading British merchants are now making vigorous efforts to raise a large sum for the relief of the destitute operatives of England. A few days since an informal meeting was held at the British Consulate, and subsequently a Committee was formed for this charitable purpose. On Thursday another meeting was held, but the movement not being sufficiently known, there were only a few gentlemen present, who immediately subscribed $3,000 toward the object. A very large sum, however, will no doubt be subscribed, and it is intended to extend the call for aid to the British residents in every part of this State, if not throughout the country.

abstract: PATSEY MCARTEY was yesterday put on trial for manslaughter in the first degree, in killing MICHAEL RING, in Water-street, in September last. It appeared from the testimony that the prisoner was passing along Water-street, in company with two friends, when he met the deceased and another person, and in passing them a collision occurred, whether intentional or not did not appear. An altercation ensued, ending in a fight, during which RING received a stab in the abdomen, from the effects of which he died the same day. Two policemen, standing near, arrested the friends of the prisonor, but the prisonor himself fled, and in his flight was seen to throw something in the street. He was pursued and captured, and subsequently a pocket-knife, stained with blond, was found in the street, near where the affray occurred. The jury had not returned a verdict at a late hour last evening, and there was little prospect of their agreeing.

abstract: The Liverpool Post has the following:  "In reference to the steamer No. "292," said to have been built as a cruiser for the Confederates, she has bean built by Messrs. LAIRD for JAMES BEASLEY, Esq., for river purposes in China, and is registered in
lead_paragraph: The Liverpool Post has the following: "In reference to the steamer No. "292," said to have been built as a cruiser for the Confederates, she has bean built by Messrs. LAIRD for JAMES BEASLEY, Esq., for river purposes in China, and is registered in his name. Messrs. LAIRD's vessels are numbered as their keels are laid and entered in their books during construction under the said number, whence this is 292. She is called the Defiance, and is a paddle steamer of 140 tons. She will leave the Mersey in a day or two for China."

abstract: A CONTEMPTIBLE REVENGE.--The Grand Jury of Union County, New Jersey, have just indicted the Rev. SYLVESTER ARMSTRONG, of Plainfield, for an alleged misdemeanor in being concerned in a disturbance which took place last Summer between the Union men of New Providence and a nest of Secessionists that infest that neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A CONTEMPTIBLE REVENGE.--The Grand Jury of Union County, New Jersey, have just indicted the Rev. SYLVESTER ARMSTRONG, of Plainfield, for an alleged misdemeanor in being concerned in a disturbance which took place last Summer between the Union men of New Providence and a nest of Secessionists that infest that neighborhood. The Union men had called a meeting to respond to the President's last call for 300,000 men. This meeting the Secessionists determined to break up, and accordingly called another meeting at the same sime, and in the immediate neighborhood of the Union meeting. So violent was the conduct of the "secesh" that the Union men finally became indignant, and taking Mr. ARMSTRONG on their shoulders, carried him to the platform from which CHAUNCEY C. BURR, a notorious Secessionist, was holding forth, from whence he proceeded to deliver a strong Union speech. So atrocious were some of the sentiments uttered during the [???] that a Col. CROMWELL, of Gen. GRANT'S army, who was present, mounted the platform, and drawing a revolver, solemnly declared that he would shoot the first man who should repeat such language, adding that he was paid by the United States to shout rebels. The affair created considerable excitement at the time, and the men whose disloyal schemes were thwarted vowed revenge. This they now imagine they have secured, in the indictment of Mr. ARMSTRONG, through a jury which it is stated was packed by the Sheriff of Union County, who is a well-known sympathizer will their views. It is hardly probable they will venture to press the matter to a trial, than which the Union men could desire nothing better. The same Grand Jury indicted for the so-called [???] Col. CROMWELL, who, however, having left but a few days since for Luka, will not, it is probable, be much disturbed [???]. Mr. ARMSTRONG is very well known in Newark, having formerly been pastor of the Franklin,-Street. M.E. [???] in that city. The editor of a sheet published at Newark, which has been quoted with warm approval at Richmond, resides at New-Providence.

abstract: What the Herald calls "the situation," is not very clear. A force of 110,000 Abolitionists is concentrated near Fredericksburgh. Northern papers tell us that BURNSIDE is waiting only for supplies, and our own papers assure us there is every indication of a great light, which may come off any day. Fredericksburgh, already commanded by the enemy's batteries, ...
lead_paragraph: What the Herald calls "the situation," is not very clear. A force of 110,000 Abolitionists is concentrated near Fredericksburgh. Northern papers tell us that BURNSIDE is waiting only for supplies, and our own papers assure us there is every indication of a great light, which may come off any day. Fredericksburgh, already commanded by the enemy's batteries, will doubtless he shelled, if any resistance to its occupation is made. There will be resistance, but, so long as the river is between the two armies,a general engagement is improbable. However, the occupation of Fredericksburgh is merely a preliminary step in the contemplated grand attack upon Richmond, which will be made in overwhelming force by land and water -- by a column from Fredericksburgh, another from Suffolk, and a fleet in the James.

abstract: United States vs. Cotton, Resin,  most interesting and novel prize question was presented in this case--one that has never before been raised in any Admiralty Court of the United States sitting as a Prize Court. The property libeled was captured on the sounds on the North Carolina coast, and on land at the capture of Newbern, by the naval forces of the United States, under command of Commodore...
lead_paragraph: United States vs. Cotton, Resin, most interesting and novel prize question was presented in this case--one that has never before been raised in any Admiralty Court of the United States sitting as a Prize Court. The property libeled was captured on the sounds on the North Carolina coast, and on land at the capture of Newbern, by the naval forces of the United States, under command of Commodore ROWAN. The cotton had been used in the construction of the rebel fortifications at that place, and in defence of the town. The resin, tar, turpentine, &c., were found collected in Newbern after the place had been occupied by the military and naval forces. It was libeled by the Government as lawful prize of war. A portion of the naval stores, resin, &c., was claimed by a person professing loyalty to the United States. No claim was made to the rest of the property. Application was made by the United States District-Attorney for its condemnation as lawful prize, and Messrs. HENRY and MEREDITH were assigned by the Court to represent the interest of absent parties who might be owners.

abstract: When the track of the railroad between Brunswick and Bath was being graded, in crossing a meadow near the populous portion of the latter city, the "dump" suddenly took on a sinking symptom, and down went the twenty feet fill of gravel, clay, and broken rocks, out of sight, and it was a long, long time before dirt trains could fill the capacious stomach that seemed ready to receive all the solid material that could be turned into it. The difficulty was at length overcome, but all along the side of the sinkage the earth was thrown up, broken into yawning chasms, and the surface was thus elevated above its old watery level. Since that time this ground, thus slightly elevated, has been cultivated, and has yielded enormously of whatever the owner seemed disposed to plant upon it. Some three months ago, by some means unknown to us, the underlying peat took fire, and for weeks, as we had occasion to pass it, we noticed the smoke arising from the smouldering combustion beneath the surface. Rains fell, but the fire burned, and the smoke continued to arise. Monday we had occasion to pass the spot, and though nearly a week's rain had been drenching the ground, and though the surface was whitened with snow, and though pools of water were standing upon the surface in the immediate neighborhood, still the everlasting subterranean fire was still burning, and the smoke arising through the snow. The fact and the attending circumstances are certainly singular. -- Portland (Mc.) Press.

abstract: editorials on plans to redeem defaced postage stamp currency in NYC; editorials on plans to redeem defaced postage stamps currency in NYC
snippet: editorials on plans to redeem defaced postage stamp currency in NYC; editorials on plans to redeem defaced postage stamps currency in NYC
lead_paragraph: We are glad to learn that the redemption of postage stamps will commence at the City Post-office within a few days. A series of rules, in the main just, have been adopted to this end, which we give this morning. We trust that not a day will be lost in carrying out the arrangement, as there are many thousands of postage stamps in private hands in this City, which are at present almost useless. This is just so much withdrawn from the currency of the City. In many instances, too, sums in stamps, varying from one dollar to twenty, are held by poor persons and small traders, who cannot afford to retain them, and yet find difficulty in passing them, as many of them are grievously defaced.

abstract: The eminent success with which this distinguished officer has managed the military affairs intrusted to his care ought not to be lost sight of by the Administration or the people. Under his superintendence, and by his skillful management, the hundreds of thousands of troops that have been forwarded to the Capital have been organized, equipped,...
lead_paragraph: The eminent success with which this distinguished officer has managed the military affairs intrusted to his care ought not to be lost sight of by the Administration or the people. Under his superintendence, and by his skillful management, the hundreds of thousands of troops that have been forwarded to the Capital have been organized, equipped, disciplined and drilled; the raw regiments, fresh from the workshop and the farm, have been marshaled into veteran battalions, many of whose deeds on the field now form a part of the nation's history. The thorough knowledge of the wants of the troops, acquired by a long military experience; the speedy adaptation of methodical arrangement, and its energetic execution, displaying administrative talent of the highest order, have exhibited to the country the formation in a few short months of a well-appointed, drilled and disciplined army, able to contest the palm with the splendid armies that the labor of years has produced in Continental Europe.

abstract: A privatee letter from an American residing in London, who is in a situation to be advised, to his friends in this city, contains the following: He says, after referring to the fact that the Federal Government has not regarded the rebellion as a serious matter, "Why, even now it would be difficult for ...
lead_paragraph: A privatee letter from an American residing in London, who is in a situation to be advised, to his friends in this city, contains the following: He says, after referring to the fact that the Federal Government has not regarded the rebellion as a serious matter, "Why, even now it would be difficult for me to induce a dozen of our so-called great men to believe that the rebels abroad are making greater efforts man ever before. I know beyond peradventure that no less than eighteen iron clad steamers of various kinds and dimensions, are being built in England and France for the Jeff. Davis Government. Some of these vessels are nearly finished and will be launched and abroad doing their work of devastation before the new year.

abstract: We were shown, on yesterday, a Yankee Minie ball picked up on the battle-field of Sharpsburgh, which is divided in three parts. The point and largest piece has a hollow in which fits a pin or plug with a heel-piece or butt the same size as the ball. On the point and next to the main part of the ball, is a thin ring of zinc which fits the hollow of the ball. The intention is that when the ball enters a man'sbody the two pieces leave the main ball and remain in the wound, the zinc causing inflammation. This is said to be the reason so many of our wounded have got the erysipelas.

abstract: Confederate press reports
snippet: Confederate press reports
lead_paragraph: To the General Assembly: I communicate herewith a copy of a letter received on yesterday from Col. HENRY H. FLOYD, commanding the militia of Camden County, informing me that on the 4th day of this month three companies of negroes were landed in St. Mary's, who, after insulting the few ladies remaining there, and taking everything they could lay their hands upon, retired to their gunboats without the slightest molestation. On the same day all the salt-works in the county were destroyed except two, which by this time have capacity to turn out twenty-five or thirty bushels per day. Unless protection is afforded these must soon share the same fate. The people on the coast possess large numbers of cattle, hogs and other stock. The enemy leave their gunboats, kill and carry off stock without opposition. The Colonel asks for an order to call out the militia for three or six months, and says he can muster about thirty to forty. Adjoining counties upon the coast could add to the number enough to make a considerable force, who are well acquainted with all the localities, and could on that account act more effectively against the enemy than the like number of men taken from any other part of the State. It cannot be denied that the State owes it to her citizens, so long as she claims their allegiance, to afford them all the protection in her power.

abstract: Be it enacted by the General Assembly: That the sum of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars be and the same is hereby appropriated from the treasury of the State, for the purpose of removing from the City of Savannah, and providing for the maintenance and support of all indigent white non-combatants for as long a time as may be necessary, at any time when it may be thought prudent by the military authorities of the Confederate States in command at Savannah, to remove said non-combatants in order to the better defence of said city. And the Governor is hereby authorized to draw his warrant on the treasury for said sum, or so much thereof as may be necessary for the purpose aforesaid.

abstract: The latest reliable intelligence we have from Suffolk renders it almost certain that the enemy has recently been heavily reinforced at that point. Parties from there state that the Federal officers do not affect to conceal their purposes, which they declare to be a demonstration from Suffolk, with a view of seizing the railroad, thus cutting the main line between the South and the Confederate capital. We have every assurance, however, that our Government is amply prepared for any contingency in that quarter, and whatever may be the designs of the enemy, they are likely to be thwarted.

abstract: Expectations which are excited only to be disappointed are better calculated to dispirit the strongest minds than the sternest realties unrelieved by a ray of hope. The Yankee politicians have contrived from the beginning alternately to elevate and depress the Southern mind, by affecting to dread foreign intervention for the South, an idea which has been dispelled by every wind from the East almost as soon as it was raised.
lead_paragraph: Expectations which are excited only to be disappointed are better calculated to dispirit the strongest minds than the sternest realties unrelieved by a ray of hope. The Yankee politicians have contrived from the beginning alternately to elevate and depress the Southern mind, by affecting to dread foreign intervention for the South, an idea which has been dispelled by every wind from the East almost as soon as it was raised. We have steadily endeavored to put the community on their guard against this delusion. In the beginning, it was reasonable to suppose that Europe, and especially England, having such manifest and powerful interests in the division of the old Union, would interpose in our behalf. But from the moment that the Queen and Parliament distinctly announced their position of neutrality, we have felt satisfied that the South had nothing to hope from that quarter, and every official development since has been such as to strengthen that conviction.

abstract: The annual Fair and Festival of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association, commenced in the Lecture Room of the Academy of Music on Friday afternoon, and was numerously attended. The schools of the Association are located in Nelson and Concord-streets, and the "Home" for the accommodation of infants is situated in Butler-street, near Flatbush-avenue.
lead_paragraph: The annual Fair and Festival of the Brooklyn Industrial School Association, commenced in the Lecture Room of the Academy of Music on Friday afternoon, and was numerously attended. The schools of the Association are located in Nelson and Concord-streets, and the "Home" for the accommodation of infants is situated in Butler-street, near Flatbush-avenue. Some sixty children are now taken care of at the Home, and about 150 are regular attendants of the day schools. Two hundred and four children were present at the Fair -- all uniformly and neatly dressed, and seated upon a raised platform at the end of the room. They sang a number of songs and recited several pieces during the evening; and altogether deported themselves in a manner which reflects the highest credit upon their teachers and the ladies under whose supervision the schools are so ably conducted. The Institution is in charge of a Board of Managers, consisting of fifty ladies, from thirty-four churches of the city, representing all Protestant denominations. Its sphere of benevolent effort is, therefore, neither local or sectarian. The managers are aided by an Advisory Committee, composed of well known and influential citizens. The officers are: Mrs. Fisher Howe, First Directress; Mrs. Jesse C. Smith, Second Directress; Mrs. Horatio W. Shipman, Recording Secretary; Mrs. Ellen Thurston, Treasurer.

abstract: The bark Harriet Spaulding, Capt. PEABODY, from New-York for Havre, was captured and burned Nov. 19, in latitude 41  13', longitude 66  16', by the pirate Alabama. abstract: The Military Governor of the State of Louisiana appointed an election on Wednesday last for two members of Congress for New-Orleans. As the greater part of the inhabitants of the city have already taken the oath of allegiance ...
lead_paragraph: The Military Governor of the State of Louisiana appointed an election on Wednesday last for two members of Congress for New-Orleans. As the greater part of the inhabitants of the city have already taken the oath of allegiance to the United States Government, we have no doubt that the election was participated in by a majority of the voters, and that two earnest, unconditional Union men will soon take their seats in Congress as representatives of the first commercial city of the South. This election, coupled with the appointment of a Federal Judge and Marshal for the District, which, it is understood, will speedily be made, will practically complete the restoration of New-Orleans.

abstract: Capt. FITZHUGH arrived at the Libby Prison, from Matthews County, yesterday, in charge of five Abolition prisoners, including Second Lieut. F.M. JOHNSON, of the Eleventh Maine Regiment, who was captured while on a piratical incursion in Mathews County, for the purpose of destroying the salt works in that county. It is said that sometimes as many as five hundred Yankees start on these predatory excursions, destroying not only salt works but everything that comes in their way. The five Abilitionists that arrived yesterday were captured by a ruse de guerre. Capt. FITZHUGH saw a company of Yankees approaching, and having only eleven men, contrived so to dispose of them in a skirt of woods that the foe was deceived, and on seeing them immediately turned and fled. A charge was made, and five of the fugacious Lincolnites were bagged.

abstract: By the arrival last evening of the steamship Ocean Queen, we have advices from the Isthmus of Panama to the 28th ult., and later news from Central and South America. The Ocean Queen brought upwards of $700,000 in treasure. A severe gale, accompanied by a heavy sea, commenced at Aspinwall at 2 A.M. on Saturday, Nov. ...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival last evening of the steamship Ocean Queen, we have advices from the Isthmus of Panama to the 28th ult., and later news from Central and South America. The Ocean Queen brought upwards of $700,000 in treasure. A severe gale, accompanied by a heavy sea, commenced at Aspinwall at 2 A.M. on Saturday, Nov. 22d, doing great damage to the shipping, wharves, &c. About daylight the Royal Mail Steamship Company's Steamship Avon, lying at the Middle Wharf, tore down part of the wharf, dragged her anchors, parted her hawsers, and went on shore. About the same time, the British brig Bolivar, lying at the same wharf, parted her moorings and struck the beach. Neither of them could be got off. The Avon took in a million of dollars in specie the evening previous, but it had all been recovered after the gale abated. The United States brig Bainbridge dragged her anchors to within a few fathoms of the reef. Her guns, spars, stores, &c., were all thrown overboard, and on Sunday her officers and crew abandoned her; but as she still held on, they took possession of her again on Tuesday. Other vessels were also seriously damaged. The gale was accompanied by very heavy rain. which caused the waters in the interior to rise so as to overflow the railroad track at different places for miles; at some points it was ten feet above the track. There was no communication with Panama by train from Saturday evening until Thursday evening, when the passengers from England for South America crossed. The passengers from San Francisco for New-York arrived at Panama Tuesday morning, but could not cross until Friday morning. The passengers and mails from South America for England were left behind at Panama, as they were not able to cross in time for the steamer from Aspinwall. Thirty-four inches of water had fallen at Aspinwall from the 1st to the 28th of November. Our correspondence contains details of news from Central and South America, but it presents no features of special importance.

abstract: The Key West New Era of Nov. 15, publishes a remarkable narrative furnished it by MARK WOOD and ALFRED WILSON, of the Twenty-first Ohio Regiment, who recently arrived at that place in the gunboat Stars and Stripes, having effected their escape from ...
lead_paragraph: The Key West New Era of Nov. 15, publishes a remarkable narrative furnished it by MARK WOOD and ALFRED WILSON, of the Twenty-first Ohio Regiment, who recently arrived at that place in the gunboat Stars and Stripes, having effected their escape from the rebel States, where they were confined as prisoners, and under sentence of death. They were two of a party of twenty, whom Gen. MITCHEL sent from Huntsville on April 7, on special service. They were disguised in citizens' clothes, and succeeded in making their way to Chattanooga. There they took the cars for Marietta, Georgia, one ANDREWS, a Kentuckian, and an exceedingly daring fellow, acting as guide and leader. After speaking of their arrival at Marietta, the narrative proceeds:

abstract: Editorial on his biography published in French journal; Editorial on biography of Butler published in French journal
snippet: Editorial on his biography published in French journal; Editorial on biography of Butler published in French journal
lead_paragraph: The Courrier du Dimanche (a French journal) has a very able, lively and astoundingly accurate biography of the "Butcher BUTLER," which we would be supremely happy to copy entire into our columns, were they not lumbered up with news from the army and the reports of Departments. The Courrier justly says that "BUTLER is the son of an Alsatian emigrant, by trade a butcher." "He did not," says the Courrier truly, "follow the law on the same principle that MCCLELLAN became a railway director -- that is to say, from a dislike to the military profession during a time of peace." "In his profession he acquired not the slightest distinction, but was known by the soubriquet of Picayune BUTLER" -- a nickname which, the Courrier neatly translates by the phrase "that worth-a-sous BUTLER." The epithet, says M. XAVIER EYMA, the accomplished writer of the biography in the Courrier, originated in this way: "Mr. BUTLER had made himself the redresser of grievances of workmen against their masters, suggesting grievances where none existed. For this 'assistance' the working men clubbed together, and paid him a certain weekly sum, a picayune salary -- a revenue of centimes as we would say on this (French) side of the Atlantic." Than which statement of our able and astute Gallic cotemporary, it would be impossible to find anything more rigidly exact and truthful. "During the last Presidential election," says the Courrier, with an astonishing knowledge of our political lingo and history:

abstract: Notwithstanding the high price which every article of produce commands, the markets and produce stores indicate anything else than a scarcity. There is apparently an abundance of the necessaries of life, and the most reasonable cause we have heard assigned for the exorbitant prices asked and obtained is the superabundance of money.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the high price which every article of produce commands, the markets and produce stores indicate anything else than a scarcity. There is apparently an abundance of the necessaries of life, and the most reasonable cause we have heard assigned for the exorbitant prices asked and obtained is the superabundance of money. We yesterday took the pains to ascertain the ruling rates, and present the following quotations: Flour -- Superfine, $20@$21; extra, $21@$22; family, $23@$25, according to the reputation of the brand. The lower grades of Flour may be quoted at an average of about $18; the market rather dull, with manifest tendency to depreciation. Stock heavy and increasing.

abstract: Passengers who came down by the Central train last evening report that a sharp skirmish occurred in the vicinity of Manassas on Monday last, between our own and a body of Yankee cavalry, in which the enemy lost six killed and fourteen prisoners. Our loss in the affair was one killed, five wounded and two missing. It seems that the Yankees, on a reconnoitering expedition, had advanced from Centreville, and were met near Bull Run, when a fight, lasting some twenty minutes, immediately ensued. Our cavalry then charged, when the enemy fled, closely pursued until within sight of Centreville.

abstract: Success to the Pacific Railroad, or it rather should be called the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad, for it certainly will be of those two oceans the connection most useful and vital to the Union. All right-minded men here desire the speedy consumma- ...
lead_paragraph: Success to the Pacific Railroad, or it rather should be called the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad, for it certainly will be of those two oceans the connection most useful and vital to the Union. All right-minded men here desire the speedy consummation of so magnificent and beneficent an enterprise. With its accomplishment the isolation of this Territory will be destroyed. Utah, for commercial purposes, will then be practically in the centre of the nation, where she can share equally in the benefits arising from the traffic of the two slopes. The chief men of Mormondom appear to be warmly in favor of the undertaking. It is well known that BRIGHAM did a good thing in helping the telegraph through. If the aspect of the stars continue favorable, he will doubtless do as much in behalf of the railroad. And then, as there is now a talk of a territorial telegraph intersecting the main line, there will he all sorts of conjectures and speculations as to a territorial railroad; and indeed there may one day be a cross railroad uniting the gold fields of Salmon River with those of the Colorado.

abstract: We find the following information in the Louisiana Democrat, of the 12th inst.: "A telegraphic dispatch dated the 5th, from Gen. MOUTON, commanding our forces at Berwick's Bay, states that the enemy's gunboats, four in number, had returned to the Bay, and that all was quiet. One of the gunboats was considerably injured by the Cotton. Gen. TAYLOR, telegraphing from PALPREY's plantation, Nov. 27, says that all is quiet there, and that all apprehensions of danger from an attack or invasion of the enemy above that point are groundless."

abstract: A stated session of the New York Sanitary Association was held on Thursday evening at the Cooper Institute, when the proceedings were of an unusually interesting character. In addition to the annual election of officers, an able lecture was ...
lead_paragraph: A stated session of the New York Sanitary Association was held on Thursday evening at the Cooper Institute, when the proceedings were of an unusually interesting character. In addition to the annual election of officers, an able lecture was delivered by Mr. HYSLOP upon a subject of the utmost importance to the whole human race -- a subject affecting the very vital principles of health -- fresh air -in other words, ventilation. ROBERT H. MCCURDY, Esq., in the Chair.

abstract: A MELANCHOLY CASE OF SUICIDE IN THE TOMBS. --Yesterday morning, Mr. OSGOOD W. GOULD, aged 33 years, committed suicide. The deceased was a messenger, employed by the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, and on Friday last he was arrested upon the charge of embezzling letters, which he had been sent to deposit in the Post-office.
lead_paragraph: A MELANCHOLY CASE OF SUICIDE IN THE TOMBS. --Yesterday morning, Mr. OSGOOD W. GOULD, aged 33 years, committed suicide. The deceased was a messenger, employed by the Commissioners of Charities and Correction, and on Friday last he was arrested upon the charge of embezzling letters, which he had been sent to deposit in the Post-office. Mr. GOULD was a man of considerable ability. In the Mexican War he lost an arm, and subsequently became considerably reduced in circumstances. Soon after coming to this City he applied to the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for aid, whereupon he was admitted to the Almshouse. Here, by his diligence and honesty, he soon gained the confidence of the officials, and they appointed him a messenger, which position be held for a number of years. Among his other duties, was that of taking letters to and from the Post-office. On Thursday last he was suspected of having retained letters committed to his care, and Officer GILMORE took him into custody. On Friday he had an examination, and was on the same day sent to the Tombs by the United States authorities. While on his way thither, in charge of a Deputy Marshal, he was imprudently allowed to enter a drug-store. Upon his arrival at the Tombs, Mr. SUTTON, the Warden of the prison, at the request of the prisoner put him into a cell alone, not suspecting that the latter intended to make any attempt to take hiss own life. Yesterday morning however, when an officer came to his cell, ho was found in a State of stupor. An examination showed that he was poisoned, and was sinking [???]. Upon his person were found a few small articles, and about half an ounce of gum opium. The poison was procured at a drug store in Pearl-street, on the pretence that it was necessary to deaden the pain in the stump of his amputated arm. GOULD died at about 11 o'clock, despite all the efforts used to counteract the effects of the deadly narcotic. Remorse and shame at the situation in which he found himself, after all the kindness which the Commissioners had extended to him, are the only reasons which can be given for the commission of the suicide. Dr. [???] made a post mortem examination of the body last evening, and found traces of the poisonous drug in the stomach. Coroner WILDEY will hold an inquest upon the body to-day.

abstract: On the 20th of July last the camp for paroled prisoners of war was established at Annapolis, Md. Up to the present time thirty thousand of our soldiers, direct from the military prisons of the South, have arrived in this camp--many of them in a pitable condition--having scant clothing, shattered constitutions, debilitated by fatigue, wounded, and suffering ...
lead_paragraph: On the 20th of July last the camp for paroled prisoners of war was established at Annapolis, Md. Up to the present time thirty thousand of our soldiers, direct from the military prisons of the South, have arrived in this camp--many of them in a pitable condition--having scant clothing, shattered constitutions, debilitated by fatigue, wounded, and suffering from diseases incidental to the parts they have come from, and reeking with the filth of Southern dungeons. The Government has supplied them with clothing and comfortable quarters, yet disease has carried a large mortality amongst them, and an unusual proportion are inmates of the hospital and confined to quarters.

abstract: Great as is the public anxiety to learn some thing with reference to the probabilities of a collision between our own and the enemy's forces it seems almost impossible to gather a single item of interest from the present seat of war. We are told, in answer to inquiries from parties coming from the neighborhood of Fredericksburgh, that all is quiet, and that ...
lead_paragraph: Great as is the public anxiety to learn some thing with reference to the probabilities of a collision between our own and the enemy's forces it seems almost impossible to gather a single item of interest from the present seat of war. We are told, in answer to inquiries from parties coming from the neighborhood of Fredericksburgh, that all is quiet, and that notwithstanding the boasts of Northern papers that BURNSIDE would lead the Yankee hosts to Richmond in less than ten days, his columns are still quartered on the Northern bank of the Rappahannock, without an apparent effort to force its passage. Unless the pressure of the radicals should urge him to advance, it is likely that his "on to Richmond" march will not be resumed until the enemy's force on the south side of James River are ready to move upon Petersburgh or Weldon. His theory no doubt is that a simultaneous attack from both points would render the capture of the city a feat easy of accomplishment.

abstract: editorial alleges Italians planned to assassinate him because of his control of Rome
snippet: editorial alleges Italians planned to assassinate him because of his control of Rome
lead_paragraph: According to the late news from Paris, a serious plot against the life of LOUIS NAPOLEON has been discovered. No less than one hundred and twenty persons, it is alleged, mostly Italians, had banded themselves together to take their stations along a new Boulevard about to be opened by the Emperor, and assail him with bombs, one after the other, as he passed, until he should certainly be slain. The story was narrated by our Paris correspondent yesterday, and is also given with entire positiveness in the Paris correspondence of the London Star, while a similar report in certain German States has created no little uneasiness among the bankers and stock operators. The plot, according to our Paris correspondent, was frustrated by its being revealed to the French Government by an American Captain. The opening of the Boulevard, for which the Emperor had made the grandest preparations, was postponed; the conspirators were placed under arrest, and the life of the Third NAPOLEON is once more, at least temporarily, safe. It is a matter of prime necessity with despots to keep from the people all knowledge of such affairs. Especially would this necessity be felt in France, where revolutions and conspiracies are consecrated, and the spirit of assassination exists as an inherited humor in the blood.

lead_paragraph: The following form of bond and guarantee of protection has been adopted by our authorities. The bond will be executed before Provost Judge FITCH, at his office on High-street. The guarantee of protection is given only to those who are "true and steadfast citizens of the United States," and cannot be expected by the enemies of the Government. No rebel need apply henceforth to a Government whose laws and Constitution he [???] and tries to overthrow, for protection from prospective injuries, or compensation for injuries done. The Government must ignore the existence of those who have outlawed themselves. All citizens who expect to avail themselves of the benefits of the guarantee, will do well to accept the offer made them by the authorities. Here is the form of the bond and guarantee:

abstract: Editorial on barbarism by both sides
snippet: Editorial on barbarism by both sides
lead_paragraph: Our readers know well that we have never justified the act of Gen. McNEIL in Missouri, in shooting the ten guerrillas; and we are not at all surprised that that act should have excited a good deal of indignant comment on the other side of the water. But, when it comes to speaking of the South as "a brave and orderly people," and of our armies as "the hordes of a barbarous invader," we must insist that the experiment upon public credulity is somewhat extreme. We certainly do not concede that the South is any less barbarous than ourselves; and if this one act on the part of supporters of our cause proves that we are barbarians, a statement of the Richmond Whig as to the hanging of five prisoners taken by them, in retaliation for the death of one of their men in Kentucky, proves that they are equally so; that is, if the same rule is to be applied to both cases.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  In the September number of the National Quar-- terly Review, may be found a most malicious and injurious article of some length, purporting to be a review of some recent publications, and entitled ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: In the September number of the National Quar-- terly Review, may be found a most malicious and injurious article of some length, purporting to be a review of some recent publications, and entitled "Quackery of Insurance Companies." The writer endeavors to conceal the evident malice with which his article overflows, by uttering some truisms, which he would gladly avoid acknowledging were they not among the recognized truths of the world, so much do they militate against all that he says afterward, but which he would not dare to contradict. He acknowledges that "none capable of reasoning can deny that insurance companies have done much good; but have they not," he goes on to say, "done as much or more harm?" He says, too, "the principle of insurance is fair and just, and in practice it has saved thousands from ruin and misery. It is only the abuse of it that does mischief, and this is all that we desire to speak against. In short, we have as much faith in legitimate insurance, in its effect on trade and commerce, as we have in medical skill in its effect on human health and longevity; but we bold that quackery is as bad in one case as in the other. We believe that no city in the world, of equal population, can muster so large a number of ordinary quacks as New-York, but they are far outnumbered by the insurance quacks."

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT AT THE RIDGEWOOD WATERWORKS.--Several of the soldiers encamped on the Union Race Course visited the engine-house of the water-works at Ridgewood, on Friday, and, in examining the large engines, one of the men approached so near to the walking-beam that in its descent it struck his head, and smashed it nearly flat, Death was instantaneous, of course.
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT AT THE RIDGEWOOD WATERWORKS.--Several of the soldiers encamped on the Union Race Course visited the engine-house of the water-works at Ridgewood, on Friday, and, in examining the large engines, one of the men approached so near to the walking-beam that in its descent it struck his head, and smashed it nearly flat, Death was instantaneous, of course. The deceased belonged to one of the New-England regiments. His name was not ascertained.

abstract: The correspondence between the State Department and the American Representatives abroad has reached us in advance of its submission to Congress. The publication is of the highest importance. It tells in the most authentic form the story of our intercourse with foreign nations during the ...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between the State Department and the American Representatives abroad has reached us in advance of its submission to Congress. The publication is of the highest importance. It tells in the most authentic form the story of our intercourse with foreign nations during the most difficult stage of the National career; how faithfully and ably the justice and progress of our cause have been presented to the Governments of Europe, and why the various difficulties necessarily incident to a contest such as ours have been prevented from becoming the provocations of an external war by the conciliatory weapons of diplomacy. It will be seen that the labors of Secretary SEWARD have been as heavy as they have been successful; and have embraced the discussion of a large number of questions, the chief of which is evidently the Relations of Europe to the War.

abstract: SIR: Following up the plan suggested in my dispatch No. 243, I asked an interview with Lord RUSSELL. He gave it to me yesterday. The Cabinet meeting appointed for that time had been postponed until to-day, which will yet be in season for the departure of Lord LYONS, who goes in the Scotia to-morrow. My surmise as to the connection between the two events proved correct.

abstract: On Saturday last Admiral GREGORY, of the United States Navy, presented himself at the office of the U.S. Marshal MURRAY, accompanied by tall, well built, dark complexioned, somewhat repulsive featured, but very polite gentleman, whom he introduced to the Marshal as JOE C. RICH, who claimed to be a Captain in the Confederate Army, and desired a pass into the land of secessia.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday last Admiral GREGORY, of the United States Navy, presented himself at the office of the U.S. Marshal MURRAY, accompanied by tall, well built, dark complexioned, somewhat repulsive featured, but very polite gentleman, whom he introduced to the Marshal as JOE C. RICH, who claimed to be a Captain in the Confederate Army, and desired a pass into the land of secessia. The gentleman wore an overcoat which the Admiral, without saying "by your leave, Sir," unbottoned, and displayed to the Marshal's gaze the uniform of a Confederate Captain as the best proof, in the absence of his commission, of the genuineness of his friend's claim. Admiral GREGORY then went on to state that he found himself unwittingly placed in a very unpleasant and delicate position with regard to Capt. RICH, and he thought his duty to the Government demanded that he should lay the case before the U.S. Marshal, and leave him to deal with it as he should think best, or as he might be instructed by the Government. The facts were these: At the breaking out of the rebellion, Capt. RICH was a Captain of Marines in the United States Navy and was stationed on board the 74 gun ship Pennsylvania at the Gosport Navy Yard, Norfolk, Va. He had for several years previous to that been an intimate friend of Admiral Gregory who, when he was stationed on the coast of Africa, appointed him one of his staff officers. Among the many resignations of officers in the United States Navy, at the commencement of the rebellion, he did not recollect of seeing Capt. Rich's name, but the Captain now informed him that his resignation was tendered in due form, but had probably been burnt up with the Pennsylvania which was soon after destroyed by the rebels at the time of the burning of the Gosport Navy Yard. The Admiral said he had never been able to ascertain what had become of his friend, Capt. Rich, and had supposed him long since dead, until about two months ago. when to his surprise, the Captain called upon him here in New-York and stated that he was a Captain in the Confederate Army, had been taken prisoner at the battle of Antietam, carried to Fortress Monroe to be exchanged, and that while there he received a letter from his father, who is a farmer in New Hampshire, informing him that his mother lay at the point of death, and imploring him, her only son, to hasten home that she might look upon his face once again ere she passed into eternity. On representing these facts to the government officers at Fortress Monroe, he was permitted to come North on his parole, and was then on his way to New Hampshire.

lead_paragraph: Saturday last will prove an eventful day in the history of our iron-clad navy. The Whitney battery, Keokuk, and the Ericsson batteries Catskill and Nantucket (not Maul as reported) were launched-- the first two here and the latter at Boston; the Lehigh was reported "ready for launching preparations," and the speed of the Weehawken, another Ericsson battery, was tried in Jersey City, her engines and machinery having been previously reported in working order.

abstract: Monsieur Tonson has come again. ALECK STEPHENS, as our readers saw on Saturday, has turned up with another speech--this time at the lively hamlet of Crawfordville, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Monsieur Tonson has come again. ALECK STEPHENS, as our readers saw on Saturday, has turned up with another speech--this time at the lively hamlet of Crawfordville, Ga. We can hardly recognize him. He looks the very Knight of the Rueful Countenance. Assuredly some great grief has overtaken him. Some twenty months ago ALECK was radiant with hope. "If we are true to ourselves, our destiny and our high mission," he exclaimed in his memorable speech of adhesion to the Montgomery Constitution, "Slavery must become the controlling power of the continent." He predicted that "the Border States will be compelled to join their fortunes to this principle," and pronounced it probable that "all the great States of the Southwest shall gravitate this way." His speech, some four months afterwards, when on his mission from the Confederate Congress for war-funds, though more subdued in some respects, yet abounded with confidence. He declared that "cotton is the tremendous lever by which we can work out our destiny under Providence," and vouched that "one thing is certain -- in some way or other the blockade will be obliged to be raised, or there will be revolution in Europe." A change has come over the spirit of Aleck's dream. In the present effusion there is not a promise, nor a prediction, nor a hopeful word. From one end to the other, it is but one strain of lamentation, deprecation, and desperation.

lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a selection from the mass of diplomatic correspondence sent in to Congress by the Secretary of State. So rapid is the progress of events in this war, that incidents a year old lose much of their interest, and very many of the questions discussed in Mr. SEWARD's letters have already passed beyond the domain of public curiosity. Many of them, however, throw considerable light on the motives of various movements of our Government, and supply an interpretation of its action which the public will be glad to receive. This feature of the correspondence applies especially to what has been done, and left undone, on the subject of Slavery.

abstract: Nothing could be more disgraceful to our arms than the capture of the brigade of troops in Tennessee, reported this morning -- if the facts be as given. The brigade was composed of three infantry regiments, a detachment of cavalry and a battery of artillery, and it surrendered to a rebel force of about equal strength, after a fight in which it suffered the small loss of between fifty and sixty killed and wounded. The telegraph says that our forces were surprised. This may take away a portion of the disgrace from the privates, but only to put tenfold more dishonor upon the officers. One of the most intrepid Generals of the first French Revolution said: "A surprise is more dishonorable than a defeat. The bravest man may be beaten, but whosoever allows himself to be surprised, is unworthy to remain officer." We trust the case will be quickly investigated, and, if found true, that the guilty parties will, as soon as exchanged, be subjected to the most condign and inexorable punishment. Even this, however, will be a poor enough palliation for these repeated surprises and surrenders -- not a few of which have taken place in Tennessee.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S opera of "Dinorah" was given here last evening to a house that might have been better in point of numbers, and warmer in point of comfort. The performance was an average one; the stage direction was anything but good. In the first act, an effigy of the Virgin persisted in toppling over; in the second, the bridge, Instead of breaking with the weight of Dinorah, caved in on its...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MEYERBEER'S opera of "Dinorah" was given here last evening to a house that might have been better in point of numbers, and warmer in point of comfort. The performance was an average one; the stage direction was anything but good. In the first act, an effigy of the Virgin persisted in toppling over; in the second, the bridge, Instead of breaking with the weight of Dinorah, caved in on its own private account, and compelled the heroine to commit a deliberate act of filo de se. These things are inexcusable in a well regulated establishment.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains the report of the Secretary of the Treasury in full. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES bas a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and marketreports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Editorial on delays in paying soldiers
snippet: Editorial on delays in paying soldiers
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a number of petitions in favor of a general Bankrupt law were presented. A memorial from Gov. MORTON, of Indiana, praying for an increase of soldiers' pay, was referred to the Military Committee. Mr. HALE gave notice of a bill to abolish the grade of medical officers in the navy. A resolution making inquiries regarding the number and ranks of Aid-de-Camps, was adopted. The Secretary of War was instructed to report to the Senate the number of Major and Brigadier-Generals now in the service. The Military Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for the more effectual suppression of the rebellion, and securing tranquillity in the State of Maryland. The call upon the Secretary of War for the correspondence relating to the Army of the Potomac was extended so as to embrace all its operations. The resolution relating to the arrest of certain citizens of Delaware, was called up and debated, but not disposed of. The Bankrupt act was taken up as the special order, but was informally laid aside. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, offered a joint resolution proposing certain amendments to the Constitution, to alter the mode of electing the President and Vice-President. It was ordered to be printed. The Bankrupt bill was then again taken up, and made the special order for Thursday, the 18th inst. The Senate spent the remainder of the session with closed doors.

WILLIAM STELLFAX, a private in Company C, Forty-ninth Massachusetts Volunteers, was shot dead; S.H. TAYLOR, Company I, Twenty-fourth Maine Volunteers, seriously wounded, and a hotel kept by a German named SCHELLEIN burned to the ground. The difficulty arose between SCHELLEIN and STELLFAX, and the members of the Forty-ninth revenged themselves...
lead_paragraph: A serious disturbance occurred among the soldiery encamped near East New-York, on Sunday evening last. WILLIAM STELLFAX, a private in Company C, Forty-ninth Massachusetts Volunteers, was shot dead; S.H. TAYLOR, Company I, Twenty-fourth Maine Volunteers, seriously wounded, and a hotel kept by a German named SCHELLEIN burned to the ground. The difficulty arose between SCHELLEIN and STELLFAX, and the members of the Forty-ninth revenged themselves by burning SCHELLEIN's house. SCHELLEIN is supposed to have committed the homicide. He made his escape, and has not yet been arrested.

abstract: Editorial lists Union's real complaints against British attitudes in war
snippet: Editorial lists Union's real complaints against British attitudes in war
lead_paragraph: Now that it is settled that magnificent contributions of food will soon be sent from our shores toward the relief of the British operatives, Englishmen can afford to make a little effort to understand the real state of American feeling toward them and their Government. There is a great deal of misapprehension on the other side of the water in regard to this; and it has had the effect of causing multitudes of well-meaning men to think us extravagantly exacting and unreasonable.

Mr. HALSTEAD shows quite clearly that the letters of KEARNEY were not mere "soliloquies," as contended by Mr. PARKER, but were intended for such use as his friends chose to make of them. He also asserts that Gen. KEARNEY's widow advised the publication of all her late husband's letters, and proceeds:

abstract: -- The bill which had been introduced into Congress by Mr. STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, to indemnify the President and others for semi-military arrests and the suspension of the habeas corpus, was very suddenly passed yesterday afternoon, in the House, by a vote of two to one. It now remains to be acted upon by the Senate. Some such bill should certainly be adopted, and we have no doubt that the people will justify its passage. They are well convinced of the substantial honesty of purpose and patriotism of the President, and of most of his subordinates, and of the substantial necessity of the great body of these arrests. But it cannot be denied that there have been instances in which that honesty has been imposed upon, where designing, dishonest men have taken advantage of public necessity, and of the crowded state of public business, and have wrought great injustice to individuals and the public.

abstract: Postmaster WAKEMAN corrects the statement that the lamp-post letter boxes have become insecure places of deposit, in consequence of frequent robberies. It is positively denied that any such robbery has taken place since these boxes were first established. Occasionally, by accident, a box has been broken by the carelessness of a driver of an omnibus or other vehicle; but, by an arrangement made by the Postmaster, the fact is immediately made known to the Post-office authorities, and the police takes charge of the box until the damage is repaired. The letters are taken from the boxes five times each day.

abstract: SUICIDE. -- At an early hour yesterday morning a woman, named Ann DUANE, aged about 22 years, was found dead in her bed at the house of SARAH QUAILE, No. 286 Mulberry-street, under the following circumstances: On Saturday evening the deceased came to the house above named, and stated to Mrs. QUAILE that she was in a destitute condition, and desired lodging for the night. She said that her husband had died but two weeks before, and that on account of her inability to pay the rent of the premises they had occupied, she had just been turned into the street. Mrs. QUAILE was an acquaintance of the deceased, and from her appearance she knew that the latter was very ill, although she denied it when questioned, and said she would be all right in the morning. Her hospitable friend did what she could for her during the fore part of the night, but in the morning she was found a corpse. A post-mortem examination made by Dr. BOUTON, of the Coroner's Office, revealed the fact that death was caused by arsenic. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest upon the body, and the jury rendered a verdict that death was the result of poison administered by herself.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE. -- At an early hour yesterday morning a woman, named Ann DUANE, aged about 22 years, was found dead in her bed at the house of SARAH QUAILE, No. 286 Mulberry-street, under the following circumstances: On Saturday evening the deceased came to the house above named, and stated to Mrs. QUAILE that she was in a destitute condition, and desired lodging for the night. She said that her husband had died but two weeks before, and that on account of her inability to pay the rent of the premises they had occupied, she had just been turned into the street. Mrs. QUAILE was an acquaintance of the deceased, and from her appearance she knew that the latter was very ill, although she denied it when questioned, and said she would be all right in the morning. Her hospitable friend did what she could for her during the fore part of the night, but in the morning she was found a corpse. A post-mortem examination made by Dr. BOUTON, of the Coroner's Office, revealed the fact that death was caused by arsenic. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest upon the body, and the jury rendered a verdict that death was the result of poison administered by herself.
