abstract: --PROMPTITUDE VS. MAGNITUDE. -- We doubt very much whether either the soldiers, or anybody else, will be very grateful to those gentlemen in Congress who are introducing bills and making speeches ostensibly with the aim of increasing the soldiers' pay. There has been no complaint that we have heard of, from any section of the army, that the present pay is insufficient; but there have been very great complaints that the men could not possibly obtain promptly and regularly the sums which really are their due. It is not long ago that the amount due the troops was stated in a Washington dispatch at $60,000,000; and though it has been greatly lessened since that time, it is yet too large. There are still many regiments which have not seen a greenback or a postal of any denomination, for months. We know of one New-York City Regiment, now under BURNSIDE, which has been in nearly every battle of the war -- whose twice filled ranks have been thrice reduced by battle to a few hundred men, and whose indomitable valor has honored the cause for which they fought; and yet these men, this shattered remnant of a regiment which, on a fine Sunday afternoon, eighteen months ago, marched down Broadway amid the plaudits of tens of thousands of citizens, has not received a cent of pay for five months; and we know that the families of many of them in this City are actually reduced to the greatest straits in this cold weather on account of this culpable dilatoriness of the Government. What these men, and what all our soldiers want, is not that their nominal pay be increased a dollar or two a month, but that they may be enabled to obtain promptly every month the sum that was promised them on enlistment.
lead_paragraph: --PROMPTITUDE VS. What these men, and what all our soldiers want, is not that their nominal pay be increased a dollar or two a month, but that they may be enabled to obtain promptly every month the sum that was promised them on enlistment.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of War, in answer to a resolution passed last week, stating that he had no information regarding the sale of free men into Slavery by the rebels.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of War, in answer to a resolution passed last week, stating that he had no information regarding the sale of free men into Slavery by the rebels. Protests against the action of the Advisory Board of the Navy were presented. A bill was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations for the relief of the owners of the French vessel Jules et Marie. A bill to increase the bonds of the Superintendent of Printing was reported. Mr. HALE introduced his bill to abolish the grade of medical officers. It was referred to the Military Committee. The resolution offered by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, relative to arbitrary arrests of citizens of Delaware, was taken up, and occupied attention until the adjournment -- the debate ranging over the whole subject of arrests and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus. The subject was not disposed of.

abstract: Coroner NORRIS commenced an investigation yesterday into the circumstances attending the death of WILLIAM STELFAX, a member of Company E, Forty-ninth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, who was killed by some persons not yet identified, on Sunday evening last, in front of the lager-bier saloon of Mr. GEO. SCHEILLEIN, at East New-York. A jury was impanneled, and after viewing the body at the Military Hospital, proceeded to Altenbrand's Hotel, where the examination was held. The evidence, as far as taken, is very conflicting. The examination was adjourned until this evening at 5 o'clock.

abstract: We are  more than compensated this morning, in a National point of view, for the defeat which our arms suffered at Hartsville, Tenn., by the news of the great and decisive victory just achieved by Gen. BLUNT in Northwestern Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: We are more than compensated this morning, in a National point of view, for the defeat which our arms suffered at Hartsville, Tenn., by the news of the great and decisive victory just achieved by Gen. BLUNT in Northwestern Arkansas. The battle was fought last Sunday, between some six or eight thousand Union soldiers, and a vastly greater force of rebels -- including all their troops west of the Mississippi, and their Indian allies; and it raged from morning till night, when the enemy were driven over those desolate Boston hills which thrice before have been pressed by their skedaddling footsteps. It is admitted that our force was decimated, and we may well believe, from the character of the troops engaged on our side, and from our advantage in artillery, that the rebel army was even more than decimated.

abstract: On Monday night an important and influential meeting of clergymen was held in the Cooper Institute, for the purpose of consulting what should be done toward sustaining the President in carrying out his Proclamation of Freedom. About forty of the most prominent ministers of all denominations were present -- Dr. FERRIS, Chancellor of the University, in the Chair. After some time spent in discussing the object of the meeting, Dr. ASA D. SMITH presented a resolution declaring that, as Slavery was the main cause and support of the present rebellion and war, there could be no permanent peace until it was abolished from the land, a Committee should be appointed to memorialize President LINCOLN to carry out to its fullest extent his Proclamation of Emancipation. The resolution was out and carried unanimously. The following ministers, as representing the denominations to which they respectively belong, were then appointed to draw up the memorial, to be submitted at an adjourned meeting, to be held in the same place, next Monday evening: Dr. W.R. Williams, as representing the Baptists; Dr. J.P. Thompson, the Congregationalists; Dr. Vermilyea, the Dutch Reformed; Dr. Tyng, the Episcopalians; Dr. Trow, the Methodists.

abstract: Dec. 8, 1862.--The father, in this case, applies for the discharge of his son, Nelson A. Buell, on the ground that he is under the age of twenty-one years, and enlisted without his consent. This is sustained by the evidence before me.
lead_paragraph: Dec. 8, 1862.--The father, in this case, applies for the discharge of his son, Nelson A. Buell, on the ground that he is under the age of twenty-one years, and enlisted without his consent. This is sustained by the evidence before me. At common law and by our statutes, the years of minority are fixed under twenty-one years of age; the relationship of parent and guardian, and master and apprentice, is well defined by statute, and established by innumerable authorities, and Congress cannot pass any act which destroys that relationship, and deprives the parent or guardian or master, against their consent, of the services and control of such minor, unless in care of invasion or rebellion, when every able-bodied male citizen between the ages of eighteen and forty-five are liable to military duty. This is absolutely compulsory; but all other acts of Congress in regard to the military establishment of the United States, apply only to volunteer enlistments.

abstract: Mrs. CALEB B. SMITH, wife of the Secretary of the Interior, in connection with other Washington ladies, is preparing to give a Christmas dinner to all the sick and wounded soldiers in Washington. Their number now exceeds 25,000, and a large outlay will of course be required. Contributions for the purpose are solicited from loyal ladies throughout the country. Any sums left with United States Marshal MURRAY, at his office in Chambers-street, will be duly acknowledged and forwarded to Washington.

abstract: United States Marshal MURRAY yesterday received an answer to his letter asking for instructions about the disposal of the rebel Capt. JOB C. RICH, concerning whom full particulars were published in Monday's TIMES. Judging from this answer, Capt. JOB C. RICH does not stand very high in the estimation of the Navy Department. The answer of the Secretary of the Navy was in the following words: "If RICH can be used as an exchange, he had better be detained; if not, he is too worthless to be imprisoned."

abstract: From the Cincinnati Gazette, Dec. 8.  We have full confirmation this morning of the evacuation of Grenada, Miss., by the rebels. A private dispatch from one of our correspondents states that Gen. GRANT's army had concentrated at that place. The expedition from Helena commanded by Gens. Hovey and C. C. WASHBURN, had succeeded...
lead_paragraph: From the Cincinnati Gazette, Dec. 8. We have full confirmation this morning of the evacuation of Grenada, Miss., by the rebels. A private dispatch from one of our correspondents states that Gen. GRANT's army had concentrated at that place. The expedition from Helena commanded by Gens. Hovey and C. C. WASHBURN, had succeeded in cutting the Mississippi Central Railroad south of Grenada, and subsequently advanced upon and took possession of the latter place. The rebels, unable to move the rolling stock, destroyed the cars and locomotives. There are no positive advices as to the position of the rebels, but we are left to infer that they retreated to Columbus, Miss., southeast from Grenada, on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad. From this point they still have railroad communication, via Meridian and Jackson, with Vicksburgh; or they can get around to East Tennessee and join BRAGG. It has been intimated heretofore that the rebel armies, if they should find themselves unable to operate separately, with the prospect of success, would abandon either the Mississippi line or East Tennessee, and unite against ROSECRANS and GRANT. Their failure to offer resistance to GRANT so far would indicate that there has been no junction in Mississippi, as it would also that PEMBERTON is not strong enough to meet GRANT. However, it is impossible to tell, from the course that has been adopted by the enemy, what the rebel plan is. If PEMBERTON has gone to Columbus, GRANT must follow him, for a rebel army cannot be allowed to remain there, with our army even at Grenada. From Columbus they could, if not pressed, easily pounce upon Corinth. Gen. GRANT, in order to protect his communications, must, as he moves south, drive the rebels before him. The situation in Mississippi is getting more and more interesting. The gunboat fleet will now soon be heard from. The boats are in motion, and many days will not elapse before the strength of Vicksburgh is tried once more.

abstract: THE TRIAL OF REV. MR. ARMSTRONG--The trial of Rev. SYLVESTER ARMSTRONG, whose indictment, with others, for misdemeanor, in being concerned in breaking up a meeting at New-Providence, N.J., last Summer, we noticed a day or two since, is set down for Monday next, before the Union County...
lead_paragraph: THE TRIAL OF REV. MR. ARMSTRONG--The trial of Rev. SYLVESTER ARMSTRONG, whose indictment, with others, for misdemeanor, in being concerned in breaking up a meeting at New-Providence, N.J., last Summer, we noticed a day or two since, is set down for Monday next, before the Union County Court, at Elizabeth, Judge HAINES presiding. Yesterday morning the counsel for defence moved to set aside the jury impanneled by the Sheriff to try the case, and impannel a struck jury. This motion the Court granted, and set down Thursday next for the impanneling of the jury. It is expected the trial will be one of unusual interest, and we have no fear but that Judge HAINES will see that Mr. ARMSTRONG and those implicated with him have a fair and just trial. We learn that the counsel for the accused propose to call not less than forty witnesses, and, no doubt, nearly an equal number will be called by the prosecution. The defence will be conducted by CORTLANDT PARKER, Esq., and A.Q. REASSEY, Esq., United States District Attorney, of Newark, and Messrs. CHETWOOD & MAGIE, of Elizabeth. The Prosecutor of the Pleas for Union County, D.Y. ROGERS, Esq., will conduct the prosecution, assisted probably by Ex-Chancellor WILLIAMSON.

abstract: A proposition was before Congress at its last session to enlarge the Illinois and Michigan Canal and to improve the navigation of the Illinois River, so as to secure a passage for gunboats and armed vessels between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan.
lead_paragraph: A proposition was before Congress at its last session to enlarge the Illinois and Michigan Canal and to improve the navigation of the Illinois River, so as to secure a passage for gunboats and armed vessels between the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan. The bill was within one or two votes of passing, but was postponed to the present session. It will soon be up for further consideration, and in contemplation of the inquiries that will be made, the General Government detailed Col. J.D. WEBSTER, 1st Regt. Illinois Light Artillery, to examine and report upon the practicability and cost of the proposed work. The report of Col. WEBSTER will be found in our columns to-day.

abstract: Another heavy battle has been fought in Arkansas, and another great victory has crowned the National arms. Gen. HERRON'S forces, already mentioned as on the way to reinforce Gen.
lead_paragraph: Another heavy battle has been fought in Arkansas, and another great victory has crowned the National arms. Gen. HERRON'S forces, already mentioned as on the way to reinforce Gen. BLUNT at Cane Hill, encountered the enemy on Sunday on Crawford's Prairie, ten miles south of Fayetteville, and after a desperate battle, lasting from 10 o'clock in the morning until dark, defeated them with heavy loss. The rebels were 24,000 strong, in four divisions, commanded respectively by Gens. PARSONS, MARMANDUKE, FROST and RAINS, the whole under command of HINDMAN. The position of Gen. BLUNT at Cane Hill was flanked by them, their intention being to prevent the joining of our two forces. The scale of battle late in the day was turned by a reinforcement of five thousand men from Gen. BLUNT's command, which fell upon the rebel rear. At 9 o'clock on Sunday night the rebels were in full flight again for the Boston Mountains, with a loss, by their own admission, of 1,500 killed and wounded. Our loss is estimated at 600.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Arabia at Halifax we have advices from Europe one week later. She left Liverpool on the 29th and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The political news by this arrival is almost wholly devoid of interest.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Arabia at Halifax we have advices from Europe one week later. She left Liverpool on the 29th and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The political news by this arrival is almost wholly devoid of interest. The British Press continues its discussion of American affairs, but bring out no new points for consideration. The excitement in Greece in favor of placing Prince ALFRED, of England, on the Throne of that country, continued unabated. The great prize-fight for the championship of England, between JEM MACE and TOM KING, took place on the 26th ult., and resulted in favor of KING -- MACE knocking him out of time in the twenty-first round. It was reported that HEENAN had agreed to fight KING for the championship, each man to put up £500. Cotton in the Liverpool market was quiet, after an advance during the week, which had been partially lost. Breadstuff's were quiet and steady, and Provisions inactive. Consols 93 7/8@94.

abstract: Observations from Great Britain; Editorial on war expenditures based on US Treasury report
snippet: Observations from Great Britain; Editorial on war expenditures based on US Treasury report
lead_paragraph: From the report of the Secretary of the Treasury we find that the ordinary Revenue of the year 1861-2 was $51,935,720 76. The derangement of several of the departments of our great industrial and commercial interests, rendered it inevitable that the revenue during the first year of the war, should be smaller than usual. It suffered, however, less than was anticipated. Among the items of which it is made up, direct and internal taxes appear for the first time in twenty-five years. The amount of these war taxes is no more than $1,795,331 73, as they only began to be collected toward the close of the year. Their amount up to July 1, 1863. is estimated at 85 millions, and for the following year at 150 millions, as by that time the Excise machinery will be in full working order.

abstract: Mr. H.L. CLINTON, counsel for Dr. E.M. BROWN, who is charged with procuring an abortion upon CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, and thereby causing her death, has brought up the proceedings at the Coroner's inquest before Judge McCUNN on a writ of certiorari, for the purpose of cross-examining the witnesses, who testified on that occasion, and effecting.
lead_paragraph: Mr. H.L. CLINTON, counsel for Dr. E.M. BROWN, who is charged with procuring an abortion upon CLEMENTINA ANDERSON, and thereby causing her death, has brought up the proceedings at the Coroner's inquest before Judge McCUNN on a writ of certiorari, for the purpose of cross-examining the witnesses, who testified on that occasion, and effecting if possible, the release of his client, or his admission to bail. The first cross-examination was held at Judge MCCUNN's office on Saturday last, on which occasion AUGUSTUS L. SIMMS, who was the principal witness against Dr. BROWN at the inquest, was subjected to a long cross-examination, mainly with reference to his intercourse with Miss ANDERSON previous to her going to the Doctor's. The evidence of SIMMS was mostly unfit for publication, and had little pertinency to the charge against Dr. BROWN, although it developed a depth of villainy and heartlessness on the part of the witness which is rarely equaled. The examination was resumed yesterday at Judge MCCUNN's office, when SIMMS was again put upon the stand, and his cross-examination continued. His testimony, yesterday referred principally to his interviews with the father and other relatives of Miss ANDERSON, during her last absence from home, and did not differ in any material point from his evidence before the Coroner, all of which has been already published in the TIMES. In answer to a question, whether he considered his conduct at these interviews, in deceiving Mr. ANDERSON with regard to his daughter's whereabouts, honest and honorable on his part, he replied that he did not know as it was honorable, but it was done at her request. To a question whether, during the last three years, he had seduced a girl in this City who worked on a sewing-machine, he gave an emphatic "No." He was then asked whether he had had any difficulty with such a girl, to which he replied that he did not know what that had to do with this case. On being instructed by the Judge to answer the question, he said, "No, it is not worth talking about." The examination was here adjourned to 3 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: -A  correspondent, representing a prominent mercantile house, and to whose letter we give place, objects to the whole scheme for furnishing relief from this country for Lancashire.
lead_paragraph: -A correspondent, representing a prominent mercantile house, and to whose letter we give place, objects to the whole scheme for furnishing relief from this country for Lancashire. He thinks that the movement is not only a mistake, but unnecessary and uncalled for -- as the two countries are at bitter enmity, as England is able to take care of her own famished operatives, as the distress there is not so bad as represented, as the proposed action would give more pain and annoyance than gratification to England, and on the whole, that it would be "wrong for America to give and equally wrong for England to receive the proffered assistance," while it would be much better that the fund raised for Lancashire be diverted to the relief of the 130,000 National troops now in hospital.

abstract: The proposition which was made some time since, that the several Sound routes between New-York and the East Should agree upon some fixed rate of freightage, has been adopted. Freight of all descriptions is taken now by the "Fall River Line," the "Norwich and Worcester Line," and the "Stonington Line," at one and the same rate. Four cents per foot is charged for measurement goods, and others as per printed tariff. No portion of the traveling public is so well served as that which patronizes these lines. For years the routes have been continually open, accidents are rare, attention to the care and comfort of the passenger is proverbial, and e boats, of which the superb ocean steamer Metropolis,is a once the type and the queen, are superior in point of accommodation, speed and security to any that float in American waters.

lead_paragraph: The admission of a new State into the Union is a very serious public event-- something like admitting a grown-up stranger into a family. Will the new member be agreeable, is he honorable, will be pay his way, will be conform to household rules and customs--or will be be factious, cross, and a pauper? In the early and even recent days of this Republic, very little heed was paid to such questions. In fact they did not rise at all -- but the country was so run mad for enlarging the Union, that such districts as Florida became States, and throughout their career were a heavy annual charge upon the National Treasury, though they furnished Congressmen and Cabinet Ministers to bully the Government and shape its policy in direct hostility to the interests of the great States that supported the Union.

abstract: The United States vs. One Box and One Bag, Marked M.M. 62 and 63, One Package of Jewelry, and One Gold Watch. -- This was an action to forfeit the goods on the ground of an intent to smuggle them. The claimant, Mr. Mandel, arrived in this port on Dec. 21, 1861. in the steamer Washington. He was asked by the Custom-house officers if he had any dutiable articles, and said he had. and he accordingly made a written statement, specifying the box and the bag as containing dutiable articles. The officers afterward, on examining his trunk, found the gold watch, which he claimed to be a second-hand watch, but which, they thereupon seized as being new. They subsequently searched his person, and found on him jewelry [???] to make a large package. He claimed that [???] he was asked if he had anything on his [???] he produced these things, and that the quantity of the articles was so great as to make the claim that he intended to smuggle them preposterous. The Government practically abandoned the attempt to forfeit the box and bag on the trial, and the case went to the jury, as to the package of jewelry and the gold watch. They were out some time, but finally found a verdict, condemning the jewelry found on his person, but releasing the rest.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a bill to establish an arsenal and ordnance depot on the tide-waters of New York Harbor, was reported from the Military Committee. A joint resolution offered by Mr. RICE, of Minnesota, forfeiting the lands and annuities of the Sioux Indians, and providing for their removal, was referred. The Military Committee was directed to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill forfeiting the pay and emoluments of officers of the army during the time they are absent, excepting upon sick leave. The Joint Committee on the Conduct of the War was requested to make a report with all convenient speed. The bill for the relief of the owners of the French ship Julie et Marie was passed. The resolution increasing the bonds of the Superintendent of Public Printing was passed. The House bill providing for the discharge of State prisoners, etc., was ordered to be printed, and postponed until to-day. Mr. HENDERSON, of Missouri, gave notice of a bill to aid that State in emancipating her slaves. The resolution regarding the arrest of certain citizens of Delaware was postponed until to-day, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The ladies' of Rev. Mr. STRYKER'S congregation, at the Dutch Reformed Church in Thirty-fourth-street, on Tuesday opened a Fancy Fair in the basement of the building. Every imaginable article -- useful and ornamental -- is offered by them for inspection and disposal. The stalls are all arranged with exquisite taste, and are attended by charming young persons of infinite personal attractions and irresistibly persuasive manners. Throughout the day, and specially in the evening, the business of bargain and sale is briskly transacted, purchasers being apparently plentiful and generous, and the lovely and accomplished venders adroit and persevering. Arrangements have been made with comprehensive care for supplying visitors with all kinds of refreshments. Whether one's taste runs in the direction of beef or bonbons, there is amble provision of either to satisfy the most fastidious and extensive demand. These good things, too, are dispensed with fairy hands and seasoned by bright smiles that would make even rebel army rations palatable and delicious. The Fair will be continued through to-day.

abstract: MELANCHOLY OCCURRENCE--TWO LITTLE SISTERS BURNED TO DEATH,--On Tuesday evening Mrs. ELLEN McCLAIR, living at No. 56 Oak-street, having occasion to go to the grocery-store, locked her two small children--one 4 years and the other 17 months old--in the room during her absence.
lead_paragraph: MELANCHOLY OCCURRENCE--TWO LITTLE SISTERS BURNED TO DEATH,--On Tuesday evening Mrs. ELLEN McCLAIR, living at No. 56 Oak-street, having occasion to go to the grocery-store, locked her two small children--one 4 years and the other 17 months old--in the room during her absence. She soon returned, and upon opening the door the oldest child (MARY ANN) ran screaming toward her, her clothes then being on fire. The other child (ELLON) sat on the floor, and the almost frantic mother soon discovered that her dress also was in a blaze. The flames were soon extinguished, but the little ones were so fearfully burned that they died in a few hours afterward. In her examination before Coroner COLLIN, Mrs. MCCLAIR testified that on going from the house she left a pot of soup on the fire, and in her opinion the clothes of the eldest child caught fire while she was stirring the soup. There being no help at hand the child, in her frenzied state of mind, ran to her younger sister, whose clothes she set on fire. This is the only explanation Mrs. MCCLAIR could give relative to the fatal burning of her children. The screams of the victims after their clothes took fire, were heard by others in the house, and an effort was made to enter the room to learn the cause, but the door was locked, and so remained till the mother returned. The jury rendered a verdict that the children came to their deaths from the effects of burns accidentally received.

abstract: Editorial scores marauding by Union soldiers; links their demoralization
snippet: Editorial scores marauding by Union soldiers; links their demoralization
lead_paragraph: A private letter to us from a highminded officer in one of the South western armies has this statement: "If I should tell you the state of demoralization of many of our old regiments in the Valley of the Mississippi, you would not believe it. They have no respect for man or woman, and are guilty of offences that, if committed at home, would send them to the penitentiary for life." Similar representations are made in so many other quarters that it is no longer possible to doubt that portions of our army have become greatly demoralized.

abstract: By the North American, at Portland, and the Hansa at this port, we have some additional items of European news, though nothing later than has been already published. lead_paragraph: By the North American, at Portland, and the Hansa at this port, we have some additional items of European news, though nothing later than has been already published. The Paris Constitutionnel denies that a second note relative to mediation has been sent by DROUYN DE L' HUYS to Lord RUSSELL. The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, at a recent meeting, passed a resolution declaring that it is not expedient to memorialize the Government to abandon the right to blockade, or diminish its efficiency. Experiments in the cultivation of cotton in the Barbary States had been successful, and the Moorish Government had ordered a large quantity of seed. The probable elevation of Prince ALFRED of England, to the throne of Greece, attracted the most serious attention by the Diplomats. Prince OSCAR, of Sweden, is also spoken of for King.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, the further hearing in the above ease was resumed before Judge McCUNN. Mr. CLINTON informed the Judge that he had concluded the examination of the witness SIMMS. Judge McCUNN then said: "Since this examination commenced before me, I have at intervals looked
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, the further hearing in the above ease was resumed before Judge McCUNN. Mr. CLINTON informed the Judge that he had concluded the examination of the witness SIMMS. Judge McCUNN then said: "Since this examination commenced before me, I have at intervals looked most carefully over the testimony of SIMMS, and it has pained me to know that a young man of his apparent intelligence and respectability should have placed himself in such a terrible situation as his evidence demonstrates. His conduct seems to me to be without a parallel and wholly unmitigated; and although the Coroner has admitted him to bail, still, upon the testimony before me, I feel that it is my imperative duty to commit him to the Tombs as an accessory before the fact in this case, for there is not a householder in our entire community that has not trembled at the revelation. I commit him to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury."

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, the Brooklyn Navy-yard presented a scene of great excitement. News came over that the San Jacinto had been hoodwinked by the Alabama, and naval officers were so much "exercised" by the intelligence that the thousands who obtained admittance to the yard, (Thursday being the ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, the Brooklyn Navy-yard presented a scene of great excitement. News came over that the San Jacinto had been hoodwinked by the Alabama, and naval officers were so much "exercised" by the intelligence that the thousands who obtained admittance to the yard, (Thursday being the regular visiting day,) mistook the cause of the furore and thronged to the wharf, where Capt. WORDEN, of the Monitor, was working hard to get off his new iron-clad, the Montauk.

abstract: The removal of the Custom-house has, at length, been completed. We announced, a few days since, that orders had been received from Washington to hurry the removal of business to the Merchants' Exchange, and that in accordance therewith the Naval Office had been removed last week. On Wednesday the clerks still remaining in the old building were notified to prepare their entries, books ...
lead_paragraph: The removal of the Custom-house has, at length, been completed. We announced, a few days since, that orders had been received from Washington to hurry the removal of business to the Merchants' Exchange, and that in accordance therewith the Naval Office had been removed last week. On Wednesday the clerks still remaining in the old building were notified to prepare their entries, books and effects for removal to their new quarters in the afternoon of that day. At 3 o'clock, when the official business of the day had been closed, each clerk took up his bundle and walked. Arriving at the new Custom-house, he found everything in considerable confusion. However, the gentlemen in charge of the work in the building endeavored to give satisfaction, and a force was at work most of Wednesday night, placing the desks in position and arranging matters so the the business of the office could be transacted with as little inconvenience to the public as possible. On Thursday morning the desks in the rotunda were in position, and the clerks to whom they belonged at them, ready to perform the duties of the day. The rotunda presented, yesterday, a very animated scene. The large floor of the room was thronged with importers and brokers, who were able to find the desks of which they were in search without much difficulty. The inclosed space in the centre of the rotunda is occupied by the entry clerks and three amendment clerks, the space inclosing a portion of the room on its circumference being occupied by the Deputies and clerks, other than those already mentioned, who formerly had desks in the rotunda of the old building.

abstract: Editorial sees inflation resulting from issuance of Notes of Circulation, instead of gold, as legal tender; urges Government act to curb it; editorial sees inflation resulting from issuance of notes, instead of gold, as legal tender; urges Government act to curb inflation; Editorial urges Government curb inflation due to issuance of US notes instead of gold as legal tender
snippet: Editorial sees inflation resulting from issuance of Notes of Circulation, instead of gold, as legal tender; urges Government act to curb it; editorial sees inflation resulting from issuance of notes, instead of gold, as legal tender; urges Governm...
lead_paragraph: A very general interest prevails as to the policy of the Government on the Currency. The increase in the price of nearly every thing which the great mass of the community have to buy is attributed in a very large degree, whether justly or not, to the inflation of the currency caused by the issue of United States notes, which are made a legal tender, -- and the extent of this increase in prices, or what is the same thing, this depreciation in the Government currency, is tested by the premium on gold. At present it is measured bysaying that gold is worth 132 1/2 per cent., when judged by the standard of United States legal-tender notes. The universal hope is that this upward tendency in prices will be checked. Persons who rely upon salaries or fixed incomes, find the existing state of things especially burdensome, inasmuch as the money they receive is worth nearly one-third less than it was when specie was the standard of value. Naturally enough, therefore, the whole community is anxious to know whether the Government intends to increase the evil, by still further issues of paper money, or to check it by returning, as rapidly as the necessities of the Government will permit, to a specie basis.

abstract: SUPPOSED POISONING OF THREE SEA CAPTAINS IN CUBA.--JOHN M. GRIFFIN, first mate, and THOMAS LEE, cook, of the bark Belsey Williams, arrived here yesterday in the steamship Eagle, Capt. ADAMS, from San Juan Remedios, Cuba, having been sent hither by the American Consul at that place as prisoners. They are charged with having poisoned three successive Captains of the bark Betsey, Williams, while the lay in the port of San Juan Remedios.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED POISONING OF THREE SEA CAPTAINS IN CUBA.--JOHN M. GRIFFIN, first mate, and THOMAS LEE, cook, of the bark Belsey Williams, arrived here yesterday in the steamship Eagle, Capt. ADAMS, from San Juan Remedios, Cuba, having been sent hither by the American Consul at that place as prisoners. They are charged with having poisoned three successive Captains of the bark Betsey, Williams, while the lay in the port of San Juan Remedios. Soon after the arrival there of the Betsey Williams, Capt. GRIFFIN was taken sick and suddenly died, when the consignees appointed a man named HOOD Captain in his place. In a few days HOOD died in an equally sudden and mysterious manner, when a man named ISRAEL S. BUNCE was appointed to succeed him. BUNCE soon snared the same fate as his predecessors, and by this time the suspicions of the consignees were aroused, and the first mate and cook were arrested and sent here for trial as above. The stomach of the last victim, with its contents, was also sent on here for analysis. It is supposed that the poisoning was done at the instance of GRIFFIN, in the hope that he would be appointed to succeed the Captain as commander of the bark. The Betsey Williams belonged in Boston, whither she has been sent by the consignees, and where the prisoners will be forwarded for trial, in charge of Deputy-Marshals MCCAY and DWIRE.

lead_paragraph: News from Mexico by way of Vera Cruz and Havana, should be received with many grains of allowance. These places are in the interest of the French cause, and every item of intelligence is colored to paint in the brightest hues the success of the invasion. Hence the general reader will receive with some suspicion the reports of the cheerful adherence of this town and of that, to the French arms, on the appearance of the invading forces, while to any one who knows the country, these statements of voluntary adhesion are preposterous and absurd in the extreme.

abstract: By an  arrival from New-Orleans last night, we learn that the election for two members of Congress to represent the districts embracing that city, took plane on the 3d inst. There were plenty of candidates in the field. The names of the successful ones were Mr. BENJAMIN F. FLANDERS, chosen for the First, and Mr. M. HAHN for the Second ...
lead_paragraph: By an arrival from New-Orleans last night, we learn that the election for two members of Congress to represent the districts embracing that city, took plane on the 3d inst. There were plenty of candidates in the field. The names of the successful ones were Mr. BENJAMIN F. FLANDERS, chosen for the First, and Mr. M. HAHN for the Second District. They are both strong, unconditional Unionists. The Delta says that Mr. FLANDERS is a native of New-Hampshire, but has resided in New-Orleans for thirty years. He was among the first to welcome Gen. BUTLER upon his arrival in May last, and is for the Union at any cost. His chief opponent was Mr. BOULIGNY, the staunch Unionist from the same district in last Congress, who received, however, only 136 votes, against 2,184 for Mr. FLANDERS. The other successful candidate, Mr. HAHN, is a lawyer by profession, of German descent, who has lived in New-Orleans since boyhood, and was a stout Unionist through the darkest hours of secession madness. His chief opponent (though not the one who got most votes) was the old antediluvian, JACOB BARKER, who made very great efforts to secure an election, but was wofully beaten.

lead_paragraph: A splendid audience thronged the Academy of Music last evening, on the occasion of a meeting under the auspices of the Woman's Central Association of Relief, in aid of the United States Sanitary Commission. Dr. BELLOWS.

abstract: The members of the New-York Chamber of Commerce and other citizens and merchants of this vicinity, who sympathize also with the suffering operatives of France, as well as the poor of other lands, are hereby most earnestly requested by the undersigned and many others to meet in mass meeting at the New Merchants' Exchange, Nos. 50 and 52 Pine street, at 2 o'clock, on Friday, 12th instant, to dopt such necessary steps as may be there deems necessary to render charitable aid in the transhipment of the produce and provisions of our country to the poor of France, who are now suffering for these necessaries of life in consequence of not receiving the usual orders for their manufactures during the last season, nor the usual supply of cotton for their mills from the United States.

abstract: We have this morning a message from President LINCOLN to the Senate in relation to the thirty-nine Minnesota Indians whom he has ordered to be executed one week from to-day. The President was anxious not to act with so much clemency as to encourage another outbreak of the savages, nor with a degree of severity which should be real cruelty, and therefore at first ordered only the execution of such Indians as "had been proved guilty of violating females;" but only two of this class were found. He then directed that out of the three hundred condemned men, such should be selected as were proved to have participated in massacres as distinguished from participation in battles. These amounted to forty, (including the two of the first-class,) but as one of them had been strongly recommended to mercy, he ordered that only thirty-nine should suffer the death penalty, and has dispatched a messenger to Gen. SIBLEY, in Minnesota, with a copy of the order.

abstract: Through the kindness of G. GRANVILLE WHITE, Esq., of Brooklyn, new zoological specimens, of great interest, have been added to the rapidly increassing collection of birds and animals at the Central Park, consisting of a pair of Syrian gezelles, rare animals, of great beauty, and a pair of musk deer, of the Nepaul musk species. They are of full growth, add not over one foot in height. They have smooth brown hair, and very slender legs, and are marked on the breast with white radiating stripes.

GRANVILLE WHITE, Esq., of Brooklyn, new zoological specimens, of great interest, have been added to the rapidly increassing collection of birds and animals at the Central Park, consisting of a pair of Syrian gezelles, rare animals, of great beauty, and a pair of musk deer, of the Nepaul musk species. They are of full growth, add not over one foot in height. They have smooth brown hair, and very slender legs, and are marked on the breast with white radiating stripes.

abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac is suddenly invested with the most startling interest. Yesterday morning the movement for crossing the Rappahannock commenced, and last night the city of Fredericksburgh was in possession of our forces, with comparatively trifling loss. During Wednesday night pontoon bridges were got in readiness for throwing across the river, and at 6 o'clock yesterday morning the construction of three of them commenced infront of the city.
lead_paragraph: When they were about half completed the enemy opened a murderous fire of musketry upon the engineers, and forced them to desist from their work. One hundred and forty-three pieces of our artillery then opened upon the city, and the fire was responded to by the rebels, but without much damage. The city was set on fire in several places by our shells. The attempt was then again made to finish the bridges, when the enemy's sharpshooters again opened, and compelled a retreat. Finally, volunteers to cross the river in small boats to dislodge the enemy were called for, and sprang out of the ranks by thousands. Only a hundred, however, were selected, who crossed the river in the most dashing style, drove out the Sharpshooters at the point of the bayonet, and captured a large number of them, who were brought over the river and secured. The bridges were then completed, and the city was immediately occupied by our forces, the rebels being driven back to their defensive works, Meantime Gen. FRANKLIN was also engaged in the construction of bridges about three miles below the city, in which work he met with but little opposition. He did not cross, however, until he heard that the city was in our possession. The gunboats were also engaged in shelling the enemy about fifteen miles below, where they had collected in considerable force. Last night everything was reported quiet, with the prospect of a great battle to be fought to-day.

abstract: Hitherto, this now popular orator has restricted himself to purely literary subjects. On Tuesday next he departs from this course, and will deliver an oration at the Academy of Music, on "The European Aspects of the American Rebellion." We perceive that, while in Europe, Mr. JONES advocated the cause of the Union with brilliancy and energy. We may, therefore, reasonably expect that his oration on our present national difficulties in relation to their European bearings, will be as acceptable as we anticipate it will be eloquent. The topics treated upon, we understand, will be very varied, embracing the schemes of LOUIS NAPOLEON as distinct from the ideas of the French people, as well as the feelings of the population of Great Britain as contrasted with the actions of the English Government. So crowded a house is expected, that no tickets will be sold on the evening of the oration, and we refer our readers to the advertisement to ascertain where they are obtainable in the interim.

abstract: Fredericksburgh is at last in possession of our army. The telegraphic details of the work of yesterday are few and brief, but they exhibit fine maneuvering, splendid bravery, and, so far as the first ahd most difficult operation was concerned, success. The previous night had been all bustle and activity among the troops, for it was fixed that they should cross the Rappahannock, in the face of the foe, in the morning.
lead_paragraph: Fredericksburgh is at last in possession of our army. The telegraphic details of the work of yesterday are few and brief, but they exhibit fine maneuvering, splendid bravery, and, so far as the first ahd most difficult operation was concerned, success. The previous night had been all bustle and activity among the troops, for it was fixed that they should cross the Rappahannock, in the face of the foe, in the morning. Before the dawn of day, the pontoons were at the river side, a hundred and forty-three pieces of artillery gaped toward the city, and the whole army, musket in hand, was prepared to rush over as soon the bridges were built. At five, the construction of bridges began, and shortly afterward the enemy opened a murderous fire upon the engineers from the houses of the town. At six, BURNSIDE ordered all the artillery to be opened upon the place, and at seven the heavy guns of the enemy replied to ours. The fire continued for two or three hours, and our engineers were driven from the bridges. Another attempt was at once made, and the rebel infantry, aided by artillery, again opened on our men. Between one and three o'clock, the fire slackened, and all our batteries were once more placed in position, numbering now 176 guns. At a given signal, they again opened, but the rebel sharpshooters could not be driven from their hiding-places, and the bridges could not be constructed till they were driven away. Volunteers were now called for to cross the river in small boats and storm the enemy's position. Hundreds of gallant men at once stepped forward as a forlorn hope, and a hundred of them were chosen. Under cover of artillery they crossed. With fixed bayonets they rushed upon the enemy, and took a hundred and one of them prisoners. At half-past two the bridges were completed and our troops swept across to the south bank of the Rappahannock.

abstract: The fact seems  at last to be fully conceded that Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior, will resign his place about the 1st of January next. Most of the indications from Washington point to Hon. JOSEPH HOLT as his successor--provided the office is not continued in the hands of a citizen of Indiana.
lead_paragraph: The fact seems at last to be fully conceded that Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior, will resign his place about the 1st of January next. Most of the indications from Washington point to Hon. JOSEPH HOLT as his successor--provided the office is not continued in the hands of a citizen of Indiana. Geographical considerations are important to a certain extent, but should not be overruling in times like the present. The chief purpose of the President and of all in authority now, should be to put always the right man in the right place.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, notice was given of a bill to facilitate the medical examination of invalid soldiers in the hospitals and convalescent camps. A message was received from the President recommending votes of thanks to Lieut. GEORGE W. MORRIS, for his defence of the Cumberland, and to Lieut. WORDEN, for his gallantry in the fight between the Monitor and the Merrimac. A communication was also received from the President regarding the Indian troubles in Minnesota, stating that he had ordered the execution of thirty-nine of the culprits. The resolution relating to the arbitrary arrests of certain citizens of Delaware, was then taken up, and debated until the adjournment.

abstract: The Golden State, as California is called, has recently furnished a valuable contribution to art in a series of splendid photographs -- which may be seen at GOUPIL's -- of those wonderful scenes in the Yosemite Valley. As specimens of the photographic art they are unequaled, and reflect great credit upon the producer, Mr. WATKINS. The views of lofty mountains, of gigantic trees, of falls of water which seem to descend from heights in the heavens and break into mists before they reach the ground, are indescribably unique and beautiful. Nothing in the way of landscape can be more impressive or picturesque.

abstract: A week or two ago we gave a brief account of the trouble in Cook County, growing out of the discovery of a treasonable plot to surrender that portion of the State to Federal authority. Cook County is a border county, contiguous to the Indian Territory, and is thinly inhabited, a great portion of the settlers being originally from Ohio and Indiana. It seems
lead_paragraph: A week or two ago we gave a brief account of the trouble in Cook County, growing out of the discovery of a treasonable plot to surrender that portion of the State to Federal authority. Cook County is a border county, contiguous to the Indian Territory, and is thinly inhabited, a great portion of the settlers being originally from Ohio and Indiana. It seems there was a secret organization formed, having signs, grips and passwords. The members were sworn to secrecy, and those found worthy were intrusted with three degrees. The first degree bound the member to secrecy and to avenge a brother member's blood. The second degree was confined to robbing, jay-hawking, &c. The third contemplated the reestablishment of the old Union.

abstract: --Of course "the entire absence of intelligence all day yesterday from Fredericksburgh created considerable uneasiness in the public mind, and gave the prophets of evil a splendid opportunity to exercise their gifts. It was
lead_paragraph: --Of course "the entire absence of intelligence all day yesterday from Fredericksburgh created considerable uneasiness in the public mind, and gave the prophets of evil a splendid opportunity to exercise their gifts. It was recalled to mind how news had been withheld from the public after every disaster our army has suffered during the war -- how the people had been treated as fools and babies who could not endure at first the full exhibit of disagreeable facts, and how, after equivocations, denials, contradictions, absurdities and falsities of all sorts we had frequently finally been led into the secret that our army had had a deadly battle with the rebels. The statements made in authorized dispatches of Thursday night, that a battle must open in the morning, were also noted, and one Washington telegram that came in the Philadelphia papers announced positively that fighting would be resumed in the morning, and even stated that our army would be ready to engage the enemy by eight o'clock! The assertion that we could get no news because the telegraph was so busily engaged in bearing dispatches to the Government, was unsatisfactory, as every one knew that in the twinkling of an eye it could convey the half-dozen magic words that would be necessary to give the public assurance. There were rumors that FRANKLIN's Corps, being isolated three miles down the river, had been fallen upon by the rebel right wing, which was known to be very strong, and cut to pieces; and the assertion in the Washington telegram to Philadelphia, that these stories "were all false," went far to make them believed by a large portion of the public. There were hundreds of other uncheerful rumors created out of nothing and nursed into monstrous magnitude in the darkness and silence of Press and telegraph, but it is not worth while to prolong their existence by giving them print. The public largely bought up each successive edition of the journals to get the news, but could find not an item.

abstract: We have anotherof those horrible stories from Texas of the execution, or rather the massacre, of Union men in that State. It is given with all particularity of detail in the Texas Republican, of the 1st ultimo. It is, briefly, that a secret Union organization had been discovered in Cook County, contiguous to the Indian Territory, which had ramifications into Grayson County, the members of which were intrusted with three degrees -- the first degree being secrecy, the second jayhawking and robbery, (doubtless false,) and the third degree "contemplated the reestablishment of the old Union." The plot was discovered -- seventyof the Unionists were arrested -- and, at the first effort, twenty-four of them were tried and executed. Subsequently to this two rebels were shot -- probably by persons of their own kidney, as shooting has always been common enough in Texas -- and this furnished a pretext for another general hanging of Unionists. "The number executed in Cook County, at last accounts," says the Texan paper, "was forty-two, and two others were shot in attempting to make their escape. Others," says the editor, "it was expected, would be summarily dealtwith;" and then he adds: "Since writing the foregoing it is rumored that several persons have been hung in Grayson County, and among them a Dr. LIVELY."

abstract: We copy from the Chicago Times the detailed statement br "J. WESLER GREEME" of his share in an attempt of JEFF. DAVIS to negotiate a peace with President LINCOLN. We copy it--just as we used to copy stories of the sea-serpent--solely to satisfy public curiosity, not, because we deem it of the slightest possible consequence to anybody. We know noth
lead_paragraph: We copy from the Chicago Times the detailed statement br "J. WESLER GREEME" of his share in an attempt of JEFF. DAVIS to negotiate a peace with President LINCOLN. We copy it--just as we used to copy stories of the sea-serpent--solely to satisfy public curiosity, not, because we deem it of the slightest possible consequence to anybody. We know nothing whatever of Mr. GREENE. He may be an "ornamental japanner" of Pittsburgh, as he claims to be; or he may have been a Methodist preacher, a confidence man and an inmate of our State Prison, as the Police Gazette says he has. He may be a perfect saint -- as saints go now-a-days; and we should be very sorry to do him an injustice. But, judging him by his own statements, we believe him to be, in this particular matter, simply a braggart and an impostor. The main part of his story, which we publish this morning, is in our judgment utterly false. We don't believe that DAVIS ever sent for him as he says he did, that he ever said to him what he is reported to have said, or that he ever had such an interview with him as GREENE describes.

abstract: Your remarks in the TIMES of to-day regarding " Military Accountability and the Pending Court-martial," are very timely, but it is only recently that the Government would consent to having either Courts-martial or Courts of Inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Your remarks in the TIMES of to-day regarding " Military Accountability and the Pending Court-martial," are very timely, but it is only recently that the Government would consent to having either Courts-martial or Courts of Inquiry. A Brigadier General, of the fighting school, who had won a reputation as a man of brains and of courage, was deprived of his command a year ago, without rhyme or reason, and notwithstanding the most strenuous efforts of himself and friend he was absolutely and rudely refused any trial either by Court of Inquiry or Court-martial. A General was this past Summer deprived of his command and of his rank, and although no charges were preferred against him, and he had a clean record of 25 years, he could not procure even a hearing of any kind. He was willing to meet all accountability, but was peremptorily refused any opportunity. I happen to know that the Government started with the determination to have no Courts of Inquiry, and the result was every way bad. It is to be hoped that the hearings granted to some favorite Major-Generals may be extended to some other greatly aggrieved officers. JUSTICE.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at terday afternoon, and occupied a short session in passing upon various matters, strictly routine. A resolution to increase the salary of the Police Justices to $5,000 each was presented and laid over. The privilege of making this increase was granted by the last Legislature. At present the
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at terday afternoon, and occupied a short session in passing upon various matters, strictly routine. A resolution to increase the salary of the Police Justices to $5,000 each was presented and laid over. The privilege of making this increase was granted by the last Legislature. At present the Justices get $2,500 each per annum, for services at the District Courts, and $1,000 each for services at the Court of Special Sessions. The new arrangement proposed will include pay for all services during the year. The Board overruled two vetoes of resolutions to connect fire company houses with bell-towers by telegraph, at an expense of $250 in each case. The Mayor thinks the patent right made use of to make these connections should be secured for the City, and the work be done in one job instead of by piecomeal. Adjourned till 3 1/2 P.M to-day.

abstract: Charitable Bequest. -- The will of DANIEL BOLL, late of this city, was now admitted to probate, leaving a large residuary estate to establish a public library in the testator's native parish of Bas Valley, in Canton Fribourg, in the village of Praz. The will leaves $15,000 with which to purchase the site and erect a library building, and $4,000 for the immediate purchase of books. The library is to be for the public use -- all classes to be admitted, and is to be known by the name of "Bibloteque Villiviennis." The entire residuary estate of the testator is to be made a fund in the hands of Trustees, whose interest is to be applied annually in the purchase of books for the library.

abstract: Our Washington correspondent states, in yesterday's TIMES, that, "in case Mr. SMITH re  tires from the Secretaryship of the Interior, Indiana will earnestly insist that the vacancy shall be filled by one of her own citizens."
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondent states, in yesterday's TIMES, that, "in case Mr. SMITH re tires from the Secretaryship of the Interior, Indiana will earnestly insist that the vacancy shall be filled by one of her own citizens." That is probable; but unless she can offer from among her own citizens a man better fitted for the place than can be found elsewhere, she ought not to insist upon it, nor should any heed be paid to it if she does. The emergencies of the public service are too formidable to allow of Executive deference to local claims at the expense of the public welfare. What the President wants is a man who will bring intellect, moral power and popular strength to his Councils. What the people want is a Minister in whose honesty, zeal and courage they can repose unlimited confidence from the start. Let such a man be found -- we believe JOSEPH HOLT is just such a man -- and let him be added by the President to his Cabinet, without any unmeaning pother over his locality. Our country is but one, our cause is but one, and the citizen who can serve the cause and country best is the one who should he called to the President's Councils.

abstract: Our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac are not so full or so late as we could desire -- owing, doubtless, to the fact that the single telegraphic wire connecting Fredricksburgh with Washington was last night fully occupied in the transmission of Government dispatches. The first telegram received by us, dated at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, did not reach us until about 8 o'clock last night. After the occupation, of the river front on Thursday night, about a hundred of our men were killed and wounded while driving the rebels through and out of the city. The troops commenced moving at an early hour yesterday. Gen. SUMNER's Grand Division leading, followed by Gen. HOOKER's Grand Division. Gen. FRANKLIN's Grand Division, also emmenced crossing three miles below. A brief artillery engagement took place there, but the rebels did not make much opposition to the crossing. Information received during the night was to the effect that the rebels had two strong [???] of batteries in the rear of the city -- one a mile beyond it, and the other a mile beyond the first that they had concentrated their forces, and intended to give battle. Our last telegram is dated last evening, and reached us about [???] o'clock this morning. From it we learn that, at 2 1/2 o'clock in the afternoon, the rebels opened with all their guns in the first range of batteries, their [???] being directed upon the city. The only damage done, however, was to the houses, none of our troops being hurt. Some of the guns opened on a large body of our troops which had crossed on the two lower bridges, and were [???] down the river, but the damage done was slight. Our guns then opened upon the rebel batteries from across the river, and silenced then after the duel of half an hour. This ended the firing for the day, and last night our troops rested upon their arms. There were no indications of the enemy evacuating their position, and a battle is regarded as unavoidable.

abstract: One of the worst nuisances of the day is the tribe of fussy fools who thrust themselves into the conduct of public affairs, and, through the ignorance or good nature of our public men, gain the notoriety and consequence which is all they seek. Almost everybody
lead_paragraph: One of the worst nuisances of the day is the tribe of fussy fools who thrust themselves into the conduct of public affairs, and, through the ignorance or good nature of our public men, gain the notoriety and consequence which is all they seek. Almost everybody has one or two such among his acquaintances, -- men who stop you in the street, and tell you they have just written to the President, telling him what must be done, -- or that they are just starting for England, to post "Pam" up on American affairs. So long as their folly remains a mere matter of conversation, no great harm is done. They are bores -- simply this and nothing more; end bores are much too common a commodity to merit special comment or excite special wonder.

abstract: J W Greene statement on his role in alleged attempt by Davis to negotiate peace with Lincoln
snippet: J W Greene statement on his role in alleged attempt by Davis to negotiate peace with Lincoln
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, Oct. 22, 1862, while engaged at my employment as an ornamental japanner, in the shop of Mr. JOHN DUNLAP, dealer in tinplate, sheet iron, brass, copper, c., and manufacturer of japanned tin-ware, , southwest corner of Market and Second streets, Pittsburgh, Penn., I was called upon by a gentleman who said he was a Baltimorean, and, having learned that my wife was from the same city, and I myself somewhat acquainted there, he took the liberty to call upon me for the purpose of spending a half or three-quarters of an hour in friendly chat. I expressed the pleasure it would afford me. As the subject of the war was, as it now is, the chief theme of conversation, ours very naturally turned upon it, and very soon glided into matters connected with the Mexican war. By some apparently casual remark I was led to speak of service rendered by myself in that war, and of my having there made the acquaintance of Mr. DAVIS, now President of the Confederate States. My visitor very soon made himself aware of the fact, that, while politically I was opposed to Mr. DAVIS, personally I was friendly. He then stated that he had been recently in Richmond, and had seen and conversed with Mr. DAVIS, who mentioned me to him; and he desired to know if be might talk confidentially with me as a messenger from Mr. DAVIS. I replied that that would depend upon the nature of the communications he had to make. If he desired to enlist me in the service of the Confederate States, in any capacity, he had better not say anything; but, if such was not his desire, he might speak freely. He then distinctly stated that he had no written communication to me from Mr. DAVIS -- he not deeming it prudent to be the bearer of such a thing; but that Mr. DAVIS greatly desired I should go to him at Richmond, immediately. At such a request I was surprised and amazed. I inquired, what for? My visitor asserted he did not know, and persisted in the assertion. I asked him who he was, when he gave his name as HORACE N. WILSON, formerly connected with the Detective Police in Baltimore, but now a resident of Richmond. I greatly feared, on hearing this announcement, that some trap was being laid for me, or some trick about to be played, which might place me in an equivocal or embarrassing position. But I soon became reassured, as the consciousness was aroused within me of having never, by word or act, occupied for a moment a false or disloyal position toward the Federal Government, or of having performed any act which the Confederate Government might have deemed of sufficient importance to revenge. I was unprepared for an answer then, and so said to Mr. WILSON. I told him he might call again in the afternoon, and that he might rely upon my secrecy. He went away, and on his returning, about the middle of the afternoon, I questioned him closely as to his knowledge of Mr. DAVIS' object in sending such a strange request, compliance with which would be attended with so much peril. All knowledge of the object he denied, as before; but scouted the idea of peril, if by that I meant risk of personal safety. I told him it was that; when he undertook to convince me I need have no fears. He then intimated that it might be productive of good to the whole country, though in what way he professed not to know; and finally wound up by saying that, if I hesitated through fear, he thought Mr. DAVIS was mistaken in the estimate he put upon my promptitude and bravery. He said Mr. DAVIS had spoken to him of the deliberate coolness and dauntless courage which I manifested in Mexico. These complimentary remarks, artfully thrown in just as I was feeling the sting of the former ones, decided my mind. I resolved to accompany him and run the risk. On the ensuing morning, I started with him for Richmond, by way of Wheeling, Staunton and Charlottesville. We arrived in Richmond on Sunday morning, the 26th; and after putting myself in order, and eating breakfast, I was conducted to Mr. DAVIS' presence.

abstract: LADIES' FAIR IN THE BEEKMAN HILL M. E. CHURCH--A Fancy Fair on quite an extensive scale is in progress at the Beekman Hill Methodist Episcopal Church, in Fiftieth Street, between First and Second avenues. The Fair commenced yesterday and is...
lead_paragraph: LADIES' FAIR IN THE BEEKMAN HILL M. E. CHURCH--A Fancy Fair on quite an extensive scale is in progress at the Beekman Hill Methodist Episcopal Church, in Fiftieth Street, between First and Second avenues. The Fair commenced yesterday and is announced to last for a week. All the knickknacks usually for sale on such occasions are offered for disposal by the young ladies connected with the Church, and they appear to have no lack of customers. There are, too, plenty of things of a more useful description to suit purchasers of a practical turn of mind. There is a small charge asked for admission to this Fair: ten cents -- fifty cents being the price of a season ticket. Attractions, though, are provided in the shape of music and speeches additional to those of the fair proprietors of stalls, though these alone ought to be enough to crowd the Sunday Sehool Hall with visitors.

abstract: The "Responsible correspondent of the NEWYORK TIMES will be wise to investigate the cases he states. Not one of the figure items given is correct. The "Responsible" correspondent has neither read the last report nor the mortgage, nor has be considered that the tax increase is 2 8 cent, on the gross earnings; that thus, on last year's basis, the ex
lead_paragraph: The "Responsible correspondent of the NEWYORK TIMES will be wise to investigate the cases he states. Not one of the figure items given is correct. The "Responsible" correspondent has neither read the last report nor the mortgage, nor has be considered that the tax increase is 2 8 cent, on the gross earnings; that thus, on last year's basis, the expenses must be at least 63 cent., while they are likely to be higher, owing to increased cost of everything. The expenses cannot be less than 63 cent., thus the "Responsible" correspondent in these two items is already about $100,000 out of his calculation: and if he will read pages 11 and 12 of last years report, he will find that he is still wider of the mark. If the "Responsible" correspondent will revert to page 13 of last year's report, he will find under table. B, income account, first item, another source of expenditure which he has not considered. If any too trusting individual, acting on the information of "Responsible" correspondent, comes out a loser, I must refer him to the "Responsible" correspondent. M.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC--TO-DAY'S MATINEE.--For the last matinee of the season Mr. GRAU offers the somewhat unusual attractions of three prime donne in one opera--that opera "It Ballo in Maschera," in
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC--TO-DAY'S MATINEE.--For the last matinee of the season Mr. GRAU offers the somewhat unusual attractions of three prime donne in one opera--that opera "It Ballo in Maschera," in which GUERRABELLA, CORDIER and MORENSI wili individually and severally sing. The weather smiles upon Mr. GRAU, and the last matinee of the season, with its liberal allotment of prime donne, will undoubtedly prove a great success. It is something to sec a masked ball, with its sombre dominoes and mysterious rustling silks, its furtive fans, and prevailing "gas and gaiters" -- to see the Countess Sweet-cake glide up to the Grand Duke of Thunder and Lightning, and recognize him by a rose worn in his button-hole. And all this brings the people out.

abstract: In view of the fact that the German element in our population is so large, and exercises so important an influence upon the political and social affairs of our country, it has long been a source of regret among thoughtful men, both Germans and Americans that so few of the journals published in that language in this country, should labor to produce that homogeneity of feeling which it is of the utmost importance should exist between a population which, for better or worse, have cast in their lot with us, and those who are "to the manner born," who have surely no more at stake in the great issue now being tried between free institutions and their opposing forces, than those who, fleeing from the despotisms of the Old World, have sought a shore where they and their posterity can be free, under the benign sway of Democratic institutions. So far from it having been sought to bring about this desirable oneness of feeling and interest, too many of our German papers have, with a strange blindness, pursued a course calculated to promote a feeling directly the reverse; and in some cases, it has seemed to be the highest aim of the Americo-German Journalist to prove that the interest of the Germans in this country demand that they shall, so far as possible, preserve their distinct nationality, and carry into our political contests the idea that they have interests to conserve which are diverse and distinct from those of the nation at large. To such an extent has this feeling been fostered, that it is well known that in most political campaigns -- particularly of local interest, the question has been with the Germans, not what is best for the general good? but what will most advance their separate and peculiar interests? There are other important moral and social questions, which affect our interests as a nation, which have been discussed by many German papers from points of view differing essentially from those they would occupy did not their fancied obligations toward German ideas and traditions distort their judgment, and prevent them from seeking their own true and highest good.

lead_paragraph: Capt. Rynders, Hon. Ben. Wood, Rev. C.C. Burr, Mr. Harrington, Mr. Thompson, formerly Mayor Wood's Private Secretary, Wm. Mulligan, Esq., and a host of the Democracy of the City, serenaded Hon. C.L. VALLANDIGHAM and Hon. Mr. PENDLETON, of Ohio, at the New-York Hotel, last evening. The serenaders employed Dodworth's Band, and started from Thorp's Hotel shortly after 10 o'clock P.M. The music consisted of sundry stirring airs, among which "Dixie" was prominent, and decidedly welcome. After a few airs had been played, there were loud cries for VALLANDIGHAM, who was led to the balcony and introduced by Ex-Senator MCMURRAY. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM commenced his address at nearly 11 1/2 o'clock, and spoke substantially as follows:

abstract: her Cargo. -- This vessel was seized on May 2, 1862, in the harbor of Beaufort, N.C., by the United States naval forces after the capture of the place by the army of the United States. She was sent to this port and libeled. A claim was put in in the cause in behalf of British subjects resident at Liverpool. The papers showed that the vessel was of American build, and was transferred to the claimants on Feb. 11, 1861, by her former owners, a firm resident at Charleston, S.C., one of whose members was in Liverpool and a member of the house which acted as agents in making the transfer.

abstract: The reserve paintings and drawings of GEORGE L. BROWN, the distinguished landscape painter, will be sold at auction by MINER & SOMERVILLE, on the 15th and 16th insts., at SNEDERER's Gallery, No. 768 Broadway, where they are now on free exhibition. Ladies, who have been almost excluded from picture auction sales in this City, will find in these elegant new rooms every attention paid to their comfort and convenience. The public are already familiar with the paintings of Mr. BROWN, but his pencil studies and other drawings have not been allowed to leave his studio. They are among his most admired works, and have hitherto been sought for in vain by connoisseurs. The collection includes a large number of his best oil paintings, including the large White Mountain picture.

abstract: DESCENT UPON AN OBSCENE PRINT ESTABLISHMENT IN WALL-STREET--ARREST OF THE PROPRIETOR.--Information was recently received at the Police Headquarters that one JAMES MURRAY was vending obscene prints, on an extensive scale, at his place, No. 19...
lead_paragraph: DESCENT UPON AN OBSCENE PRINT ESTABLISHMENT IN WALL-STREET--ARREST OF THE PROPRIETOR.--Information was recently received at the Police Headquarters that one JAMES MURRAY was vending obscene prints, on an extensive scale, at his place, No. 19 Well-street, but the informant did not evince a disposition to make a complaint against MURRAY. A little strategy was accordingly resorted to to obtain the requisite proof against the alleged offender. Detective KELSO entered the place, and representing himself as a countryman, said he wished to purchase largely provided the goods suited him. Soon gaining MURRAY's confidence, the latter displayed his stock of card photographic pictures and stereoscopic [???] some of which were of the most obscene and infamous character. This exhibition was sufficient, and at a given signal from the pretended purchaser, in rushed Detectives ELDER, McCORD and RADFORD, and not only arrested MURRAY, But seized his contraband goods. The prisoner had a large and varied assortment of filthy publication, all of which were duly deposited with the Property Clerk, till they may be consigned to the flames. MURRAY was taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, and held to bail in $1,000 to answer the charge before the Court of Sessions. It is stated that the accused was doing quite an extensive business in the disgusting traffic, particularly with a certain class of country dealers.

abstract: Editorial on Burnside strategy; says his goal is Richmond
snippet: Editorial on Burnside strategy; says his goal is Richmond
lead_paragraph: The "thick fog" which for the last three days has hung over the two great armies now on the south side of the Rappahannock, has been almost equaled by the fogs of doubt and uncertainty which have hung over the mind of New-York,--but through which the narrative of our correspondent published yesterday enabled us to get a good view of the splendid operations of Thursday. The fog continued yesterday both over the armies and over us, though toward evening we got a glimpse of what was going on behind the clouds, in the telegraphic sentence, dated at 11 o'clock, that "the great battle so long anticipated between the two contending armies was then progressing." Up to 1 o'clock this morning, however, we had received nothing additional with which to satisfy the public craving for news.
