abstract: At any other -- time at a time when peace, as of yore, was the condition of the country, and a progressing commerce commanded the admiration of every one -- the fact that the largest vessel ever built lay helpless in the waters which surround New-York, would have exercised the curiosity of our citizens, and every movement toward a restoration of her healthfulness (and, consequently, her returning strength) would have been bulletined and read with the same avidity with which the announcements of the conditions of dying Kings made by their physicians have been received by a loyal people. But as we are not at present enjoying such a condition of State and National affairs, the presence for months of the Great Eastern, seriously injured during her last voyage here, has not created any excitement; neither has there been sufficient curiosity to develop more than a passing paragraph in the newspapers. Recent intelligence from London intimates that unless the present holders of her stock make an advance upon the capital invested, she must pass into other hands; and in the same announcement it is stated that a large sum of money will be required to secure her return to England. It has been stated that she will be in a condition to return in a few days, and, perhaps, she will. Experienced men have been at work upon her ever since she arrived, and they considered their duties nearly fulfilled. Her injuries, in consequence of her great dimensions, were of a much more serious character than they would have been in the case of a smaller ship. On her way here, and while off Montauk Point, the extreme of Long Island, she ran too near the shore and struck ground several times. This caused great damage to a number of her bottom plates -- damage sufficient to have caused her to sink had she not had what is called an outer and an inner skin, which are divided into compartments, each of which are, without injury, water-tight.
lead_paragraph: At any other -- time at a time when peace, as of yore, was the condition of the country, and a progressing commerce commanded the admiration of every one -- the fact that the largest vessel ever built lay helpless in the waters which surround New-York, would have exercised the curiosity of our citizens, and every movement toward a restoration of her healthfulness (and, consequently, her returning strength) would have been bulletined and read with the same avidity with which the announcements of the conditions of dying Kings made by their physicians have been received by a loyal people. But as we are not at present enjoying such a condition of State and National affairs, the presence for months of the Great Eastern, seriously injured during her last voyage here, has not created any excitement; neither has there been sufficient curiosity to develop more than a passing paragraph in the newspapers. Recent intelligence from London intimates that unless the present holders of her stock make an advance upon the capital invested, she must pass into other hands; and in the same announcement it is stated that a large sum of money will be required to secure her return to England. It has been stated that she will be in a condition to return in a few days, and, perhaps, she will. Experienced men have been at work upon her ever since she arrived, and they considered their duties nearly fulfilled. Her injuries, in consequence of her great dimensions, were of a much more serious character than they would have been in the case of a smaller ship. On her way here, and while off Montauk Point, the extreme of Long Island, she ran too near the shore and struck ground several times. This caused great damage to a number of her bottom plates -- damage sufficient to have caused her to sink had she not had what is called an outer and an inner skin, which are divided into compartments, each of which are, without injury, water-tight.

abstract: Mills vs. Sterrills, et al. -- The defendant Sterrills, was engaged in business in Sacramento, California, in 1859, and as alleged, became indebted to the firm of Milliken Bros. of that city, for the sum of $707. In settling their indebtedness Milliken Bros. required Sterills to give them two notes signed by himself and two other parties, as security. Sterrills procured the signatures of the two other defendants in this action, the notes being drawn as joint and several, and they signing as sureties, as they claim, but without adding the word "surety" after their signatures.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Mr. WALSH presented a resolution to give the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G., the sum of $10,000, this corps being the only one entitled to this favor, in pursuance of the resolution adopted by the Common Council last September, guaranteeing $10,000 to each militia regiment that should be reorganized for the war and enter the United States service with eight full companies. The Sixty-ninth have had tencompanies mustered in. The resolution, which was laid over under the rule, proposes to appropriate the money from the "Bounty Fund," which, was raised on the authority of an ordinance, "for the speedy recruitment of troops" for the National army. A veto message of the Mayor, on, the resolution increasing the salaries of the President and other officers of the Croton Department, was read and laid over. The ordinance from the other Board, designed to have the pavement torn up by the new railroad companies replaced by the Croton Department, and appropriating $25,000 for the purpose, was made the special order for the next meeting. Concurrence was had on the resolution directing the Street Commissioner to include in his estimates of appropriations for his Department next year the sum of $5,000 for working One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street, from Broadway to Harlem River, as a country road. The Board adjourned till 5 o'clock P.M. of Monday.

abstract: DEATH OF JUDGE PHILEMON DICKERSON. -- In the death of Hon. PHILEMON DICKERSON, at Paterson, on Wednesday, the 10th inst., New-Jersey has lost one of her ablest and most accomplished jurists. Judge DICKERSON was, at the time of his death, United States Judge for the District of New-Jersey, a post he had filled for some fifteen years with great acceptance, being peculiarly fitted, by his deep researches in the physical sciences, and his rare powers of discrimination, to adjudicate in the large class of patent cases which came within his jurisdiction Judge DICKERSON was formerly Governor and Chancellor of New-Jersey, and also represented the State for four years in Congress. His age was about 75 years. He leaves a son, E.M. DICKERSON, Esq., of New-York, distinguished, like his father, in the examination of patent cases. The death of Judge DICKERSON makes it incumbent upon the President to appoint a successor in the office of District Judge. We learn that a strong effort will be made to obtain the appointment for Essex County, as that county, with a population comprising nearly one-sixth of that of the entire State, has no representation in the Supreme Court or Court of Errors and Appeal which fact has long been a source of great inconvenience to the Bar of that county.
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF JUDGE PHILEMON DICKERSON. -- In the death of Hon. abstract: We trust the statement is correct which Secretary STANTON has allowed to be published right under his nose in Washington, that SIGEL's grand division took up its line of march in the early part of the week, so as to be within supporting distance of the main body of BURNSIDE's army, and that it is by this time in position to co-operate with BURNSIDE. We trust, also, the statement is true which has been published in the Southern newspapers, and telegraphed us from Fortress Monroe, that our large force at Newbern, in North Carolina, has moved up toward Weldon, and that it is to combine with a still larger force, which has left Suffolk to advance upon Petersburg, and from thence close in upon Richmond. Some people suppose that Gen. BANKS did not go much further south than Cape Hatteras, where his vessels, the other day, were reported to have been seen, but that he has already thrown his troops somewhere on the coast of North Carolina or into Virginia, that he also may join in the general movement upon the rebel Capital. We cannot avouch the truth of all these statements and speculations, but the scheme of operations that might be evolved from them is very pretty. If all these columns were combined around Richmond, or into grand cooperating columns on its north and south sides, the force would be over a quarter of a million strong, and if they could carry out, on a large scale, the manoeuvre which Gens. BLUNT and HERRON executed in Arkansas, last Sunday, on a small scale, we might soon expect to see JEFF. DAVIS himself flying to the dismal region of the Boston Mountains. The feasibility of a movement from Suffolk to attack Richmond in the rear, has often been pointed out. If the indications that it is now to be carried out are correct, it must quickly lead to all-important results.

abstract: Owsley, William; ex-Gov. of Kentucky
snippet: Owsley, William; ex-Gov. of Kentucky
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Kentucky, a day or two ago, announced the death, at Dauville, in that State, of Ex.Gov. WILLIAM OWSLEY. At the time of his decease no man living in that State, except Hon. JOHN J. OFITTENDEN, had acted so prominent a part in the his tory of Kentucky as he. As Supreme Judge in 1824 WILLIAM OWSLEY aided in carrying Kentucky through one of the most violent civil commotions that ever convulsed a State, and threatened it with civil war -- not unlike in its incidents, the "Dow rebellion" of Rhode Island. In that healed struggle, FRANCIS P. BLAIR, Sr., and AMOS KENDALL, first came before the world as political controversialists on the side opposed to OWSLEY and his associates. But the Judges triumphed, and with them the Conservative Constitutional Party, that with HENRY CLAY at its head, so long ruled the State. Their defeated opponents were cared for by the Jackson Administration as soon as it was installed at Washington in 1828.

abstract: Editorial on how value of gold has been affected since its removal as lawful currency because of war; Editorial on how value of gold has been affected since its removal as lawful currency because of war
snippet: Editorial on how value of gold has been affected since its removal as lawful currency because of war; Editorial on how value of gold has been affected since its removal as lawful currency because of war
lead_paragraph: The change in the lawful Currency of the country, last Winter, under Government authority, was brought about by the previous suspension of payments in Specie by the Banks. It was one of the absolute necessities of the War, besides being the proper and timely exercise of the National power to regulate Commerce and the Currency. The Act, of course, practically converted the Gold and Silver in circulation, previous to the Bank suspension, into mere articles of traffic or merchandise. They were no longer required in the settlement of ordinary domestic debts. Congress, however, very wisely pledged the public faith to the continued payment of Gold for the semi-annually accruing interest on the Public Debt of the United States, of all classes and descriptions. The amounts necessary to meet this important requisition, were levied upon the Foreign Import trade, by stipulating that all Customs Duties must be paid in Gold after the issue of United States Notes of July 17, 1861, which bear upon their face a recievability for all public dues, is exhausted. This period is now very near at hand. The subsequent receipts in Gold, exclusively from Customs, will greatly exceed the Public Interest accruing after February next. Already the Treasury has negotiated, without trouble, for a loan of Gold to pay the January interest, something less than $4,000,000, in anticipation of the Spring revenues from the Custom-house, and after the reimbursement of this loan, there will be no question of the ability of the Customs Duties to bear the Interest charge upon the entire. Public Debt, taxing the extreme total to which it is estimated by the Secretary it may reach, if the war be continued for the ensuing year and a half. The mercantile demand for Gold for this object, after it sets in, will be both gradual in its nature and comparatively moderate in amount. And the whole will at once return to the market through the periodical disbursements on the Public Interest, these being well distributed at present through nearly the entire twelve months.

abstract: Minnesota Bishop states the Sioux case, lr
snippet: Minnesota Bishop states the Sioux case, lr
lead_paragraph: Bishop WHIPPLE, of Minnesota, has addressed an able and earnest letter to the editor of the St. Paul Pioneer, on the subject of the late Indian massacres in that State, and the condemnation of three hundred of the savages to be hung for the murders committed. It does not seem to be the object of the Bishop to ask mercy for the murderers. He says; "There is no man who does not feel that the savages who have committed these deeds of violence must meet their doom. The law of God and man alike require it. The stern necessities of self-protection demand it. If our own inefficient system had not permitted the Spirit Lake murderers to go unpunished -- if we had not refused to regard them as subjects of law -- we should not have suffered as we have in this outbreak."
headline: {'main': 'THE CASE OF THE SIOUX INDIANS.; Interesting Letter from Bishop Whipple in Regard to them.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CASE OF THE SIOUX INDIANS.; Interesting Letter from Bishop Whipple in Regard to them.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: speaks, Boston, on Emancipation Proclamation; Phillips again speaks on war, Boston
snippet: speaks, Boston, on Emancipation Proclamation; Phillips again speaks on war, Boston
lead_paragraph: The tenth lecture of the Fraternity Course was delivered last evening before a large audience by WENDELL PHILLIPS. The lecturer was received with applause, and said that although be had spoken quite often, recently, on the although of the rebellion, he should not apologize for taking the same topic for this lecture, since he had never found audiences either this winter or last, who had listened cheerfully to any other subject. He would occupy the time in speaking of the proclamation and the message of the President. The message belonged to the past, the proclamation to the present and future; the message was a word, the proclamation a blow; the message was a bugle to summon the camp to surrender, the proclamation a mine whose explosion would scatter the camp into the air, and carry death and confusion to our enemies; the message was like the address of our fathers to the tyrants of Great Britain in 1774, the proclamation was the Declaration of Independence on the fourth of July. 1776. [Applause.] The dictates of history would accord to ABRAHAM LINCOLN honor or affix a stigma to his name, but when his acts were done the people would experience their practical results in the same proportion with him. The future and the prosperity of the nation was ours as well as his. No public officer could complain that his acts were criticised. "Paint me as I am. with every seam and every wrinkle," said CROMWELL to Sir CHRISTOPHER NEELY, "or you get not a penny from me." So we had a right to scrutinize every action in the rebellion, and no man had a right to complain if his conduct was looked into or his services refused. One great weakness overhung our great national effort. It was concession, compromise, conciliation. In '87 our fathers made compromise to a wicked and unjust institution, but this was no reason why it should hold its own now. Loaded dice never gained a fortune in spite of me skill of the gambler. The Southerner found that although the Constitution was on his side, he had no chance in the right against free speech and free labor. He demanded something beyond, and he received it. The North had never begun any resistance until the 22d of September, 1862. As an instance of the feeling which once existed in Massachusetts, he spoke of SAMUEL DEXTER, who had offered in the House of Representatives an amendment to the hill of Mr. JACKSON, of Georgia, that no person should be admitted, us a citizen of the United States until he had renounced all patents of nobility, a clause that no man should be admitted who owned slaves. For this he was defeated in this State at the next election. Men had fought with their hands tied by the well-understood agreement that Slavery was not to be interfered with, but liberty must take its chance. CALHUON came into the Senate and WEBSTER replied to him with his feet tied by compromises to the Constitution, and his hands fettered by the interests of State-street. The lecturer then went on to speak of further points in the history of Slavery. He then declared his intention or speaking of President LINCOLN, although his purpose, he said, was not to blame him. It was as well to remember the saying of HORACE MANN that the difficulties which reformers had to meet, was that God could wait and men could not, and also the fine words of VICTOR EMANUEL, that it was wiser and braver to wait at the fitting time than to dare. The excuse, the palliation, the justification which lie under these maxims belongs to the President. We must be governed by the old proverb, "never praise the day till evening." It might be asked how could ABRAHAM LINCOLN succeed when he was chosen President of the United States by a party who were half-Southern in their feelings. No other man wholly national could have been chosen. Unless the Republicans had yielded half way to the convictions of the South, they never could have carried the election. Mr. PHILLIPS here left Mr. LINCOLN, and proceeded to speak of the reason why foreign minds had been prejudiced against us. It was our own fault, and was owing to the lenient view which we had all along taken of Slavery, and was the result of the conversation of Americans who bad been abroad. He then drew illustrations at some length from the history of other countries, and said that what the STUARTS had been to England, centralization to France, the power of the Church in Spain, and division in Italy, Slavery was to our country. He alluded to the conduct of the Republicans in office, which he considered weak and unsatisfactory. They had not been able to rise to the exigencies of the crisis, and in playing debate had lost sight of the death-struggle of the nation. He urged the emancipation of slaves as a war measure. He did not care to talk of the capture of Richmond. Taking Richmond was not like taking Washington. He did not take much stock in the the "on the Richmond" cry. The rebels had an itinerant capital, which they moved at their pleasure from Richmond to Montgomery. Let us set free the two millions slaves, he said. Let us take out the keystone of the Southern arch by raising an army of colored men. The speaker then returned to Mr. LINCOLN, who, he said, was afraid to strike the blow which every boy in Massachusetts would tell him was right. The President was bred in Kentucky, and and had come covered with Kentucky cobwebs, and with his boots clogged with Kentucky soil, which would be known everywhere, whether it traveled to Chicago or to the White House. Around him, too, were group counselors, every one of whom with one exception, avowed himself in favor of conciliating and submission. Let us make a nation of ourselves -- a separation of fifty or a hundred years was better than the Union with even Delaware for a Slave State. Not even a single bitter bondman should poison the air of America. [Applause.] He continued at some length with his animadversions upon the Cabinet, and was particularly bitter against Mr. SEWARD. He would not say that Mr. SEWARD was not honest, although the honesty of a statesman was among the undefined and inexplicable mysteries in which SOUTHEY had classed woman's idea of manly beauty. He would ask, however, if a respectable and wealthy house in this city should place a half idiot at the head of the firm, how long would they probably stand? He hoped Congress would strengthen the President in his resolution. Let them ask him if he had not a proclamation somewhere in his desk which declared that on the 1st of January, 1863, every man should be free. Let then make him swear to stand by that, and then let them agree to follow it up themselves. Let them demand of the President not merely to sound the bugle, but to lead the hosts.

abstract: editorial lauds heroism of soldiers who crossed Rappahannock in small boats under fire
snippet: editorial lauds heroism of soldiers who crossed Rappahannock in small boats under fire
lead_paragraph: Every one who read the [???] account given by our Virginia correspondent, yesterday, of the unsurpassed coolness and valor displayed by the "forlorn hope" of 400 men, who crossed the Rappahannock in small boats, in face of the fire of the rebel sharpshooters, and drove them pellmell through Fredericksburgh, must have felt that these were heroes who, indeed, merited the recognition of their country. From the moment that the men of the Seventh Michigan sprang from their crouching places behind the rocks on the north bank of the river, and rushing for the pontoon boats, pushed them into the water, and leapt into them, all the time under the enemy's fire -- through that solemn scene when the first boat-load of gallant fellows pushed off amid the crack! crack! of a hundred rebel rifles, followed quickly by another and another boat-load, up to the moment when, rushing from their boats, amid the applauding shouts of our army which was watching them, they swept up the hill, on the further side of the river, and, musket in hand, fell upon the skulking rebels and killed, captured, or chased them all from their lurking places -- everything through the whole affair was as fine as ever was anything in military history.
headline: {'main': 'HONORS TO HEROES.--', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HONORS TO HEROES.--', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We received yesterday, in time for publication in our latest afternoon edition, a dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, stating that a great battle had commenced south of the Rappahannock. Gen. REYNOLDS' Corps, on the left, advanced at an early hour, and at 9 1/4 o'clock engaged the enemy's infantry, and seven minutes afterwards the rebels opened a heavy fire of artillery, which had continued until the time the dispatch was transmitted -- 11 o'clock. Our heavy guns answered quickly, but the firing on both sides was necessarily much at random, as a fog obscured almost everything from view. Not much infantry had then become engaged, and results were unknown. No other dispatches had been received by us up to 1 o'clock this morning.
lead_paragraph: We received yesterday, in time for publication in our latest afternoon edition, a dispatch from the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, stating that a great battle had commenced south of the Rappahannock. abstract: The Proclamation of Emancipation was, at the outset, loudly decried by its opponents as utterly futile and nugatory. The earnestness and zeal with which they proclaimed that it was only a "Pope's Bull against the Comet," was always suspicious. One could not help
lead_paragraph: The Proclamation of Emancipation was, at the outset, loudly decried by its opponents as utterly futile and nugatory. The earnestness and zeal with which they proclaimed that it was only a "Pope's Bull against the Comet," was always suspicious. One could not help asking why they were so much disturbed by it, if it was indeed the impotent menace which they declared it to be. As the day of its operation approaches, however, we fancy that this idea is pretty generally abandoned, if, indeed, there ever were any persons well informed on the subject who honestly held it. If there are people who still hold it, we commend to their consideration a recent article in the Louisville Journal, urging upon the colored preachers in Kentucky "to set themselves to work earnestly, zealously, and energetically," to explain to their people (the slaves of Kentucky) that the Proclamation has no application to them.

abstract: --The most extraordinary conversion on record, perhaps, is that of the Bishop of Natal. We do not know that ever before in the history of the Church a missionary has been converted by the natives who were the objects of his mission, or won over by them to open and avowed disbelief of any portion of the Book he was sent to preach.
lead_paragraph: --The most extraordinary conversion on record, perhaps, is that of the Bishop of Natal. We do not know that ever before in the history of the Church a missionary has been converted by the natives who were the objects of his mission, or won over by them to open and avowed disbelief of any portion of the Book he was sent to preach Bishop COLENSO, we apprehend, furnishes the first instance of the kind. The natives of his diocese, it seems, turned the tables on him completely, and succeeded in shaking his faith in Moses and the Prophets to its very foundation. Abandoning his mission to the Zulus for the moment, the good Bishop is now turning his attention to his own countrymen, for whose benefit he has written a book on the Pentateuch and the Book of Joshua a book calculated to do more injury to the Christian religion than all that ever TOM PAINE thought for VOLTAIRE wrote. Heretofore the Church has suffered only from blows dealt from without; now one of its heads, speaking from the sanctuary and clothed in his official robes, grasps at one of its pillars and shakes it to the peril of the whole fabric.

abstract: THE LAST NEW-YORK HOMICIDE.--The investigation in this case was concluded, on Friday, at the office of Coroner NoRRIS. The proprietor of the lagerbier saloon, which was burned down, delivered himself up to Detective VAN WAGNER, and was brought before the Coroner. He was placed on the witness'...
lead_paragraph: THE LAST NEW-YORK HOMICIDE.--The investigation in this case was concluded, on Friday, at the office of Coroner NoRRIS. The proprietor of the lagerbier saloon, which was burned down, delivered himself up to Detective VAN WAGNER, and was brought before the Coroner. He was placed on the witness' stand, and testified in regard to the transaction which resulted in the death of WM. STELFAX, of the Forty-ninth Massachusetts Regiment, and the burning of the building which he occupied. His evidence was corroborative of that given by ADOLPHI HILDEBRAND, on the first day of the inquest, with the addition that the soldiers attacked the house and broke in the doors. He did not know who [???] the musket which resulted in the death of STELFAX. The case being given to the jury, the following verdict was rendered: "That the said WILLIAM STELFAX came to his death by gunshot wounds, but are unable to say who the person was who perpetrated the act. They deem it their duty to censure the officers of the military camp at East New-York and vicinity for permitting so much liberty to the men under their command. There is a looseness of discipline quite deplorable noticed among them." GEORGE SCHEILLEIN, the proprietor of the saloon, was relieved from custody.

abstract: Editorial calls movement in NYC to raise money for needy in France unnecessary
snippet: Editorial calls movement in NYC to raise money for needy in France unnecessary
lead_paragraph: Wherever inthe wide world there is a human being famished, naked or uncomfortable, we would at once, were it in our power, have him fed, clad and comforted. We would not only furnish moral pocket handkerchiefs to the naked heathen in Africa, and dish up for the Greenlanders a superior article of blubber, but wherever from China to Peru, from the Sicilies to the Hebrides, there is an individual with a legitimate want unsatisfied, we would have proper means taken to satisfy it.

abstract: NEW-JERSEY TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION-- Much good to the cause of education has been effected in New-Jersey, as well as in other States, by means of the State and County Teachers' Associations, at the meetings of which the views and experience of those engaged in teaching are Interchanged, and by the
lead_paragraph: NEW-JERSEY TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION-- Much good to the cause of education has been effected in New-Jersey, as well as in other States, by means of the State and County Teachers' Associations, at the meetings of which the views and experience of those engaged in teaching are Interchanged, and by the operation of many minds looking to a common end, a more enlightened and harmonious system of teaching is secured than could otherwise be hoped for. The next annual meeting of the State Teachers' Association of New-Jersey will be held at Bridgton, beginning on Monday, the 29th inst., and continuing until the 31st. Among the subjects which will be brought before the Association will be "Nornal Schools," "The School Laws of New-Jersey," "Report of Prof. PHELPS, Principal of the State Normal School, upon the Course of Study best Suited to the Objects of the Public Schools of the State," "Object Teaching," &c. Preparations will be made by the citizens of Bridgton to entertain strangers, and it is expected the meeting will be one of unusual interest.

abstract: MCGOWAN ON JAPAN. -- Dr. MCGOWAN, the recognized authority in Chinese and Japanese affairs, is about to deliver a course of lectures on Japan and its Customs. The Doctor's long official residence in Japan, and his thorough knowledge of everything pertaining to its private habits and public customs, afford him the very best material for a lecture both instructive and entertaining. The first lecture will be given to-night at Stuyvesant Institute, No. 659 Broadway.

abstract: The preliminary examination before Judge McCUNN in the case of Dr. BROWN, charged with procuring an abortion upon Miss ANDERSON, and thereby causing her death, was concluded on Saturday. Dr. BROWN was present, but appeared to take little interest in the proceeding. The examination was
lead_paragraph: The preliminary examination before Judge McCUNN in the case of Dr. BROWN, charged with procuring an abortion upon Miss ANDERSON, and thereby causing her death, was concluded on Saturday. Dr. BROWN was present, but appeared to take little interest in the proceeding. The examination was conducted by Mr. H.L. CLINTON, counsel for Dr. BROWN, and was confined to the medical men who attended the post-mortem examination and testified at the Coroner's inquest. The object appeared to be to show that the death of Miss ANDERSON was not necessarily caused by an abortion, or indeed that there was any positive evidence that an abortion had been procured. The first witness was Dr. THOS. C. FINNELL, who made the second post-mortem examination, and who gave his evidence in a remarkably clear, prompt and intelligent manner. The details are not proper for publication, but the substance of his testimony was that the post-mortem developed evidences of an abortion having been produced, in the altered condition of the womb, the intense congestion of the parts, and the abscesses that had formed as a result of the inflammation. The immediate cause of death, he said, was pymenia, or poisoning of the blood, resulting from the abscesses which were superinduced by the inflammation. The fact that the deceased had been pregnant was also shown by the enlarged breasts, the areola, and the enlarged glands upon its surface. He described a large number of instruments which were shown to him at the Station-house, as belonging to Dr. BROWN, most of which he said were not such as are ordinarily used by physicians and surgeons in their regular and legitimate practice. The post-mortem was conducted in the presence of Drs. Ranney, Tucke, Connolly, Galen Lieutenant [???].

abstract: General HALLECK has announced, either twelve or fourteen time, that desertion from the Union Army is not permissible. If he continues to reiterate this statement long enough, there is hardly a doubt, that some of the twenty thousand men and officers who are now said to be absent without leave,
lead_paragraph: General HALLECK has announced, either twelve or fourteen time, that desertion from the Union Army is not permissible. If he continues to reiterate this statement long enough, there is hardly a doubt, that some of the twenty thousand men and officers who are now said to be absent without leave, will finally get indoctrinated with the notion that quitting the army without the knowledge of their superiors is an objectionable practice. But that his weekly denunciation of it through the newspapers will put a stop to it, there is not the least probability. He has as yet given no indication of any intention of punishing it in any way beyond striking the names of offenders amongst the officers from the army list. Upon the officers this will doubtless produce some effect. Some of the absentees will be stimulated by it into joining their regiments, and some who intended to become absentees whenever the opportunity offered, will be deterred by it into resigning themselves to the performance of their duty. But that the country will gain by the infliction of this penalty we greatly doubt. Any officer who needs to be threatened in this manner in order to keep him at his post, is, in nine cases out of ten, unfit for it, and would benefit the service by quitting it. If he has so little zeal and so little pride, and so little love of the work and of the cause, that nothing but the fear of losing his commission prevents him from abandoning his regiment, the regiment is sure to be better without him; and any order which simply calls him back, after a month or two or three of disgraceful shirking, and puts him in his old place with credit unimpaired, reputation untarnished and pay untouched, is an injury both to the army and the country.
headline: {'main': 'The Evil of Desertion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Evil of Desertion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: By the arrival yesterday of the steamship Champion, we have advices from the Isthmus of Panama to the 5th inst. The treasure list of the steamer foots up nearly $700,000. There is no later news from Central or South America. Quiet prevails in Panama. A large fleet of war vessels was in the harbor -- four French, four United States and one British. The loss or dismantling of the Bainbridge, during the recent gale at Aspinwall, leaves our Government without any naval representative on this side of the Isthmus. The flood along the railroad track had subsided, and travel had been resumed.

abstract: ATTEMPT TO BURN DOWN THE OLD LUNATIC ASYLUM--An attempt was made on Friday night last to burn down the old Lunatic Asylum in the town of Flatbush. The building is now occupied by the Fifty-second Regiment, New-York State Militia, as a barracks, and it appears that it was set on fire by some
lead_paragraph: ATTEMPT TO BURN DOWN THE OLD LUNATIC ASYLUM--An attempt was made on Friday night last to burn down the old Lunatic Asylum in the town of Flatbush. The building is now occupied by the Fifty-second Regiment, New-York State Militia, as a barracks, and it appears that it was set on fire by some of the soldiers so as to enable all who desired to escape in the confusion. The discovery was made in time by the officers to enable them to suppress the rising flames. Two recruits, named WALTER HAWKINS and THOMAS DICKSON, were arrested by Officers BEASLEY and GREGORY, of the Ninth Ward Police, upon the complaint of Lieut.-Col. WM. C. BOOTH, who charges them with having set the place on fire.

abstract: Sir: Permit me a few remarks, by way of rejoinder to your strictures upon my letter of the 5th last. In that letter 1 fully admitted the personal benevolence and kindly feeling evinced by the contributors at the Chamber of Commerce ;but, bearing in mind the state of public feeling between the two countries, I was anxious to enter my protest against
lead_paragraph: Sir: Permit me a few remarks, by way of rejoinder to your strictures upon my letter of the 5th last. In that letter 1 fully admitted the personal benevolence and kindly feeling evinced by the contributors at the Chamber of Commerce ;but, bearing in mind the state of public feeling between the two countries, I was anxious to enter my protest against any aid being given in the spirit of "heaping coals of [???]" upon the head of Great Britain, particularly as no appeal had been made to the United States, and as England was not only both able and willing to meet the emergency, but was meeting it in the most ample and vigorous manner. While we are told that "he that hath pity upon the poor, lendeth unto the Lord," we are also told, "when thou doest thine alms do not sound a trumpet before thee as the hypocrites do, that they may have glory of men." How far the Rev. T.L. CUYLER, yourself, and some of your cotemporaries have acted in the spirit of these admonitions, we now know, and duly appreciate. Consistent inconsistency, however, bas so long characterized the New-York Press, and many of your public men, in their effusions against England, that possibly I may be thought unseasonable in looking for a change, and yet one is almost indicated from your remarks that "we do not propose to feed the London Times, nor Lord JOHN RUSSELL, nor Mr. GLADSTONE, nor the selfish and treacherous men who are now building piratical vessels to destroy American commerce, and we do not care whether they feel offended or not, provided their poor fellow-countrymen are SAVED BY-US from starvation."

abstract: We
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a notice from the Postmaster of this City, that the redemption of postage stamps which have been used for currency, and no others, while command to-day, and be continued thirty days, and no longer. Mr. WAKEMAN states very clearly and distinctly the rules which must be rigidly observed in presenting these stamps for redemption. They seem to be, in the main, reasonable and just. We do not quite see how the Department is to determine what stamps have been used for currency, and what have not; -- but its decision in the matter is to be final, -- and it will also reject peremptorily all which, in its judgment, have been used for the prepayment of postage.

abstract: Our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac this morning, inform us that the great battle of the was commenced on Saturday, and was continued throughout the day with great pertinacity and much slaughter.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from the Army of the Potomac this morning, inform us that the great battle of the was commenced on Saturday, and was continued throughout the day with great pertinacity and much slaughter. The morning opened with a dense fog, in the midst of which Gen. REYNOLDS' corps, on the left, advanced, and at 9 1/4 o'clock engaged the enemy's infantry. Seven minutes afterward the rebels opened a heavy fire of artillery, which was responded to by our batteries' though the firing was necessarily much at random, owing to the fog. This, however, soon afterward cleared away, and an unobstructed view of the rebel position could be had. It was determined that the first ridge of hills occupied by the enemy's works must be carried by assault, and this duty was assigned to Gen. FRENCH's Division, supported by Gen. HOWARD's. At ten minutes before noon our troops advanced to the works, but when within musket range, were met with such a terrible fire of musketry that they were forced to fall back. Reinforced, they again essayed the task, but were again driven back by the terrible fire of artillery and musketry now concentrated upon them. The firing was then continued at longer range until after dark, no other attempt being made to storm. On the left, where the attack was commanded by Gen. FRANKLIN, our troops were more successful. After a hard day's fight the Rebels were driven back about a mile, with heavy losses. At one time the enemy advanced to attack, but were handsomely repulsed, with the loss of between four and five hundred prisoners. Our troops slept at night where they fought during the day. Our losses were severe, including Gens. JACKSON and BAYARD of Pennsylvania, killed, and Gens. VINTON, GIBBONS, KIMBALL and CALDWELL, wounded, besides numerous line-officers killed and wounded. Yesterday there was no fog. At daylight there was a heavy fire of artillery and infantry in front of the first line of works, and also in front of Gen. FRANKLIN's Division, down the river, but it slackened in about an hour, and continued only at intervals until noon; and the indications were that no decisive battle would be fought on that day, unless the rebels should bring on the engagement. During the night and forenoon they considerably extended their works, and strengthened their position. Our wounded were all removed from the field and cared for, but the dead who fell near the enemy's works, still remain upon the field, the rebels firing upon all who attempted their removal during the night.

abstract: Mr. GRAU's season of Italian opera came to an end on Saturday, when there was a capital attendance at the Academy, to enjoy an excellent morning performance of " Un Ballo in Maschera" We need scarcely remind our readers that the impresario has more than fulfilled his promises to the public. The season originally announced was of ten nights only. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather which
lead_paragraph: Mr. GRAU's season of Italian opera came to an end on Saturday, when there was a capital attendance at the Academy, to enjoy an excellent morning performance of " Un Ballo in Maschera" We need scarcely remind our readers that the impresario has more than fulfilled his promises to the public. The season originally announced was of ten nights only. Notwithstanding the unfavorable weather which has, of course, materially interfered with the prosperity of the enterprise, Mr. GRAU has given nineteen opera nights and three matinies, playing during that time no fewer than ten operas, namely: "La Traviata," "Il Trovatore," "Norma," "Dinorah," "La Figlia del Reggimento," "Lucrezia Borgia," "La Favorita," "Un Ballo in Maschera," "Ernani," and (to-night) "I Puritani." When it is remembered that the management was in a way thrust upon Mr. GRAU, and that he had at a moment's notice to form a company from material that had been wrecked on our shore by Mr. ULLMAN, it will, we think, be conceded that this is doing pretty well. The season, in point of female artists, has been unusually interesting, no fewer than four prime donne -- GUERRABELLA, LORINI, CORDIER and MORENSI -- having appeared. Mr. GRAU's efforts are always well patronized by the public. On the present occasion they seem to have been appreciated by the artists. It will be seen by the following letter that riches are in store for Mr. GRAU:

abstract: A short time
lead_paragraph: A short time since a very considerable military force, not less than six regiments, it is supposed, steamed out of Hampton Roads and directed their course to a Southern port not very far distant. We have direct and authentic information from Newbern, N.C., very recent in date, to the effect that the entire force there, (and it is larger by some thousands than it was,) is about to move under Gen. FOSTER, "upon the enemy's works," wherever those works may be. The same information, slightly magnified, is conveyed in the extracts from Southern newspapers, which we receive by telegraph from Fortress Monroe, this morning.

abstract: The action of Saturday is evidently to be classed with the great battles of the war. The whole of the Richmond Rebel Army seems to have been in the field, though, we are sorry to say, it does not appear that it
lead_paragraph: The action of Saturday is evidently to be classed with the great battles of the war. The whole of the Richmond Rebel Army seems to have been in the field, though, we are sorry to say, it does not appear that it was opposed by the whole of the "Army of the Potomac." We hardly know of an outlying division of the rebel force in Virginia. All had been gathered in from the Shenandoah Valley and from the country East of the Blue Ridge -- they had been brought from Gordonsville, from Richmond and the peninsula leading up to it, from the regions on the South bank of the James, from the North Carolina coast, and from all the points for a hundred miles around Richmond occupied against the menaces of Union columns. There were very good facilities for this; for though there is but a single line of railroad running into Fredericksburgh, yet at the junction forty miles below that place the whole railroad systems of the South and West converge. We do not credit the assertion of the telegraph that they had two hundred thousand men on the field; but even a half of that force, posted in such formidable positions as they held, was an army that certainly should not have been met with less than its own strength. Of the rebel Generals, LEE, JACKSON, LONGSTREET and the HILLS, appear all to have been on hand.

abstract: Gen. McClellan returned to this City on Friday evening last, at a very late hour. He was recognized upon his arrival at the Jersey City Depot by the crowd, who manifested their appreciation of his presence by vociferous cheering.
lead_paragraph: Gen. McClellan returned to this City on Friday evening last, at a very late hour. He was recognized upon his arrival at the Jersey City Depot by the crowd, who manifested their appreciation of his presence by vociferous cheering. The General acknowledged the recognition in a quiet manner, after which he proceeded across the river to Cortlandt-street, and was driven directly to the Fifth-avenue Hotel. He was accompanied home by Lieut.-Col. Hudson, one of the members of his Staff.

abstract: Editorial on Lee's non-defense of Rappahannock in allowing Union forces to cross and his preference for ridges as more defensible line; traces great battles in history fought in dispute over a river
snippet: Editorial on Lee's non-defense of Rappahannock in allowing Union forces to cross and his preference for ridges as more defensible line; traces great battles in history fought in dispute over a river
lead_paragraph: Much astonishment has been expressed in some quarters that LEE did not interpose a more serious resistance to BURNSIDE'S crossing of the Rappahannock. Save the covert efforts of a few hundred sharpshooters, and the occasional firing of a few batteries, he kept his great army absolutely idle during the twenty-four hours occupied in the construction of the bridges and the passage of our troops. It cannot be said that he was taken by surprise, or in anywise deceived by stratagem. The operation was mainly performed with great deliberation in his full view, and without any special natural advantages on the side of his foe.

abstract: There being noth  ing particulariy interesting going on in the vicinity of Richmond at the present time, we see JEFF. DAVIS has taken the opportunity of paying a flying visit to the West. He made a speech at Knoxville, Tenn.,
lead_paragraph: There being noth ing particulariy interesting going on in the vicinity of Richmond at the present time, we see JEFF. DAVIS has taken the opportunity of paying a flying visit to the West. He made a speech at Knoxville, Tenn., last Thursday, in which he expressed the opinion that the "toryism" (Unionism) of East Tennessee is "exaggerated." If Parson BROWNLOW could only have been permitted to be present and answer him, we think the rebel chief would have got an "exaggerated" idea of the Unionism left in that part of the Confederacy. What was lacking in numbers would have been fully made up in the intensity of the patriotic sentiment of the crushed loyalists.

abstract: An evening paper gave currency last night to a most cruel and false statement concerning JOHN DEAN and his wife nee Bona. The case is not as stated by the paper referred to. The couple are living happily together in a neighboring city. Mr. DEAN's income is larger than that of the individual who wrote the fiction. Mrs. DEAN, as Lady Inspector of the Customs, adds revenue to their mutual purse, and if the public Press will not interfere with their cheerful home, they will need nothing further at its hands.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the annual inspection of the First Regiment National Guard, Newark Brigade, took place at Newark, under the orders of Brig.-Gen. RONYON. The regiment, owing to the large number of its officers and men who have gone to the war, was able to muster but five companies, numbering altogether but 147 men, presenting a melancholy contrast to the full and gallant array they were wont to exhibit in other years. The regiment was under the command of Col. PECKWELL, the inspection being performed by Brigade-Inspector Maj. OLDS. We learn that an effort is being made by the regiment to induce the city to take the old malleable iron foundry, in Nesbitt-street, and fit it up as a drill-room, it being very spacious and well adapted for the purpose.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The season ended here last night with a bumping house for Mr. GRAU, whose benefit it was, and a bumping programme for the public, who, in this respect, also had a benefit. The performances opened with an act of "Ernani," followed
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The season ended here last night with a bumping house for Mr. GRAU, whose benefit it was, and a bumping programme for the public, who, in this respect, also had a benefit. The performances opened with an act of "Ernani," followed by the entire opera of "I Puritani," and succeeded by a new anthem. As if this were not sufficient, the audience, which was unusually brilliant and lively, insisted on encoring almost every well-known morceau. The performances concluded at so late an hour that we are compelled to defer any further notice of them until another opportunity. We may congratulate Mr. GRAU on the satisfactory conclusion of the season, and hope that he may not be less fortunate in Philadelphia, whither he is bound.
headline: {'main': 'Amusements.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Amusements.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, petitions were presented in favor of a General Bankrupt Law, and protesting against the action of the Advisory Board of the Navy. The bill to abolish the grade of Medical officers was reported back from the Military Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass. A bill to amend the Tariff and the Confiscations acts was introduced by Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and referred. A bill to provide for the extinction of the Indian titles in Kansas, and to provide for the removal of the Indians, was introduced by Mr. LANE. A resolution was adopted, calling for the report and accompanying documents of Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, as Commissioner at New-Orleans. A resolution of censure against Ex-President BUCHANAN, for his failure to prevent the rebellion, was introduced by Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, and laid over. A resolution to inquire whether some method cannot be devised to manifest the sympathy of Congress with the suffering Lancashire operatives, was ordered to be printed. The Judiciary Committee was instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing that any loyal citizen who has sustained damage from the troops of the States engaged in the rebellion, may set off such damages against any claim or demand against him in any action at law by any such rebellious States, or the agents or trustees of such States, etc. The resolution relative to the arrest of certain citizens of Delaware, was then debated until the adjournment.

abstract: The City Inspector reports that 351 persons died in New-York last week; 84 men, 77 women, 112 boys and 78 girls -- an increase of 31 upon the mortality of the previous week, and a decrease of 50 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1861. Of the deceased, 170 were children under five years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 46; croup, 38; diphtherite, 17; infantile convulsions, 17; inflammation of the brain, 16; infantile marasmus, 15; scarlet fever, 13; dropsy in the head, 10; inflammation of the bowels, 8; disease of the heart, 6; death from external causes, 35; among which are reported 6 premature births; I suicide; 1 drowned; 8 killed by accidents. There were 28 interments in Potter's Field, and 32 deaths in the Institutions.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES. is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and marketreports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: We take it for granted that Count MEJAN, whilom French Consul at New-Orleans, has been permitted by our Government to withdraw from the Consular service at that port, although we do not remember to have seen any public announcement of the fact.
lead_paragraph: We take it for granted that Count MEJAN, whilom French Consul at New-Orleans, has been permitted by our Government to withdraw from the Consular service at that port, although we do not remember to have seen any public announcement of the fact. From the day of Gen. BUTLER's capture of that rebel city, the Count found his position extremely disagreeable. Many things that he had previously been in the habit of doing -- such as manifesting his intense sympathy with the rebellion -- he found no longer practicable. If it had only been no longer politic, he could have got along with the difficulty. But Gen. BUTLER was a rude and vulgar man, who regarded treason as a mortal State offence, who held the robbery of mints and arsenals of the Government to be a terrible crime, and who consequently had not the slightest consideration for the more refined and educated principles of Count MEJAN, who, while deriving the right to exercise his office from the American Government, thought it not amiss to encourage and aid the traitors who were aiming to destroy it. Gen. BUTLER would not allow this. Hence the Count was mad. Nay, more, he was vexed -- indeed angry -- and resolved to have Gen. Butler removed! It was a big contract -- as well as a modest one -- but the Count thought himself equal to it, as a letter of his, written on the 30th of May last to M. THOUVENEL, sufficiently proves.
headline: {'main': 'A French Count.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A French Count.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gotlieb Kunz vs. Robert L. Stuart and Alex. Stuart.--This was an action by the plaintiff to recover of the defendants for personal injuries sustained, as alleged, while in their employ, under the following ...
lead_paragraph: Gotlieb Kunz vs. Robert L. Stuart and Alex. Stuart.--This was an action by the plaintiff to recover of the defendants for personal injuries sustained, as alleged, while in their employ, under the following circumstances: The plaintiff was a workman employed in the fill-house of the defendants' sugar refinery, and a part of his duty was to hook on loaded wagons containing full sugar moulds, to be hoisted to an upper story, and to unhook empty wagons lowered from above. These wagons were usually of wrought-iron.

abstract: -- Though there were, of course, a few persons in town yesterday who croaked lugubriously after they had read the published news of Saturday's operations at Fredericksburgh, the City in general had a wonderfully cheerful, strong, firm feeling. The croakers found it hard work to convince any one that we had met with any serious repulse. There was no such feeling in the atmosphere as always pervades it after disaster -- none such as there was after MCCLELLAN's retreat from the Chickahominy, or after POPE's fiasco. Nobody had his confidence in BURNSIDE shaken; no one doubted the speedy success of the campaign of the Rappahannock. The knowledge seemed to be instinctive that the repulse of SUMNER's Division was but a temporary and insignificant incident, that our force had not been at all called out or tested, and that the effort of Saturday, brave and great though it was. was nothing more than preliminary to the general contest that would soon open. The fact was clearly apprehended that We had immense forces which had not been called into action, and that the Winter campaign of the army included something more than an assault on the enemy's front. All these things contributed to the firm and cheerful feeling we have noted; and though there could be no exultation as over a victory, there was a perfect confidence in our army, in its leader, in the success of his campaign, and the pending route of the rebels and capture of Richmond.
lead_paragraph: -- Though there were, of course, a few persons in town yesterday who croaked lugubriously after they had read the published news of Saturday's operations at Fredericksburgh, the City in general had a wonderfully cheerful, strong, firm feeling. The croakers found it hard work to convince any one that we had met with any serious repulse. There was no such feeling in the atmosphere as always pervades it after disaster -- none such as there was after MCCLELLAN's retreat from the Chickahominy, or after POPE's fiasco. Nobody had his confidence in BURNSIDE shaken; no one doubted the speedy success of the campaign of the Rappahannock. The knowledge seemed to be instinctive that the repulse of SUMNER's Division was but a temporary and insignificant incident, that our force had not been at all called out or tested, and that the effort of Saturday, brave and great though it was. was nothing more than preliminary to the general contest that would soon open. The fact was clearly apprehended that We had immense forces which had not been called into action, and that the Winter campaign of the army included something more than an assault on the enemy's front. All these things contributed to the firm and cheerful feeling we have noted; and though there could be no exultation as over a victory, there was a perfect confidence in our army, in its leader, in the success of his campaign, and the pending route of the rebels and capture of Richmond.

abstract: A meeting of the Tammany Society was held last evening, at the Old Wigwam, for the purpose of receiving the banner of the Tammany Regiment, that floated in many battle-fields, from Ball's Bluff, the Peninsula, and the whole campaign. Capt. DOWNING, of the Forty-second (Tammany) Regiment, was the honored bearer of this relic to the fathers of the regiment. After the meeting was organized, and the warriors arrayed in their regallas, a Committee of Three was appointed, consisting of Hon. ELIJAH F. PURDY, J.M. MARSH and Sheriff LYNCH, to conduct the gallant Captain, accompanied by Capt. JAMES MCGRATH, J.W. TOBIN and Lieut. M. DOHENY, to the Great Wigwam, where the gallant defenders of Tammany's banner were received with vociferous applause. Addresses of welcome were made by the Grand Sachem, Hon. NELSON J. WATERBURY, on behalf of the Tammany Society, and responded to by Capt. DOWNING, in a modest manner. As this flag has seen service in the whole campaign, and carried by the decimated ranks of this brave regiment at the battles of South Mountain and Antietam, without being captured by the enemy, but always leading on the gallant boys, the Society has voted to place it in sate custody with the other relics of the ancient Columbian Order of St. Tammany.

abstract: The precise strength of BURNSIDE's army at present, we cannot give; but we know it to be quite safe to say, that if only forty thousand troops took part in the action of Saturday, less than one-fourth of its force was engaged. We do not include in this estimate SIGEL's column, nor BANKS' hypothetical column, but simply the troops under the immediate eye of Gen. BURNSIDE. With SIGEL's force and the force on the Blackwater, we do not suppose that two hundred and fifty thousand would be too high an estimate to make of the numbers of the army now encompassing Richmond. It is the knowledge of these vast numbers, with the perfect belief in their valor, and the confidence that they will be skillfully handled, that gives the public confidence in the success of the Winter campaign.

abstract: If there be any truth whatever in the statement made with such circumstantiality of de tail this morning, that Gen. BANKS has landed with twenty thousand men at Winton, N.C., pushed up to Suffolk, formed a junction with
lead_paragraph: If there be any truth whatever in the statement made with such circumstantiality of de tail this morning, that Gen. BANKS has landed with twenty thousand men at Winton, N.C., pushed up to Suffolk, formed a junction with our troops there, and been joined by Gen. FOSTER's force from Newbern; and that this army is about to march up to Petersburgh, and from there obtain command at once of the James River and the rebel Capital -- then we begin to see now what we have been looking for so long and eagerly -- the development of a plan of campaign against the main rebel army, at once intelligible, comprehensive and hopeful.

abstract: The day following the breaking into the store of Messrs. AUFFMORDT, HESSENDERG  Co., No. 146 Duane-street, and the stealing therefrom of $15,000 worth of silks, Officer RICHARD KING, of the Essex Market Police Court, received information which led him to suspect one GEORGE FOREST, living at No. 76 Forsyth-street, as being implicated in the burglary. FOREST has been previously suspected of such crimes, and the Police have a frequently
lead_paragraph: The day following the breaking into the store of Messrs. AUFFMORDT, HESSENDERG Co., No. 146 Duane-street, and the stealing therefrom of $15,000 worth of silks, Officer RICHARD KING, of the Essex Market Police Court, received information which led him to suspect one GEORGE FOREST, living at No. 76 Forsyth-street, as being implicated in the burglary. FOREST has been previously suspected of such crimes, and the Police have a frequently apprehended him. Mr. KING and Officer WOOD, of the Tenth Precinct, accordingly commenced an investigation, and they soon learned that FOREST and one WM. PETERS had, last Saturday, hired a room in the tenement house, No. 210 Elm-street. Upon searching the apartments the officers discovered remnants of wrappers which had been taken from pieces of silks and partially burned in the grate. After this clue was obtained, the officers went in search of FOREST and PETERS and at lenght they were found, and their every movement watched till yesterday morning, when they were traced to the jewelry establishment of CHARLES JACOBS, No. 181 East Broadway. As they left the house the suspected parties were arrested, and, on searching them, $400 in current funds were found in their possession.

abstract: The public were startled to learn by telegraph yesterday that the army of Gen. BURNSIDE had, under cover of the darkness of Monday night, returned to this side of the river which it had so triumphantly crossed last Thursday and Friday. No one could divine the reason for this movement. If the operations which had been represented as in
lead_paragraph: The public were startled to learn by telegraph yesterday that the army of Gen. BURNSIDE had, under cover of the darkness of Monday night, returned to this side of the river which it had so triumphantly crossed last Thursday and Friday. No one could divine the reason for this movement. If the operations which had been represented as in progress of execution were really going on -- if an army were ready to attack Richmond in the rear -- if the Grand Division of SIGEL were in the very act of effecting a junction with the other three grand divisions at Fredericksburgh -- if the heavy reinforcements which had been sent from Washington and elsewhere, were constantly increasing BURNSIDE's strength -- if the battle of Saturday were only a reconnoissance in force by less than a moiety of BURNSIDE's troops, followed by no disastrous results -- and especially if, as was represented, the battle were on the very eve of being renewed on a more stupendous scale -- why should he bring back his entire army to this side of the Rappahannock, when the successful crossing of that river, four days before, had been held up as one of the greatest achievements of the war? Could it be that there was a hitch somewhere in the carrying out of the plan of operations? Could it be that there was no such plan as the grand one of which we had had intimations, and which had furnished a theme for public eulogy for some days? Could it be that BURNSIDE had learned from his so-called reconnoissance that the enemy's works were too strong to be carried by assault? Was it possible that the accounts we had had by telegraph of Saturday's battle were grossly false, and that our army had suffered a disastrous repulse on that day, instead of meeting with the hopeful degree of success which had encouraged the public. Every one had his own conjecture in the premises. But no one could bode from the movement anything cheerful or hopeful; and the firm and courageous feeling of the previous day was changed into one of depression and gloom.

abstract: editorial laments Banks failure to go to either Fredericksburg or Richmond, where he was most needed
snippet: editorial laments Banks failure to go to either Fredericksburg or Richmond, where he was most needed
lead_paragraph: -- The curiosity of the public in regard to the destination of Gen. BANKS, is still in lively exercise. The interest was cheerful at first -- but since yesterday noon it has grown rapidly and fiercely sardonic. The hope that his picked and formidable force of twenty thousand men would turn up in dangerous contiguity to Richmond -- that it was to play an immediate and important part in the capture of that town, which was down in all the bills for the holidays -- that at least and at farthest it would join in an effective blow at the rebel southern line of communication, North Carolina -- this hope -- these hopes -- have perished; and we fall back exhausted, upon that profound witticism of the Secretary of War, that "BANKS would land in a good place!" Perhaps he will. Galveston Island, on the Texas coast, should be redeemed. It is a good place. Powder-Horn Bay, two hundred miles further on, is also a place much beset by rebels, that deserves Governmental attention. It is "a good place." Brownsville, Texas, covers much contraband trade, and should be looked after by some of our numerous expeditious. It is "a very good place."

abstract: Attorney-General BATES, in a case officially submitted to him, has pronounced that the law confining the command of American coasters to American citizens, does not exclude colored masters. This is equivalent to declaring that black men map be citizens of the United States, and that the dicta to the contrary in the Dred Scott case are incorrect. We say the dicta and not the decision itself.
lead_paragraph: Attorney-General BATES, in a case officially submitted to him, has pronounced that the law confining the command of American coasters to American citizens, does not exclude colored masters. This is equivalent to declaring that black men map be citizens of the United States, and that the dicta to the contrary in the Dred Scott case are incorrect. We say the dicta and not the decision itself. The majority of the Court never decided that colored men cannot be citizens. What they decided was, that the record showed a disability on the part of DRED SCOTT to maintain the suit, because he was no citizen -- nobody but a citizen being allowed to sue in a United States Court. Only three of them, TANEY, WAYNE and DANIEL, held that he was not a citizen for the reason that he was a blackman. The other members of the majority forebore to touch this point, and confined themselves to the argument that SCOTT was no citizen, because the record showed him a slave. MCLEAN and CURTIS held that the record did not so show, and that his being a black man, simply did not make him any the less a citizen. We therefore say that it is not the Dred Scott decision which Attorney-General BATES now contravenes, but the positions of the three Judges, who constituted only a third of the Court.
headline: {'main': 'Attorney-General Bates on the Dred Scott Decision.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Attorney-General Bates on the Dred Scott Decision.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the 27th of last August, when the Great Eastern was endeavoring to make this port by way of the Sound, off Montauk Point she struck on a sunken rock not noted down in any chart, and tore a fracture in her outer skin of such dimensions as to make it doubtful whether she could be trusted in that state on her voyage home. In all probability she could have made the voyage well enough, for her inner skin was untouched, and so long as that is sound the vessel remains perfectly seaworthy.
lead_paragraph: On the 27th of last August, when the Great Eastern was endeavoring to make this port by way of the Sound, off Montauk Point she struck on a sunken rock not noted down in any chart, and tore a fracture in her outer skin of such dimensions as to make it doubtful whether she could be trusted in that state on her voyage home. In all probability she could have made the voyage well enough, for her inner skin was untouched, and so long as that is sound the vessel remains perfectly seaworthy.

abstract: Last evening the Academy of Music was crowded to hear Mr. MASON JONES' new oration on the "European Aspect of the American Rebellion." Mr. JONES is a staunch Union man, and handles the monarchial and aristocratic depotisms of Europe without gloves. The nation most likely to interfere on behalf of the South, is France. NAPOLEON must keep the minds of his subjects employed by causing his large standing army to be actively engaged. When he was elected President of the Republic of France he assasinated Liberty there, and would, no doubt, endeavor to do so here. Mr. SEWARD was too timid in the tone of his dispatches; he must be more firm. Monitors, not Ministers, should be sent in answer to any future attempts at mediation. The whole Southern institutions that have caused this rebellion must be swept away before peace is made, in order to prevent a recurrence. During the lecture Mr. JONES was frequently interrupted by prolonged applause; it will be repeated to-morrow evening.

abstract: One of the most busy departments of the military service just now is that of the Medical Director, Surgeon McDOUGALL. Most of the hospitals under his charge are full, and with the exception of Fort Schuyler, Governor's Island, and a few other smaller hospitals, no more sick and wounded can be accommodated. There are at present over seven thousand under treatment.
lead_paragraph: One of the most busy departments of the military service just now is that of the Medical Director, Surgeon McDOUGALL. Most of the hospitals under his charge are full, and with the exception of Fort Schuyler, Governor's Island, and a few other smaller hospitals, no more sick and wounded can be accommodated. There are at present over seven thousand under treatment. This morning surgeon-General MCDOUGALL received a dispatch from Washington stating that five hundred sick had left that city at 5 o'clock on Monday evening. Not a word was said as to whether they had left by water or rail, and consequently the Director scarcely knows where or when to expect their arrival. He is run down nearly by applicants for discharge, some with and others without the Regimental Surgeon's certificate.

abstract: -- DEFICIENT SUPPLIES OF GOVERNMENT CURRENCY. -- In answer to some inquiries in the TIMES, why the soldiers are not paid, and certain other inquiries to the same effect propounded in Congress, a correspondent in another column makes what is apparently a sufficient response. He alleges that the contractors are not exerting themselves as they might to meet the demand of the Treasury for paper currency, and that until they concentrate all their efforts and machinery upon the Government work the actual evil will continue. The point seems to be a good one, and should command the attention of the Secretary of the Treasury and of Congress. Why should not a Committee of Investigation be appointed?

He alleges that the contractors are not exerting themselves as they might to meet the demand of the Treasury for paper currency, and that until they concentrate all their efforts and machinery upon the Government work the actual evil will continue. The point seems to be a good one, and should command the attention of the Secretary of the Treasury and of Congress. Why should not a Committee of Investigation be appointed?

abstract: The redemption in this City of the soiled postage-stamps, which have been used as currency, proves to be a very large undertaking. Already about five hundred persons have presented their "gum-backs" at the Post-office to be redeemed, or for the inspection which is necessary previous to redemption. Scarcely more than a fourth of the applicants bring packages of less value than $5, and in such cases the stamps are received, counted and redeemed at once, while some of the packages containing over fire dollars' worth of stamps, all of which are left for assorting and counting, reach the high valuation of one thousand dollars.

abstract: It will be remembered by our readers that on the evening of the 10th of November last, the rear walls of HECKER's new Bakery, five stories in height, situated at No. 58 Rutgers-street, suddenly fell, and buried under the ruins a family whose dwelling was a small house directly in the rear. A child about eight months old was crushed to death, and other members of the family seriously injured. Coroner NAUMANN immediately impanneled a jury, and commenced an inquest upon the body of the child, but, after the examination of several witnesses, it was found necessary to adjourn the inquisition for the purpose of enabling laborers to clear away the rubbish, to the end that it might be ascertained whether the proprietors, or those having charge of the construction of the building, had been guilty of negligence.
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered by our readers that on the evening of the 10th of November last, the rear walls of HECKER's new Bakery, five stories in height, situated at No. 58 Rutgers-street, suddenly fell, and buried under the ruins a family whose dwelling was a small house directly in the rear. abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a message was received  from the President, placing at the disposal of Congress the swords formerly belonging to Gen. TWIGGS, forwarded to him by Gen. BUTLER. The President suggests that if the swords should be given as rewards for honorable services, Gen. BUTLER is entitled to the first consideration. Resolutions introduced by Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, relative to the payment of interest and Customs duties in coin, were referred to the Finance Committee. A bill for the relief of sufferers by the Indian massacres in Minnesota was referred; also a bill providing for the removal of the Indians from the State. The President was called upon for correspondence relating to the cultivation of cotton in Asia Minor and Egypt. The resolution censuring Ex-President BUCHANAN was taken up, but after some bebate it was laid on the table. The bill concerning the arrest of State prisoners was postponed until to-day. The resolution concerning the arrest of certain citizens of Delaware was laid on the table, as the subject is embraced in the general bill. The death of Hon. LUTHER HANCHETT, late Representative from Wisconsin, was announced, and after the usual proceedings the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a message was received from the President, placing at the disposal of Congress the swords formerly belonging to Gen. TWIGGS, forwarded to him by Gen. BUTLER. abstract: Trial trip of iron-clad battery Montauk
snippet: Trial trip of iron-clad battery Montauk
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, in compliance with orders from the Navy Department, the United States ironclad battery Montauk started on her trial trip. In order that there should be no doubt about the result of the important experiments, Secretary WELLES appointed a Naval Commission to witness the trial trip, and report upon it. The commission consisted of the following officers, all gentlemen of the highest professional reputation in the service; Commodore STEVEN C. ROWAM, Commander of the iron-clad frigate Roanoke; Capt. ROGERS, late of the Galena, and Capt. JOHN ROGERS, of the ERICSSON battery Catskill. The following distinguished officers were also on board:

abstract: THE TREMAINES IN BROOKLYN.--This popular troupe gave their seventh annual concert at the Athenaeum on Monday night. They were assisted in their very excellent and entertaining performance by Miss MATILDA FOEDT, a youthful and prety violinist; Mrs. E.A. PARKHURST, pianist, and Mr. J.G. PIERSON, basso. The young ladies--Misses LAURA and HETTIE
lead_paragraph: THE TREMAINES IN BROOKLYN.--This popular troupe gave their seventh annual concert at the Athenaeum on Monday night. They were assisted in their very excellent and entertaining performance by Miss MATILDA FOEDT, a youthful and prety violinist; Mrs. E.A. PARKHURST, pianist, and Mr. J.G. PIERSON, basso. The young ladies--Misses LAURA and HETTIE -- of course, looked charmingly and sang delightfully; the boys didn't do so well; the honors of the night were carried by Miss FOEDT, who is a superior performer. Miss PARKHURST did well, as she always does, and Mr. PIERSON was encored in his song of the "Exile."
