abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the resolution to give the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G., the sum of $10,000, was adopted, and also the resolution to procure a portrait of Ex-Gov. MYRON H. CLARK, at an expense of $1,000. Mr. ALLEN made a very earnest effort to have the Finance Committee discharged from consideration of the ordinance passed by the Councilmen, ordering a further issue of Central Park stock. He urged that the Committee ought to be requested to investigate the alleged improper management of the Park Commission, or else report upon the question of issuing more stock. Mr. BOOLE said the Committee had proceeded so far as to order notices printed for summoning witnesses, and would soon go ahead with the investigation. Mr. ALLEN's mo[???]on was lost by 12 to 1. The Board adjourned till 5 o'clock P.M. to-day.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the resolution to give the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G., the sum of $10,000, was adopted, and also the resolution to procure a portrait of Ex-Gov. MYRON H. CLARK, at an expense of $1,000. Mr. ALLEN made a very earnest effort to have the Finance Committee discharged from consideration of the ordinance passed by the Councilmen, ordering a further issue of Central Park stock. He urged that the Committee ought to be requested to investigate the alleged improper management of the Park Commission, or else report upon the question of issuing more stock. Mr. BOOLE said the Committee had proceeded so far as to order notices printed for summoning witnesses, and would soon go ahead with the investigation. Mr. ALLEN's mo[???]on was lost by 12 to 1. The Board adjourned till 5 o'clock P.M. to-day.

abstract: editorial calls movement Southwest perplexing; questions whether it is a reversal
snippet: editorial calls movement Southwest perplexing; questions whether it is a reversal
lead_paragraph: We confess to a total lack of appreciation of Union strategy in the Southwest. The telegraph tells us briefly that Gen. SHERMAN has returned to Memphis, Gen. HOVEY has returned to Helena, Gen. GRANT pauses at Oxford, Miss.--and "an immediate advance is not expected." Gen. HOVEY was famously gazetted quite recently for having captured Grenada, Miss.--one of the most valuable railroad centres of the rebels. But sober truth overslaughed this cheerful bulletin and killed it. Gen. HOVEY's Cavalry did not come within six miles of Grenada, which might have been taken, if our officers had possessed the audacity. Of the famous expedition of Gen. HOVEY, from which we had been led to expect so much, the telegraph presents this morning the following tame and spiritless conclusion: "The results of the expedition sum up 160 rebels killed, wounded and captured; and our loss, 34 killed, wounded and missing." For an expedition, numbering, according to report, twenty thousand men -- that traveled twenty miles or more by water, and marched seventy-five miles by land into the enemy's country, crossing two rivers on the route, and aiming at a vital point of the rebel country -- we must say the above fruits do not seem large. The compensation is not obvious. If this is all that could be done, or that was intended to be done, Gen. HOVEY had done almost as well to have remained at Helena, and saved his transportation and the wear and tear of his men and animals.

abstract: DIED IN THE CELIS.--A man named THOMAS BROWN, residing in Canal-street, Jersey City, was found lying in the street near his residence, about 3  o'clock yesterday morning, and was conveyed by the Police to the Station-house, and placed in a cell, where he was found dead a few hours afterward.
lead_paragraph: DIED IN THE CELIS.--A man named THOMAS BROWN, residing in Canal-street, Jersey City, was found lying in the street near his residence, about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, and was conveyed by the Police to the Station-house, and placed in a cell, where he was found dead a few hours afterward. It appears that about 1 o'clock A.M. he fell in the canal, and was rescued by two men, with whom he afterwards took several drinks, and then separated from them and was found as above stated. An inquest was held by Coroner FARRELL, and a verdict of death from exposure was rendered.

lead_paragraph: The Skating Community of New-York--which may be said to comprise nearly the whole population, male and female, so popular has the amusement become within the last two or three years--must be gratified at the change in the weather which has taken place in the last forty-eight hours; and as they are no doubt looking round for the best place to indulge their favorite sport, a list of the various ponds in the vicinity of New-York may be valuable as a reference. We are enabled to give such a list, which we compile from a forthcoming work by EDWARD L. GILL, called the Skater's Manual, and to be published at No. 702 Broadway. The book will contain a history of skating in New-York, and a guide to the art. The following is a list of the ponds, and for particulars regarding each we would refer the reader to the book itself:

abstract: The Chaplain of the United States General Hospital, David's Island, N.Y., would earnestly appeal to the friends of the soldier, in behalf of the "Chapel of St. Luke, the beloved Physician," and the perpetuation of church service among the sick and wounded men sojourning at the above hospital.
lead_paragraph: The Chaplain of the United States General Hospital, David's Island, N.Y., would earnestly appeal to the friends of the soldier, in behalf of the "Chapel of St. Luke, the beloved Physician," and the perpetuation of church service among the sick and wounded men sojourning at the above hospital. The Government has generously provided, and is rapidly completing, a neat and commodious chapel building, which will be ready for occupancy at Christmas; but with so many claims pressing upon the Central Government on every hand, it will perhaps be esteemed a privilege by the many friends of our church, and of the Union abroad, to aid us in furnishing our chapel with melodeon, bell, communion service, lamps, carpets, etc., all of which will add much to the convenience of our new church, and the comfort of the noble-hearted men who, on every occasion of a religious service, heartily respond to and devoutly attend upon the call.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY COURT CALENDAR.--Thursday, Dec. 18--Nos. 5, 42, 40, 22, 23, 24.  THE PENALTY FOR EJECTING A PASSENGER FROM A RAILROAD CAB:--The case of RICHARD HARGET against the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, was tried in the Brooklyn City Court during the present week. The plaintiff, who is a colored man, brought an action against the Company for having
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CITY COURT CALENDAR.--Thursday, Dec. 18--Nos. 5, 42, 40, 22, 23, 24. THE PENALTY FOR EJECTING A PASSENGER FROM A RAILROAD CAB:--The case of RICHARD HARGET against the Brooklyn City Railroad Company, was tried in the Brooklyn City Court during the present week. The plaintiff, who is a colored man, brought an action against the Company for having been expelled from one of their cars. He had no change and offered a dollar bill. The conductor either could not or would not make change, and ordered the plaintiff from the rear platform, upon which he was standing. The plaintiff refused to get off and was forcibly ejected. He then got upon the front platform, from which he was also ordered, and finally driven off by the driver. The difficulty occurred in one of the Court-street cars, near Joralemon-street, about the time the Railroad Company commenced refusing to change bills. The question whether passengers should provide themselves with change, or whether the Company is bound to make change in reasonable amounts, was therefore also involved in the case. The case was given to the jury on Tuesday evening, and yesterday morning they brought in a verdict of 6 1/4 cents damages for plaintiff.

abstract: -- It is to be hoped that the resolution introduced into the Senate by Senator FIELDS of New-Jersey, proposing to "manifest the sympathy of Congress toward the suffering operatives in Great Britain," will come to naught. It is obviously and utterly improper that our Government should do any such thing as the New-Jersey Senator proposes, though it is obviously proper and humane that our citizens should express, and manifest, and furnish the munificent testimonial of, their sympathy with the parties referred to, as has already been done. The Government of Great Britain has done nothing, and most likely will do nothing, to aid the suffering operatives of the realm; and any action of the kind is strenuously opposed by leading men and Presses of England. Under such circumstances, it would be impertinent for our Government, as such, to interfere in the matter. The people of Great Britain, however, are making vast efforts to relieve their famished fellow-countrymen; and our citizens have nobly stepped forward to aid them in the work of charity. In this City and Philadelphia contributions to the extent of a quarter of a million of dollars have already been received; and the offers of grain from the West, and the offers of railroad and sea transportation that have been made, will raise the total amount furnished by our citizens for the relief of Lancashire, in thirty days, to over half a million of dollars. We do not see that there is any need for Congress meddling in this work. The proper bodies to manage such things are just such bodies as now have this one in hand -- Committees of citizens formed from those who furnish the donations. The matter will thus be managed economically, efficiently and wisely. If Congress takes it up, it will be not only an impertinence, but a job.
lead_paragraph: -- It is to be hoped that the resolution introduced into the Senate by Senator FIELDS of New-Jersey, proposing to "manifest the sympathy of Congress toward the suffering operatives in Great Britain," will come to naught. abstract: -- In response to a communication upon this subject, which appeared in the TIMES yesterday, we learn that the printers have already furnished the Treasury with $220,000,000 of demand notes, in denominations of one, two, five, ten, twenty, fifty, one hundred, five hundred, and one thousand dollar bills. Of the postal or fractional currency, we understand nearly four millions have been supplied. Of the notes, larger and smaller, still forthcoming from the presses of the contractors, there are thirty millions above one dollar to be delivered, and some forty-six millions below that denomination; making a deficit at this moment of seventy-six millions of dollars. The work upon the contracts has been delayed by the call for notes of the smaller numerical designations. This call, while it has largely increased the profits of the contractors, has made a corresponding demand upon their mechanical resources; a demand to meet which they have not chosen to sacrifice all outside business. It is obvious, however, that whatever portion of the responsibility for the withholding of the soldiers' pay may be due to the note printers, a weighty share of it must rest elsewhere. Where, let investigation ascertain.

abstract: HONORABLY DISCHARGED.--On the 1st inst. Mr. J.M. MACKAY was arrested and held to bail under a warrant issued by an Alderman of this City for the alleged crime of perjury, preferred against him by WM. McMONNIES and BENJAMIN F. MUDGETT.
lead_paragraph: HONORABLY DISCHARGED.--On the 1st inst. Mr. J.M. MACKAY was arrested and held to bail under a warrant issued by an Alderman of this City for the alleged crime of perjury, preferred against him by WM. McMONNIES and BENJAMIN F. MUDGETT. An examination was immediately demanded by the accused, and after a full investigation of the facts presented by the prosecutors, and, without any evidence for the defence, Mr. MACKAY was honorably discharged by Mr. Justice CONNOLLY, the examining magistrate.

abstract: The country will be gratified to  learn that the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War were yesterday "directed to inquire into the facts relative to the recent battle at Fredericksburgh, Virginia, and particularly as to what officer or officers ...
lead_paragraph: The country will be gratified to learn that the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War were yesterday "directed to inquire into the facts relative to the recent battle at Fredericksburgh, Virginia, and particularly as to what officer or officers are responsible for the assault which was made upon the enemy's works, and also for the delay which occurred in preparing to meet the enemy." We trust the committee will push this matter through with a promptitude equal to that with which they have performed other essential services to the country, and let the facts be known to the people at once, so that swift punishment may follow upon the crime. The feelings of the country are terribly strong upon this subject, and instead of decreasing, are daily becoming more intense. We assure those in authority that it will be dangerous to trifle with them.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains a VIGOROUS, GRAPHIC AND FULL ACCOUNT OF THE DISASTROUS BATTLE AT FREDERICKSBURGH ON SATURDAY, from our Special Correspondent with the Army of the Potomac, and a MAP OF THE BATTLE-GROUND, showing the position and nature of the rebel defences, the line occupied by our troops, the location of our batteries, &c. Also, a full report of the Gen. PORTER COURT-MARTIAL, from our Special Correspondent, with COPIES OF DOCUMENTS that give interesting glances into the GREAT HISTORY of the WAR. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- The House of Representatives passed the Army Appropriation bill, yesterday, by an almost unanimous vote, the only names recorded against it being NORTON of Ohio, MAY of Maryland, and WICKLIFFE of Kentucky. Mr. STEVENS of Pennsylvania, in response to a question from Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, said it contained an aggregate appropriation of $731,000,000. Even VALLANDIGHAM appears to have voted for the bill. Men of every party and shade of party voted for it. It is pleasing at this moment to see the unanimity with which Congress thus votes that the army must be sustained, and the war pushed on.
lead_paragraph: -- The House of Representatives passed the Army Appropriation bill, yesterday, by an almost unanimous vote, the only names recorded against it being NORTON of Ohio, MAY of Maryland, and WICKLIFFE of Kentucky. abstract: An immense audience filled the Academy of Music last night to hear Mr. JONES repeat his oration upon the war. His first attempt upon this subject gave promise for the second, and well repaid were those present last night for having affronted the biting cold on their way to the crowded Academy. As upon the first lecture, Mr. JONES amused his hearers of his having watched the progress of the rebel-...
lead_paragraph: An immense audience filled the Academy of Music last night to hear Mr. JONES repeat his oration upon the war. His first attempt upon this subject gave promise for the second, and well repaid were those present last night for having affronted the biting cold on their way to the crowded Academy. As upon the first lecture, Mr. JONES amused his hearers of his having watched the progress of the rebellion unprejudiced, and with a full determination to arrive at great conclusions. As an ardent lover of liberty, he could but condemn DAVIS and his compeers, who were fighting, he said, for no holy cause, for no independence, as before the struggle they had these full and untainted. In indignant terms he changed upon the rebels that they were waging a war to ensure the existence and spread of the accursed institution Slavery, and he pronounced their cause a damnable one. He urged a continuance of the struggle, until the rebellion were crushed, even should we be forced to accomplish this purpose to destroy the South. He attacked the laxity and want of decision of the Administration, hampered as it is by personal and petty schemes, bribery and corruption. He called upon the people to rise in their great power, and put aside the wretched politicians, who sacrifice the welfare of the nation to their own advancement; and he urged that, as a great people, we no longer show fear of European intervention, but that Mr. SEWARD announce to France and England that mediation meant war, and that we should answer any demands upon us with our Monitors; that five hundred pound balls were heavy arguments, much more likely to convince than Mr. SEWARD's letters. Mr. JONES dwelt forcibly upon the fact that our struggle is one which concerns directly all the oppressed and tyranized of the world -- that our defeat would rivet their chains, while our triumph would hastan the date of their delivery. During these remarks; continued and loud applause testified to the effect produced upon the audience by the warmth, sincerity and eloquence of the speaker.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions for a Bankrupt law and for other objects, and the introduction of a number of bills which were referred to the appropriate Committees, a resolution was adopted directing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into the facts relating to the late disaster at Fredericksburgh, and make report to the Senate. The bill to facilitate the discharge of disabled soldiers ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, after the presentation of petitions for a Bankrupt law and for other objects, and the introduction of a number of bills which were referred to the appropriate Committees, a resolution was adopted directing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into the facts relating to the late disaster at Fredericksburgh, and make report to the Senate. The bill to facilitate the discharge of disabled soldiers from the army was taken up, and after some debate was passed. A resolution was adopted calling upon the President for information regarding the recall of Gen. SAXTON from Port Royal. The bill to improve the organization of the cavalry force was passed. The Bankrupt bill was taken up, and Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, argued in favor of its passage. Subsequently a resolution was adopted calling upon the Secretary of War for information relative to the disabled transports of the Banks Expedition, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Early yesterday morning the enemy appeared roaming over the plain vacated by us the night previous. Sharpshooters were thrown down near the river bank to pick off the engineers employed on the pontoons, which, though taken up, had not been mounted on the wagons. They also attempted to plant a battery on a woody crest about half a mile back from the Barnard House.

abstract: At a moment when the pictures of the famous Dusseldorf Gallery are about to pass under the hammer of the auctioneer -- for that meritorious and, in some respects, extraordinary collection will be sold by HENRY H. LEDDS & Co. to-day -- It is a consolation to know that a pleasant artistic remembrance of them may be preserved by means of the photographer's art. Messrs. APPLLETON & Co. are now issuing a splendid serial publication, called Gems from the Dusseldorf Gallery. It is a large quarto, and will be completed in twenty-six parts -- each part containing two large photographs and accompanying letter -- press, explanatory of the pictures thereby presented and preserved. The friendly communion of the masters will thus be perpetuated, and the admirers of their vigorous and well-represented school will be able to recall, and sadly we venture to say, the day when New-York could boast at least one public collection of pictures that was not made ridiculous by pretense, or wearisome by mediocrity. It is a thousand pities that such a collection should ever be exposed to the accidents of commerce; that the owner should be under the vulgar necessity of turning the canvasses into cash. But the fiat has gone forth, and at 11 o'clock to-day connoiseurs and dealers will be haggling over poor old "Lear," and talking dollars and cents to "Diana and her Nymphs." The loss is well nigh irreparable, for what speculator will touch the Arts again with this result before him! There are pictures in the collection that enjoy a world-wide reputation, and that would be regarded singly as a good attraction in any European capital. Here a congregation of worthies was not sufficient to draw a remunerative response from the community. To-day the pictures will be scattered to the winds. Under these circumstances, we hail with peculiar satisfaction the publication to which we have referred. Its appearance at any time should be a matter of congratulation, for in all details of the publisher's art it is perfect, and a credit to the presses whence it comes. The photographs have been taken from the original pictures by Mr. A.A. TURNER, and are reproduced for the first time under the superintendence of Mr. B. FRODSHAM. The first-named gentleman is well known as one of the most skillful operators in America, and Mr. FRODSHAM's knowledge of art, quickness of glance, and taste as a writer, is a guaranty that nothing has been passed over hastily. The photographs are in fact superior to any that have been produced in this country, and equal to the best that are imported from Dresden and Munich. They are rightly called "Gems;" our only wonder is how such a work, on which care and capital have been lavished, can be sold at the small price of one dollar a part.

abstract: Warren vs. Owen. -- This was an action to recover of the defendant, who is a lawyer, for an alleged libel in publising in the Herald, Tribune and Transcript, a statement or report of a certain trial in the Marine Court, in October, 1861. The report of the trial complained of, stated that the plaintiff and his partner, while carrying on business in this City, had engaged in issuing fictitious paper in the shape of accommodation paper, by issuing notes and bills of exchange made by clerks, salesmen, and parties in their employment, for the purpose of raising money.

abstract: Editorial explores Union mistakes to date
snippet: Editorial explores Union mistakes to date
lead_paragraph: We have tried, and for the moment failed. But no time should be lost in trying again, on some other line. We cannot afford to lose the Winter in idle repining. Our armies, in all probability, will never again be so strong as now. Volunteering has substantially ceased. Conscription seems to have about finished its work. Every army, without new recruits, constantly and rapidly grows weaker by disease, even without battle. Moreover, the time will soon come when the term of enlistment of many of the soldiers will expire. There are two large classes in the army -- the two years' men enrolled at the beginning of the war, and the nine months' men called out by the Proclamation of last Summer -- who soon will be no longer available. Our Government is bound ever to bear in mind that there is this very important difference between itself and the rebel rulers: it can have no soldiers except for limited periods, while they, practically liberated from all control of law, can force their rank and file to serve as long as they please. It is specially bound, then, to use its present soldiers while it has them. Even if their places could be supplied with fresh volunteers, which is by no means certain, it must take long and valuable time to organize and discipline them --- a disadvantage the rebels are mainly free from, for the personnel of their armies will remain nearly the same throughout the war, however long it may be continued. We repeat, then, that we must waste no time in vain regrets. Action must still be the word.

abstract: After a somewhat tedious march of three days --over numerous streams and muddy roads--we have arrived at the point indicated above. No incident of importance has transpired since we left Fairfax Court-house and Centreville, except that at Dumfries, HAMPTON'S Legion made a dash into the town, early Friday morning, and captured the telegraph operator, Mr. LAME, of Boston, Lieut. BOWERS and fourteen men, of the Third Virginia Cavalry, seventeen loaded and seven empty Sutlers' wagons.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN -- BENEFIT OF MRS. BARNEY WILLIAMS. -- This charming artist, who has been attracting such delighted crowds to this establishment during the past six weeks, takes her first benefit this season to-night. We doubt not the many who have derived so much merriment and enjoyment from her performances, will gather around their favorite in full hosts. The performances are of a highly attractive character -- "All Hallow Eve," the "Law for Ladies," and "Irish Assurance and Yankee Modesty."

abstract: proceedings
snippet: proceedings
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. An ordinance to create the offices of clerk and Deputy Clerk of Washington Market, at the salary respectively of $1,500 and $1,000, was presented and laid over. A report from the Finance Committee in favor of donating $2,500 to the Prison Association was recommitted because Dr. GRISCOM's name was attached to the petition upon which the report was based. The reason for this aversion was stated by Mr. BRADY to be a villification of the Common Council by the Doctor at Albany, last Winter, while in his petition he addressed the Aldermen as "Honorable body," &c. Two or three veto messages of the Mayor were read and laid over. They may be found in full in the official proceedings. The Board adjourned till 5 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: Unless our officers in the Far West draw very largely upon their imaginations for their facts when they report a battle, they are doing even more for the country in the suppression of the rebellion than they have ever had credit for. The great distance from headquarters, and the unaccountable absence of that omnipresent person, "Our Special Correspondent," from the extreme Western armies, give comparative immunity to any little trifling with our credulity ...
lead_paragraph: Unless our officers in the Far West draw very largely upon their imaginations for their facts when they report a battle, they are doing even more for the country in the suppression of the rebellion than they have ever had credit for. The great distance from headquarters, and the unaccountable absence of that omnipresent person, "Our Special Correspondent," from the extreme Western armies, give comparative immunity to any little trifling with our credulity that vain-glorious commanders may be disposed to practice. But we are very far from asserting or believing that any officers in the war have taken advantage of the opportunity thus afforded them. On the contrary, we truly believe that our distant champions have transcended by far the average effectiveness of the Union armies, and for reasons that it; needs no very deep inquiry to furnish.

abstract: --WHO IS GUILTT?--We are gratified to observe that a resolution was adopted by the Senate yesterday, directing the Secretary of War to furnish information concerning the circumstances of the charter of the vessels of Gen. BANKS' expedition--from whom, and by what agent of the War Department they were ebariered, at what price and for what period of time they were engaged, and what agents examined them as to their seaworthi- ...
lead_paragraph: --WHO IS GUILTT?--We are gratified to observe that a resolution was adopted by the Senate yesterday, directing the Secretary of War to furnish information concerning the circumstances of the charter of the vessels of Gen. BANKS' expedition--from whom, and by what agent of the War Department they were ebariered, at what price and for what period of time they were engaged, and what agents examined them as to their seaworthiness. Our readers know that a number of rotten hulks, belonging to this expedition, have been floundering along the Southern coast for the last fortnight, and that it is the greatest wonder in the world that whole ship-loads of our troops have not fallen through their decayed timbers into a watery grave. The transport Niagara, as the telegraph has already informed us, which left here a few days ago with five hundred soldiers, had to put into Philadelphia to escape destruction; and on examination, her cross-timbers were found to be a mass of black-rot. Our South Carolina correspondent yesterday described the condition of the ship Thames, also of the Banks Expedition, which put into Port Royal on the 10th in a disabled condition, and was there surveyed and condemned. The report of the Examining Board was, that she was altogether unseaworthy. "Her timbers," wrote our correspondent, "in some places, were found to be placed three feet apart, and she was built up above the water-line with 1 1/2-inch pine plank, without any ceiling. This planking, through which one might have driven a marling-spike, was the only barrier between four hundred lives and eternity." These are not the only vessels of this expedition of which we have heard ill accounts.

abstract: The United States vs. The Brig Robert Bruce and her Cargo.--This vessel was captured by the Penobscot, off Charleston Inlet, about a mile from the land, on the coast of North Carolina. No one appeared in the suit brought against her, for either vessel or cargo.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Brig Robert Bruce and her Cargo.--This vessel was captured by the Penobscot, off Charleston Inlet, about a mile from the land, on the coast of North Carolina. No one appeared in the suit brought against her, for either vessel or cargo. The ship had a register issued at Bristol, England, to William Gough, a merchant resident there, on Feb. 7, 1856. There were shipping articles executed Aug. 26, 1862, for a voyage "from Hull to Halifax, N.S., thence to any ports or places in British North America, or the United States, or North or South America, or the West Indies, and returning to any port on the Continent of Europe, or in the Baltic or seas adjacent, (with leave to call for orders,) and terminating finally in the United Kingdom, for a probable period of nine months." There was no manifest or clearance among the ship's papers, The log was kept up till Oct. 20, when it stopped. The muster testified that the vessel sailed directly from Hull to the ceast of North Carolina, and intended to enter the port of Wilmington, if she could evade the blockade. He knew of the blockade, and had been in Wilmington in September, 1861, and brought away a cargo of turpentine.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Secretary of the Navy was called upon for information regarding the appointment of Rear Admirals. Mr. MCDOUCALL, of California, introduced a resolution, which was laid over, calling for information regarding the Buell Court of Inquiry.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Secretary of the Navy was called upon for information regarding the appointment of Rear Admirals. Mr. MCDOUCALL, of California, introduced a resolution, which was laid over, calling for information regarding the Buell Court of Inquiry. A resolution granting pecuniary aid to Missouri to emancipate the slaves in the State, was referred to the Judiciary Committee. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, called up his resolution inquiring whether any oath had been proposed to citizens released from arbitrary arrest but it was not acted upon. The Bankrupt act was considered, and several verbal amendments were made. The Senate then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: A majority of the Border State Congressmen are about to make a dead set upon the President to constrain him to revoke, or at least postpone, his Emancipation Proclamation. This majority is known to be that portion of them whose speches and votes in the past have shown them to be the most devoted
lead_paragraph: A majority of the Border State Congressmen are about to make a dead set upon the President to constrain him to revoke, or at least postpone, his Emancipation Proclamation. This majority is known to be that portion of them whose speches and votes in the past have shown them to be the most devoted to Slavery. Their intended demonstration would amaze us, had we not long ago learned that judicial blindness is one of the peculiar effects of the peculiar institution. Nothing can be more plain than that these men are doing the thing most calculated to defeat their proposed object.

abstract: We have a week later advices from Europe, by the arrival at this port yesterday morning of the steamship Scotia. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Queenstown on tha 7th inst. The comments of the English newspapers on affairs in America are without any particular significance. Chancellor of the Exchequer GLADSTONE had written
lead_paragraph: We have a week later advices from Europe, by the arrival at this port yesterday morning of the steamship Scotia. She left Liverpool on the 6th, and Queenstown on tha 7th inst. The comments of the English newspapers on affairs in America are without any particular significance. Chancellor of the Exchequer GLADSTONE had written a letter to Prof. NEWMAN, in which he denied ever having expressed any sympathy for the Southern cause. At the same time he intimates his belief that the North had better consent to a separation. The Paris correspondent of the London Times states that contracts have been concluded by the French Government for the supply of the army in Mexico for two years -- indicating that a prolonged occupation of the country is intended. The distress resulting from the cotton famine begins to be most severely felt in the manufacturing districts of France. The Ministerial crisis continued in Italy. Voting for the election of a King commenced in Greece on the 5th inst.; 2,500 signatures had been taken, which were without exception in favor of Prince ALFRED. His election is considered cortain. The Queen of Spain, in her speech on the opening of the Cortes, said she felt confident that events on the coast of Cuba would not change the excellent relations maintained with the united States Government. There is very little change to note in the London or Liverpool markets. Consols were down to 92 1/8@ 92 1/4 for money.

abstract: A COUNTRYMAN VICTIMIZED. -- WM. M. O'RESON, of Webster, Iowa, stopping at FRENCH's Hotel, complains that he was seduced into a monkey show in Chatham-street, and while there was induced to gamble with JAMES SOUTHWICK. In one sitting of an hour, at a game of chance, with cards, SOUTHWICK won from O'RESON the sum of $130. SOUTHWICK is also charged with having won $2 50 from RESON at a game played with dice. Officer WHITMORE, of the Fourth Ward, arrested SOUTHWICK, and Alderman DODGE committed him to the Tombs for trial. O'RESON was held as a witness.

abstract: The Trial of George Wilkes, Esq., editor of Wilkes' Spirit of the Times, for an alleged libel upon one John Lawrence, was resumed in this Court yesterday morning. A large audience was in attendance, comprising numerous members of the gambling fraternity. Mr. McKeon, for the prosecution, called to the stand Thomas H. Ferris, who testified that he was now Deputy Sheriff of the City of New-York, which office he had held since January last. He had known the complainant, John Lawrence, fifteen or sixteen years. Witness was shown a picture of Lawrence, published in the same number of Wilkes' Spirit that contained the alleged libel, and asked if he would recognize it as Lawrence. Mr. Whiting, for the defence, objected to the question, and the objection was overruled by the Court. Witness answered that he would recognize it.

abstract: Moses Goldstein vs. Nelson Sherwood. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff to recover for the loss of services of his daughter, a girl of about fifteen years of age. The defendant occupies a marble-yard on the corner of Attorney and Rivington streets, and on the evening of the 9th of October, 1862, the daughter of the plaintiff, in company of another young lady of her own age, were passing in front of the defendant's place, when she slipped, putting her foot against a marble slab, which fell over and crushed several of the fingers of her right hand.

lead_paragraph: We may expect soon to hear a new and deafening outcry against Gen. BUTLER as the curtain rises on " the fifth and last act" of his great play--How to Tame a Secesh City. Our New-Orleans correspondent, in yesterday's issue, quoted an order issued by BUTLER on the 5th of December, requiring all "registered enemies" of the United States, both men and women, with their families, who desire to go within the rebel lines and not return, to report themselves to the Provost-Marshal-General on or before the 10th of December, when conveyance was promised them. They were to be allowed to take with them personal clothing only, and fifty dollars in money for each adult.

abstract: A brief dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated yesterday, gives us the highly important intelligence that Kinston, N.C., has been captured by Gen. FOSTER, who secured five hundred prisoners and eleven pieces of artillery. The rebel General--EVANS--who was in command at Kinston, on...
lead_paragraph: A brief dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated yesterday, gives us the highly important intelligence that Kinston, N.C., has been captured by Gen. FOSTER, who secured five hundred prisoners and eleven pieces of artillery. The rebel General--EVANS--who was in command at Kinston, on the 14th inst. telegraphed to the rebel War Department that Gen. FOSTER had attacked the place with 15,000 men and nine gunboats, and that, alter a ten hours' fight, the National forces were repulsed. He took care to say, however, that Gen. FOSTER was still "in his front," and the sequel shows that he staid "in front" until he saw the enemy's rear. The details of this brilliant operation will be awaited with much interest. Kinston, it will be seen by a glance at the map, is but twenty miles from Goldsboro, situated on the Neuse River, where it is crossed by the Atlantic and Carolina Railroad. Gen. FOSTER is doubtless by this time in Goldsboro, and has command of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad.

abstract: While on Saturday last the great battle raged all day at Fredericksburgh, forty miles this side of Richmond, another battle, of smaller proportions, was going on at a point one hundred and sixty miles south of Richmond, two hundred miles south of Freder
lead_paragraph: While on Saturday last the great battle raged all day at Fredericksburgh, forty miles this side of Richmond, another battle, of smaller proportions, was going on at a point one hundred and sixty miles south of Richmond, two hundred miles south of Fredericksburgh -- at Kinston, North Carolina. Our first news of the latter engagement was by a dispatch from the rebel Gen. EVANS to the authorities at Richmond, dated on Sunday last, which announced that Gen. FOSTER had attacked Kinston the previous day with 15,000 men and nine gunboats; and, said the rebel officer, "I fought them ten hours, and have driven them back to their gunboats;" but, added he, "his army (FOSTER's) is still in my front." A telegram this morning from Fortress Monroe puts quite a different aspect on the result of the engagement. It is briefly that "Gen. FOSTER's forces have taken Kinston, capturing five hundred prisoners and eleven pieces of artillery." It may be that the battle was undecided after the ten hours' engagement of Saturday, and was renewed next day by our army with greater success; or it may be that the dispatch of the rebel commander deviated slightly from truth and from the facts. Whichever may be the case, it is certain that this not unimportant point is now in possession of our forces; for we give an extract from a Richmond paper which puts the matter beyond dispute. But we have no idea that Gen. FOSTER's movement terminated with Kinston.

abstract: NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS.--The Ninth NewJersey Regiment has had its scattered companies consolidated at Newbern, N.C. Col. HEEKHAN, of the Ninth, is in command of a brigade in Gen. FOSTER'S department. Lieut. Col. WILSON, also of the Ninth, has resigned, and several other officers of the regiment have been discharged for disability, caused by the severe and harassing duty they have performed.
lead_paragraph: NEW-JERSEY REGIMENTS.--The Ninth NewJersey Regiment has had its scattered companies consolidated at Newbern, N.C. Col. HEEKHAN, of the Ninth, is in command of a brigade in Gen. FOSTER'S department. Lieut. Col. WILSON, also of the Ninth, has resigned, and several other officers of the regiment have been discharged for disability, caused by the severe and harassing duty they have performed. The Ninth was one of the regiments which originally landed with Gen. BURNSIDE, in North Carolina, and participated in the battles of Roanoke Island and Newbern, since which the several companies have been engaged, most of the time, in remote picket duty, having also been engaged in several important expeditions. An elegant silk banner, prepared by order of Gov. OLDEN, will be shortly sent to the Ninth, by the hands of Surgeon WOODHULL. The flag beats elegant paintings of Roanoke Island and Newbern, and is intended as a testimonial to the bravery of the gallant regiment.

abstract: Hon. Horatio Ballard, Secretary of State:  MY DEAR SIR: To serve our country in any hour of peril has been my highest ambition. I have looked fondly in many distant climes upon the emblem of her greatness, power and glory floating from the masthead, and ever with the determination that it should never be sullied, if my life could avert such a calamity.

abstract: Personal security is not to be numbered among the blessings which foreigners enjoy in Japan. Whatever disposition the Government of the Tycoon may have to protect them, there can be no doubt that the Princes and their followers regard outside barbarians with aversion, and avail themselves of every opportunity to give vent to their animosity.
lead_paragraph: Personal security is not to be numbered among the blessings which foreigners enjoy in Japan. Whatever disposition the Government of the Tycoon may have to protect them, there can be no doubt that the Princes and their followers regard outside barbarians with aversion, and avail themselves of every opportunity to give vent to their animosity. The latest instance of this, and perhaps the most wanton and outrageous that has yet occurred, has been narrated by the Yokohama correspondent of this paper, and occurred on the 14th of September. A party of English, consisting of three gentlemen and one lady, left Yokohama on horseback, to visit a temple in the vicinity of Kawasaki. They had arrived midway between Kanagawa and the place of their destination, without meeting with accident of any kind; but there they unfortunately encountered a Prince and his retinue, who brusquely ordered them to turn back. This they immediately proceeded to do. Hardly, however, had they commenced their retrogade movement, when they were fiercely assaulted by the armed followers of the Japanese Chief. The lady, a Mrs. BORRADALE, had her hat cut from her head by a stroke of a sword, and owed her life to the fleetness of her horse. Two of the gentlemen -- Messrs. MARSHALL and CLARKE -- were severely wounded, yet succeeded in reaching the American Consulate in Kanagawa. But the fate of Mr. RICHARDSON, the remaining member of the party, was more tragic and terrible. Faint from loss of blood, he was unable to keep his seat, and fell on the road insensible. On recovering consciousness he begged for a drink of water. There was, however, no good Samaritan there to minister to the wants of the dying stranger. Far otherwise. A noriman, or native carriage, passing at the time, its occupant, seeing a wounded man sitting on the wayside, asked what was the matter. "Oh, nothing," responded some of the bystanders, "he is merely a foreigner." Whereupon the inhuman wretch descended from his vehicle, drew his sword, and completed the work which the retainers of the Prince had left unfinished. The corpse of the murdered RICHARDSON was dragged some ten or twelve yards off the road, where it was subsequently pointed out to a party of Europeans and Americans, who came to seek it, by a youth who had been an eye-witness of the last act of butchery. When found it was covered with matting, and horribly mangled and mutilated. Such, according to our correspondent, and confirmed by the Japan Express and Herald, are the leading facts of this shocking catastrophe. A Singapore journal, evidently in the interest of Col. NEALE, the British Charge, who has given great offence by his want of sympathy with the sufferers, attempts to apologize for the conduct of the Japanese, by alleging that the Europeans, in obstructing the way of the procession, were violating one of the social customs of Japan, which allows no person to intrude upon the thoroughfares when a Prince and his train are to pass. This view of the matter cannot, however, exculpate the assassins, or take from the atrocity of the outrage. For, notwithstanding the existence of such a custom, Mrs. BORRADALE and her friends were guiltless. The Prince who contemplated the procession was bound to notify the Government of his intention, while the Government was bound to give notice to the foreign Consulates or Legations. Now, in the present case, no notification of any kind had been given either to the Government or the foreign representatives, and therefore none of the individuals who composed that fatal pleasure party could have had the faintest conception that they were committing any breach of etiquette in riding forth to visit Kawasaki, or that, by so doing, they were performing an act which might have cost them all their lives.
headline: {'main': 'The Latest Outrage in Japan.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Latest Outrage in Japan.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We cannot help wondering oftentimes at the excessive audacity in falsehood, which we cannot avoid observing. It prevails everywhere, but especially is politics. One would have said that the political untruth which had disgraced this country in years past could not be excelled this side the bottomless pit. But the rebellion has given increased virulence to it.
lead_paragraph: We cannot help wondering oftentimes at the excessive audacity in falsehood, which we cannot avoid observing. It prevails everywhere, but especially is politics. One would have said that the political untruth which had disgraced this country in years past could not be excelled this side the bottomless pit. But the rebellion has given increased virulence to it. It would seem as if no previous respectability, no station in society, no position, no reputation prevented any one who became touched with this fatal heresy of secession from losing all regard for truth; and more than that, such men seem to lose all regard for common sense, and give the public no credit for any knowledge of facts or power of reasoning, and make statements, not in the heat of a verbal discussion, but coolly, and in writing, which every one who has any memory of the events of the past two years knows are utterly false. Think, for instance, of BUCHANAN's written, deliberate statement that FLOYD had never stolen any public arms at all! which Gen. SCOTT so summarily exposed, and which needed no such exposure, for every one both North and South who knew anything of what has happened the past two years, knew it was untrue the moment he saw it.

abstract: The Br. brig Hannah, of Shelburne, N.S., from Maracaibo, with a cargo of hides and coffee -- before reported ashore on the Romer Shoal -- was got off, and on the 18th, at night, got aground on the West Bank. The steamers P.B. Van Houghton and Stillman Witt have gone to [???] assistance. She had no pilot. Later -- The steamtug Stillman Witt came up to the vessel last evening, and [???] her still ashore and perfectly tight. The tug will exceed to the vessel to-morrow (Sunday) morning at high water, when she will probably be got off.

abstract: There has been a singular fatality attached to the family of the lamented Chaplain Fuller, of the Sixteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who fell at the battle of Fredericksburgh. Three of the family have...
lead_paragraph: There has been a singular fatality attached to the family of the lamented Chaplain Fuller, of the Sixteenth Massachusetts Regiment, who fell at the battle of Fredericksburgh. Three of the family have perished by untimely deaths. Eugene Fuller, one of the sons, was drowned on the voyage from New-York to New-Orleans in 1859, the same year that the mother died. Margaret Fuller, Countess of Ossoli, perished by shipwreck on Fire Island, near New-York, in 1850. She was returning from Italy to her native land, from which she had long been absent. Her husband and child were lost with her. And now Arthur B. Fuller has been killed to battle. In every instance the surviving members of the family received the sad tidings by telegraph. Gov. Andrew, in a letter to the brother of the deceased, writes.

abstract: The Assembly, at the last session of the Legislature, in recognition of the gallant services of the commander of the Monitor, Lieut. JOHN L. WORDEN, in the action with the Merrimac, in Hampton Roads,...
lead_paragraph: The Assembly, at the last session of the Legislature, in recognition of the gallant services of the commander of the Monitor, Lieut. JOHN L. WORDEN, in the action with the Merrimac, in Hampton Roads, it will be recollected, authorized the Secretary of State to "cause a sword and its accoutrements, with a suitable inscription, to be manufactured and presented to that gallant son of the State of New-York, as a slight testimonial to his bravery." The sword was completed by Messrs. TITTANY & Co. a few weeks since, and a description given of it in the TIMES.

abstract: Dr. RICHARD D. AVEERSON, a dentist, residing at a boarding-house, No. 26 Clinton-place, was arrested yesterday, and brought before Jusitce KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on three charges of deadly assault with a knife upon his landlady, Mrs. RICH, and two other persons.
lead_paragraph: Dr. RICHARD D. AVEERSON, a dentist, residing at a boarding-house, No. 26 Clinton-place, was arrested yesterday, and brought before Jusitce KELLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on three charges of deadly assault with a knife upon his landlady, Mrs. RICH, and two other persons. The facts of the case, as they transpired upon the examination before the Justice, yesterday, are these: Dr. ADDINGTON was complained of by some of the lady boarders in the establishment as having been guilty of taking improper liberties with them, and when this intelligence reached the ears of the hostess she at once took steps to put an end to the scandal. The latter keeps an extensive and somewhat private boarding-house at the number above indicated, and she very naturally felt that the reputation of her house was at stake, when stories, of this nature were put into circulation by her own boarders. She therefore applied for counsel to her brother-in-law. Mr. CHARLES W. MILLER, a boarder in the house, and it was finally concluded that the best way would be to wait upon the objectionable boarder at once, and inform him that his presence there was no longer required. Mrs. RICH, accompanied by Mr. MILLER, went to ADDINGTON's room. The latter, upon being informed of the conclusion to which Mrs. RICH had arrived, seized a long knife lying upon his table, and with it struck the lady in the face and also on the right arm, thereby wounding her very severely. At this stage of the affray. Mr. MILLER, her brother-in-law, interfered, when the gallant Doctor stabbed him in eight different places on the head and body. Some of the wounds are very serious, and may possibly prove fatal. About, this time MILLER's wife interfered for the protection of her husband, when the desperado struck that lady in the breast with his knife, and then stabbed her on the nose, just between the eyes. After having glutted his apparent thirst for blood in this manner, he fled from the house, but was very soon afterwards taken into custody by Officer JONES, of the Fifteenth Precinct. Dr. SANGER was called in, and dressed the wounds of the injured persons, none of which are considered dangerous, with the exception of those inflicted upon MILLER. The prisoner had a preliminary examination, yesterday afternoon, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, during which he stated that he was 42 years of age and a dentist by occupation. As to the question of guilt he had nothing to say. Justice KELLY committed the accused to prison upon three separate charges of felonious assault.

abstract: Editorial says 2 main Union blunders in conduct of war are bureaucratic dictation and lack of concentration
snippet: Editorial says 2 main Union blunders in conduct of war are bureaucratic dictation and lack of concentration
lead_paragraph: The City was as much startled yesterday by the announcement of the resignation of Secretary SEWARD as it had been a few days before by the news of the repulse of Gen. BURNSIDE, and the retreat of our army across the Rappahannock. Indeed, the first-mentioned event, and the rumored breaking up of the Cabinet, affected the public more profoundly, if possible, than the other. Mr. SEWARD has been the right-hand man of the President from the day of his election until now. He has had, in great measure, the shaping of the policy of the Government, beside the management of what has been, on several occasions, its most important and difficult Department. For him to step out of the Cabinet at this most critical moment of the Government's and the Country's history, portended -- no man knew what. But every one was filled with apprehension and doubt.
headline: {'main': 'Resignation of Secretary Seward.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Resignation of Secretary Seward.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Editorial notes war events that created greatest sensations in public mind occurred on Sunday
snippet: Editorial notes war events that created greatest sensations in public mind occurred on Sunday
lead_paragraph: It has happened, throughout the war, that the events creating the greatest sensations of the public mind have occurred on Sunday. Whether this is owing to that fatality which often seems to impel men and nations directly on to that fate that they exhibit the greatest anxiety to avoid, belongs to philosophers to investigate. We only call attention to the fact in the case of our own Government, that Sunday has been marked by more and intense excitements than any other day, notwithstanding the efforts of our authorities, civil and military, to secure its sanctity and peace.
headline: {'main': 'Sunday and Its Sensations.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Sunday and Its Sensations.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SENTENCES IN THE COURT OF SESSIONS.-- GEORGE PRICE, colored, was brought up on Friday on an indictment for manslaughter in the fourth degree, in causing the death of MICHAEL FARRELL by stabbing him with a butcher's knife in the abdomen. He pleaded guilty.
lead_paragraph: SENTENCES IN THE COURT OF SESSIONS.-- GEORGE PRICE, colored, was brought up on Friday on an indictment for manslaughter in the fourth degree, in causing the death of MICHAEL FARRELL by stabbing him with a butcher's knife in the abdomen. He pleaded guilty. FARRELL, accompanied by two acquaintances, met PRICE in Atlantic-avenue one evening about a month ago, and charged him with having insulted a friend of theirs. They then attacked and beat him, when he drew a knife and stabbed FARRELL. The Court sentenced him to sixty days' imprisonment in the Penitentiary.

abstract: SURPRISE AND PRESENTATION.--On last Wed  nesday evening a large delegation of Alderman BOOLE'S constituents visited his house without the slightest notice beforehand, and presented his wife and himself with a magnificient silver tea set, valued at $1,500, the presentation being made by Mr. HARVEY C. CALKINS. The Alderman was thoroughly, taken by...
lead_paragraph: SURPRISE AND PRESENTATION.--On last Wed nesday evening a large delegation of Alderman BOOLE'S constituents visited his house without the slightest notice beforehand, and presented his wife and himself with a magnificient silver tea set, valued at $1,500, the presentation being made by Mr. HARVEY C. CALKINS. The Alderman was thoroughly, taken by surprise, but speedily recovered himself and returned thanks for the honor paid Mrs. BOOLE and himself, adding that if he had been previously consulted about the matter, he probably would have objected to the presentation taking place, as he had always been averse to formal testimonial-giving, because it was popularly supposed that such affairs were generally prearranged by the beneficiary. He was willing to excuse the surprise given him, and was happy over the gift from his friends, although he somewhat feared they had not taken into consideration the additional burden of taxes they were imposing upon him by the possession of so much valuable plate. A rich repast brought by the visitors caused a further surprise, and was zestfully enjoyed by all present.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Special Committee of the Board of Councilmen, consisting of Messrs. HOGAN, LENT and HATES, to whom was referred for investigation the matter of the protest against giving the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G., Col. MAT-...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Special Committee of the Board of Councilmen, consisting of Messrs. HOGAN, LENT and HATES, to whom was referred for investigation the matter of the protest against giving the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.N.G., Col. MATTHEW MURPHY, the sum of $10,000, gave a full hearing to the parties interested. The proposition for the appropriation is based upon the pledge of the Common Council, given in a series of resolutions adopted last September, that any militia regiment from the City volunteering into the National army for either nine months or three years, should be entitled to $10,006 from the City Treasury for their regimental fund. It was introduced in the Board of Aldermen by Mr. WALSH, and passed there, but when it came up in the Board of Councilman a protest against it was presented by Mr. MORGAN JONES, signed by Major BAGLEY, in behalf of a number of the old officers of the original Sixty-ninth Regiment.

abstract: The growing interest which centres in our latest Virginia battle-field necessitates the most searching investigation into the causes which brought disaster when we had every reason to expect triumphant success. Fruitful in evil as would be the old French Revolutionary policy of following with a special inquest of querelous functionaries every movement of the army, in this case inquiry is a sacred, public duty.
lead_paragraph: The growing interest which centres in our latest Virginia battle-field necessitates the most searching investigation into the causes which brought disaster when we had every reason to expect triumphant success. Fruitful in evil as would be the old French Revolutionary policy of following with a special inquest of querelous functionaries every movement of the army, in this case inquiry is a sacred, public duty. Among other necessary information which will be elicited, we shall learn how far our repulse was probably due to the delay of the pontoon bridges, and why the battle was fought at a perilous bend of the river where the position was strong, and the chances ran so seriously against us. On whom the crushing responsibility must fall, the report of the Congressional Committee will inform the expectant nation without undue delays.

abstract: Rourke vs. Duffy.--This was an appeal from the Eighth District Court. The plaintiff sued the defendant for a balance, which he alleged to be due to him upon an excavation of rock.
lead_paragraph: Rourke vs. Duffy.--This was an appeal from the Eighth District Court. The plaintiff sued the defendant for a balance, which he alleged to be due to him upon an excavation of rock. On the trial the plaintiff testified that the defendant had promised to pay him 84 cents per cubic yard, and the defendant testified that he promised 78 cents only, at which rate it was admitted that he had paid in full. It was shown that, upon a dispute between them concerning the claim in suit, the plaintiff had offered to be satisfied if the defendant would swear that the price agreed upon was 78 cents. The defendant made an affidavit to that effect and showed it to the plaintiff, notwithstanding that the Court below gave judgment for the plaintiff and the defendant appealed.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A message from the Mayor, vetoeing the resolution to increase the salaries of the Police Justices to $5,000 per annum, was received and laid over. The Mayor thinks the salaries paid by the city are liberal, and that out of patriotism every municipal or county officer should be satisfied with his present pay, in order to save the city from as much taxation as possible, within reason. The Board were in session but a short time, and adjourned till 6 o'clock, P.M. on Monday.

abstract: During yesterday this wing of the army was employed in changing position so as at the same time to present's bold and extended front to the Southward, and occupy more suitable camping grounds. Gen. FRANKLIN'S Headquarters have been removed back from near the river to a delightful grove on the road leading to--The troops are in fine condition.
lead_paragraph: During yesterday this wing of the army was employed in changing position so as at the same time to present's bold and extended front to the Southward, and occupy more suitable camping grounds. Gen. FRANKLIN'S Headquarters have been removed back from near the river to a delightful grove on the road leading to--The troops are in fine condition and fully prepared to do battle with the enemy as before the late terrible conflict. Our flag of truce extended until 6 o'clock last evening, up to which time our men were busily employed in crossing the river and burying the dead. Several of the soldiers have gone over and exchanged tobacco and other commodities with the Rebels scattered along the banks. During yesterday afternoon, a member of Col. COBB's Fifth Wisconsin regiment -- LADUE by name, constructing a raft and paddling himself over spent several hours with the Rebs. Before leaving he made arrangements to get forty over the river to our lines who wished to desert. Among the number were two young men from Lockport, New-York, whom he had known at that place. Affairs remained unchanged in the vicinity of Fredericksburgh; the enemy have not returned to the city in any force, and probably will not so long as our guns frown down upon it from the opposite shore.

abstract: Eight hundred sick and wounded soldiers arrived at Jersey City, last evening, from Washington. Quartermaster JOHNSON, of this City, had two large steamboats ready for their reception, which had been heated during the afternoon, and on board of which he had placed bedding, blankets, clothing, and other
lead_paragraph: Eight hundred sick and wounded soldiers arrived at Jersey City, last evening, from Washington. Quartermaster JOHNSON, of this City, had two large steamboats ready for their reception, which had been heated during the afternoon, and on board of which he had placed bedding, blankets, clothing, and other essentials for the well-being and comfort of the soldiers. A corps of nurses and hospital stewards were also in attendance to assist the maimed and helpless on board, and every effort was made to facilitate their careful and tender removal. A hot supper for the convalescent, and soups for the sick, were also provided by Mr. JOHNSON, and competent persons remained on board all night. In addition to this, Medical Director MCDOUGALL was on board, with his assistants, and attended to the medical wants of the sick. This (Sunday) morning they will be served with a nice hot breakfast, and will be taken to the hospital in this vicinity. Quartermaster JOHNSON has been untiring in his exertions to devise ways whereby he could add to the comfort of the suffering soldiers, and he deserves from the community, as he receives from the soldiers daily, their warmest thanks.

abstract: editorial on crisis; editorial on Cabinet crisis
snippet: editorial on crisis; editorial on Cabinet crisis
lead_paragraph: It is not unusual for a military disaster to bring on a political crisis. We are not surprised, therefore, that the defeat at Fredericksburgh should have taken effect upon the Administration at Washington. The first result was Mr. SEWARD's resignation; and this will doubtless be followed by that of the other members of the Cabinet. A correspondent in another part of this morning's TIMES, gives a detailed, and we think an accurate, account of the incidents which led to Mr. SEWARD's retirement. It was caused by a vote of the Republican Senators, in effect holding him individually responsible for the unsatisfactory progress of the war. The Senators who started the movement aimed it avowedly and directly at him alone. They concurred, however, in finally giving it such a direction, as by implication to include others in the scope of its condemnation.

abstract: Capt. Coleman, of schr. John Totten, abandoned at sea, reports: "Sailed from Elizabethport, N.J., bound to New-Market, N.H., with a cargo of coal and pig iron, 6th inst., off Cape Ann, took a heavy gale from N.W., during which lost fore and mainsals, big anchor, boat, galley, &c., and started a leak; was compelled to throw overboard the deck load of pig iron, and obliged to scud before the gale for two days, when we fell in with the Br. brig Princess Alice, Capt. Kerr, and were kindly taken on board."

abstract: The announcements at the various places of amusement are more than usually interestinig to  night. Mr. WERATLEY, the spirited manager of Niblo's Garden, will produce a new version of "Faust and Marguerite," for the purpose of introducing Mr. J. R. ROBERTS, a gentleman who has won much distinction as Mephistophiles.
lead_paragraph: The announcements at the various places of amusement are more than usually interestinig to night. Mr. WERATLEY, the spirited manager of Niblo's Garden, will produce a new version of "Faust and Marguerite," for the purpose of introducing Mr. J. R. ROBERTS, a gentleman who has won much distinction as Mephistophiles. The play is based on [???] well-known work, and whilst affording a one opportunity for scenic display, is, in a literary point of view, immeasurably superior to the average run of spectacles. At the Winter Garden, Mr. BARNEY WILLIAMS revives the "Lakes of Killarney," prepared, also, with unusual care, as a holiday piece, with new scenery, dresses, &c. At Mr. WALLACK's Theatre, "A Bachelor of Arts" will be played; and to-morrow evening, a lively and delightful piece for the laughing season, "The unvisible Husband" will be revived. At Miss LAURA KEENE's the burlesque of "Blondette" is now in its prime and gains favor with the public. It is certainly filed with brilliant scenery and curious mechanical contrivances. At Barnum's Museum BOURCICAULT's drama of the "Colleen Bawn" -- which is excellently placed upon the stage and admirably noted -- is still the sufficient attraction. Great preparations, however, are being made for the holidays, when performances will take place every hour. In the way of miscellaneous entertainments, we would refer our readers to the advertisements of the Palace of Music (Buckley's Serenaders;) of BANWARD's Panorama; of Father Kemp's Old Folk's Concerts, (Cooper Institute;) of the Broadway Menag[???]; of Professor MOORE's series of ventriloquial performances, and of the Artists' Fund Society and Mr. CHURCH's picture.

abstract: We give in other columns a full history of the resignation of Secretary SEWARD, with the causes which influenced him in his decision. It will be seen also that Secretary CHASE tendered his resignation on Saturday morning, and the indications were that an entire reconstruction of the Cabinet would be necessary. Our correspondent
lead_paragraph: We give in other columns a full history of the resignation of Secretary SEWARD, with the causes which influenced him in his decision. It will be seen also that Secretary CHASE tendered his resignation on Saturday morning, and the indications were that an entire reconstruction of the Cabinet would be necessary. Our correspondent telegraphed last night, however, that Mr. SEWARD had consented to resume his position, and it was thought that Mr. CHASE would do likewise. So the reconstruction of the Cabinet will probably be but partial.

abstract: Mr. JOHN F.C. THIELEMANN, a well-known citizen, doing an importing business at No. 75 Murray street, was taken sick in the street on Saturday night while proceeding homeward, and requested an officer to put him into a carriage. As he grew rapidly worse the carriage was driven to the Station House, butdeath intervened before the Station could be reached. Coroner WILDEY was notified and held an inquest in the case and Dr. GEORGE B. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination in the case which showed death to have resulted from disease of the heart. Mr. THIELEMANN was 99 years of age, and resided in Jersey City, where he leaves a family.

abstract: editorial says new postal currency is of such poor quality that it already has been reported counterfeited; editorial says new currency is of such poor guality it already has been reported counterfeited
snippet: editorial says new postal currency is of such poor quality that it already has been reported counterfeited; editorial says new currency is of such poor guality it already has been reported counterfeited
lead_paragraph: people and the Government are absorbed in the consideration of the great events of the day -- those that affect the existence of armies and the continuance of Cabinets in place -- there is reason to fear that many small but still important interests may be lost sight of. Are the people fully alive to the great losses they are liable to suffer through the Postage Currency? And is the Government doing any part of its duty for our protection against the threatened losses? It has already been stated that the Postage Currency notes have been counterfeited. We were about to write successfully counterfeited, but it is a burlesque on success to impute it where there is no difficulty of achievement. It seems that the style of Postage Currency bills furnished by the authorities to the people, was adopted without the slightest suspicion that a value was to be attached to the notes, which might lead dishonest persons to attempt their imitation -- so vile is the paper used and so common and unskilled the designs of the print. Probably there is not a town of twenty thousand inhabitants in the Union that cannot turn out an engraver who can duplicate the plate of any Postage Currency note now in circulation. The counterfeiting of them began within a mouth after their first emission, and if the Government agents do not respond more freely to the wants of the Treasury Department, it will not be long before the bastard bills will be thrown upon the public more rapidly even than the genuine ones.

abstract: Last evening the Thirty-sixth Anniversary of the City Tract Missionary Society was held in the Presbyterian Church, Madison-avenue. Addressed were delivered by several influential clergymen, and at the close, a collection was made to sustain the operation of the Society for 1863. During the past year the Society has distributed 1,200,051 tracts, in various languages, containing 5,129,500 pages; 760 bibles and 911 testaments. The published report shows the Society to be in a prosperous condition, having eight mission stations in various parts of the City.

abstract: The political thunder gust seems nearly spent, which, for a few days past, has agitated with tempestuous emotion the Senate, the Cabinet and the President. abstract: A body of rebel cavalry, variously estimated at from 2,000 to 8,000, made a raid on the railroad three miles this side of Jackson, Tenn., yesterday morning. After firing into a train, they tore up the track for a considerable distance, and burned a long trestle-work.  The operator at Trenton this evening reports an attack on that place. There has even been considerable excitement at Columbus, in anticipation of a rebel visit to that place.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- Midnight.

abstract: The gunboat Marmora arrived to-day from Yazoo River. She brings the crew of the Cairo, which gunboat was destroyed by a torpedo, twenty-one miles up the Yazoo. Friday last, at noon. In a reconnoissance made up the Yazoo some time ago, by the Marmora and Signal, torpedoes were discovered in the river, two miles below Horn's Bluff, where the rebels have a battery of four or five guns.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock on Saturday afternoon. A message from the Mayor, vetoeing the resolution to increase the salaries of the Police Justices to $5,000 per annum, was received and laid over. The Mayor thinks the salaries paid by the city are liberal, and that out of patriotism every municipal or county officer should be satisfied with his present pay, in order to save the city from as much taxation as possible, within reason. The Board were in session but a short time, and adjourned till 5 o'clock, P.M. on Monday.

abstract: G Smith speaks, Cooper Institute, on link between slavery and war
snippet: G Smith speaks, Cooper Institute, on link between slavery and war
lead_paragraph: The "Hall of the Union," Cooper Institute, was filled to repletion last evening by a most intelligent audience, fully one-half of whom were ladies, brought hither to hear the views of Hon. GERRITT SMITH touching the connection of Slavery with the rebellion. OLIVEE JOHNSON, Esq., editor of the Anti-Slavery Standard, presided, and the proceedings were enlivened by choice selections of vocal and instrumental music by Father EZMP'S band of "Old Folks".
