abstract: Sigel testifies
snippet: Sigel testifies
lead_paragraph: During the operations on the Rappahannock I was under the direct orders of Gen. Pope, cooperating with Gen. McDowell. After the engagements at Freeman's Ford, Sulphur Springs and Waterloo Bridge, I received an order from Gen. Pope that my corps were attached to the command of Gen. McDowell. I regarded myself under his orders from this time until after the battle of Bull Run. I cannot give the exact date of the engagements without the papers. I cannot give the date when I went to Harper's Ferry and Winchester. We arrived at Harper's Ferry about the 6th of June, and I marched the same day to Winchester. I arrived at Culpepper on the 9th of August, during the battle of Gen. Banks at Cedar Mountain. After the battle of Cedar Mountain my corps marched to Robertson River and Crooked Creek. We left this position in the middle of August, and marched by [???] River to Sulphur Springs, and from this to Rappahannock Station, where we joined Gen. McDowell's Corps. On the 24th of August we were at ----- Bridge, and on the 27th in Warrenton. On the 28th we marched from Gainesville toward Manassas, Gen. McDowell following the First Corps -- my Corps -- which was at that time the first. I do not know how far Gen. McDowell followed my movements from that day. I had orders to march to Manassas, and took the shortest road I could find. This was on Aug. 28. During the march from Gainesville to Manassas I heard firing to lay left. I marched toward that point and formed in line of battle, when I received orders from Gen. McDowell to march to Manasses. When my advanced guard arrived at Manassas it was reported that there was no enemy there; that the enemy had retreated to Centreville; I therefore sent my Aid-de-Camp to Gen. Pope to get permission to march to New-Market. He then directed me to march to Centreville. On this march, when we arrived near New-Market, I met a detachment of the enemy, which I attached immediately, and advanced toward Grovetown. During this engagement we heard firing on our left, which I supposed came from part of Gen. McDowell's corps. It had become dark, and my camp pen that night was on the heights near Mrs. Henry's farm, near Grovetown, when, on the morning of the 29th, I received direct orders from Gen. Pope to attack the enemy, which I did about 5 o'clock in the morning. I did not know where Gen. McDowell's Corps was at that tone, nor where any other troops were, except those of the enemy. During the 29th, and toward noon, when all the troops of my corps were engaged with the enemy, I received a dispatch from Gen. Pope, saying that Gen. McDowell and Gen. Porter would attack the enemy's, right flank, and would come on on my left; and that we had probably to go back to Centreville that night, to get provisions. This is what I remember; I can probably find the original dispacth of Gen. Pope. I do not know whether any attack was made by Gen. McDowell, or when his troops arrived on my left, because I was too much occupied on the right, where the battle was principally fought. I did not see Gen. McDowell during that day, until 6:30 P.M., when I saw Gen. McDowell and his staff arriving. On the next day, the 30th August, I did not know where Gen. McDowell's Corps was, and did not sec Gen. McDowell during the whole day, as much as I can remember; but I knew that Gen. Reynolds' Division was on the left of our line, or near the left of our line, on the 29th and 30th. On the 30th of August, when Gen. Porter made his attack on the centre and was forced to retreat, I received a dispatch, which I believe was transmitted to me by an officer of Gen. McDowell's Staff, but the dispatch was written by Gen. Porter, as much as I can remember. In this dispatch, it was said that probably the conflict would end fatally, and that Gen. McDowell should push my corps forward. I did not receive an order, but made all preparations to assist Gen. Porter or to take his troops up, who were at that time coming out of the woods by squads. I did not receive any order from Gen. McDowell during the day. I have also to add in regard to the connection between the corps and that of Gen. McDowell, that when at Sulphur Springs Gen. Pope wrote to me that Gen. McDowell would assist me in supporting him at Waterloo Bridge; but I did not see any troops of Gen. McDowell's there, or some miles from that point; and at Waterloo Bridge, on that same day I received an order through Gen. McDowell, of which one page was missing, so that I did not know what my orders were. I immediately sent to Gen. McDowell for orders, but he answered that he could not give me any. Allow me to say that I sent to McDowell for instructions, because I am not sure that when I received the order from Gen. Pope that my corps was attached to that of Gen. McDowell's, but I can find it our. The officer whom I had sent to Gen. McDowell then proceeded to Warrenton Junction to find Gen. Pope; he returned nearly at dark with an order from Gen. Pope for my corps to march to Warrenton that night which I did. When the corps was at Warrenton with the main force, and I came in with the rearguard at two and a half o'clock A.M. on the next morning, I met an officer of Gen. McDowell's at the entrance of the town, who deliverer me a dispatch in which it was said that I should force with my corps the pass at Waterloo, on that same morning, which was an impossibility. I state this to show that I received an order from Gen. McDowell on that morning. When my corps had arrived at Gainesville I received an order that night from Gen. McDowell at three o'clock in the morning, saving that I should march to Manassas. I asked the orderly when he had left Gen. McDowell, and he said he had left him two hours ago -- although the headquarters of Gen. McDowell were not more than two hundred paces from my quarters. Those are the principal facts which I can give you.

abstract: Editorial, holding courts-martial take too long to prepare and remove many needed men from battlefield, proposes trials and punishments be carried out right in camp
snippet: Editorial, holding courts-martial take too long to prepare and remove many needed men from battlefield, proposes trials and punishments be carried out right in camp
lead_paragraph: A member of Congress has given notice of his intention to bring in a bill, giving soldiers and officers convicted by Courts-martial the right of appeal at any time within six months after receiving sentence, and giving the President the power of ordering a new trial. If we concurred in the principle of this bill, we should object to it on the ground that it does not go far enough. If we thought that the soldier in the field was entitled to two trials, and to six months' time in which to lodge an appeal whenever he committed an offence, we should object to his being tried by Court-martial at all, and urge the passage of an act giving him the benefit of the common law and of the habeas corpus. We should recommend the detailing of Justices of the Peace to each regiment, and two or three Judges of the Courts of Record to every division, and compel officers, in case of a man's skulking, or deserting, or disobeying, to the bills for specific performance, or bring actions for damages against the culprit before juries of privates, and give in every case the usual right of appeal to the general term of the Court of Appeals, with the usual delays for printing cases, taking evidence by commission, &c., &c.

abstract: "Who it is, I can't say; all I can say is, somebody ought to be wopped for this." A very natural feeling, that of Sam. Weller, when things go wrong. Were the feeling, as in his case, confined to the indefinite somebody, there, perhaps, would be no great harm in it -- though it is notorious that things often do go wrong when nobody is really in fault, inasmuch as all human affairs are more or less at the mercy of fortune. But the great mischief is that men in this humor are apt to hit out incontinently against any one who happens to be in their way, and, in their blind choler, are as apt to "wop" the innocent as the guilty. Matters are only made worse by this folly, and yet it is common enough.

snippet: proceedings continue; Anniversary dinner, NYC
lead_paragraph: The Sons of New-England held their annual festival at the Astor House last evening. At 7 o'clock the three large tables running the entire length of the dining-room were filled with the members of the Society and the prominent natives of New-England residing in or transiently stopping in New-York. WM M. EVARTS, Esq., President of the Society, presided at the officers' table, having as guests Brig.-Gen. ANDREWS and Gen. WHITE, of Massachusetts; Judge DALY, President of the St. Patrick's Society; EDWALKER, Esq., of the St. George's Society; PARKE GODWIN, Esq., of the New-York Evening Post, and other gentlemen. Each table was decorated with pyramidal confections and pieces descriptive of the landing of the Pilgrims, and a fac simile of the Mayflower. The room and all the tables were lighted with red, white and blue candles. Full justice having been done to the luxuries provided by the host, Mr. STETSON, and the cloth having been removed, the toasts were then taken up.

abstract: INQUEST ON THE BODY OF ONE OF THE VICTIMS. -- It will be recollected that a very serious accident occurred to a train on the New-York and Erie Railroad, about 7 1/2 o'clock on Friday evening last. The train was coming East, and when near Ramsay's Station, about twenty-seven miles from Jersey City, the boiler exploded. A young man named CALLAHAN, who acted as firemen, was thrown with great violence from the train and instantly killed. Mr. WM. CALLOHAN, the Engineer, was also found at some distance from the place where the train stopped, in a horribly mangled condition. He was put on board the cars, brought to this City and placed in the New-York Hospital, where he remained in an insensible condition until Saturday evening, when he died. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest upon his body yesterday. The jury rendered the following verdict, viz.: "That death was the result of a compound fracture of the skull, caused by the explosion of an engine of the New-York and Erie Railroad."
lead_paragraph: INQUEST ON THE BODY OF ONE OF THE VICTIMS. -- It will be recollected that a very serious accident occurred to a train on the New-York and Erie Railroad, about 7 1/2 o'clock on Friday evening last. abstract: events, probably many of our readers have already forgotten the startling reports which reached us by telegraph of the extraordinary behavior of Gen. MCDOWELL, as attested by Gen. SIGEL, on the battle-field of Manassas, in the Pope campaign. It was asserted that Gen. SIGEL had detected MCDOWELL waving his handkerchief as a treasonable signal to the enemy -- that he marched his men up to be surrendered -- that Gen. SIGEL rode up and indignantly demanded explanations of his conduce, and that, failing to receive them, he shot the detected traitor on the spot. The next day it was ascertained that MCDOWELL was not dead, and that SIGEL's bullet glanced from his sabre. But confirmations of the main part of the story continued to come in, and probably thousands and tens of thousands of our people settled down into a calm conviction of its truth.

abstract: editorial holds crisis over; editorial notes Cabinet crisis seems to have passed; says success of Senate move would have been a disaster
snippet: editorial holds crisis over; editorial notes Cabinet crisis seems to have passed; says success of Senate move would have been a disaster
lead_paragraph: The latest advices from Washington import that the "ministerial crisis," as it is styled, has passed, and that the members of the old Cabinet are all back in their places. We are not sure whether this is the best result that could have been attained, under the circumstances, or not. We are inclined to believe that the confidence of the country in the Administration would have been increased by the infusion of new blood into the Cabinet. But we have no hesitation in saying that this result is infinitely better than would have been the ejection of Mr. SEWARD from the Cabinet, through the action taken by the Senate caucus.

abstract: Spencer S. Benedict et al. vs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. -- The plaintiffs, in their right of Harbor Masters of the port of New-York, claim to recover from the defendant, as owner of the steamships Vanderbilt, North Star. Ariel and Northern Light, certain tonnage duties, imposed by a statute of this State, upon vessels entering the port of New-York and making fast to a wharf. The complaint claims that this tonnage duty is 1 1/2 cents upon each ton in the register of the vessels, payable within forty-eight hours after the arrival of the vessel, and that in default of payment within the limited time, double the amount is recoverable by the plaintiffs by action in any Court of competent jurisdiction.

abstract: -- The pupils of theBrooklyn Packer Institute hold their annual Christmas Festival to-night in the chapel of the institution. There will be performed, or rather exhibited, a Panorama Vivant of the Progress of civilization, called. "Tides in the Affairs of Men." which beginning at the First Era, 1491 years B.C., with the story of Egyptian Bondage, runs through the darkness of the Middle Ages, brightening with the promises of the Reformatory Era, and concluding with the glories of the Era or Liberty. Those who are favored with tickets are most fortunate.

abstract: The trial of GEORGE WILKES, Esq., editor of Wilkes' Spirit of the Times, for libel upon JOHN LAWRENCE, was resumed in this Court yesterday morning. A large crowd of spectators was in attendance. There was a delay of over an hour after the opening of the Court, caused by the non-attendance of the witnesses summoned for the defence. Attachments were issued-against them, but they were not forthcoming, and, as the Recorder would not keep the Court waiting, the defence had to close their testimony without them. In consequence of the absence of witnesses the testimony had to be taken very irregularly, the defence and the prosecution calling witnesses alternately, according as they could catch them in Court.

abstract: Our Havana correspondent gives an interesting account of the arrival there of the new CaptainGeneral of Cuba, DULCE, which event took place on the 9th instant, although he did not make his public entry into the city until the 11th. His predecessor, Gen. SERRANO, took his departure a day or two afterward. The addresses delivered on the two occasions are given in our correapondent's letter. PIERRE SOULE is now a resident of Havana.

abstract: Considerable interest has lately been produced among the members of the Police Department, in regard to the way in which it was proposed to expend the Japanese Fund, and although, as it appears, a large majority of the force were in favor of distributing the proceeds of it among the families of those who have thrown up their situations in the Department, and gone to fight the battles of their country, a few were found opposed to this plan. Accordingly the Commissioners have, as will be seen by the following resolution passed yesterday, come to the conclusion to make a compromise of the whole difficulty.

abstract: GEORGE W. HOPKINS, a pupil of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb in this City, absented himself, on Sunday, Nov. 30, and has not since been heard from. His parents reside at Fishkill Landing, and as, after making diligent inquiry, and advertising in the City newspapers, no tidings have been received of him, it is supposed that he had taken some public conveyance, for the purpose of going home, but was carried in a wrong direction. He is twelve years of age, has a slender figure, fair complexion, blue eyes, and light brown hair. His name is maked on his clothing. He belongs to the class of deaf mutes, but having lost his hearing in childhood, he still retains some knowledge of articulate sounds, and can utter a few words, though not very intelligible to strangers -- such as his own name and the place of his residence. He was admitted into the Institution last September, and consequently has not acquired written language, so as to enable him to communicate with others, except to a very limited extent.
lead_paragraph: GEORGE W. HOPKINS, a pupil of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb in this City, absented himself, on Sunday, Nov. 30, and has not since been heard from. He belongs to the class of deaf mutes, but having lost his hearing in childhood, he still retains some knowledge of articulate sounds, and can utter a few words, though not very intelligible to strangers -- such as his own name and the place of his residence. He was admitted into the Institution last September, and consequently has not acquired written language, so as to enable him to communicate with others, except to a very limited extent.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a communication was received from the Secretary of War, relative to the chartering of steamers for the Banks Expedition. It appears that Gen. BANKS was authorized to procure his vessels from Commodore VANDERBILT, but that no official report has yet been received from Gen. BANKS in regard to the matter. A letter was also submitted from the owners of the steamer Thames, similar in purport to the one published by us yesterday. A resolution, providing for a Select Committee of Inquiry, was adopted. A memorial from the Express Companies, asking for an amendment of the Internal Revenue law, was presented. A resolution was adopted, directing an inquiry into the expediency of abolishing the Marine Corps as a naval organization, and attaching it to the army as the Twentieth Regiment of Infantry. The Secretary of the Navy was called upon for information regarding the appointment of a greater number of Captains and Commanders than are authorized by law. The resolution, inquiring whether any person arrested had been required to take an oath not to sue those arresting them, was passed. A motion to refer Mr. SAULSBURY's resolution, relative to sending troops into Delaware on the occasion of the election there, to the Military Committee, was debated until the expiration of the morning hour, when the bill relating to the discharge of State prisoners was taken up. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, and others addressed the Senate, which subsequently adjourned, after an Executive session.

abstract: There were during the past week 330 deaths in the city and county of New-York, of which 66 were of men, 81 women, 101 boys, 82 girls; 147 adults, 183 children; 167 males, 163 females, and 4 colored persons. The most frequent fatal diseases were consumption, of which there were 55 cases; inflammation of the lungs, 28; scarlet fever 22; croup, 21; and other infantile illnesses, 34. There were also 8 cases of typhoid and I of typus fever, and four deaths from old age.

abstract: It is refreshing in these days of shirking and sneaking to find a man willing to take the full responsibility of his acts, and especially of his failures. Gen. BURNSIDE'S letter to Gen. HALLECK is a model of manliness and true courage. While the popular heart is
lead_paragraph: It is refreshing in these days of shirking and sneaking to find a man willing to take the full responsibility of his acts, and especially of his failures. Gen. BURNSIDE'S letter to Gen. HALLECK is a model of manliness and true courage. While the popular heart is swelling with grief and indignation over the repulse at Fredericksburgh, -- while a howl of wrath goes up from every quarter against the officials at Washington for having forced Gen. BURNSIDE to make this attack against his judgment and in spite of his protest, and while, one after another, his subordinate commanders seek to clear their skirts of all responsibility, the General himself calmly informs the country that he alone is responsible for the failure, -- that the Government, through every Department, gave him to the full its confidence and support, -- that the "extreme gallantry, courage and endurance shown by his troops were never exceeded," and that he is largely indebted to the Division Commanders and to all his officers for their support and hearty cooperation.

abstract: Affairs at the Brooklyn Navy-yard are exceedingly brisk, over five thousand men being employed, many of them by night and day. The caulkers, especially, are kept busy incessantly. The different houses and shops, of which hardly more than a single department of each was used in time of peace, prove too small for the exigencies of war.
lead_paragraph: Affairs at the Brooklyn Navy-yard are exceedingly brisk, over five thousand men being employed, many of them by night and day. The caulkers, especially, are kept busy incessantly. The different houses and shops, of which hardly more than a single department of each was used in time of peace, prove too small for the exigencies of war. Hence the great ordnance rendezvous, which was as large and roomy as a long block of city houses, is now increased by the addition of an entire story; several additional forges have been added to the blacksmith's department, an immense bakkehouse is soon to be constructed, and no less than two paddle-wheel steamers are in progress in the open air, while the ship-houses are also taken up with new craft. The Lyceum, in which the different, officers of the yard have their bureaus, is crowded always with persons who were not supposed to even have any business there when it was built. The Storekeeper, the Commandant, the Commander, the Purser, the Constructor, of the yard, are obliged for the present to work in old quarters.

abstract: Secretaries SEWARD and CHASE are once more at their places in the State and Treasury Departments. The President, we learn from Washington, acknowledged the reception of their resignations, and informed them that after due deliberation he had come to the conclusion that their acceptance would be "incompatible with the public welfare." He therefore requested both Mr. SEWARD and Mr. CHASE to resume their respective functions, and they have done so. The cabinet thus remains precisely as before.
lead_paragraph: Secretaries SEWARD and CHASE are once more at their places in the State and Treasury Departments. The President, we learn from Washington, acknowledged the reception of their resignations, and informed them that after due deliberation he had come to the conclusion that their acceptance would be "incompatible with the public welfare." He therefore requested both Mr. SEWARD and Mr. CHASE to resume their respective functions, and they have done so. The cabinet thus remains precisely as before.

abstract: editorial lauds his recent successes
snippet: editorial lauds his recent successes
lead_paragraph: Again the rebel report of a disaster to our arms in North Carolina is followed by our own report of a victory. A day or two ago, it will be remembered, we published a rebel dispatch, received by way of Nashville, dated at Wilmington, N.C., announcing that Gen. FOSTER had attacked Goldsboro, but had been repulsed with great slaughter. This morning we have a dispatch from Gen. FOSTER, which, though covering but a dozen lines, is pregnant with importance and success. He says he has burned the railroad bridges at Goldsboro and Mount Olive, and torn up several miles of the track of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad. Four engagement have been fought -- atSouthwest Creek, Kinston, White Hall and Goldsboro -- in all of which the enemy have, to use Gen. FOSTER's expression, been "handsomely whipped." The details of these brilliant operations will be awaited with much interest. No intimation as to our losses is given.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a message was received from the President, transmitting the report of Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, as Commissioner to New-Orleans. The House resolution, to adjourn over for the holidays, was concurred in. A resolution, making the inquiries of the Committee appointed to investigate the matter of the Banks' transports general, was adopted. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, gave notice of a bill to authorize the President to raise two hundred regiments of colored soldiers.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a message was received from the President, transmitting the report of Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, as Commissioner to New-Orleans. The House resolution, to adjourn over for the holidays, was concurred in. A resolution, making the inquiries of the Committee appointed to investigate the matter of the Banks' transports general, was adopted. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, gave notice of a bill to authorize the President to raise two hundred regiments of colored soldiers. A bill for the relief of the owners of the Norwegian bark Admiral P. Tordenskiold was reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations. The resolution relative to sending troops into the State of Delaware during the election was discussed until the expiration of the morning hour, when the Bankrupt bill was taken up and debated at considerable length. During the proceedings, a report from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, relative to the disaster at Fredericksburgh, was handed in and ordered to be printed. After an Executive Session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: We were standing, the other day, in Barnum's Museum, looking at the male and female Esquimaux and the little picaninny, and talking to Capt. Hall, the distinguished Arctic explorer, who brought the strangers down with htm. Among the topics of conversation were the handsome dresses of skins of Arctic animals worn by the Esquimaux, and Capt. Hall gave us some very interesting information in regard to the polar bear, the white polar fox, the seal, and other animals from which the adventurous hunters manage to derive subsistence for themselves and to supply luxuries to others. Speaking of polar bears: "They have some very fine specimens of polar bear skins now in the City," said the Captain. We remarked that we had occasionally seen one, burarely one large enough or fine enough to be worthy of special notice. "Eh, havn't you, though?" said the Captain; "Well, just put on your hat and light one of these cigars, and go out with me for only a few steps, and see if we cannot find a few." We followed his directions and went out with him to Broadway, expecting to be introduced to some kind of "Fur Company" or other, Marvel of marvels! he merely led us down the sidewalk a few steps, and into KNOX's, No. 212 Broadway, corner of Fulton-street. KNOX was busy selling hats and chatting with customers, and the Captain led us down the counter, past piles of what seemed to be Arctic fox skins, and showed us a skin suspended from the top shelf on the Fulton-street side. "There," he said, "there is one of the very largest and finest Polar bear skins I ever saw, and I have seen many thousands." We examined it. It was really a marvel in size and quality -- pure cream white, without a spot or blemish, and enough to make the very soul of a fashionable sleigh rider content. But that was not all. The Captain, who seemed to have paid several visits to "KNOX's Arctic Regions" previously, showed us others of those superb bear skins, of nearly the same size and value. Then he showed us such a wilderness of other rich Arctic furs, fox, lynx, sable and otter, as we had thought could not be found nearer than Siberia or the Hudson's Bay Territory, and concluded by calling our attention to a splendid assortment of Buffalo Robes, trimmed in the handsomest manner, and many others without trimmings, tanned so as to shed water like a mackintosh, and especially fitted for keeping dampness and eventual rheumatism out of the legs of soldiers who sleep upon the ground. The Captain informed us, speaking of this, that the Indians of the far Northwest never have such an ache as rheumatism, no matter how much they sleep upon the damp ground, owing to the fact that they always sleep upon the impervious tanned skin of the Buffalo. By this time, and looking around to see what a splendid collection of Ladies' Furs, of all styles and qualities he had in his boxes ready for the visits of the fashionable, we became aware that KNOX really kept the most extensive fur store in the City, in addition to his extensive trade in head coverings. We had long known him as the leading Hatter in the City, keeping one of the very largest assortments of Hats, Caps, Fur Caps and Soft Hats always on head in the cool season, as well as Panamas and other light Hats in Summer, and making Dress Hats to order with a rapidity and skill to which no other manufacturer could pretend. But we had no idea, until Capt. Hall opened our eyes, how extensive and choice was his stock of Furs -- ready, apparently, to accommodate all tastes and all pockets. KNOX himself, meanwhile, was about half the time busled in seiling Military Caps to officers who continually came dropping in; and from the conversations held between one and another, and which we occasionally overheard, we learned that he had a peculiar reputation through the whole service for furnishing blue Cloth Caps, both for army and navy, of such excellent dyed-in-the-wool material, that while those from other makers became gray and dingy after being out in the rain a few times, those of KNOX never faded, and come back looking about as bright as when they went away. Then we took a general look around the establishment and studied the Fall and Winter styles of Hats, more curved in the brim, and with more bell to the crown than they have before been for a long period, and unmistakably French in their whole appearance. Then he had a short chat with KNOX himself, who is quite as much an object of interest as any object he has in his collection, being an unmistakably earnest business man, who thinks that every man should devote his whole energies to the profession he has chosen, and who believes (with good reason) that the mission of a man who makes a better Hat than his neighbor, is just as important and just as noble as that of the man who preaches a better sermon, or the other man who makes a more telling speech. Such men as KNOX, who buld up a business like his, with probity at the bottom, and enterprise and taste furnishing the superstructure, are among the reliable features of an unreliable age, and we cannot pass them by without a word of appreciation when we happen to meet them, All these things impressed us more than ever with the fact that KNOX's, No. 212 Broadway, corner Fulton-street, is as much of an institution as the City Hall, or the Museum itself; and so, bidding good day to the Arctic Captain -- who ordered a new Fur Tippet, and carried it back to the Esquimaux woman to delight her heart on Thanksgiving Day -- we had our measure taken for the new Winter Dress Hat we had been so long intending to order, and came away, intending at the time to put KNOX before the people in precisely this manner.

abstract: Foster reports capturing Goldsboro, NC
snippet: Foster reports capturing Goldsboro, NC
lead_paragraph: The victorious feats of Gen. FOSTER, in North Carolina, come to the country as gleams of light and glory in a dark hour. The dispatch which he sends concerning the work he performed in the week extending from Saturday, the 13th, to Saturday, the 20th inst., is brief and soldierly. In four lines he chronicles as many triumphs: "We fought," says he, "four engagements, viz.: At Southwest Creek, Kinston, Whitehall and Goldsboro, and whipped the enemy handsomely each time."
headline: {'main': 'Goldsboro Captured--Four Battles and Four Victories in One Week.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Goldsboro Captured--Four Battles and Four Victories in One Week.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday was another eventful day in our iron-clad navy. The United States steam battery Montauk left this City, her commander, Capt. WORDEN, receiving a perfect ovation on his departure. As early as 10 o'clock A.M. crowds of persons endeavored to obtain admission to the Navy-yard to witness the departure of the gallant officer, and his new Monitor. All were kept outside, however, save a favored few. Steam was got up on board the Montauk at an early hour, and Admiral PAULDING was informed at 10 1/2 that she was about to leave. Officers then thronged the wharf, and when Capt. WORDEN arrived each took a warm farewell of him. The scene was most affecting. Prophecies of great events, and fresh laurels soon to be won, were heaped upon him. On board the receiving-ship North Carolina the enthusiasm of sailors, both recruits and old salts, was so marked, that the commanding officer ordered the rigging to be manned, after which three rousing cheers were given for the hero of the Monitor. At 11 o'clock the Montauk began to move, and cheers greeted her as she turned seaward. The engines were subjected to a brisk pressure of steam, and commenced making over forty revolutions a minute. Considerable anxiety was felt lest the boilers should leak again, as it was their doing so which prevented the departure of the vessel for some days. They remained tight, however, and worked well all the way down the river. Opposite Fulton Ferry boatmen and passengers on the river shouted and waved handkerchiefs in an excited manner. The speed attained on the trip down the Bay was nearly seven miles an hour, although the engines were not doing their best. When off the Battery the Revenue ensign and the flags of all naval vessels and transports were dipped, it having been known who commanded the Montauk. There was no stopping for powder, and at about 1 1/2 o'clock, the low hull of the "Monitor No. 4," disappeared in the distance. Annexed is a list of the Montauk's officers;

abstract: A reconnoissance last night by a squadron of the Third North Carolina Cavalry, under Capt. CARROWAY, found the enemy encamped about two miles below Whitehall. The citizens represent them as scared and out of food and ammunition. A rumor on the streets this morning says reinforcements have passed Kinston, on the south side of the Neuse, to succor their skedaddling friends.

abstract: Editorial on Grant retreat and lack of action in Tennessee
snippet: Editorial on Grant retreat and lack of action in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The war news continues to come in unfavorably from the Southwest. From the day of Gen. GRANT's pause at Oxford, Mississippi, the rebel reaction against his movement has been manifest. Gen. HOVEY's expedition against Grenada came to nought because it was a cooperating demonstration, only lacking in the vital element that it failed entirely to cooperate. There was no communication between GRANT and HOVEY, and the former did not know that the latter had been near Grenada until HOVEY returned to Helena and reported the fact via Cairo, Columbus and Holly Springs! Cooperation between commands thus distant and isolated is a remarkable idea.The grand combination between GRANT, SHERMAN and HOVEY that promised so much in the matter of clearing the State of Mississippi of rebel armies and opening up the Mississippi River, having ended so unsatisfactorily, it became a very serious question with some, whether any forward movement of our whole forces had been really intended. But we see no reason to doubt that the general advance was meditated, and that it has been arrested for causes not given to the public. In no other way can we excuse Gen. GRANT for the present position of his army. He abandoned Jackson, Bolivar, Corinth and Grand Junction -- all very valuable strategic points in and for West Tennessee, which were strongly held by his troops, and in which positions he was able to keep his communications easily open with his base at Cairo. He was likewise able to keep the rebel troops pressed down into Mississippi. The citizens of West Tennessee being thus delivered from Confederate authority were rapidly returning to their senses, resuming their ordinary avocations, engaging in trade and taking steps to elect members to the National Congress. Conventions were held, and nearly every county in West Tennessee was well represented by Union delegates. Candidates of sterling loyalty were nominated, and it seemed likely that a formal return to the Union of all that part of the State would soon be witnessed. But as soon as Gen. GRANT moved on to Oxford the rebel hordes began to rush in behind him, and now all that section of Tennessee where loyalty was so lately nurtured into strength is given up to Confederate occupation and pillage, except just around the military posts which are garrisoned. The rebel conscript law will be enforced, hundreds of recruits obtained, the elections broken up, and those loyal citizens that took part in the Union movement subjected to wrong and violence.

abstract: The schooner Mary E. Mangum, HALLETT, from Dominica in twenty-five days, reports that on the night of Nov. 27, while entering the port of Rosean, Dominica, she was fired into by the rebel steamer Alabama. She fired two shots at her and then steered away. Dec. 1, at night, when passing the Island of Guadaloupe saw the Alabama making signals to the shore. Next day saw her anchored close in shore, apparently receiving provisions.
lead_paragraph: The schooner Mary E. Mangum, HALLETT, from Dominica in twenty-five days, reports that on the night of Nov. 27, while entering the port of Rosean, Dominica, she was fired into by the rebel steamer Alabama. She fired two shots at her and then steered away. Dec. 1, at night, when passing the Island of Guadaloupe saw the Alabama making signals to the shore. Next day saw her anchored close in shore, apparently receiving provisions.

abstract: SOLDIERS' BURIAL-GROUND. -- Yesterday morning Alderman FARLEY, Chairman of the Committee on National Affairs, accompanied by President HENRY, of the Board of Aldermen, and Aldermen BRADY, BOOLE, REED, MITCHELL, OTTIWELL and SMITH, and Councilman JONES, visited Calvary Cemetery, to view the plot of ground recently accepted by the City as a gift from the Trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral, for the interment of Catholic soldiers from this City who fall in the war. At the cemetery gate the party were met by the Trustees who donated the land, and were escorted by them to the plot specially sat apart for the purpose. It is about fifty feet square, and handsomely situated on high ground, nearly at the crest of a hill, and overlooks, a large portion of the surrounding country. Near by are graves with headstones bearing dates as far back as 1650, at a spot that was used long after, as well as long before, the Revolution, as a family burying-ground, by the early settlers who occupied the farm of 120 acres, now converted into a great cemetery. The appropriateness of such a contiguous position to this spot for the Union soldiers' resting place was recognized and commended by all the visitors. Having satisfied their curiosity here, the party were conducted by Mr. D. CAROLIN, the Secretary of the Cemetery Board of Managers, to the residence of Father JOYCE, situated a short distance off to the eastward, and within the cemetery grounds. There the entire party were hospitably entertained by the Rev. Father, who paid a high compliment to the Common Council for their liberality in providing for the wants of the families of volunteers. Aldermen Ottiwell, Farley, Reed, Mitchell, Henry and Boole, and Councilman Jones made remarks in response to various sentiments, some personal and others complimentary to the Municipality of New-York, offered by other gentlemen of the party, and all gave the due meed of praise to the cemetery authorities for their liberality and patriotism, in being the first, and, so, far, the only donors to the Corporation of a burial plot for the Interment of the patriotic dead. The gift, it should be added, was originally intended only for the benefit of such Catholic soldiers as might die in the hospitals of the City, but the more liberal condition of including all Catholic soldiers of New-York, falling in the war, has since been added to the terms of the donation. The deed for the land is now being prepared. The visitors returned to the City at 1 o'clock in the afternoon, much pleased with their jaunt. It now remains for the Common Council to inclose the burial plot with a suitable railing and place an appropriate monument in the centre of it.
lead_paragraph: SOLDIERS' BURIAL-GROUND. -- Yesterday morning Alderman FARLEY, Chairman of the Committee on National Affairs, accompanied by President HENRY, of the Board of Aldermen, and Aldermen BRADY, BOOLE, REED, MITCHELL, OTTIWELL and SMITH, and Councilman JONES, visited Calvary Cemetery, to view the plot of ground recently accepted by the City as a gift from the Trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral, for the interment of Catholic soldiers from this City who fall in the war. abstract: -- It has been the customol -- Principal of one of the most fashionable schools for young ladies in the City to prepare every year a magnificent Christmas Tree, filled with beautiful and costly presents, for her scholars. Circumstances have this year induced her to give the tree, not to her fair scholars but to the ladies who are providing for the wants of our sick and wounded heroes. Its exhibition and the sale of the presents, on Friday, at Irving Hall, as our readers will see by the advertisement, will surely be the occasion of a brilliant gathering of fashionable belles who are not yet "out," of various ages, from sweet seven to sweeter seventeen.

abstract: A supplementary dispatch from Gen. FOSTER has been received by the Government to-day, in regard to the capture of Goldsboro, in which he states that the rebels are reported to be advancing upon him in heavy force, estimated at 25,000, for the purpose of driving him from his position. He is confident of his ability successfully to resist until reinforcements can reach him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Dec. 23.

abstract: The war needs many amendments doubtless; but the prime one is this: the people must deal more fairly by the Government, and the Government more fairly by the people. The Government and the people have reciprocal rights and duties. These must be better observed on both sides, or failure is inevitable.

abstract: The "Ironsides" Regiment (One Hundred and Seventy-sixth New-York State Volunteers,) now quartered on the line of the Long Island Railroad, about half-a-mile from the village of Jamaica, numbers upwards of 800 men. The regiment is prepared to move to the seat of war at any moment. Yesterday was quite a gala day among them, it being the occasion of the presentation of a stand of colors to the "Ironsides" on behalf of the ladies of New-York. The regimental banners are seven in number, the largest being of blue silk bearing the coat-of-arms of the State, beautifully embroidered, and costing in all $350. Accompanying this was a national flag, regimental size, of blue, white and red silk, the stars in the blue ground being tinsel-work. A large deputation of New-York ladies were on the platform during the presentation ceremonies, while numbers of the "sterner sex," friends of the "Ironsides," took occasion to exchange congratulations with the regiment on this interesting occasion. At 2 1/2 P.M., Rev. Dr. STORRS, who had been selected to make the presentation on behalf of the lady donors, ascended the platform temporarily erected for the occasion, the regiment having been, in the meantime, formed in hollow square around it, and after thanking the ladies for the honor conferred by selecting him, spoke substantially as follows:

abstract: Yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock Grammar School No. 19 held the anniversary of its opening at the School-house in Fourteenth-street, near First-avenue. The school-room was prettily decorated with evergreens and draped with flags. At one end of the room was the inscription "Excelsior;" at the other "Welcome Christmas," both of which were formed by evergreens. A large number of the parents and friends of the scholars were present, and appeared highly delighted at the performances of the children. The programme consisted of reading andsinging, the most noticeable of which were the reading of "The Bells" by six young ladies, and the declamation of "The Ravens" by Master SAMSON ADELS. Class Section C performed several military evolutions with a precision that reflected great-credit on their drill-master. Mr. WILLIAM SMEATON is principal of this school.

abstract: -- Among the juvenile books that are in the market about this time, those published by the HARPERS must not be forgotten. Theirs are the standard works -- the classical ones, so to speak -- of the youthful library. The Rollo Books, The Franconia Stories, Dickens' and Bonner's Child's Histories, The Child's Book of Quadrupeds, The Child's Book of Birds, and a hundred of books and series of books, neatly and uniformly bound, and securely packed for transportation in the snuggest, strongest and most portable of boxes, suggest themselves as necessaries as well as delicacies of the season.

abstract: A melancholy case of suicide, by shooting, occurred on Monday morning at the private boarding-house, No. 240 West Thirty-second-street. The victim was a young man named EDWARD TOMLINS, aged about 19 years, and was regarded by all his friends and acquaintances as a young person of good moral character and promising business habits. For nearly two years past he has been employed in the store of Messrs. T.S. YOUNG & Co., wholesale clothiers, No. 120 Chambers-street. Upon his entrance into that establishment, he came highly recommended to his employers, and be soon exhibited such a marked talent for business, and was withal so apparently conscientious and honest, that his employers were induced to repose the most implicit confidence in him. He had not been long with them before the whole charge of the books of the firm were intrusted to his care, and for several months past he has acted as their cashier. In the latter position, large amounts of money passed daily through his hands, and many workmen were weekly paid by him -- he making the entry of such payments in the books of the concern in such a manner as best suited his purposes. During the last four months, his employers and others noticed, with some surprise, that the young man was very extravagant in dress, and also in some other respects, but, strange as it may appear, they did not for a moment suspect that he was robbing their money-drawer. Their idea seems to have been that their fast clerk was living beyond his means, or perhaps that he was in the receipt of money from his parents. One thing was very certain in their judgment -- the young man could not afford to indulge in all the luxuries and extravagances by which he surrounded himself upon the paltly sum of $300 a year, which was the salary paid him by this firm. He was seen morning after morning to come to his place of business in a carriage, and when the labors of the day were over a carriage awaited at the store door to convey him to his boarding-house; and yet such was the confidence with which this firm trusted young TOMLIN's, that it never occurred to them to examine the cash-book or drawer, to see whether or not their confidence was misplaced. But the 1st of January was drawing near; the time was approaching when as the habit is with all thorough business men, the accounts of the year would be overhauled, and all errors, whether of head of heart, on the part of the book-keeper and cashier, would be brought to light. The result of this examination would involve the clerk in hopeless ruin. This was, no doubt, the reasoning of the young man, as the sequel will show.
lead_paragraph: A melancholy case of suicide, by shooting, occurred on Monday morning at the private boarding-house, No. 240 West Thirty-second-street. The victim was a young man named EDWARD TOMLINS, aged about 19 years, and was regarded by all his friends and acquaintances as a young person of good moral character and promising business habits. Upon his entrance into that establishment, he came highly recommended to his employers, and be soon exhibited such a marked talent for business, and was withal so apparently conscientious and honest, that his employers were induced to repose the most implicit confidence in him. He had not been long with them before the whole charge of the books of the firm were intrusted to his care, and for several months past he has acted as their cashier. In the latter position, large amounts of money passed daily through his hands, and many workmen were weekly paid by him -- he making the entry of such payments in the books of the concern in such a manner as best suited his purposes. During the last four months, his employers and others noticed, with some surprise, that the young man was very extravagant in dress, and also in some other respects, but, strange as it may appear, they did not for a moment suspect that he was robbing their money-drawer. Their idea seems to have been that their fast clerk was living beyond his means, or perhaps that he was in the receipt of money from his parents. One thing was very certain in their judgment -- the young man could not afford to indulge in all the luxuries and extravagances by which he surrounded himself upon the paltly sum of $300 a year, which was the salary paid him by this firm. He was seen morning after morning to come to his place of business in a carriage, and when the labors of the day were over a carriage awaited at the store door to convey him to his boarding-house; and yet such was the confidence with which this firm trusted young TOMLIN's, that it never occurred to them to examine the cash-book or drawer, to see whether or not their confidence was misplaced. But the 1st of January was drawing near; the time was approaching when as the habit is with all thorough business men, the accounts of the year would be overhauled, and all errors, whether of head of heart, on the part of the book-keeper and cashier, would be brought to light. The result of this examination would involve the clerk in hopeless ruin. This was, no doubt, the reasoning of the young man, as the sequel will show.

abstract: The Post-office continues to be crowded between the hours of 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. daily, by applicants for the redemption of postage-stamps. The term in which the office is permitted to redeem the stamps will expire on the 31st, and it is anticipated that a great rush of increased numbers will be made before that time to the office. The value of the stamps already redeemed will probably not fall far short of $80,000. The following notice was posted up at the office yesterday:

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the Comptroller sent in his estimates of the expenses of the City Government for 1863, which were referred to the Finance Committee. Their total amount is $7,088,587 56, of which $1,071,657 36 is for the redemption of the City debt, including war loans, and $825,771 20 for interest on the City debt. The total amount of the appropriations for the City for 1862 was $6,187,659 15. The Board then adjourned till 1 o'clock P.M., on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the Comptroller sent in his estimates of the expenses of the City Government for 1863, which were referred to the Finance Committee. abstract: We are indebted to Col. THOS, F. DEVOE for a volume containing the proceedings of the Society for the Promotion of Useful Arts in the State of New-York, published at Albany in 1807. We find in it a description of a plan for a revolving battery, to be used on the water, which contains suggestions not unlike those recently realized by the revolving turret of Capt. ERICSSON. In the volume referred to there is a cut illustrating the nature of the new machine, and accompanying it is the following description:

abstract: This afternoon, at 3 o'clock, the customary Children's Christmas Festival will be held at Trinity Church. It is expected that it will be of an unusually interesting character. The church is gaily decked with evergreens, many ladies and gentlemen having volunteered their services for that purpose. In the middle porch will stand a large Christmas tree ladened with presents, which will be distributed to the children of Trinity Church Sunday School at the conclusion of the Festival. The celebration will commence by the children singing "Adeste Fideles;" after which Rev. Dr. OGLEBY will offer up an evening prayer. The following Carol will then be sung, which has been written for the occasion, commencing:

abstract: Gen. FOSTER arrived at Fortress Monroe this morning. After leaving Kinston his forces took Goldsboro without much loss, tearing up the railroad, burning the ties, and destroying the rails so they cannot be used again, and also destroyed the telegraph. The forces have returned to Newbern in safety.

abstract: We publish in another column a communication from a member of the "Paper-Makers' Association," intended to enlighten the public as to the reasons for the recent very rapid increase in the price of paper, and especially to correct the impression that it has been caused...
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column a communication from a member of the "Paper-Makers' Association," intended to enlighten the public as to the reasons for the recent very rapid increase in the price of paper, and especially to correct the impression that it has been caused in any degree by a combination among the paper-makers themselves. The writer attributes the increase to the scarcity of rags -- to the efforts of paper-makers to lay in a supply for the future, which caused an increased demand -- to the alarm of consumers of paper, which led them to pay large prices, and to sundry other reasons of a kindred character. Unquestionably, all these causes had a good deal to do with it. They certainly laid the foundation for the movement. The main question relates to the action of the paper-makers themselves, to the extent to which they availed themselves of the opportunity offered by the scarcity of rags to create the very state of things which they now attribute to other causes.
headline: {'main': 'The Rise in the Price of Paper.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rise in the Price of Paper.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The members of the Ninth New-York Cavalry, Col. SACKET, were rejoiced yesterday at the return to camp of some twenty of their companions, who were captured at Haymarket in October last, while conducting a train of provisions to Thoroughfare Gap. By some mismanagement or misfortune, we at that time lost eight teams, and had thirty odd soldiers taken prisoners. But for the fact that a portion of the rebels wore blue overcoats, as it was, our men might have destroyed the train and escaped, after seeing the immense superiority of the attacking force. The returned prisoners state that they were hurried off to Warrenton, and thence to Richmond. They were in Warrenton at the time our troops, under Gen. STAHL, advanced upon that place, a few hours after their capture; and, in their opinion, the town might have then been easily taken and the train and soldiers recaptured, as the rebels had an inferior force in every respect, and for cannon there were only two 12-pounders and 6-pound shells only were used in them. Some of these shells exploded within a few feet of the guns and killed and maimed a number of rebel soldiers. The soldiers speak in the highest terms of their treatment while prisoners -- that is, they fared quite as well as their captors did, who lived mostly upon flour and bacon, and these were the only articles issued as rations. The rebels were quite inquisitive as to the number of Union troops in the field, and as to their supply of clothing and provisions, and seemed to be astonished when told that there were a plenty of troops, and clothing and provisions for them. They saw no large force of troops on their way to or in Richmond. Below Richmond they saw a fort -- supposed to be Fort Darling -- which they look upon as a very small affair, mounting not more than ten guns. On every hand they saw evidences of want and destitution, and all with whom they conversed expressed a strong desire to see the war terminate at once. The President's Emancipation Proclamation was everywhere alluded to as an outrage, and they could not see why it was Mr. LINCOLN desired to interfere with their slave property, for it was all the means of support they had. "What should we do," says one, "If our slaves were emancipated?" The response was a natural one: "Go to work and earn your living, as all honest men do in the Free States." But the "reb" grunted out "Oh!" as if the very idea of laboring for one's living was a most painful thought, and not to be considered for a moment.

abstract: The People ex rel. Engle & Co. vs. John Yates. -- This proceeding came up on certiorari to review the proceeding had before Justice Perry, one of the Police Justices of the City of Brooklyn. The defendant is charged with embezzling $2,500 from Engle & Co., of the City of New-York. The defendant has been arrested upon three orders of arrest issued against him for the same cause in civil actions instituted against him, and he was discharged from all of them; thereupon criminal complaint was made against Yates in Brooklyn, and the Justice committed him in default of $2,000 bail to await the action of the Grand Jury. Alexander H. Reavey, of counsel for the prisoner, contended that the defendant was entitled to his discharge, for the reason, first, that all the money alleged to have been embezzled was embezzled in this City and not in Kings County, and that Engle & Co.'s place of business is in this City; therefore the Justice had no jurisdiction; and second, there was no proof that the money alleged to have been embezzled belonged to Engle & Co. After hearing Judge Morris, of counsel for Engle & Co., the Court ordered the discharge of Yates, and he was accordingly discharged.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel. After hearing Judge Morris, of counsel for Engle & Co., the Court ordered the discharge of Yates, and he was accordingly discharged.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN--For a holiday entertainment at the Winter Garden, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS give a revival of "The Lakes of Killarney," an Irish drama, which has been so constructed as to admit of its being put upon the stage in a framework of very beautiful scenery. The piece combines an interesting plot, of a domestic nature, (wherein several young...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN--For a holiday entertainment at the Winter Garden, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS give a revival of "The Lakes of Killarney," an Irish drama, which has been so constructed as to admit of its being put upon the stage in a framework of very beautiful scenery. The piece combines an interesting plot, of a domestic nature, (wherein several young persons do the usual amount of love-making,) with episodes of fairy intervention. Whenever the fairies appear, they are always surrounded by the most brilliant pictorial accessories; and themselves -- in the persons of a large and well-appointed corps de ballet -- present a series of specially attractive groupings. The dancing, indispensable to the existence of theatrical fairies, is led by Mr. G.F. BROWNE, a neat and graceful performer. Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, of course, play in the leading earthly parts, and the subordinate characters are capably supported by the regular company. "The Lakes of Killarney," as a spectacle, will afford unlimited delight to the young folks, and it possesses enough dramatic merit to amuse the play-goers of experience.

lead_paragraph: We are threatened with two 7,000-ton ships, iron-clad in a manner which the whole practice of Europe and America has proved defective, at four million two hundred thousand dollars a-piece. If that is not bad enough, we may add that the designs of hull and machinery were made by the Bureaux of Construction and Steam-engineering. We understand that the Department has actually received proposals for the construction of these vessels.

abstract: Hen. JAMES A. PEARCE, United States Senator from Maryland, died at Chestertown, in that  State, on Saturday, Dec. 20. Mr. PEARCE was born in Alexandria, Virginia, on Dec. 10, 1805. He graduated at Princeton College, in 1822, with the highest honors, and then took up the study of the law. He did not resign himself entirely to the arduous duties,...
lead_paragraph: Hen. JAMES A. PEARCE, United States Senator from Maryland, died at Chestertown, in that State, on Saturday, Dec. 20. Mr. PEARCE was born in Alexandria, Virginia, on Dec. 10, 1805. He graduated at Princeton College, in 1822, with the highest honors, and then took up the study of the law. He did not resign himself entirely to the arduous duties, of his profession, for the possession of ample means enabled him to indulge his taste for agricultural pursuits, and he gave up much of his time to them. In 1831, he was elected a member of the Maryland Legislature, and from 1835 to 1839, and from 1841 to 1843, three terms in all, represented his district in Congress. In 1843 he was elected to the United States Senate, and has ever since continued to be a member of that Body; a large part of the time he has acted as Chairman of the Committee on the Library. Mr. PEARCE has also held the post of Professor of Law, in Washington College, Chestertown, Pa., and for a number of years was a Regent of the Smithsonian Institution.

abstract: Editorial speculates whether there will be military operations this winter
snippet: Editorial speculates whether there will be military operations this winter
lead_paragraph: We suppose that this year at least will witness no more military operations. Whatever might be the desire of the country, or the army, or the President, it would be impossible for Gen. BURNSIDE, to make any movement in the solitary week that remains of 1862. Gen. SIGEL's Grand Division has been moved up north from Falmouth, to act as a check upon any designs of the rebels against Washington, and the other three Grand Divisions which fought the great battle of the 13th, could not now be judiciously led into another such assault upon the enemy's works. Our soldiers will enjoy their rough and tough Christmas dinner to-day, and their New Years' Festival on Thursday next, on the north bank of the Rappahannock -- our Generals in the meantime keeping a sharp eye upon the enemy, lest he attempts to take some advantage of the expected repose and enjoyments of the holidays.

abstract: At the opening of the Court yesterday morning, Judge MCCUNN presiding, the Grand Jury came in with several indictments for minor offences, which they delivered to the Court, and announced that they had concluded the business before them. The Judge thanked them for the attentive and faithful manner inwhich they had discharged their duties, and discharged them for the term. It was expected by some, and hoped by others, that the Grand Jury would find an indictment against the Secretary of War, for his supposed agency in certain alleged arbitrary arrests, but the jury, it appears, did not think fit to make asses of themselves for the sake of gratifying the spite of certain politicians of doubtful loyalty.

abstract: THE FINANCIAL PROJECT OF SECRETARY CHASE. Secretary CHASE has sent to Representative  STEVENS his financial project, recommending a loan of nine hundred millions of dollars, at rates of interest not exceeding those now authorized by law. The Secretary does not suggest any augmentation of Treasury notes. The Committee of Ways and Means have not yet considered the subject.

abstract: The Ninth New-York Cavalry boasts of a Lieutenant named BLY, who took a distinguished part in the recent reconnoissance to Berryville. In my account of that affair, I omitted to state one incident worthy of mention, particularly as it illustrates a nice sense of honor manifested toward an enemy by a gallant soldier, and an esprit du corps reflecting credit upon the officer and the branch of the service to which he is attached. In the charge upon the rebels beyond Berryville, the pursuit was kept up for several miles at a full gallop. Our men in advance used their weapons as best served their purpose, with the exception of Lieut. BLY, who only used his sword. In one instance, he pursued a rebel officer for nearly two miles. The speed of their horses was so nearly equal that Lieut. BLY could only get near enough to reach the point of his sword within about six inches of the officer's head, and it required all the stretch there was in him to do that. Each spurred their horses on at the top of their speed -- one determined to escape, and the other equally determined to cut him down. Thus they rushed on, over hills and through valleys, streams and mud-holes. Lieut. BLY occasionally making an unsuccessful cut with his sword, and expressing his disgust each time, in the most emphatic terms imaginable, that his weapon was not six inches longer, the rebel officer all the time dodging and twisting, and spurring on his horse. The road had been made soft by the melting of a small covering of snow that had fallen the night before. The mud and water was scattered by the horses in every direction, covering man and beast and everything else near. Eventually all of our advance reined up except Lieut. BLY; he continued the pursuit of his man, and the last seen of him for some time was a streak of mud and water. The chase proved bootless -- the Lieutenant's horse gave out. As he returned to the advance some one cried out: "Why in the d -- l didn't you shoot the fellow?" To which he replied: "Why, I did not have the heart to do it!" Who can say after this that true chivalry has become extinct?

abstract: About two months ago an Israelite, giving his name as Mons. EDREHI, and wearing the full uniform of a Captain in a French Zouave regiment, arrived in this City, and stopped at the Prescott House, attracting a great deal of attention by his appearance, almost every day promenading Broadway in his gay uniform. In a short time his ostensible errand became known. He introduced himself to the most prominent Jews in this City, and represented that he had just arrived from Algeria where the regiment to which he claimed to be attached was stationed. Owing to some difficulty between the Emperor of Morocco and the Jewish inhabitants of that country as he stated, the Emperor oppressed the Jews most grievously, and levied a heavy tribute on them, amounting to some hundred thousand francs. In case this sum was not paid within a certain time, the Jews were to be banished, or otherwise punished. He also represented that the Jewish community there were in great distress and destitution, and consequently unable to pay the sum required by the oppressor. The community determined to apply to their co-religionists in other countries, and had delegated this gay Zou-Zou to travel to Europe and America and make collections among the benevolent Jews for the purpose of liquidating this heavy burden put upon their brethren in Morocco by a despotic ruler. The soldier told his piteous story in such a manner, and was supplied with such apparently genuine credentials, that he met with greater success than he could have anticipated, and the Jews, ever willing to respond to a call from a portion of their people in distress, received the delegate from Morocco very kindly, threw their houses open to his visits, and contributed liberally to the object of his journey. Appeals were made in the behalf of the supposed distressed people by the Jewish clergy, and in a short time Mons. EDREHI collected over $3,000. During this time, however, certain parties, partially distrusting the story of the Algerian, opened a correspondence with the Board of Deputies of British Jews in regard to the Morocco gentleman and his mission. Letters were received in this City that Mons. EDREHI was evidently an impostor, and his story a base fabrication from beginning to end. This somewhat opened the eyes of those who had been so basely imposed upon. In the meantime, however, the bird had flown, he having announced his intention to visit the principal cities of the vicinity. Nothing was heard of him until yesterday morning, when it was ascertained that he was in this City, and staying at one of our fashionable hotels. Information was immediately conveyed to the police, and Detective FARLEY was detailed to work up the case, add arrested EDREHI at the Prescott House. He still wears his Zouave uniform, but states that his right name is Mons. MESSARD DRAID. When arrested he was searched, and a considerable sum of money was found on him. He states that he has just returned from Philadelphia, where he went probably on a similar errand on which he visited this City.

abstract: In justice to our columns, in justice to the wants of our readers, we call attention to Mr. KNOX. Not content with tiptoeing the topmost round of hatdom, this individual has wormed himself deep into fur, and advertises a collection of bear-skins, lynx-skins, fox-skins and otter-skins, fur caps, fur capes. fur collars and fur cuffs; fancy hats of all styles, sober hats, with no fancy whatever, and Winter dress hats by the score, grace his windows, while military caps suitable to the humblest private or the most distinguished General, perch saucily by their side.

abstract: and hoped for great things from the Goldsboro expedition of Gen. FOSTER, with its four successive victories, will be badly disappointed to learn that his army has retired from the line of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, and is now back at Newbern, while he himself was at Fortress Monroe on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Those who expected and hoped for great things from the Goldsboro expedition of Gen. FOSTER, with its four successive victories, will be badly disappointed to learn that his army has retired from the line of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, and is now back at Newbern, while he himself was at Fortress Monroe on Tuesday. The entire result of the expedition, and its victorious battles, was that FOSTER "tore up the railroad, burnt the ties and destroyed the rails and telegraph." This is rather small fruit, certainly, compared with the promise we had yesterday, and compared with the heavy losses we sustained in the four victories. The battles were well fought, and undoubtedly were victories for our arms; but we think that if the object of the movement was merely to cut the telegraph wires, and tear up some rails, that a properly organized secret expedition of a dozen men, or a cavalry raid after the style of STUART and HAMPTON, might have accomplished as much, without sacrificing a single life. The dispatch states that the destroyed wires and rails "cannot again be used" -- which is quite likely; but it remains to be proved that the rebels cannot put up other wires and put down other rails in a shorter time than was occupied in this expedition. We have no doubt that, if when Gen. FOSTER got to the line of the railroad, he had run his troops down in the rear of Wilmington, instead of back to Newbern, he could easily have captured that most important city of North Carolina, and the port at which the blockade is often run.

abstract: THE ARENA.--Brooklyn has added another to her permanent places of amusement, in a little bijou of a theatre, just completed, on Raymondstreet between Fulton and De Kaib avenues, called the Arena. It is designed more particularly for the circus, but can be easily adapted to theatrical or other amusements.
lead_paragraph: THE ARENA.--Brooklyn has added another to her permanent places of amusement, in a little bijou of a theatre, just completed, on Raymondstreet between Fulton and De Kaib avenues, called the Arena. It is designed more particularly for the circus, but can be easily adapted to theatrical or other amusements. The Arena was opened on Monday night, under the management of Mr. J.Q. STOKES, with an excellent company of riders, acrobats, gymnasts, et cetera, whose performances elicited repeated marks of approbation from a large and select audience. The acrobatic and gymnastic feats of the DELEVANTA brothers surpasses anything ever witnessed in this community. The celebrated ELLA ZOYARA, whose horsemanship stands unequaled through her sex may be still in dispute, appeared in her (?) usual parts, and is, we understand, to be permanently attached to the company. The manager pledges himself that the sports of the Arena, wfille under his management, shall be so conducted as not to offend the most fastidious, and in view of this fact the City of Churches may congratulate itself on the possession of another home resort for these cold Winter evenings, in lieu of the long and tedious journey to the up-town theatres of Gotham.

abstract: Article on high price of paper caused by Civil War; Article on causes of present high prices of paper
snippet: Article on high price of paper caused by Civil War; Article on causes of present high prices of paper
lead_paragraph: The recent rapid advance in the price of paper has elicited much comment, and some of the daily papers in this City have attributed this advance to a combination among the manufacturers and dealers in paper in connection with the "Paper Maker's Association." An article in your columns a few days since shows that you have fallen into this error. A brief explanation of the causes of the present high prices of paper may interest your readers and correct much misapprehension upon this subject. For some time before the war began the paper market was depressed, mainly from over-production, and for many months afterward the tendency was to still lower prices. This state of things was less disastrous to the paper makers in consequence of the low price of stock. The revival of business and the increased demand for paper for Government purposes, gave prices an upward tendency, and created a greater demand for rags and other stock used by paper makers. There are few branches of manufacturing where the raw material forms so large a per centage of the whole cost as in the manufacture of paper, especially of the quality used by the newspaper press. The ordinary annual production of paper in the United States for several years, is estimated at not less than 100,000 tons. To produce this quantity of paper would require more than 150,000 tons of stock, so great is the waste in manufacturing. This stock comes mainly from the following sources: 1st. Domestic rags saved by careful housewives. From this source paper makers obtain at least 65 per cent, of the whole quantity used. These rags are chiefly of cotton fabric. 2d. Foreign rags, both linen and cotton; from this source is obtained from 10 to 12 1/2 per cent 3d. Rope and bagging used in baling cotton, and the refuse of raw cotton from the cotton mills; this is estimated at about 10 per cent. The balance is made up mostly from old canvas and straw. This statement shows that domestic rags, with rope, bagging and cotton-waste, furnish about seventy-five per cent. of all the stock used in the manufacture of paper. Non-intercourse with the Cotton States has cut off the entire supply of rope, bagging and cotton-waste. The high price of cotton has greatly abridged the consumption of cotton goods. Old garments have been patched and worn which have heretofore gone into the rag-bag, and it must be borne in mind, that one million of men now in public service wear no cotton. Consequently, alarge percentage has been cut off from this source. A new and unlooked-for competition has sprung up for the better quality of cotton rags from the manufacturers of colton goods and batting. Paper makers soon found that rags were becoming scarce, and they naturally began to look ahead, fearing that they might be unable to get stock for their mills. The demand being greater than the supply, prices advanced, and, as a consequence, the increased cost of paper raised the price. This alarmed the large consumers of paper, and they thought it necessary to look ahead. Thus, a combination of circumstances created great activity in the rag and paper market, and stock went up from 100 to 300 per cent. Foreign rags have advanced at least 100 per cent. Not less than 35 per cent. of the advance in the price of paper can be attributed to the depreciation of the currency and the Government Excise tax. The alarm of paper makers and paper consumers has doubtless been instrumental in causing a more rapid rise than would have otherwise taken place. The rag collectors and smaller dealers throughout the country refuse to sell, holding for higher prices. Some of the journals in this City which complain of the "combination of paper makers," to protect themselves against higher prices, have, by their own purchases, given an upward impulse to the market which they little dreamed of. The paper markets deprecate this state of things as much as the consumers. No branch of business is benefited by such violent fluctuations, and many of the men who are charged with combining to create a paper panic have large contracts to supply at former prices, while they have to pay the present high rates for stock, and consequently are suffering large losses. Paper makers have been and are now, free to buy stock and sell paper at just such prices as they choose without the control of the Paper Maker's Association or any combination of paper makers or paper dealers connected therewith. The only resolution passed at the meeting of the "Paper Maker's Association," relating to prices, was not obligatory, but simply a recommendation in regard to two or three qualities. Those prices were based upon the value of stock at that time, but the market soon advanced 50 per cent. above the rates named. But even it there had been an agreement in reference to prices, it would have given no just ground for complaint. Nothing is more common than such agreements. The proprietors of the newspaper Press have had conferences upon kindred topics, which afford a high precedent. Many of the writing-paper manufacturers, some months since, in view of the excise tax and the advance in stock, agreed to an advance in prices, and no one thought or criticising their action.
