abstract: de Joinville's History of Gen. McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed; Prince de Joinville's History of Gen. McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed; his History of General McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed
snippet: de Joinville's History of Gen. McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed; Prince de Joinville's History of Gen. McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed; his History of General McClellan's Peninsular Campaign reviewed
lead_paragraph: In a former notice of the Prince DE JOINVILLE'S historical sketch of the campaign of the Army of the Potomac--[See NEW-YORK TIMES Nov. 29]--we followed his narrative to the date of Gen. McCLELLAN'S embarkation for the Peninsula, on the 9th of March, 1862, in pursuance of the plan he had formed in October of the previous year, but which he had pondered in "secresy and silence" during the whole of the intervening Winter. According to the Prince's statement, this plan was to avail himself of the water approaches and to throw his whole army suddenly upon the rebel capital. The enemy evacuated Manassas in his front on receiving through treachery, (as the Prince believes, though without any just ground so far as we can see,) information of this scheme. MCCLELLAN spent a week in a sham pursuit of their retreating force -- going no further, however, than to the most advanced position they had occupied -- and then devoted himself to the embarkation of his army, -- for which, however, very inadequate preparations had been made.

abstract: St. Thomas' Episcopal Church, corner of Broadway and Houston-street, was filled yesterday afternoon by the communicants of that parish, and others, the occasion being the annual Christmas Eve festival by the children of the Sunday schools attached to the church. The interior was most attractively decorated with evergreens, the work of the ladies of the congregation. On the left of the chancel was placed a wide-spreading Christmas tree, the branches of which were filled with gifts for the scholars, and toward which their youthful eyes would wander with delight even amid the religious ceremonies which preceded the distribution. The pulpit was tastefully adorned with green festoons, and immediately under the grand window, in the extreme rear of the chancel, was the inscription. "Thou shalt call His name Jesus." The marble baptismal font was placed at the end of the centre aisle, immediately in front of the communion railing, having on one side the beautiful banner of the Sunday school, and on the other the National flag. The scholars, seated on each side of the church, the infant class being in the extreme front, numbered upward of seven hundred, under the direction of Mr. THOMAS H. SILL, Superintendent. At half past three o'clock the exercises were commenced by a voluntary on the organ, followed by the singing of the hymn "Shout the Glad Tidings, Exultingly Sing," In the rendition of which the children exhibited the careful training they have undergone as to musical culture. Rev. Dr. MORGAN, Rector, then recited evening prayer, which was followed by the singing of a Christmas Carol by the Infant Departments in chorus. The Rev. Rector then propounded to the scholars catechetical questions, which were answered with unusual promptness. After these exercises were concluded, Dr. MORGAN took occasion to thank the teachers for their "labor of love," in having instructed the children so thoroughly in a knowledge of Christian doctrine, and complimented the scholars for their proficieny. He also congratulated the congregation on the increasing success of the schools, and predicted that great and good results to the cause of religion would ensue therefrom. He was followed by Rev. FREDERICK SILL, assistant pastor, in the same strain, after which the freewill offerings of the scholars and congregation were received, the baptismal font being used as the receptacle. After another hymn and the Benediction, the exercises were closed by the distribution of the gifts with which the Christmas tree was laden, when the assemblage dispersed, the countenances of the children betokening their great satisfaction on being the recipients of these kind remembrancers of their teachers and friends.

abstract: It appears from the dispatches published this morning, that Gen. FOSTER did not remain at Goldsboro long after its capture, but returned to Newbern after destroying both the railroad and telegraph, so that they cannot again be used by the rebels. The capture of Goldsboro was effected without much loss. In destroying the railroad Gen. FOSTER seems to have taken a lesson from the rebels in the destruction of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. He took up the ties, burned them, and rendered the rails unfit for use. The General is reported to have arrived at Fortress Monroe on Tuesday.

abstract: NATHAN BREED, Jr., proprietor of a respectable grocery store in Lyan, Mass., was murdered last night by a young man named HORACE DAVIS. The murder was perpetrated in the store with a hatchet, while Mr. BREED was engaged in putting up some article which DAVIS had called for. DAVIS has been arrested.

abstract: A young German named THEODORE MANHEINS, has been arrested by Detective J.C. KINNER, of the Merchants' Independent Private Police, upon complaints lodged with him by the merchants of Park-place, Chambers, Reade and Murray streets and Broadway. Young MANHEINS was recently employed as a cutter in one of the large tailoring establishments on the west side of the town, from which he was discharged for having stolen a pair of shears. Having acquainted himself with the signatures of various firms, he turned his attention to another branch of tailoring, that of purchasing the goods. He drew orders upon firms for samples of goods, and presenting, these orders represented that he would call again and take several cases of goods, but that at the time he would take several pieces of goods as a sample. The card ran well. He thus purchased many pieces of valuable goods from Messrs. HOYT, SPRAGUE & Co., of Park-place; HAVILAND, LINDSLEY & Co., of Chambers-street; WEAVER, RICHARDS & Co., of Reade-street; LEE, BLISS & Co., of Broadway, and others. His orders purported to have been drawn by LONG-STREET, BRADFORD Co., Broadway, PAINE & CARHART, and others. For some time Detective KINNER had been watching for this rare bird, and the merchants had arranged to give their detective officer the earliest information. A day or two since, MANHEINS presented an order at the warehouse of Messrs. LEE, BLISS & Co., when he was at once detained and surrendered to an officer, who took him to the 6th Ward Station House. On his person were found many pawn tickets, leading Captain DOWLEY to regard him as a dishonest person. The Captain gave him lodging during the night, and in the morning took him before Justice CONNOLLY, by whom he was committed. Counsel sued a writ of certiorari, and took the case before Judge MCCUNN, and owing to the non-appearance of witnesses he was discharged. But Detective KINNER preferred other complaints, upon which the prisoner was held for subsequent examination, and a hearing was had yesterday afternoon at the office of the City Judge. Some of the goods have been recovered.

abstract: In the absence, for the present, of more exciting news, it may, perhaps, be well to say something of regal cotton. After having spent months in offering inky incense to red-browed Mars, it is no more than right to pay one's duty to the white-headed monarch, to whom Manchester, Jewery, and the hungry and speculating world, generally, pine to pay allegiance.

abstract: IN BROOKLYN.--A matter came up in the City Court of Brooklyn last week, to which we think the attention of people of that city should be called. It appears that a man sued the city, to recover damages occasioned...
lead_paragraph: IN BROOKLYN.--A matter came up in the City Court of Brooklyn last week, to which we think the attention of people of that city should be called. It appears that a man sued the city, to recover damages occasioned to him by falling into a hole in the street, which had been opened to receive sewer pipes, and left in a dark night without any light up or any safeguard around it. The counsel for the city, when the case was opened to the jury, called the attention of the Court to the 39th section of the new city charter, passed by the last Legislature, and which, as he claimed, relieved the city from all claims for such injuries. The section provides that the city "shall not be liable for any nonfeasance or misfeasance" of "any officer of the city" of duty imposed upon him by the act in question, but "the remedy of the party Aggrieved for any such nonfeasance or misfeasance" shall be by mandamus or other action against the officer.

abstract: Between two and three o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the building in which is located the cracker bakery establishment of J.A. KNAPP & Co., No. 177 Washington-street, and, owing to the combustible nature of the materials in the building, the flames spread very rapidly. The firemen were early on the ground, and used great efforts to subdue the flames, but the destroying element had got the start, and soon an adjoining building, occupied by H.H. WATT as a tobacco manufactory, was found to be on fire. Both of these structures were entirely destroyed. Mr. WATT's loss is estimated at about $4,000. He is insured for $8,000 in four or five City companies. The estimated loss to KNAPP & Co., is about $10,000; partially covered by insurance. From the buildings above indicated, the fire rapidly spread to the adjoining buildings Nos. 61 Dey street and 173 Washington street. The latter was occupied by Messrs. DUCKWORTH & Co., as a wholesale grocery and provison store, and was nearly consumed. Their loss is very extensive, but the amount could not be ascertained. No 61 Dey-street was occupied in part as a storehouse for cotton, a large amount of which was destroyed.

abstract: FIRE IN WALKER-STREET. -- About the time the alarm was given for the fire in Washington-street, the bells sounded for the Sixth District. The fire proved to be at No. 102 Walker-street -- a five-story building, occupied as workshops. The flames were first seen issuing from the windows on the second floor, and then extended to the stories above. The second floor was occupied by GEORGE FURMAN, machinist; the third by Messrs. BLUNT & SYMS, gun-smiths; the fourth by BOSCH & OESTRIECHER, tobacconists, and the filth floor by M. COHEN, hoop-skirt manufacturer. The aggregate loss by fire and water to the stock and fixtures belonging to the several occupants is estimated at about $6,000. The damage to the building will be upward of $3,000. The latter is fully insured in City Companies.

abstract: THE DAY BEFORE CHRISTMAS IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOL AT BLOOMFIELD, N.J.--An occurrence connected with the Public School at Bloomfield, N.J., on the day before Christmas, deserves special mention. Under the able direction of the Principal, H.A. VENTRES, and his officient assistants, the school has enlisted the particular interest of the friends of education in the community. It had been whispered among
lead_paragraph: THE DAY BEFORE CHRISTMAS IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOL AT BLOOMFIELD, N.J.--An occurrence connected with the Public School at Bloomfield, N.J., on the day before Christmas, deserves special mention. Under the able direction of the Principal, H.A. VENTRES, and his officient assistants, the school has enlisted the particular interest of the friends of education in the community. It had been whispered among the scholars for several days that something of interest to themselves would transpire, in connection with a visit from their nearest neighbor. Prof. WM. B. BRADBURY, author of the popular series of Sunday School music-books, but the exact nature of the exercise seems to have been as well kept a secret as the destination of the Banks Expedition. On the afternoon of Wednesday, at a given signal, the scholars marched from the school house to the lecture-room of the Presbyterian Church, which was soon filled by them and their friends. Prof. BRADBURY introduced the ceremonies by speaking pleasantly of the goodwill maintained between his family and all the scholars during a ten years' residence opposite the school, and declared his determination to give them another testimonial of his friendliness and interest in their progress in knowledge whereupon Golden Showers began to fall in every part of the room, until each scholar and friend present possessed a copy. Then the National Flag, which had been patriotically hung at one end of the room, was lifted and fifteen pairs of skates appeared in view, which Mr. BRADBURY distributed to the fifteen boys and girls who stood highest on the merit roll. After a unanimous vote of thanks to the donor and some appropriate remarks by Rev. H.F. SMITH, Pastor of the Baptist Church, with a few declamations and some good singing, the exercises closed and the scholars dispersed with high anticipations of a "Merry Christmas."

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains full reports of the Gen. PORTER COURT-MARTIAL, from our Special Correspondent, with COPIES OF DOCUMENTS that give interesting glances into the GREAT HISTORY of the WAR.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES, is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. It contains full reports of the Gen. PORTER COURT-MARTIAL, from our Special Correspondent, with COPIES OF DOCUMENTS that give interesting glances into the GREAT HISTORY of the WAR. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving, the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN.--Why "Faust and Marguerite," produced at Mr. WHRATLEY'S charming theatre on Monday night, should be the delight of theatrical managers, (seeing that it is but an indifferent favorite with the public,) is one of those inscrutable mysteries that defy the ingenuity of human guessing, and refuse to be solved by any ordinary process of explanation. It is certainly not out of veneration for GORTHE, for the dialogue of the Teuton Shakespeare is seldom used.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN.--Why "Faust and Marguerite," produced at Mr. WHRATLEY'S charming theatre on Monday night, should be the delight of theatrical managers, (seeing that it is but an indifferent favorite with the public,) is one of those inscrutable mysteries that defy the ingenuity of human guessing, and refuse to be solved by any ordinary process of explanation. It is certainly not out of veneration for GORTHE, for the dialogue of the Teuton Shakespeare is seldom used. Long before GOETHE wrote, the play was a favorite with showmen. Performed before gaping mobs of peasantry by those early actors, the marrionettes, (alas! there are some wooden artists yet) it taught its little lesson of life, and raised its small voice against the danger of wisdom and the pride of learning. The great poet borrowed liberally from the machinery of the puppet show -- and have his followers not done the same? A few years ago the work returned almost to its original conditions. The marrionettes, however, were members of the Ronzani ballet troupe. The aged Faust pirouietted with learned velocity, sold himself to the Devti with a cheerful caper, and waltzed smilingly to perdition by the side of a somewhat exposed Marguerite. That men betray and women are lost is indeed so trite a story, that it may be told by the toes as well as the mouth. The only wonder is that it is told at all, seeing that the telling seldom pays expenses.

abstract: I understand that news has gone, or will go, to New-York by the same mail with this note, of the supposed loss of this vessel, with all on board. Will you have the kindness to publish this note in your journal, contradicting any such report, and thereby relieve the minds of our friends from anxiety on this account. We arrived here at 5 P.M. this day, all well and no accidents; are now taking in coal, and shall leave for our destination to-morrow morning. Probably by publishing the above you will confer a lasting favor on Yours truly, G.W. DALEY,

abstract: THE DANGER OF JUMPING AFTER THE FERRY BOATS. -- A man named JAMES MCDONALD fell over board at the Fulton Ferry on Wednesday night, and sustained fatal injuries. The boat had just left the bridge when he sprang forward to reach the deck but the gap having become too great, he fell into the water, and, as supposed, struck some obstacle in his descent. Officer WM. CREREND jumped overboard and succeeded in bringing him out, when he was conveyed to the Second Precinct Station-house, where he was attended to by a physician. He failed rapidly however, and yesterday noon died from the effects of the hurts he had sustained. The deceased leaves a wife and several children residing in York-street.
lead_paragraph: THE DANGER OF JUMPING AFTER THE FERRY BOATS. -- A man named JAMES MCDONALD fell over board at the Fulton Ferry on Wednesday night, and sustained fatal injuries. abstract: We have on several occasions referred to the peculiar naval structure, the What Is It? which, for some months past has been growing into form under the hands of the Government employes. This singular affair has attracted considerable attention, as no one knows in what manner it is to be made available for warlike purposes. At present it is nothing more than a large box with thick sides, and an interval space for a gun. When afloat, however, it will be clothed with iron some inches in thickness. Its armament with consist of one piece of ordnance, from which will be discharged a projectile of as unconceivable a nature as the battery itself. This armament is now in New-York, being rifled, it is said. The inventor of the What Is It? as the workmen and visitors have christened this freak of naval architecture is, as stated some months since, Lieut. HUNT. To-day proper preparations will be made to float the machine off satisfactorily. It will  be launched in the forenoon.

lead_paragraph: -- It is received as an established rule in military affairs that an officer must obey orders. It would seem to be a natural inference that he should read them. abstract: Editorial says current figures prove war tariff did not affect US foreign trade; editorial cites current figures to show tariff did not affect US foreign trade
snippet: Editorial says current figures prove war tariff did not affect US foreign trade; editorial cites current figures to show tariff did not affect US foreign trade
lead_paragraph: The report of the British Board of Trade for the ten months ending Oct. 31, has just been completed, and shows the fallacious character of the predictions so confidently made on both sides of the Atlantic that our war-tariff would annihilate the trade between this country and England. This fiscal measure, according to the leading London journal, was destined to render the commerce of the United Kingdom with the "Northern Americans" of less consequence than that with the cannibal islanders of the Southern Ocean. At present, so far as Great Britain is concerned, it is only too evident that the changes we have found necessary in our customs duties have given her no just ground of complaint. The British trade with our Northern ports has not fallen off. On the contrary, it has in several important points received considerable increase. Indeed, English commerce seems, on the whole, to have been a gainer, rather than a loser, from the war. For if in one direction her cotton manufactures have suffered, her shipping and general maritime interests have reaped a compensating advantage in another.

abstract: --There is inexpressible pleasure, a singular feeling of satisfaction, and the content of a gratified longing, in plunging the thirsting buckets of the brain deep down into the wells of past ages, and bringing them up brimming with the lucent legendary waters that gather in the tombs of slumbering centuries. At the bottom of these...
lead_paragraph: --There is inexpressible pleasure, a singular feeling of satisfaction, and the content of a gratified longing, in plunging the thirsting buckets of the brain deep down into the wells of past ages, and bringing them up brimming with the lucent legendary waters that gather in the tombs of slumbering centuries. At the bottom of these wells we do not always find truth, but mere bold veracity is not always the great desideratum, nor does it always present itself as the sum of human happiness to the inquiring mind. Courts of law occasionally dispense with it for convenience's sake, and he were an ambitious and unreasonable fool indeed, who insisted upon its presence in his amusements as well as in his councils, and applied everything brought before him to its inexorable test. Shadowy fictions are oft times infinitely preferable to a stern embodiment of facts. Readers of a subsequent period will have more pleasure in stories of the battles now raging than do we of the present. Deeds of arms gather magnitude as centuries crust upon them, and with that magnitude interest grows. It is quite probable that the Knights of King Arthur's Table, and the Peers and Paladins of CHARLEMAGNE's Court, were held as lightly in their day as we estimate our own Colonels and Captains. But the helmets of Launcelot and Tristram; of Orlando, Rinaldo, Astalpho and Ogier the Dane, blaze brightly amid the golden mists of the mediaval ages, surrounded by a halo of dazzling glory. So with their loves. More of interest attaches to Launcelot and Genevieve than any one in the United Kingdom can muster for the approaching marriage of the Prince of Wales, or any one in this disunited country feel in hymeneal crises in Mr. LINCOLN's Cabinet. These remarks -- not strictly relevant perhaps to the book itself -- are suggested by The Legends of Charlemagne: or, Romance of the Middle Ages, published by J.E. TILTON & Co., of Boston. Mr. BULLFINCH, the author, is already known to the public by two previous works, "The Age of Fable" and "The Age of Chivalry," to which the volume before us forms a most fitting corollary. The Court of CHARLEMAGNE is one with which the public generally is not familiar, and to the popular mind CHARLEMAGNE himself is more of a puzzle and a problem than even LOUIS NAPOLRON. Mr. BULLFINCH introduces us to the grandson of him surnamed the Hammer, and to the Peers and Paladins, who to him stood in the light of crown jewels -- quite as valuable, and infinitely more useful -- in a series of legends gathered from all available sources --chiefly, the Italian poets and the "Romans de Chevalrie" of the Comte de TRESSAN. He makes us familiar with Malagigi, the magician, who stood on such good terms with demons that one always stood ready to his elbow, saddled and bridled, ready to mount or to be mounted, or in any way to do his bidding. And the reflection forces itself upon us, what a capital Prime Minister Malagigi would have made. Of course it is impossible to read of the achievements of Binaldo putting thousands of Saracens to flight by the might of his unaided arm, without longing for his services in our army as Chief of Cavalry, or something of the kind -- though granting we had the man, it might be difficult to get him appointed to a command, or confirmed. But political influence judiciously directed might manage this, and then, with his sword "Duvindana," and Malagigi deposed for the moment from the office of Secretary of State or of the Interior, to attend to such little necessaries for marching armies as supplies and pontoon trains, STUART's prestige would fade into utter insignificance, and the strategy of LEE and JACKSON be shorn of their glory. But why turn with eager eyes to the shadowy vision of Rinaldo, albeit, belted and helmeted, he looks out from the clear, beautiful page before us? For

abstract: Some $700,000 allegedly swindled from US Government appropriations for recruiting regiments in NYC
snippet: Some $700,000 allegedly swindled from US Government appropriations for recruiting regiments in NYC
lead_paragraph: It is generally known to the public that Commissioners, appointed by the General Government, have been at work for several weeks past, in this City and elsewhere, investigating alleged frauds,upon the Government in connection with the raising and subsisting of volunteers, organizing of regiments, and other operations, from the commencement of the rebellion to the present time. The Press has thus far been requested to withhold information developed during the progress of the investigation, for the reason that the Government desired, before making it public, to perfect the chain of evidence against the parties already implicated, and to prevent a general skedaddle among those whose guilt might be discovered as the investigation progressed. The Commissioner appointed for this City was Mr. H.S. OLCOTT, who has now arrived at that point in his investigations when the general facts connected with the frauds, and the manner in which they were perpetrated, may be made public without interfering with the aims of the Government and the ends of justice.

abstract: TERRIBLE ACCIDENT -- A FIRE ENGINE RUNS AWAY. -- An exciting scene occurred in Bridge street, Newark, on Christmas morning, about 2 o'clock. A fire in East Newark had called out the Fire Department, and the Turnpike Bridge and street west of the same were crowded with engines and firemen, having been stopped at that point by the engineers. The street there descends very rapidly, and Engine No. 4, a heavy double-decker, in racing with No. 9, became unmanageable, and her men deserting her she plunged down the hill with great momentum, dashing into the rope of No. 5, knocking down a number of men, and seriously injuring two, one of whom, a member of No. 5, named JAMES NOLAN, sustained a severe sprain of the ankle, and another named MICHAEL MCMANUS, a "runner," was thrown under the wheels, which passed over his legs, badly fracturing them both. The engine narrowly escaped being dashed to pieces, fortunately swinging round just in time to escape striking a house at the bottom of the hill.
lead_paragraph: TERRIBLE ACCIDENT -- A FIRE ENGINE RUNS AWAY. -- An exciting scene occurred in Bridge street, Newark, on Christmas morning, about 2 o'clock. abstract: Gen. JOHN P. HATCH was for a long time Chief of Cavalry in Gen. BANKS' Corps, composing an effective portion of the Army of Virginia. While in that position he had general charge of the many cavalry reconnoissances which were made by Gen. BANKS' Cavalry during the time he was in command of the corps. The General was, some time ago, ordered to the command of an infantry brigade, of which the celebrated old Fourteenth of Brooklyn forms a part. While Chief of Cavalry, the First Vermont, Col. TOMPKINS, and Fifth New-York, Col. DE FORRESTS, were used by him for scouting parties and reconnoissances, perhaps quite as often as any other regiments of cavalry under his command, and therefore, with a view to a moderate expression of their esteem for him as a gentleman, and as a General, while under his command, the officers of the two Cavalry Regiments named, have caused to be manufactured a splendid sabre, with dress and field scabbards, and a sash and belt, to be presented to him. The presentation is to be made on behalf of the donors, by Capt. CURTIS, of the Fifth New-York and Lieut. GROVER of the First Vermont. The inscription is as follows:

abstract: The bark Montezumas, Capt. HAMMOND, from Trinidad on Dec. 3, and St. Thomas on Dec. 7, arrived at this port yesterday. She reports that, on Dec. 15, in latitude 29째 18', longitude 72째 53, she passed a large steamship, with two smoke-stacks, steering south, supposed to be the Vanderbilt. On Dec. 24, latitude 37째 42', longitude 72째, passed a large number of navy bread boxes, and wrecked stuff. The Confederate schooner Retribution ran the blockade at Wilmington, N.C., on Nov. 24, and arrived at St. Thomas Dec. 7. She had as cargo 370 barrels spirits turpentine, 100 bales cotton, 100 bbls resin. She had a crew of 15 men, with three guns in the hold, and was allowed to enter in the customs, the same as any other vessel. She was commanded by Capt. PARKER, and consigned to LAMB, BALL & Co.

abstract: Yesterday at 3 o'clock the City Assembly delegation met at the Astor House, for the purpose of having a nice dinner, and to talk over matters, preparatory to assembling in Albany on Jan. 5. There was much good feeling evidenced, and an entire absence of bickering of any kind. Mr. THOS. C. FIELDS, of the Twelfth Ward, presided, and was made Chairman of the delegation. After remarks by Messrs. LOUTREL, WARD and others, it was unanimously resolved to present the name of Ex-Judge GILBERT DEAN as the candidate of the New-York Democracy for Speaker of the House of Assembly. There were many politicians awaiting the action of the meeting, and much interest manifested in its results. There will evidently be lively times in Albany this Winter.

Speculation had carried the price of everything--real estate particularly--to such a height that the sudden fall was terribly crushing to thousands of our citizens. Then came two years of poor crops throughout the West, adding greatly to our embarrassments. We were recovering slowly from the effects of these,

abstract: An agent of the War Department, Mr. O.S. OLCOTT, has been secretly but busily engaged in this City, since the 1st of November, in the investigation of alleged frauds upon the Government in the enlistment, organization and subsistence of Volunteers. During the prog
lead_paragraph: An agent of the War Department, Mr. O.S. OLCOTT, has been secretly but busily engaged in this City, since the 1st of November, in the investigation of alleged frauds upon the Government in the enlistment, organization and subsistence of Volunteers. During the progress of these investigations, it was thought advisable to arrest certain individuals who were brokers in claims against the Government, and whose complicity in the frauds seemed too surely established. A cry of indignation arose from certain quarters when these arrests were announced. The Administration was execrated by all the organs of disloyalty for its tyranny in seizing men without charges preferred, and holding them in custody without trial.

abstract: Post calls upon the War Department to publish the reports of Gen. McCLELLAN, containing the details of his campaign on the Peninsula. We have repeatedly done the same thing. But the War Department will find it very difficult to comply with this demand, reasonable as it would otherwise
lead_paragraph: Post calls upon the War Department to publish the reports of Gen. McCLELLAN, containing the details of his campaign on the Peninsula. We have repeatedly done the same thing. But the War Department will find it very difficult to comply with this demand, reasonable as it would otherwise be, because there are no such reports in existence. The Albany Atlas & Argus, we are aware, some months ago asserted, in the most explicit terms, that Gen. MCCLELLAN had made full and detailed reports of the movements of his army, and of the several battles in which they had been engaged; -- and it further charged that these reports had been suppressed by the War Department for the purpose of injuring Gen. MCCLELLAN, and depriving him of the credit which was his due.

abstract: Editorial surveys military prospects at year's end
snippet: Editorial surveys military prospects at year's end
lead_paragraph: The aspect of military affairs at the close of the year is not very brilliant, at least on the surface. In its last month, we have suffered our severest repulse, and the old Army of the Potomac is, as at this season last year, checked in the advance upon Richmond by a powerful foe in front. Our army operating in the rear of Richmond, too, under Gen. FOSTER, has just made a retrograde movement, which it would be folly to represent as anything but a very serious setback -- a setback, too, which is likely to make future operations on the same line much more difficult and hazardous than they were before. Along the line of the seacoast and the Gulf all that can be said is, that nothing now is less cheerful than things were in the Spring. We have gained but little there during the Summer and Fall, and the small operations that have taken place, though they may have annoyed the rebels, have resulted in very little permanent gain to the Union cause. In the Western field, where nearly half our entire army is scattered, the prospect for the opening year is not very cheerful. The army of Gen. ROSECRANS seems to be utterly paralyzed at Nashville, and its advance into East Tennessee is now checked by the largest army which the rebels have ever had in that State. The army of Gen. GRANT, in Northern Mississippi, is virtually cut off from its base of supplies, and the rebels, as appears from the accounts we now daily publish, are operating with audacity on every side of him. The Mississippi River is still closed against us, and though it is to be hoped that the military and naval expedition now preparing to open it up will be successful, yet it is liable to all the chances and hazards of war.

lead_paragraph: By the arrival at Halifax of the steamship Europa, we have advices from Europe one week later. She left Liverpool on the 13th, and Queenstown on the l4th inst. The English news by this arrival is not important. It was reported that the war at steamer Ariadne had been ordered to leave Halifax and join Admiral MILNE'S aquadron at Bermuda. The Shipping Gazette in forms us that a concentration of Admiral MILNE's force is to be made with a view to prevent what is termed outrages on British commerce. In Paris, unfavorable rumors were again current regarding the French in Mexico. An urgent call for reinforcements was said to have been made, which would be sent under the device of establishing a reserve at Martinique. Gen. PRIM had made lengthy explanations in the Spanish Cortes regarding affairs in Mexico. Confidential letters were read by him, containing strange details. According to these letters, ALMONTE was authorized by NAPOLEON and the Archduke MAXIMILIAN himself to put the latter forward as a candidate for the throne of Mexico. Gen. PRIM expressed the opinion that the French expedition would not be successful, A slight advance had taken place in the Liverpool Cotton market. Breadstuffs and Provisions were flat. Consols were quoted at 92 1/8@92 1/4.

abstract: We have already given by telegraph an abstract of the opinion of Attorney-General BATES on the question submitted by the Treasury Department, whether colored men may be citizens, and thus competent to command American vessels. That opinion, very
lead_paragraph: We have already given by telegraph an abstract of the opinion of Attorney-General BATES on the question submitted by the Treasury Department, whether colored men may be citizens, and thus competent to command American vessels. That opinion, very long and elaborate, is now published in full. The subject is analyzed with great keenness and thoroughness, and the conclusion that color is not a bar to citizenship, under the Constitution, seems to be irresistibly established. The Attorney-General elucidates with great success that citizenship does not necessarily involve a legal capacity to hold office or cast votes; that it simply means such a membership of the body politic that there is a reciprocal obligation of allegiance on the one side and protection on the other. The Constitution, in using the term "natural born citizen," uses no affirmative language to make them such, but only recognizes and reaffirms the universal principle common to all nations, that the people born in the country constitute the nation, and that every individual of them is prima facie a citizen. The Constitution, in not excluding the free man of color from the pale of citizenship, must by implication, the Attorney-General holds, comprise him, and entitle him to protection, in return for allegiance. While yet, without positive statute law in his favor, he can no more vote or be eligible to office than women and children, who, in the view of constitutional law, are also citizens, if born in the country.

lead_paragraph: FIRE IN BROADWAY--ARREST ON SUSPICION OF ARSON.--About 4 o'clock yesterday morning a fire was discovered on the second floor of premises No. 641 Broadway, in apartments occupied by Dr. COBERT. Two men, named CHARLES GROVER and JOHN REYNOLDS, were found in Dr. COBERT'S rooms about the time the alarm of fire was given. Officer PARSONS, of the Eighth Precinct, arrested them upon suspicion of having set the place on fire. Fire-Marshal BAKER to engaged in making an investigation as to how the fire originated. COBERT's loss is about $50; not insured. The stock of LEWIS LEFFERTS, dry goods merchant, who occupied the first floor, was damaged to the amount of about $1,200. LEFFERTS is fully insured. KIRBY's bookstore, adjoining, was damaged on the stock about $150.

abstract: In addition to the enormous frauds upon the United States Government which are brought to light in the statement above, we have still another feature of the general system of swindling to which, it is said, the State and country have been subjected, almost ever since the offer of bounties for the enlistment of private soldiers was made. At first--
lead_paragraph: In addition to the enormous frauds upon the United States Government which are brought to light in the statement above, we have still another feature of the general system of swindling to which, it is said, the State and country have been subjected, almost ever since the offer of bounties for the enlistment of private soldiers was made. At first -- that is, for a very few weeks -- there was, at least, a show of honesty in drawing the exceedingly liberal bounties offered to men to enlist; and, at that time, when a man enlisted he was taken to the quarters of the company or regiment into which he had enlisted, and there kept. That course, however, was not long generally pursued. The men, when enlisted and having received their bounties, would ask for a "pass" for a few days, to regulate their family affairs and to spend the bounty money for what themselves of their families needed. This seemed proper enough at the time, but experience proved that many of the men thus let go did not return, and were, in consequence, marked as deserters. The system was then commenced by many officers of retaining a large portion of the bounty, on granting a pass, in order to insure the return of the enlisted man. Those who had enlisted with the intention of going to the war, returned, of course, and claimed the remainder of their bounty money. But there were many who did not; and it is, at least, remarkable that of those who did not return very few have been arrested. Of the (about) six thousand men who received the bounties in the City of Brooklyn, and the immensely larger number who received the bounties in this City, it is not believed that much more than one-half are now connected with the army by reason of their first enlistment. In this connection it is proper to say that the charge of giving passes to men, while withholding the principal portion of their bounties, and taking no other measures to insure their return to camp, does not, of course, apply to officers whose desire to fill up their companies and regiments was paramount to every other. But, nevertheless, the fact is notorious among officers and privates that an immense amount of money has been taken from the resources for bounties, and that the men credited for receiving it are reported "missing."

abstract: Bates Aug. 12, 1861 opinion on constitutionality of West Virginia admission recalled; he opposes move at this time
snippet: Bates Aug. 12, 1861 opinion on constitutionality of West Virginia admission recalled; he opposes move at this time
lead_paragraph: It is understood that the President, in his action upon the bill now in his hands, for the admission of West Virginia as a separate State, will be guided mainly by the question of the constitutionality of the measure, as indicated by the Attorney-General. Mr. BATES has already given his opinion in the case. It was written in reply to a question of a member of the West Virginia Convention, in session at Wheeling, a year and a half ago. He puts the case clearly and forcibly, and it will be seen he is opposed to the creation of a new State, at this period of time. It is probable, under these circumstances, that the President will veto the bill.

abstract: Editorial sees Nashville area endangered; Editorial on Anti-Slavery Party in Great Britain
snippet: Editorial sees Nashville area endangered; Editorial on Anti-Slavery Party in Great Britain
lead_paragraph: Two of our City cotemporaries, wide as the poles asunder on almost every other point, agreed lately in expressing their opinion that the Anti-Slavery Party in England had always inveighed against Slavery before the war, for the express purpose of bringing about a dissolution of the Union; and has taken to defending and palliating Slavery since the war begun, for the purpose of making a restoration of the Union impossible. This is the opinion of the Tribune, and the World triumphantly concurs in it. The attitude of England toward the Secessionists is, however, a phenomenon of sufficient interest to prevent its being disposed of in this remarkably easy and off-hand way. This mode of explaining it is precisely that to which a "pot-house politician," as DICKENS paints him, or the editor of an Arkansas weekly journal, as we all know him, would be likely to resort. There is no error into which weak and provincial wits are so apt to fall in endeavoring to solve political mysteries, as that of applying to the conduct of great masses of men the same rule used in calculating the aberrations of a defaulting clerk, or of a dissipated cobbler. And very frequently philosophers, whose range of vision has been very much wider, labor under the same delusion. All England has, for the last year or two, been sitting at the feet of Mr. JAMES SPENCE, of Liverpool, and receiving from his lips the explanation of every incident of the great civil war in America. The basis of that gentleman's theory of our troubles is the hypocrisy -- arrant and unblushing hypocrisy -- of the Republican party in their professions of hostility to Slavery. He says they not only do not dislike Slavery, but have never disliked it, and have used it simply as a party cry, in order to get the gentle and patient South into their power for purposes of spoliation and insult. The worst of all this is, that he has got a large portion of the English public to believe him; and it is evident that some of our political instructors here give us credit for similar stupidity and credulity, when they inform us that the Anti-Slavery fever in England was simulated in order to cover a fiendish design upon the American Union.

abstract: The proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS is an extraordinary piece of ferocity and falsehood. It sets forth a specific charge against Gen...
lead_paragraph: The proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS is an extraordinary piece of ferocity and falsehood. It sets forth a specific charge against Gen BUTLER, in the case of MUMFORD, who was executed at New-Orleans, and, in retaliation for the alleged act pronounces the said "BUTLER to be a felon, deserving of capital punishment," and orders that he be treated as "an outlaw and common enemy of mankind, and that, in event of his capture, the officer in command of the capturing force do cause him to be immediately executed by hanging." It then proceeds to set forth certain general and vague charges against the same functionary and his subordinate officers, for violations of the laws of war, and concludes by ordering that all the commissioned officers in BUTLER's command be considered as "robbers and criminals, deserving death, and that they and each of them be, whenever captured, reserved for execution." It further makes provision for the disposition of private soldiers taken prisoners, of negro slaves captured in arms, and of officers found serving in company with said slaves, The whole proclamation has a special application to the case and rule of Gen. BUTLER, but there are points in it which make its application in some respects general to the conduct of the war.

abstract: --The Bridgeport (Conn.) Standard has the following paragraph regarding Gen. Tom Thumb, who, it says, is but 26 years of age, and has amassed enough ...
lead_paragraph: --The Bridgeport (Conn.) Standard has the following paragraph regarding Gen. Tom Thumb, who, it says, is but 26 years of age, and has amassed enough money not only to render himself, but his mother, two sisters and a younger brother independent. "His habits," it says, "are unexceptionable, and his intellect and general business ability are such that he personally attends to his own finances, and transacts all the business appertaining in leasing his houses, loaning his money on bond and mortgage, and looking after his estate in general. He owns a fine yacht, bearing his own name, which he sails himself with as much as nautical skill as any 'old salt' who sails out of Bridgeport harbor. He also keeps a fine pair of Shetland ponies and a splendid fast horse for his own driving, as well as a highly-trained pair of hunting dogs. His rifle and fishing tackle were of course made expressly to suit his diminutive size, and he is a very successful sportsman. He killed several deer which traveling West last year. A few months since the little General was made a Freemason. He has already taken three degrees, and expresses a determination to ascend the mystic ladder until he has reached the top round. Although Gen. Tom Thumb has always led a life of excitement, and twice after retiring to private life has felt compelled to exhibit himself again, to keep off the ennui, he remarked to the writer of this article last week, while quietly twirling his elegant little moustache, of which he seems quite proud, that he hoped one of there days to get married, 'in which event' he added, with a roguish look, 'I guess that the cares of a family, added to my ordinary duties, will give me enough to occupy my attention and prevent the necessity of again seeking the excitement of a traveling exhibition!' The General is something of a politician, he contributes liberally to charitable objects, and is highly respected by his fellow-citizens. He has been offered the candidacy for several public offices, but he says he leaves such honors for smaller men!"

abstract: About 9 o'clock on Friday night a difficulty occurred on board the ship Francis B. Cutting, lying opposite Bedloe's Island, which resulted in the death
lead_paragraph: About 9 o'clock on Friday night a difficulty occurred on board the ship Francis B. Cutting, lying opposite Bedloe's Island, which resulted in the death of the second mate, named THOMAS HUTCHINSON. The crew had been shipped that afternoon, and the ship was on the eve of taking her departure from this port to Liverpool when the melancholy occurrence took place. HENRY OLIVER, the sailor who committed the offence, was arrested by the Harbor Police soon after the affair took place, and held to await an investigation. The circumstances, as gathered from the officials who made the arrest, are as follows: A difficulty between HUTCHINSON and OLIVER had occurred during the previous afternoon, while the vessel was getting ready for sea. In the course of the altercation OLIVER had remarked that he would strike the second mate. At about 9 o'clock in the evening, the crew in the forecastle became quite boisterous, and HUTCHINSON, the deceased, as an officer of the ship, went down to see what was the trouble. When the latter arrived there, it is said that he began to abuse OLIVER, who at this time was lying in his bunk, and the former repeated the taunts and threats used by him in the previous difficulty. During this altercation HUTCHINSON, it appears, struck OLIVER several blows while the latter was in his berth. OLIVER at once drew a revolver and fired two shots in quick succession, the balls taking effect in the head and body of the mate. The victim died almost immediately. Capt. TODD, with a posse or men, boarded the vessel, and took into custody the offender, and also the other members of the crew as witnesses.

abstract: The most startling intelligence we have this morning, is the announcement, telegraphed from San Francisco yesterday, that the Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, on her outward trip to Aspinwall, ...
lead_paragraph: The most startling intelligence we have this morning, is the announcement, telegraphed from San Francisco yesterday, that the Vanderbilt steamship Ariel, on her outward trip to Aspinwall, was captured by the pirate Alabama on the 7th inst., near the east end of Cuba. She was detained until the 10th inst., and then allowed to proceed on her voyage, after giving a ransom bond in the sum of $228,000. She had on board a quantity of arms and ammunition, which was taken out by the Alabama, and a detachment of one hundred and twenty marines who were paroled. The only other plunder taken was $8,000 in "greenbacks" belonging to WELLS, FARGO & Co. The pirate seems to have overtaken the Ariel with the greatest ease.

abstract: The inevitable JOHN MORGAN turns up again in Kentucky, unexpectedly, no doubt, to many, but not to careful readers of the TIMES. The scene of MORGAN'S last exploit was Hartsville, ...
lead_paragraph: The inevitable JOHN MORGAN turns up again in Kentucky, unexpectedly, no doubt, to many, but not to careful readers of the TIMES. The scene of MORGAN'S last exploit was Hartsville, which is a town considerably east and north of Nashville. It was evident, on a mere glance at the map, that if MORGAN could roam at pleasure in the vicinity of Hartsville, he could dash into Kentucky again whenever it suited the purpose of his superiors to give the order. The order has been given and obeyed. MORGAN has captured Glasgow, Ky.; driven the National forces north again into Munfordsville, and broken the railroad and telegraph communication between Louisville and Nashville. We are all in the dark now as to the army of Gen. ROSECRANS. We only feel sure that it is strong enough to take care of itself, provided it has food enough to subsist on. But just here is the doubt. It is believed that Gen. ROSECRANS has not advanced upon the rebels at Murfreesboro, because the railroad to Louisville was not equal to the work of supplying his great army. He was supposed to be waiting for a rise in the Cumberland River, so as to be able to use that stream in supporting his advance. If this be correct, the position of Gen. ROSECRANS -- now that he is out off from Louisville -- is not a comfortable one. It will not do to evacuate Tennessee in order to feed his army. But he may be obliged to advance and fight the rebels for the provisions they have.

abstract: The Military Department west of the Mississippi River has had a varied and eventful history.
lead_paragraph: The Military Department west of the Mississippi River has had a varied and eventful history. It has been commanded by a Captain, a Committee or Public Safety, two Brigadiers, and three or more Major-Generals; and the transactions of the Department have given rise to more arrests, Courts-martial, investigations by Congressional and other Committees, than any other Department has been blessed or cursed with. Controversies have arisen there which a generation will not outlive -- and yet the verdict of the people, who have been bored beyond measure by the constant outcry from the West, will be, that there has been nothing yet developed to justify the space the local troubles of that Department has been allowed to occupy.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A preamble and resolutions by Mr. FARLEY, relative to the death of Maj. WILLIAM HORGAN, of MEAGHER'S Irish Brigade, who was ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. A preamble and resolutions by Mr. FARLEY, relative to the death of Maj. WILLIAM HORGAN, of MEAGHER'S Irish Brigade, who was killed at Fredericksburgh, were adopted. They offer the condolence of the Common Council with the family of the deceased on his loss, and direct the Committee on National Affairs to receive his remains, and take charge of the funeral. [The funeral will take place, at 2 o'clock P.M. to-day, from the City Hall.] A communication was received from the Central Park Commission, urging the necessity of a further appropriation, to enable them to proceed economically with their work. They state that the improvements above One Hundred and Second-street cannot be proceeded with advantageously until the question is settled whether the land lying between One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Tenth streets is to be added to the Park. Their liabilities amount to $175,000; and no more money will be wanted to complete the Park than has been authorized for the purpose by the Legislature, of which $833,000 remains to be raised. So far the expenditures amount to $3,595,330 75. Add to this sum the cost of the land, $3,788,751 37, and the total outlay for the Park has been $7,384,082 12. Messrs. FROMENT and FARLEY endeavored, but without success, to have the paper published. It was referred to the Finance Committee, who have before them other matters in regard to the Park. The Mayor's veto of the resolution to increase the salary of the President of the Croton Board to $5,000 per annum, and to increase the salaries of some of the subordinates in the same Department, was overruled by 14 to 1. The Board adjourned till 4 o'clock Monday.

abstract: In resuming the perusal of the series of letters produced in the course of the McDowell Inquiry, the reader may need to be reminded that the operations referred to were those destined
lead_paragraph: In resuming the perusal of the series of letters produced in the course of the McDowell Inquiry, the reader may need to be reminded that the operations referred to were those destined to cut off the retreat of "Stonewall" JACKSON from the Shenandoah Valley, after that General had driven Gen. BANKS to the Potomac. On the 29th of May, Gen. SHIELDS, who was detached from Gen. MCDOWELL's command to participate in the capture of the rebel leader, had pushed his march as far as Rectortown, on his way to Front Royal. Gen. FREMONT, proceeding from the opposite direction, had penetrated into the valley as far as Strasburgh. On the 30th, the main body of the enemy was at Winchester, while his advance was compelling the rear guard of BANKS to withdraw into Maryland. From this era the correspondence itself sufficiently indicates the movement of events:

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, held yesterday afternoon, at the suggestion of Ald. FARLEY, a series of resolutions, eulogistic of the late Maj. WILLIAM HORGAN, Eighty-eighth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, Irish Brigade, who fell in the late battle at Fredericksburgh, were passed; and it was resolved, in honor of the gallant command with which he had served, and nobly died, that the funeral expenses should be borne by the City. To this end, thearrangements were referred to the Committee on National Affairs, the members of which having consulted with the officers of Gen. MEAGHER's command, now in New-York, have taken charge of the funeral. The remains will be taken at 9 o'clock this morning from the head recruiting office of the Irish Brigade, No. 596 Broadway, to the City Hall, where they will be laid in state, and remain till 2 o'clock in the afternoon, when they will be borne to Calvary Cemetery, and interred in the ground appropriated by its trustees for the burial of the Catholic soldiers who fall in the present war. The friends of the deceased, and admirers of the command to which he belonged, as well as members of other military organizations in the City, are respectfully invited to join in the public ceremonies.

abstract: who, prior to the advent of Commodore PERRY, were, like the Britons of old, penitus divisos toto orbe, have their political factions and political convulsions. The Tycoon is not a despot, but a puppet in the hands of the dominant party, who control his will and dictate his policy. Until lately it was the "Liberals," the party favorable to commercial intercourse with foreigners, and to general reform, that held office, and directed the Government. Intelligence, has, however, just reached us, via San Francisco, that this party has been suddenly driven from power, and that the first act of their opponents, on assuming the management of affairs, was to strip their sovereign of the few special privileges which still remained to him. Though no detailed account of this revolution has yet come to hand, it is nevertheless very easy to perceive why the Liberals lost popularity, and were unable to hold their ground against the reactionists. The Liberals were the party who had entered into treaties, and introduced commercial relations with Christian Powers -- who had sent peaceful embassies to America and Europe, and endeavored to protect the persons and property of alien residents. But this enlightened policy was hateful to the oligarchs, who misrepresented its object to the multitude, and charged its supporters with want of patriotism, and indifference to the honor and independence of the empire. The reiteration of these calumnies produced in time the desired effect. The popularity of the Liberals waned; that of the Reactionists increased. The former gradually came to be regarded as the enemies of their country; the latter, as its only well-wishers and trustworthy champions; until, finally, the aristocrats, emboldened by their growing strength, organized an armed force, expelled their adversaries from the palace, and possessed themselves of the Tycoon and the Government.

Until lately it was the "Liberals," the party favorable to commercial intercourse with foreigners, and to general reform, that held office, and directed the Government. Intelligence, has, however, just reached us, via San Francisco, that this party has been suddenly driven from power, and that the first act of their opponents, on assuming the management of affairs, was to strip their sovereign of the few special privileges which still remained to him. Though no detailed account of this revolution has yet come to hand, it is nevertheless very easy to perceive why the Liberals lost popularity, and were unable to hold their ground against the reactionists. The Liberals were the party who had entered into treaties, and introduced commercial relations with Christian Powers -- who had sent peaceful embassies to America and Europe, and endeavored to protect the persons and property of alien residents. But this enlightened policy was hateful to the oligarchs, who misrepresented its object to the multitude, and charged its supporters with want of patriotism, and indifference to the honor and independence of the empire. The reiteration of these calumnies produced in time the desired effect. The popularity of the Liberals waned; that of the Reactionists increased. The former gradually came to be regarded as the enemies of their country; the latter, as its only well-wishers and trustworthy champions; until, finally, the aristocrats, emboldened by their growing strength, organized an armed force, expelled their adversaries from the palace, and possessed themselves of the Tycoon and the Government.

abstract: The main point made by JEFF. DAVIS, in his proclamation pronouncing Gen. BUTLER " a felon," who, when caught, shall be "immediately executed by hanging," is that "W.M.B. MUMFORD, a citizen of the Confederate States, had been executed by the United States authorities ...
lead_paragraph: The main point made by JEFF. DAVIS, in his proclamation pronouncing Gen. BUTLER " a felon," who, when caught, shall be "immediately executed by hanging," is that "W.M.B. MUMFORD, a citizen of the Confederate States, had been executed by the United States authorities at New-Orleans, for having pulled down the United States flag in that city, before its occupation by the United States forces." After thus explicitly stating his case, he mentions the correspondence of the Confederate authorities with Gen. HALLECK on the subject, and again asserts that he "has received evidence fully establishing the truth of the fact that the said WILLIAM B. MUMFORD, a citizen of the Confederacy, was actually and publicly executed in cold blood by hanging, after the occupation of the City of New-Orleans by the forces under Gen. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER, when said MUMFORD was an unresisting and non-combatant captive, and for no offence even alleged to have been committed by him, subsequent to the date of the capture of said city."

abstract: One of the most astounding miracles of modern science occurred on Saturday last, when the City of New-York obtained from the City of San Francisco, the first intelligence of a startling event, occurring in our immediate vicinity and affecting largely our property and citizens.
lead_paragraph: One of the most astounding miracles of modern science occurred on Saturday last, when the City of New-York obtained from the City of San Francisco, the first intelligence of a startling event, occurring in our immediate vicinity and affecting largely our property and citizens. The steamship Ariel, belonging to Commodore VANDERBILT, which left New-York on the 1st inst., was captured, off the east coast of Florida, on the 7th inst., by the Confederate privateer, the Alabama, detained till the 10th, and then on a ransom bond for $228,000 being given, "payable thirty days after the recognition of the Southern Confederacy," was permitted to continue her voyage to Aspinwall, which place was reached on the 12th inst. From Aspinwall the news was borne across the Isthmus to Panama; and from Panama, conveyed north along the Pacific coast several thousand miles to San Francisco; and from San Francisco it is sent back toward the East, four thousand miles overland, to New-York City. Thus the Pacific Ocean becomes the reporter of deeds done in the Atlantic waters, and in the track of one of its most frequented routes of travel.
headline: {'main': 'The Capture of the Ariel.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Capture of the Ariel.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The mystery of the Banks' expedition is now entirely cleared up. By the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamships Roanoke and Potomac, the first from New-Orleans on the 18th and the second on the 19th inst., we learn of its arrival at that city, where Gen. BANKS has established his headquarters as Commander of the Department of the Gulf--Gen. BUTLER being superseded by him.
lead_paragraph: The mystery of the Banks' expedition is now entirely cleared up. By the arrival at this port yesterday of the steamships Roanoke and Potomac, the first from New-Orleans on the 18th and the second on the 19th inst., we learn of its arrival at that city, where Gen. BANKS has established his headquarters as Commander of the Department of the Gulf--Gen. BUTLER being superseded by him. Our special correspondence this morning gives full details of all that has transpired, from the time Gen. BANKS left New-York on board the North Star, to the date of the sailing of the Potomac, including the General Order of farewell issued by Gen. BUTLER to his soldiers, and the proclamation of Gen. BANKS on assuming command. The first duty assigned to Gen. BANKS is the opening of the Mississippi, in conjunction with the expedition going down the river from Cairo, and already a portion of his forces had gone to Baton Rouge and taken possession of that city, and preparations were being made for an attack on the rebel fortifications at Port Hudson, fifteen miles above -- unless, indeed, the rebels had already evacuated that point, which was rumored in New-Orleans when the Potomac left. A report was also in circulation that Vicksburgh had been evacuated; but this is probably an error, as we should ere this have heard of such an occurrence by way of Memphis and Cairo. The change in Commanders in the Department -- which, by the way, now includes Texas -- of course created considerable excitement in New-Orleans. Gen. BUTLER had appointed a day for the reception of his friends, and was expected to leave for New-York on Tuesday, the 23d inst., on board the North Star.

abstract: The annual Fair held under the auspices of the ladies connected with the various Methodist Churches of the City, to aid in sustaining the Old Ladies' Home -- a most worthy charity -- was commenced last Monday, in the City Assembly Rooms, and closed on Saturday evening. This Fair was most liberally patronized, and we are happy to learn that the proceeds will amount to about $10,000. Perhaps the most interesting part of the proceedings on Saturday was the presentation of a beautiful and unique picture of the Bishops and ministers to Bishop JANES, it having been purchased by representatives of the various churches, at a cost of $125. The novelty of this picture consisted in its having a likeness of the respective gentlemen, inclosed in a wreath worked out of their hair. This novel piece of work was executed by the wife of Rev. J.P. NEWMAN, of the Washington-square Church, and of course attracted considerable attention. Quite a number of the wealthy men who were present offered a high price for the picture, the highest sum being $500, which was bid by a member of the Forsyth-street Church, but when it was learned what disposition was to be made of it, all personal rivalry for its possession of course ceased. Rev. Dr. WAKELEY made a most eloquent presentation speech, to which Bishop JANES happily responded.

abstract: The holiday entertainments at the various places of amusement have been attended with the usual festive gatherings during the latter part of last week. Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday preceding Christmas were, of course, less acceptable in their results to the treasuries, being affected by the dullness which usually precedes the holiday times. The young folk, however, are in such force now that there is no fear of a relapse, and, in truth, the bills are attractive enough for them and for children of a larger growth. At the principal show-piece establishments there will be no change. Thus, at the Winter Garden the "Lakes of Killarney;" at Niblo's Garden, "Faust and Marguerite;" at Laura Keen's, "Blondette," at the Old Bowery, "Little Red Riding Hood" and the "Schoolmaster;" (Fox is excellent in both;) and at Barnum's Museum, the "Colleen Bawn;" are still the all-sufficient attractions. A more intellectual feast than can be found at these establishments is provided by Mr. WALLACK, whose bulletin for the week is as follows: To-night, the "Invisible Husband;" to-morrow night, the "School for Scandal;" on Wednesday, the "Clandestine Marriage;" on Thursday, the "invisible Husband;" on Friday, "Love and Money," and on Saturday, (for the last time,) "A Bachelor of Arts." A word is due also to Mr. JUIGNET, of the French theatre, who strives, and with good effect, to produce for the public the originals of many popular plays, as "Don Caesar de Bazan" and "Camille," the last of which will be brought out to-morrow-night. Mlle. MARGUERITE DE BOUHELIER appears as the heroine, and Mons. ERNEST GRAVIER as Armand. In the way of music we have to-night at the German Opera AUBER's opera of the "Macon," and next week, the Italian Opera, under the steady direction of Mr. GRAU, will commence operations with the charming American prima donna. Miss KELLOG, In the opera of "Il Poliuto."

The young folk, however, are in such force now that there is no fear of a relapse, and, in truth, the bills are attractive enough for them and for children of a larger growth. At the principal show-piece establishments there will be no change. Thus, at the Winter Garden the "Lakes of Killarney;" at Niblo's Garden, "Faust and Marguerite;" at Laura Keen's, "Blondette," at the Old Bowery, "Little Red Riding Hood" and the "Schoolmaster;" (Fox is excellent in both;) and at Barnum's Museum, the "Colleen Bawn;" are still the all-sufficient attractions. A more intellectual feast than can be found at these establishments is provided by Mr. WALLACK, whose bulletin for the week is as follows: To-night, the "Invisible Husband;" to-morrow night, the "School for Scandal;" on Wednesday, the "Clandestine Marriage;" on Thursday, the "invisible Husband;" on Friday, "Love and Money," and on Saturday, (for the last time,) "A Bachelor of Arts." A word is due also to Mr. JUIGNET, of the French theatre, who strives, and with good effect, to produce for the public the originals of many popular plays, as "Don Caesar de Bazan" and "Camille," the last of which will be brought out to-morrow-night. Mlle. MARGUERITE DE BOUHELIER appears as the heroine, and Mons. ERNEST GRAVIER as Armand. In the way of music we have to-night at the German Opera AUBER's opera of the "Macon," and next week, the Italian Opera, under the steady direction of Mr. GRAU, will commence operations with the charming American prima donna. Miss KELLOG, In the opera of "Il Poliuto."

abstract: editorial on replacement
snippet: editorial on replacement
lead_paragraph: The legislation of all the Slave States, even in time of peace has, so far as related to slave property, been of a very desperate character. In it all the ordinary restrictions imposed by humanity, civilized usage and sound principles of criminal jurisprudence, have been entirely disregarded. The one great object of the slave code has been to strike the greatest possible amount of terror into slaves and "Abolitionists;" and for this purpose cruel and unusual punishments have always had a preference. Cases occurred too, every year, in almost every county, in which the law, sanguinary and ferocious as it was, was found too slow or too mild to satisfy public feeling, and the mob was left to work its own wild will by burnings alive and torturings of greater or less atrocity. If we had chosen to conduct the war with religious respect for Slavery, and had cautiously forborne to meddle with it, this savage policy might, perchance, never have been put into force against us. Not that the Southern mob would not have devised it, for the propriety of hoisting the black flag has been a subject of discussion and commendation in the Southern papers ever since the battle of Bull Run; but the leaders were too wary to resort to it, as long as our intentions touching the "institution" were harmless. It was their last bolt, and to hurl it before we came to close quarters would have been the height of imprudence.

lead_paragraph: The fog which hung so long and so heavily over the Banks Expedition lifts this morning. Our copious correspondence announces its progress and arrival at New-Orleans, and the departure of a detachment from it up the Mississippi River. Its principal mission is to cooperate with the descending expedition in opening that river to free and unobstructed navigation, and in holding it permanently for the Government of the United States.

lead_paragraph: Whereas, a communication was addressed on the 6th day of July last, 1862, by Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, acting under the instructions of the Secretary of War of the Confederate States of America, to Gen. H.W. HALLECK, Commander-in-Chief of the United States Army, informing the latter that a report had reached this Government that WM. B. MUMFORD, a citizen of the Confederate States, had been executed by the United States authorities at New-Orleans, for having pulled down the United States flag in that city before its occupation by the United States forces, and calling for a statement of the facts, with a view of retaliation if such an outrage had really been committed under the sanction of the authorities of the United States;

abstract: A STEAMER CHARTERED FOR SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDERS.--Dr. McDOUGALL, the Medical Director of this City, has selected the fine steamer, Thomas P. Way, belonging to the Newark line of STEPHENS CUNDIT  CO., to accommodate the sick and wounded soldiers who may arrive here.
lead_paragraph: A STEAMER CHARTERED FOR SICK AND WOUNDED SOLDERS.--Dr. McDOUGALL, the Medical Director of this City, has selected the fine steamer, Thomas P. Way, belonging to the Newark line of STEPHENS CUNDIT CO., to accommodate the sick and wounded soldiers who may arrive here. She is well suited for this purpose, having been remodeled, and is sufficiently spacious to accommodate comfortably a large number. Arrangements have been made by which the patients will be supplied with all necessary comforts on board, the cooking to be done in the vessel. On the arrival of sick and wounded soldiers by rail or steamer, they will in future be transferred to the Thomas P. Way till they are sent to the hospitals destined to receive them.

abstract: A MAN CHARGED WITH MURDERING HIS OWN SISTER--INQUISITION BEFORE CORONER RANNEY.  For some weeks past, AUSTIN HEENY and MARGARET MCLAUGHLIN, his widowed sister, have occupied apartments in the upper part of premises No. 38 Trinity-place. Both being persons of intemperate habits they often quarreled and during their troubles HEENY...
lead_paragraph: A MAN CHARGED WITH MURDERING HIS OWN SISTER--INQUISITION BEFORE CORONER RANNEY. For some weeks past, AUSTIN HEENY and MARGARET MCLAUGHLIN, his widowed sister, have occupied apartments in the upper part of premises No. 38 Trinity-place. Both being persons of intemperate habits they often quarreled and during their troubles HEENY would beat her in a brutal manner. Last Tuesday evening, while engaged over their cups, they had an angry altercation concerning the right of possession to a bank-book; and after HEENY had struck and badly cut his sister about the face, he dragged her to the top of the stairs, and giving her a violent push, hurled her headlong to the bottom. Not content with this murderous act, he ran down stairs, and, in the most inhuman manner, stamped upon her prostrate form; and when remonstrated with for his brutality, HEENY replied that she was drunk. The woman then being quite insensible, HEENY flung her across his shoulder, with the intention, as he said, of taking her to the Station-house. Other parties then interfered, and conveyed Mrs. MCLAUGHLIN to her room.

abstract: A person crossing the Wall-street ferry from Brooklyn will have his attention attracted by a fine, new ship lying at pier No. 9, flying the American ensign at the mizzen, and the English cross at the fore. Upon inquiring as to the meaning of this fraternal blending of the flags of Old England and of the...
lead_paragraph: A person crossing the Wall-street ferry from Brooklyn will have his attention attracted by a fine, new ship lying at pier No. 9, flying the American ensign at the mizzen, and the English cross at the fore. Upon inquiring as to the meaning of this fraternal blending of the flags of Old England and of the United States, at this time, he will learn that the noble ship at whose masthead these national emblems are displayed, is loading with breadstuffs, at the rate of over a thousand barrels a day -- the free gift of generous merchants -- to feed the starving poor of England and that the ship herself, the property of an honored New-York merchant, has been freely given for the purpose of conveying this, her first cargo, as a freewill offering to the pining operatives of Lancashire. The wharf at which she lies he will find literally blocked up with barrels of flour of the best New-York brands, while horses and men are busily employed in hoisting them in at the rate of nearly three per minute, and a gang of stevedores in the lower hold is engaged in receiving and stowing away the precious burden in the capacious sides of the ship.
headline: {'main': 'INTERNATIONAL RELIEF.; Bread for the Suffering Operatives of England. HER CARGO. Respectfully yours, Fatal Affray in Howard-street.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'INTERNATIONAL RELIEF.; Bread for the Suffering Operatives of England. HER CARGO. abstract: WILD CATS IN NEW-JERSEY.--"Wild Cat Banks" are popularly supposed to flourish in NewJersey, but the real article--the feline ranger of the forest--has been regarded as extinct.
lead_paragraph: WILD CATS IN NEW-JERSEY.--"Wild Cat Banks" are popularly supposed to flourish in NewJersey, but the real article--the feline ranger of the forest--has been regarded as extinct. Mr. D.J. CAMFIELD, of Newark, while hunting with a party of friends, a few days since, in Morris County, upon what is called Copperas Mountain, shot two wild cats, each measuring about three feet in length.

abstract: Yesterday evening, at 6 o'clock, the Conference, between Mozart and Tammany, took place at the last mentioned hostelry, when a proposition was made that a union should, and ought to take place between the two factions.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday evening, at 6 o'clock, the Conference, between Mozart and Tammany, took place at the last mentioned hostelry, when a proposition was made that a union should, and ought to take place between the two factions. Tammany feeling proud over her recent supposed achievements, undertook rather to Poo poo! Mozart, but like their namesake -- the Musician, they blew a trumpet that brought the Boys. Hereupon the Fourth Ward appeared, and great was their prowess. They cheered and swore that MICKEY MCGINNESS should not go on the General Committee. A Samaritan said it was better to adjourn until 8 o'clock, which was accordingly done.

lead_paragraph: The affair of the Ariel continues to excite deep feeling in this community. And well it may. It is the highest aim yet ventured by the rebel privateersman, and comes nearest the vital interests of our commerce. The disappointment of not receiving a million dollars in gold at the time when it was expected, amounts to a great deal with its owners, who have obligations to meet, and involves a multitude of other disappointments in its train which anyone possessing the slightest knowledge of a commercial community can readily understand. Wider even than this is the circle of injurious results in the threatened rise in the rates of insurance (war risk) on American bottoms, and the consequent serious drawback on American shipping interests.
headline: {'main': 'The Ariel Affair.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Ariel Affair.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
