abstract: But few persons in the comfortable classes or our City know the great good which this association is doing among the poor. We find, by their report, that they have in charge 410 children; daily attendance over 300. Of the families visited and aided, according to their ability, 73 have no table, 79 sleep on the floor, 44 have neither stove nor fireplace; 136 whose children depend chiefly upon the Mission for food; 140 whose fuel is the cinders gathered from ashboxes; 133 whose poverty is the result of intemperance; 80 where the mothers drink, and 201 are widows. This institution, modest and unostentatious, deserves public sympathy and support. Its office is at No. 37 New Bowery, where Mr. VAN METER, the Superintendent, will receive visitors and donations with pleasure.

abstract: Our reports of Gen. BANKS' operations yesterday, left his Mississippi River Expedition at Baton Rouge, about to advance against the rebel position at Port Hudson, fifteen miles above. We now have the important intelligence, by way of Memphis and Cairo, that Port Hudson was immediately ...
lead_paragraph: Our reports of Gen. BANKS' operations yesterday, left his Mississippi River Expedition at Baton Rouge, about to advance against the rebel position at Port Hudson, fifteen miles above. We now have the important intelligence, by way of Memphis and Cairo, that Port Hudson was immediately captured, but whether any fighting was necessary to accomplish it does not appear. We judge not, however, from the fact that the capture is announced in the Vicksburgh Whig, of the 18th inst., while the date of our correspondence from Baton Rouge is the 17th. The place was, doubtless, evacuated by the rebels. Our dispatch this morning also makes the announcement that the expedition at last accounts was only twelve miles below Vicksburgh. Some of the Western correspondents insist that Vicksburgh has been evacuated by the rebels, and it will be recollected that a rumor to that effect prevailed in New-Orleans at the date of our latest letters from there. If so, the first work of Gen. BANKS' Expedition is easily accomplished, and the Mississippi River is once more open to navigation throughout its entire navigable extent.

lead_paragraph: By the steamship Etna, which passed Cape Race on Saturday, we have advices from Europe four days later than were received by the Europa. The President's Message was generally commented upon by the English Press. It is mainly discussed in relation to his scheme to liberate the slaves, which is regarded as impracticable. It was reported that the United States steamer Tuscarora had overhauled the steamer Thistle, when leaving Madeira for Nassau, and that the British war steamer Leopard tried to stop her afterward, to learn what the Tuscarora had done, but the Thistle would not stop. SLIDELL is said to have had another interview with the French Emperor. DROUYN DE L'HUYS and PERSIGNY, it is understood, favor the South. The Liverpool cotton market was dull. Breadstuffs were firmer, but Provisions were still tending downward. Consols were quoted at 92 1/4@92 3/8 for money.

abstract: U.S. Marshal MURRAY yesterday received from the State Department a commutation of the sentence of FERDINANDO DEMARCHI, the Italian, who was convicted at the July term of United States District Court of the murder of a fellow seaman named Frank Vincent, on board the American ship Blondel, on her voyage from England to Singapore. DEMARCHI was to have been hung the 6th of February next. The jury recommended him to mercy, which recommendation was concurred in by the Judge and the District-Attorney, and in accordance therewith President LINCOLN has commuted his sentence to 15 years at hard labor in the State Prison at Sing Sing.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Marshal MURRAY yesterday received from the State Department a commutation of the sentence of FERDINANDO DEMARCHI, the Italian, who was convicted at the July term of United States District Court of the murder of a fellow seaman named Frank Vincent, on board the American ship Blondel, on her voyage from England to Singapore. DEMARCHI was to have been hung the 6th of February next. The jury recommended him to mercy, which recommendation was concurred in by the Judge and the District-Attorney, and in accordance therewith President LINCOLN has commuted his sentence to 15 years at hard labor in the State Prison at Sing Sing.

abstract: J Brooks speaks, Democratic Union Association meeting
snippet: J Brooks speaks, Democratic Union Association meeting
lead_paragraph: The Democracy assembled in considerable numbers, last evening, at the roms of the Democratic Union Association, No. 932 Broadway, corner of Twenty-second-street, the occasion being a celebration of the fitting up of the new rooms of the Association. A brass band was in attendance, and previous to the vocal exercises, enlivened the assemblage with choice selections of music. The rooms, as newly fitted up, present a very comfortable appearance, and are situated in a section of the City quite convenient for our up-town citizens of Democratic tendencies. The National flag was draped in front of the rostrum, and behind it was hung a banner bearing the inscription, "Democratic Union Association of New-York." At 7 1/2 o'clock the meeting was called to order by LUKE F. COZANS, who welcomed the audience to the new rooms, and trusted that they would continue to be the headquarters of a party successful in the future as in the past. He congratulated them on the changed feeling which was now observable in favor of conservatism. He then briefly narrated the rise and progress of the Democratic Union Association, stating what they had done during the past two elections, and the exertions they were determined to make in future to bring the Northern people to a sense of their duty as citizens in this crisis of our country. After a short appeal for material aid he introduced Hon. JAMES BROOKS, who spoke substantially as follows:

snippet: Editorial notes Legislature will reconvene next Tuesday; editorial again says main object of expedition is occupation of Texas
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and immediately took a recess for fifteen minutes, the object of which was a myth to all but the members. On reassembling, the veto massage of the Mayor, on the resolution appointing 162 Commissioners of Deeds, overruled by the Councilmen the day previous, was called up for action. Mr. BOOLE thought the objections of the Mayor were inconsistent, because it would be quite in impracticable matter to settle the legal difficulty respecting the excess of appointments by limiting the number of new appointments. The most feasible plan of adjustment -- and the one which the Common Council would strive to have carried out -- was to have a law passed legalizing the acts of all the appointees. Such a law would set at rest all questions of doubt concerning the acts of Commissioners of Deeds in the City, since their number has exceeded 300. The Board concurred in overruling the veto. No further business of importance was transacted. Adjourned till 1 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: Some half-dozen reports of cannon were heard upon our right this morning. It is supposed the firing was in front of Gen. SIGEL'S Line. The cause has net yet been communicated to the headquarters of this division. It may have originated in consequence of the rebels making their appearance at Catlett's Station, it having been reported that quite a force of their cavalry are hovering about that vicinity.

abstract: The work on this splendid ship is now rapidly drawing to a close, and in a few weeks she will be the bearer of the heaviest armament of any vessel in the world. Yesterday two more of her immense guns were brought to the Brooklyn Navy Yard by the derrick. The entire six with which she is to be armed will weigh over 120 tons, without carriages. One solitary discharge of her broadside will throw 2,700 lbs. of iron, or more than the entire discharge of a broadside from an old-fashioned 80 gun line-of-battle ship. Nor are here attributes for offensive war-ware her only ones. The iron on her sides is in solid plates, the perforation of which seems utterly impossible. The proprietors of the Novelty Iron Works have finished their work in the best manner. Capt. S.C. ROWAN, one of the most competent officers in the United States Navy, has been specially selected to command this great ship. The locality in which the Roanoke will he permanently stationed is not as yet definitely fixed. It is said she will have a fine band on board, and be moored off the Battery, where a United States man-of-war is badly wanted to represent our navy. Another rumor is that she will be the flagship of a fleet of harbor batteries devoted to the protection of New-York, Boston and Philadelphia, and that she will make short cruises to sea, but nothing is certain as yet about her future movements, save that New-York will be her headquarters.
